comment: I live alone. To justify the expense of delivered meals  I usually order something that will provide enough for more than one meal.  I also tend to use the store's own app.
Name: michaela

comment:
People pay extra for convenience in many different aspects of their lives  not just when figuring out what's for dinner. 

Owning a car (or using Lyft/Uber/taxis) is more expensive than using public transit  for example. 

Flying non-stop is more expensive than taking a one-stop route.

People paying extra for convenience is not exactly a ground-breaking observation....
Name: matt

comment: And the costs are even greater than what is stated in this article because it doesn’t even take into consideration the added environmental impact of getting takeout delivered to you.  When you live in the city and can walk or take public transit to the restaurant  paying more to have someone burn fossil fuel to deliver to your door is a lazy choice.  And then there is the extra packaging involved.  How much single use plastic is involved in getting takeout sushi?  Enough that towns and cities are starting to legislate what materials can be used for such containers; like here where styrofoam containers have been banned.  I would be curious to know how the demographics of those that use these apps line up with their cohort’s views on climate change.
Name: dh

comment: It seems odd that anyone would be surprised that it costs $4-5 to $15 to have food delivered to your home.  Even assuming you call at a moment in time that a driver is only five minutes away from a restaurant when summoned and the food is ready  with no waiting time for the driver  and you are only 10 minutes away from the restaurant  a five mile round trip would cost the driver $2.50 in mileage and 15 minutes at $15/hour or $3.75 unless you're interested in exploiting the worker.
Name: ebmem

comment:
Not to mention what these apps do to the workers and people waiting in line.

 I talked to a guy at Subway yesterday. He might have three or four people in line and then gets an order for 10 sandwiches from Grub Hub. Guess who gets served first? Right  not the folks waiting in line. The app order is already paid  and he has to prepare it first. 

Of course the person who pressed a few buttons to order his meal doesn't know or care. But the rest of us suffer.
It's all about convenience with no thought to the real costs  monetary and otherwise.
Name: laura

comment: And now we know why people are demanding higher and higher salaries.  Food delivery apps.
Name: aaron

comment:
I live in NJ and occasionally order meals for my mom in DC.  She loves the occasional foray into exotic foods that neither she nor her aides can cook.  I've also found that Uber Eats is the most expensive (regardless of the location).  

I don't mind if the bill creeps up to give an extra tip to the delivery driver (who deliver mom's meals to her 6th Fl apartment door).  I do mind paying outrageous fees to apps who're only providing a platform to get a service.  They're not cooking or delivering anything.
Name: ali

comment: I already knew Postmates did this  but really enjoyed seeing the comparisons between apps and how they adjust prices  fees  etc. Thank you for creating this data and telling us about it!
Name: e

comment: Yes  get out and walk to get your meal.  Also I don't use these bc of the fossil fuel required to deliver.  If we are going to change  this is an easy out.
Name: calleen

comment: We have friends in their 80's thinking about assisted living. They are concerned that they are getting to the age that they should think about discontinuing driving. I pointed out that at least a transition to assisted living would be using all the delivery services available in our area with the high costs of assisted living. Drug store  grocery store  restaurants  even doctors making house calls. They compared prices and sure enough they are transitioning to delivery. Not being able to drive is an excellent reason to get delivery.
Name: carroll

comment:
Having been lucky enough to grow up rarely going out to eat  I learned home economics in the home and  as an adult  we still mostly cook at home  ideally in batches large enough to freeze or cycle throughout the week. It doesn’t have to be difficult or fancy  and meals at home almost always are healthier than restaurants (and always cheaper). [Too easy to joke about millennials not cooking for leftovers because avocado toast doesn’t keep well].  It’s a fun exercise to compare serving costs between homecooked meals and restaurant equivalents. (Well  “fun” if you enjoy thrift and daydreaming about how you’ll spend the savings). 
To pivot to politics: the same factors that make the app-based delivery services expensive also apply to heathcare: too many for-profit intermediaries getting in the way  trying to profit from basic human requirements  whether healthcare or sustenance. (I’ll draw the line way before claiming Panda Express et al as a human right  however).
Name: geoff

comment: excellent article. I love the data given and the comparisons. I am definitely going to avoid Ubereats from now on!
Name: mark

comment:
I think this generation is missing on one big aspect. Going out.

My wife and I enjoy going out  going to a favorite retardant  not only for the convenience and the food but ESPECIALLY for the restaurant atmosphere and the experience ... Delivery apps can't deliver that.
Name: truenorth

comment:
A couple of things - I see a lot of comments about how you should just cook at home. Though I love making meals  sometimes I'm just tired and want someone else to do the work for me. It's not unreasonable. 

Also  before I realized that these apps were charging outrageous fees  it was nice to make an order and not have to repeat myself several times. Let's be honest  sometimes there is a language barrier when calling to have an authentic meal delivered.
Name: db

comment:
I will always support in-house delivery when available. The option is cheaper. The decision also supports regular employment in the food industry. Both my pizza shop and my sandwich shop provide in-house delivery options. I order from these two locations more frequently as a result.

However  I also live in a place where delivery service is questionable. Restaurants assume working adults don't order delivery unless they have children. There are entire neighborhoods where only dominoes and papa johns deliver. I still regularly struggle to find a decent eggplant dish at any Italian restaurant.

This is weird. The city has good food. Many of the restaurants are short-order and take-out oriented. However  the delivery culture here is extremely lacking. Establishments simply do not provide delivery services on the scale you would find in other quasi-urban spaces like New Jersey. New Jersey has tons of good food and they almost always deliver.

At the same time though  sometimes you really don't want pick up Sushi Burrito at 8 o'clock at night. You've had a long day. There are still an hour worth of dishes. It's raining outside. You just want to be done. The value is worth a markup. The question is how much value is the markup worth.

We can eliminate sales tax. You should be paying it anyway. In my opinion  delivery is always worth a 20% markup. More if the service is good. But not before the service is good. That's the problem with delivery services. They make you pay upfront.
Name: andy

comment:
Wow  these delivery services are outrageously expensive. You make chicken in your toaster oven.
How about considering the purchase of an Instant Pot  digital pressure cooker. It's one-pot cooking and you can make hundreds of wonderful meals very quickly and have only one pot to clean. You'll typically make more than enough for several meals and thus only have to warm something in  the microwave on other days.
Name: razzy

comment: Restaurants may charge extra for takeout because too many takeout orders clogs the kitchen and slows service to the diners in the restaurant. We dined at a favorite Mexican place a few days ago and waited for our dinner while a parade of GrubHub and other take-out drivers marched through -- some of whom also had to wait.
Name: jeff

comment: I am frugal. Not cheap. I don't like wasting money. So it's a no-brainer for me to order directly from the restaurant. The concept of food delivery in Brooklyn  much less Bed-Stuy is probably 20 years old. (In NY  that's not a long time...) It's true- you couldn't even get a yellow cab to take you to BK  back then! For whatever reason  the local Chinese restaurant and pizza shops did not venture outside their establishments. The first time I got any type of food delivered to my residence was at college. Since the early 2000s  and then the eventual gentrification of my community  food delivery was now a possibility! I remember when I saw a Fresh Direct truck in MY neighborhood- I was gobsmacked! I say all of this to say that I was never dependent on food deliveries. However  I do enjoy the convenience like anyone else. Yet  you will NEVER see me pay almost twice the price for a meal! Sometimes I am starving and I search through the food delivery apps...  I'm almost desperate to order something. Then I see the total! CLOSE APP. Next  call the restaurant directly and keep it moving. Or if they don't deliver (to my address)... I'll pick up or choose another place. I don't understand why people get so lackadaisical when it comes to ordering on food apps and get duped into paying out the wazoo for some tacos or sushi! I am married with a nine-year-old... I have better things to spend that extra money on instead of fees fees fees... that I can't eat!
Name: sonso

comment:
Duh  of course. People are addicted to convenience and not paying attention to what you spend is downright fashionable. 

If god did not want them sheared he would not have made them sheep!

On the flip side  there is so much money sloshing around that I would wager many people who use these services simply do not care.

Living the dream!
Name: clotario

comment: I'm surprised there's no mention in the article about what these delivery apps are doing to local restaurant businesses. The math looks pretty unsustainable for a lot of these places. https://missionlocal.org/2019/05/custards-last-stand-mission-pie-vs-the-gig-economy/
Name: jenny

comment:
If you are poor  these prices are crazy. 

If you are wealthy  why do you want several poorly-paid strangers tempted to carry out class warfare on your likely-mediocre food?

If you think you are middle class and immune from such resentment  ask yourself how sure you are that  everyone handling your food feels the same way every day.
Name: alan

comment: This is why Americans are broke. If you do not watch the bottom line they steal from you. It must be a joke when Uber say their prices are high to ensure their contractors are paid well. They really mean the masters at HQ.
Name: albert

comment: Thank you Brian X. Chen for suggesting that we consider cooking our own meal because it is cheaper than eating out/take out/delivery. Such wisdom.
Name: matthew

comment: You are paying for convenience of not having to go out and get the food  wait or it  and return.
Name: david

comment: I don't understand. In my area Grubhub is incredibly higher than DoorDash. I don't order from them because of that.
Name: laura

comment: I can't decide if my response should be "There's one born every minute" or "TANSTAAFL."
Name: dennis

comment: Lazy and stupid behaviour. Worst of all  I imagine the food in only warmish at best.
Name: denis

comment: " there's a sucker born every minute'
Name: shah

comment: Not to mention the fact that ordering out all the time is bad for your waistline and long-term health.
Name: jend

comment: The same millennials that LOVE and I mean LOVE ordering food via Uber Eats etc...complain about not having affordable housing and never being able to buy a house....or a car....or leave parent's house...
Name: lt

comment:
To avoid the outrageous "App" markups  you can still go the old-fashioned route and call the restaurant for free delivery (just a tip). But that might require putting down your phone and actually communicating directly via speech with someone. 

Also  many restaurants are now developing their own web-sites to order from them directly  the mark-up is much lower.
Name: vic

comment: I live alone and cook for myself 75% of the time.  I go out to eat about once or twice a week  including lunch (I am able to go home for lunch everyday).  But every once in awhile  usually on a weekend and after I’ve gone grocery shopping so I have a full refrigerator  I’m on my couch and I just don’t want to get up and cook something and then do the dishes after.  So I’ll spend 30 minutes browsing DoorDash to figure out what I want to eat  because the hungrier I get  the less decisive I am  decide on a restaurant  put something in the cart and then look at the total. When it turns out that I will be paying $30 for a one meal  I close the app and pour a bowl of cereal. It’s not really about “learning to cook” for me  it’s just that sometimes I want  even if I can’t bring myself to pay for it  someone to make my food for me and I want to eat it at home in my pjs on the couch without expending hardly any energy at all.
Name: mm

comment: I mean these are pretty easy to figure out- they show you the fees and final cost at the end of the order. You can see you're paying a significant amount more. I would've mentioned the cheaper low effort option of frozen meals- I like cooking  but there are days when I'm out of food without time to get to the grocery store or too busy to cook and frozen meals are great for that. There's also larger meal options like frozen dumplings  prepared frozen chicken  etc. I can't imagine eating out every night  though I have a bigger kitchen where I live than your average new york kitchen
Name: leah

comment: I had one experience with one of the food delivery services and that was all it took. Unless this problem gets fixed or I become so disabled and alone that I can’t go get my food myself  I wouldn’t even consider it again. These “services” are a colossal rip-off!
Name: will

comment: My go to when I don't want to cook is grilled cheese.  Cut bread  put cheese on top  use toaster oven on toast setting.  Done.  Or a can of beans.
Name: nanny

comment:
The delivery apps are destroying the restaurant business.

More restaurants are closing faster now.

Some industries need to be regulated.

Panda Express has overcharged forever.
Name: paul

comment:
Wow  I remember when people used to  you know  make their own food. Or maybe stop by someplace for takeout.

So yeah  got it. Add to the carbon footprint because you don't have time to drive through In n' Out Burger.
Name: ray

comment: The willingness to pay for convenience easily gets out of hand.  Every time I see someone complaining about their middle-class income  often double or triple what I earned when I worked  I wonder how much they squander their hard-earned money.  There are still plenty of restaurants that deliver for the cost of a tip and many more who make take-out very easy  even in the semi-rural area where I live.  In a city  there are many more.  I cook for myself  making sure to freeze meals for the days when I don't feel like cooking. I also have a repertoire of curries  soups and other meals I can make in 10 minutes or less.  If all else fails  there's always cereal.  I won't be paying these exorbitant prices for delivery.
Name: barbara

comment: Sometimes  it's as if people make so much money that they have to think up new ways of spending it. I can see ordering food to be delivered perhaps twice a year  but as a weekly service  it's just a waste of money. A little planning ahead could ruin the market for take-out  not to mention clearing the streets of small delivery vehicles burning up more gas.
Name: merrymarjie

comment: We don't order often but when we do we use GrubHub and its nice to know that at least it is the least marked-up of the bunch. It also has decent points accumulation which translate directly into money off from future orders. I don't understand why people flocked to DoorDash or UberEats. We have been with Foodler which then got bought by GrubHub for many many years and it never failed.
Name: nh

comment:
Another negative impact of the rise in food delivery is the amount of waste it produces. Even a simple meal for one comes in a shocking amount of packaging  which often can’t be recycled (i.e. black plastic  packaging soiled with grease etc).

If the cost properly handling this waste was built into the cost of the food the prices would be much higher and presumably less people would order takeout. Unfortunately  the costs of this waste are being absorbed by mother nature for now until we are forced to deal with it down the road.

It is sad to think that the waste produced from one lazy person’s meal may exist on the earth for the rest of their life. 

It is interesting to see the rise in food delivery while  at the same time  also seeing a growing interest in the zero waste movement. I hope that the later proves move popular.
Name: mj

comment: Trader Joe's frozen main courses.   I live in Mexico half year and really miss the occasional convenience of having Trader Joe's "cook" for me.
Name: judith

comment: What's wrong with millennials that even the simple truth (a meal delivered to your home costs more) needs explanation?
Name: chef

comment: Postmates has a relatively high markup because they mail you your food. Or so I'm told. This will affect delivery times. Also  Grubhub has a relatively low markup  but the company can't guarantee there won't be actual grubs in the food.
Name: jeff

comment:
This is a simple story about capitalism. Most working people may not be able to afford the cost of having their meals delivered on a day to day or even once a week basis. So what's the big deal? At this stage  based on the information of the article  delivery is somewhat of a luxurious convenience for those who feel they can afford it. Most working people possibly can't afford to do it.
The additional costs seem to provide " a job"  if you will   for others. The costs of having meals delivered are what they are  for those who can afford them. That's America  for better or worse.
Home cooked food is usually much better anyway. Delivery apps don't eat up your budget. Your income determines if you should be using them in the first place.
Name: kb

comment: For the convenience premium you pay  you don't always get actual delivery  either. First night home from a total knee replacement  I decided to use GrubHub. An hour later  the delivery driver called me from the street and told me to come down and get it....Sigh.
Name: pat

comment: I manage marketing for a small family-owned restaurant chain in San Diego. I have had several meetings with account executives for these delivery services. One thing that seems to have been glazed over in this article is the “commissions” that these third party delivery services get from the restaurants. While the big national brands may pay a smaller commission  most smaller establishments are typically paying commissions of 22% to 30% of the sale per order. That is in most cases the restaurant’s entire profit margin! What’s a restaurant owner to do but increase their prices? Keep in mind that this modern third party delivery concept (such as it is) has a long way to go and will inevitably evolve  hopefully for the better. Eventually  your Panda Express order will be delivered by drone or autonomous quadruped robot. Until then  the “everything in moderation” mantra should apply.
Name: danny

comment:
Here is an irony. We want to pay everybody fair wages. We vote for hiking minimum so called livable wages and but when the prices go up  we complain. 
Off-course nothing is better than cooking at home. However  if there is a need for quick delivery it's  there.
Name: ap

comment:
All those markups and none of the food delivery companies are even close to making a profit.

In the end  the restaurant makes less money on the order  the meal costs the consumer more  the delivery person makes a pittance  and the delivery apps lose money. It's magic!
Name: paul

comment:
I use these services when ordering for people at work  and I have freelanced in the delivery world in the past. 
A few points the article doesn't even talk about:
The delivery services charge the restaurant a portion of the sale amount. If the restaurants don't or can't afford the loss  they have to recoup the difference by increasing the prices. Not good for the customer  but understandable to the business. I've heard it's between 20 and 40%  so grubhub  etc get $2-4 bucks out of every 10 you spend. 
The people bringing the food need to be paid somehow. How much do you think is fair for upto 30-45 minutes of time (going from where they are to get the food  verifying/waiting for food  and then bring it to you) plus the cost of fuel? That's where those delivery costs are going.
Finally  while the apps may not be as transparent as they could be about the food item costs being different  they are about the service fees  etc.
Remember  you're paying for the convenience.
Name: robbie

comment: I hate cooking. There I said it. But I'll be in the poorhouse if I eat takeout (also overweight). My solution is: a microwave veggie steamer (a magical contraption that steams any and all veggies in 6 minutes) and a rotisserie chicken  precooked from the grocery store for 5.99  alternate with cans of tuna. Buy prewashed veggies and prewashed lettuce bags  mix with different sauces for variety. I spend (actually just waiting) 5 minutes warming up my daily chicken veggie bowl  if you can call that "meal prep". You know what's really funny? I eat healthier than all my friends who cook. Keep it simple folks!
Name: lt

comment: Living in NYC  at times  can make a $30 delivery seem more than worth it....
Name: hall

comment: I’d consider myself a pretty stereotypical millennial for many reasons - one being that I don’t like or have time to cook - and I’ve never understood the hype around the food delivery apps. It’s just hard to justify the cost of getting food delivered when most of the time it’s probably faster to go to the restaurant and pick it up yourself. I also typically don’t eat from restaurants unless I’m with others because I view it as more of a social activity. Trader Joe’s/Aldi/Walmart   an air fryer give me tons of quick and easy options for meals  even if it is hummus with fries or cereal  both of which are actually pretty good.
Name: archnerd

comment: I use Seamless. No Delivery Fee  no Service Fee - at least they're not billed to me. The food is delivered by the same delivery person already working for the restaurant. I will check whether the prices are higher than at the restaurant  but it hasn't seemed like it. I thought GrubHub worked the same way. I know that the other services provide delivery service for restaurants that don't already have it  and yes  there is a cost there.
Name: nakedhikernyc

comment: Why was the sales tax only 5% at Subway? And closer to 10% at the local Chinese restaurant? What’s going on there? :)
Name: dan

comment:
There is nothing in my small town of 20 000 more than a
10 minute drive - unless I have to wait for a train. And there
are few things I dislike more than wasting money.
Name: zetelmo

comment: I'm with you.  A $19.99 dinner at Popeyes would have cost almost $40 with the "free" delivery service provided by my Sapphire Reserve card.  Quite simply  discounts available on various apps don't come into play when a delivery service is involved.
Name: bruce

comment:
@brianxchen  How come you don't do an article on online college tuition breakdown with the ridiculous fees or why online newspapers charge a one time low subscription then revert back? Your logic here is what?Delivery expensive  always do yourself?  Everything you explained in the article the customers are well aware of. 
    Is it not a treat to have a hot warm meal with drinks delivered on a freezing or raining night? A lot of places also have waiting involved so once again consider these factors.Ofcourse cooking at home or going out are options but just how often can one do this. food delivery fills the gap especialy for workers. Some restauraunts have a quality to uphold; they never deliver  however have a 3rd party delivery sytem.
Name: daniel

comment: WAY out of context. Using an inexpensive item for one person at a fast food restaurant. This greatly distorts the impact of delivery and service fees. More realistic would be 2 entrees from a casual dinning restaurant. And you would then include a 15% dine in gratuity. VERY misleading chart.
Name: leonlevitt

comment: In working with millennials  I see much higher expenses for things I do for far less.  Uber  meal kits  grocery delivery  lunch out every day  gadgets galore.  I spend $0 per month on all these combined.
Name: djt

comment: Never used a food delivery app  but I occasionally pick up a takeaway meal at my local Indian or Chinese restaurant around the corner from my flat. After reading this I think I’ll give Uber eats and the like  a miss. Mostly we cook and eat meals at the table together as a family  the way I was raised.
Name: tony

comment:
It's a huge mistake for him to speak openly about these problems  because with every statement to the effect of "things were worse than we thought " or "we should have seen " he's opening the company to more and more liability in the form of securities and shareholder lawsuits.

Boeing's counsel is asleep at the switch.
Name: todd

comment:
Incredible. He asks to speak off the record when asked if American pilots could have handled the aircraft?

Outrageous. He says the airlines from "lesser" countries just weren't up to the task of flying the aircraft? If they knew that - and I am not sure that's true  then why did they sell the planes to them.

This guy isn't any better than his predecessor and needs to go.
Name: leslie

comment: Not sure that I would give this job to a protege of Jack Welch; we all can see the mess he made of GE  focusing on short-term profits over long-term strengths.
Name: carden

comment: It begs the question of whether Dennis A. Muilenburg should be prosecuted for criminal negligence and potentially man slaughter.  The C level is the most protected class in the U.S. Run a well established  publicly traded  industrial conglomerate into the ground? Don't worry  you will be rewarded with a handsome severance package.  What was Muilenburg's comp package? I am afraid to ask.
Name: stuart

comment:
Calhoun's first stop was to go genuflect before Trump?

This does not inspire confidence.  

I worked for Boeing for 15 years and was there when the downfall started  which was the McDonnell Douglas "merger" where Harry Stonecipher wound up in charge.  The focus after that was to maximize Department of Defense sales and profits.  The commercial business became less important.
Name: woody

comment:
David Calhoun: "...win back the confidence of international regulators and appease an anxious President Trump — all while moving as quickly as possible to get the grounded 737 Max back in the air."

Two questions:

What if "the confidence of int'l regulators" and getting the "grounded 737 Max back in the air" aren't compatible?

What if it turns out that the 737 Max simply isn't airworthy?
Name: batavicus

comment: I am not at all reassured about the future of Boeing. He was on the board and responsible  for the CEO and for knowing what was going. Either he was really bad at his job on the board or he knew what was going on and was OK with it until it hit the fan. Either way  he is not the person who can fix the problems.
Name: jackie

userName: SF or Sweden by the bay
comment: At least we will not be able to say that we did not know this new guy  he was clear and we know what to expect....just more of the same; and thank you but I will drive before I get in one of those planes . One thing we should be asking ourselves is what is happening to the USA?  and the answer it is not just trump.
Name: sf

comment:
" Mr. Calhoun criticized his predecessor in blunt terms and said he was focused on transforming the internal culture of a company mired in crisis following two crashes that killed 346 people."

What's has he learned that was hidden from him during his 10 years on the board of directors and as chair of the board in the months up to moving over to CEO?  Was Muilenberg lying to the board that much?

(I doubt it)

(I doubt anything will change)
Name: aps

comment: The company has not been Boeing for a long time now.  It's the scion of McDonell Douglas.  The original spirit of the company was killed with the buyout years ago.  Now we get a reprise of the DC-10.  Predictable.
Name: leonard

comment: So Muilenburg and other poobahs are allowed to keep their ill-gotten bonuses based on designing and producing hundreds of flawed aircraft? Where are the consequences for those who sacrificed safety to profit? It will take Boeing years to recover from this mess.
Name: tom

comment: I'm not convinced there's much change if they still think they can patch the 737 MAX.  It's an unstable passenger plane.  You can't patch that.
Name: zach

comment: I blame the FAA for not doing their job.  And their job is not to make things easy for airplane companies or airlines.
Name: sjs

comment:
Well this is sure an odd "defense" given that Mr. Calhoun was on Boeing's Board of Directors for a decade before taking over as CEO. Apparently he is admitting that he was a terrible Board member along with all the others  which I'm sure is true but I'm surprised to see they agree.

Clean out the Board and get a truly different CEO  one who isn't tied to this whole mess. Bring the company back to Seattle and refocus on safety. The rest is window dressing and everyone knows it.
Name: tim

comment: One thing the new CEO needs to do is convincer me that the aircraft manufactured during these past several years is safe to fly.  The previous administration should be sued for their pay and the board should be dismissed en masse and their salaries and expenses for the past 5 years clawed back.  We are talking lives and tax payer money on defense and space systems that was spent on who knows what.  People should be held accountable.
Name: tom

comment:
I worked at the original Braniff airways  that always had a positive financial standing. Then Harding Lawrence  the CEO  decided he wanted a Braniff to expand to every place in the world. It started with direct flights from DFW to Guam. The flights were on empty 747s. Then he bought not only more new 747s but also 747SPs  that have a very small cargo carrying capacity  which negated any chance of the cargo load making up for lack of passengers.
Soon the ramp was covered by idle 747s.
What drives me nuts that there are union members who say the unions killed Braniff when it’s obvious it was Harding Lawrence and his enablers.
Witness that airlines refuse to accept Boeing 787 aircraft that are built in South Carolina  a non union shop  because of poor quality control and only want the union built aircraft from the Washington plant.
In the non union shop I assure you  management couldn’t care less about quality  they want the product out the door ASAP. I also assure you that management threatens the employment of mechanics and inspectors that are trying to assure quality control.
I have worked as a contractor in such places that low ball bid overhauls of aircraft for the airlines  a job that used to be in house at the airlines but the bean counters decided it would be cheaper to farm it out. At least I had the luxury to tell them no and roll my toolbox out the door which I have done several times.
Name: paulie

comment: Anyone stepping into a position taking over will always find fault with their predecessor.  Mr Calhoun has sat on the Board of Directors since 2009  so he bears responsibility as much as anyone for the push in production (read: stock price).  Again  $ trumps safety and people's lives.  How far this company has fallen: from producing the most rugged WW2 4-engine bomber  that because of it's ruggedness  saved airmen's lives  to rushing the 737 Max from design through production because they had been out- competed by Airbus  costing 346 lives  a complete halt to production  and the grounding of all 737 Max planes.  Boeing is lost and must find themselves  and quick.
Name: lapine

comment: Actually  I think it probably all started one CEO earlier with James ("Jack Welch Jr") McNerny who brought the Six Sigma culture to Boeing and systematically devalued its employees. I was with 3M when McNerny tried to do it to us. I can still remember the culture of uncertainty and lack of trust in management. McNerny was with Jack Welch at GE before coming to 3M. Six Sigma kept everyone scurrying /currying favor with new Six Sigma chiefs.
Name: freebeau

comment:
"Before becoming the chief executive  he had vigorously defended Mr. Muilenburg  saying in a CNBC appearance in November that Mr. Muilenburg “has done everything right” and should not resign. One month later  the board ousted Mr. Muilenburg and announced Mr. Calhoun as his replacement."

Just another smooth talking empty suit 
exec who is focused on shareholder value. I'll pass  thanks.
Name: high

comment:
Surely Calhoun's statement should be in the top 20 list of the most disingenuous statements of the year: "“I’ll never be able to judge what motivated Dennis  whether it was a stock price that was going to continue to go up and up  or whether it was just beating the other guy to the next rate increase.”
Is there something radically different in Dennis Muilenberg's behavior  some out-of-left-field motivation that any top CEO might not recognize? Might it not be a variant of greed and hubris? And why should this be considered surprising in a context that pushes these top executives to behave this way? Maybe immediate profit at all cost should be junked in favor of a broader examination of what is happening. "I'll never be able to judge..." Really?  Calhoun is mired so deeply in this culture that he likely does not even have the perspective  the depth of field to form a judgement. And when you consider where he came from  Jack Welch (may he rest in peace)  there appears to be a pattern. Consider this Wikipedia quote from the Welch biography: Welch's critics questioned whether the short-term performance pressure he placed on employees may have led them to "cut corners"  thus contributing to subsequent scandals over defense-contracting  and/or the Kidder  Peabody & Co. bond-trading scheme in the early 1990s." Remind anyone of anything? Calhoun; who has been on the Boeing board since 2009 and his predecessor perhaps?
Name: saquireminder

comment:
If they don't use three sensors in a computer voting arrangement instead of two  they will never solve the problem of which sensor to believe when one fails. Do it the way NASA does it.
Also there must be one switch that removes the computer from control and allows the pilot to fly the airplane MANUALLY.
Name: ken

comment:
I think Boeing's decline began with moving the corporate hq to Chicago in 2001 after having been born  nurtured  matured  and thrived in Seattle. The corporate offices left behind a dedicated work force represented by strong unions that built safe and reliable planes. Secondly  was opening production South Carolina to avoid union protections for its workers there. And the Dreamliner has faltered.

Boeing was a proud Seattle-area-based aerospace company with international respect and markets that has lost its way due to poor strategic decisions. You cannot change the culture of a successful major corporation this dramatically without losing your way and possibly worse...your good reputation.
Name: david

comment: Calhoun is clearly a part of the problem  not the solution. He sat on the Boeing board that oversaw the literal disaster that is the MAX and defended his predecessor up until almost the bitter end. He places all the blame on the pilots at two airlines - one of which  Ethiopian  has a fine reputation - while defending his corrupt company and its inherently dangerous product. Most infuriating of all  he thinks Boeing can get away with this ongoing BS-ing. I despair at the thought that he might be right.
Name: thunder

comment:
Wow! His arrogance and a 737-sized blind spot are on full display and I guess I shouldn't be surprised coming from a GE/Welch protege. The foundation of this guy's executive upbringing explains why Boeing finds itself with the troubles it does. 

Blaming your predecessor for the mess they left behind is a bit of a cliche and though I don't doubt that things are an absolute dumpster fire there  I do find it absurdly laughable he's uttering those words given his presence on the board since 2009. Execs and attitudes like his need to be called and ostracized for the greedy  wasteful  value destruction they enable.
Name: em

comment: He was on the board for years  agreeing to everything Muilenburg did. Blood is on his hands too.
Name: pnwgal

comment: Calhoun is a protege of Jack Welsh.    Good luck with that.  Welsh was a bully and a fool that drove GE into the ground while laying off hundreds of thousands and making himself rich.
Name: keith

comment: Jack Welsh is no role model for fostering a healthy company culture.
Name: bob

comment: “If I don’t accomplish all that ” he said  “then you can throw me out [with my multi-million dollar golden parachute].”
Name: cedar

comment: Oh boy  here we go. Success has many fathers  but defeat is an orphan. This guy reminds me of Trump - all the bad stuff was Obama's fault.
Name: tom

comment: Here's a beware to airlines - you can check ahead what plane your flight is on.  I will only be booking flights on Airbus planes.
Name: nope

comment:
"He dismissed concerns about the board’s decision to give him a $7 million bonus based in part on whether the Max returned to service. “The objective is to get the Max up safely ” he said. “Period.”

Then they should not tie a personal financial incentive to it. Period.

You want someone in this role working against their own interests  or at least in the interests of other  to  keep them honest.  Distribute the 7mil to the lowest-level employees if the plane goes up.
Name: easy

comment:
I'd say it's his predecessor  the board of directors  the regulators and everyone who works there and turned a blind eye. 

Not much different from the folks at Wells Fargo. But Wells didn't kill anyone.
Name: a

comment: I imagine he is saying things like this because eventually Boeing will ask the government for a bailout. Come on  he was on the board. He’s dropping hints and has already fawned over trump. This is how the scam works America. When Boeing comes begging shut the door in their face. Let them fail  they created the problem.
Name: oliver

comment: Muilenburg was more than just a bad leader.  His irresponsible decisions and negligence of oversight appear to have had criminal intent and consequences.  People died.  Why has this man not been appropriately charged so a jury may get to the truth of the matter?
Name: bearboy

comment:
"David Calhoun largely laid the blame for the company’s 737 Max on his predecessor"

Right out of the Corporate Tycoon Management 101 Playbook: Blame your predecessor!  And keep blaming him/her for all the things that go wrong in your new regime!

But NEVER  ever address the corporate culture of PR and marketing replacing engineering  which is the REAL cause of Boeing's problems  as the Times has documented.  And the cause of so many other businesses fiascos.

And notice that Mr. Calhoun's stated "priorities" make no mention of improving quality or restoring the culture of Boeing to one where engineers -- not greedy CEOs  boards  and marketeers -- run the place and set priorities!

"To get Boeing back on track  Mr. Calhoun said he was working to mend relationships with angry airlines  win back the confidence of international regulators"
Name: nyer

comment:
"Mr. Calhoun has been on Boeing’s board since 2009  and was elevated to chairman late last year."

But  boy  that other guy really hid the stuff I should have seen in 11 years. 

How much do you think he pockets to rubber stamp approvals?
Name: paul

comment:
Calhoun lost me when the article reported:  "Mr. Calhoun formally took over in January  but he has been involved in this mess from the beginning. A protégé of Jack Welch from his time at General Electric  Mr. Calhoun has been on Boeing’s board since 2009  and was elevated to chairman late last year."

1) Why wasn't the board doing due diligence?  Did board members think governing by policy was enough?
2) Calhoun  as do all board members  need to accept some responsibility here.

I plan to never fly on a Max even if it is approved.
Name: charlie

comment:
Clueless when on the board.

But not clueless now?

Still blowing smoke that the "fault" was with Indonesian and Indian pilots and that American pilots who were equally clueless about Boeing's deception would somehow fare better in emergencies?  

Boeing's new CEO gives no confidence that much of anything will be different in the smokescreens Boeing sends out.

FAA  please for our sake  continue to be very wary and please be mistrustful of anything you hear from Boeing.  "A couple of people who wrote horrible emails!"  A "values" lesson is sure to change everything.  Is this the kind of GE "fix" that decimated the company (and the many companies ex-GE guys have gone on to lead)?  Likely.  Too bad now it's not just the engine maker but the maker of planes that fly us.
Name: aj

comment:
“If we were complacent in any way  maybe  maybe not  I don’t know ” Mr. Calhoun said. “We supported a C.E.O. who was willing and whose history would suggest that he might be really good at taking a few more risks.”

Oh come on. The Board (and you) need to take your share of responsibility. What kind of leadership is this?
Name: cjn

comment:
As a board member he had no problem with his predecessor as long as the stock price was soaring and enriching them all.  Two crashes and a few hundred dead folks would not have changed any of that had they not been able to pin it on an obviously flawed design. Everyone would have "thought and prayed for the victims and their families" and gone to dinner.
The entire corporation including all company officers and board members should be held liable.
Shame on him for trying to throw one man under the bus and then move on.  Everyone knew and everyone is guilty.
Name: tim

comment: He's been on the board since 2009  and has served as chairman since last year  and he's only now figuring out how bad things are? Either he chose not to ask  or he chose not to listen.
Name: di

comment: Sooo.. according to Mr. Calhoun those who wrote internal emails about shortcomings at the FAA and Boeing regarding the 737 Max were just bad apples? They didn't have a point?  All was rose and dandy and a few bad apples decided to write bad emails? That sounds hardly like an executive who has taken the measure of the disaster that Boeing has generated.
Name: ronald

comment: This reminds me of the old "prepare three letters" joke: A new manager meets the outgoing manager  who wishes him luck  hands him three envelopes  and says  "Open these when things get tough."  A few months go by  things are not going well  so the new manager opens the first envelope and finds a letter that reads  "Blame your predecessor."  So he does.  A few more months pass and business does not improve  so he opens the second letter which reads  "Reorganize."  So he does.  A few more months pass  business is still bad  so in desperation he opens the third envelope and finds a note that says  "Prepare three letters."
Name: craig

comment:
Let's see ....the new guy had been on the board for 11 years  but wasn't aware of any "culture" issues. He doesn't think there were systemic issues  unlike some engineers and pilots.

And he's all about communication- with politicians and airline companies.
Plus  the Indonesian and Ethiopian pilots were at fault for the crashes - even though they received no training about the new system. 
 At the same time  he declined to say if American pilots could have done better. 
No mention of the poor quality control in a no union N Carolina factory  leaving metal shavings and a ladder (yes) in a fuel tank; not the first quality control issue Boeing has faced in recent years.

In few years  he too can get 60 million when he leaves - hopefully without killing hundreds  including children   and devastating thousands of family members.
Name: dr

comment: This is the most self-serving bunch of tripe that I have read in a long time. Calhoun has been on the BoD for over ten years where he and the other board members presided over the destruction of the reputation of what was once one of the crown jewels of American manufacturing. A company with a proud history going back over a century. A company that built products that were instrumental in winning World War II. A company whose worldwide name recognition was without equal. All in the name of "shareholder value " which   translated into plain English  means that the price of the stock became more important than the quality of the product. It a toxic concept pioneered by Jack Welch  who constructed a house of cards at GE and then got out in time to escape the consequences of his work. Calhoun is a product of this culture  as was Jim McNerney  the CEO that started Boeing down this road. For a company whose products are among the most complex designs ever  which sell for hundreds of millions of dollars  and on which thousands of people trust their lives every year not to have  representation on its board by someone with engineering expertise in designing and producing commercial airplanes (Muilenburg was out of Aerospace) is  inexcusable. If ever a Board of Directors has abdicated its responsibilities in a more egregious manner   I'm not aware of it.  And to try to fix the problems with more Jack Welch clones borders only invites more and even worse problems.
Name: william

comment:
This is the classic take by a new CEO "turnaround" type  setting himself above the fray at the outset  in an act of premature self-protection  and an attempt to self-immunize (couldn't resists).
We should be on the lookout for "it was too broke to fix".
And he's been on the board since 2009.  What was he doing during the board meetings?
Name: slann

comment: As a former principal  I was asked harder questions by my small board of education than the board of directors at Boeing asked Muilenburg. If my test scores were increasing as fast at Boeing's stock prices  believe me  I would have been asked some pretty hard questions by my board--for which  the only answer would have been  I was cutting corners in someway. It seems with all of these corporate scandals  the boards are asleep at the switch.
Name: aj

comment:
' .... David Calhoun largely laid the blame for the company’s 737 Max crisis on his predecessor ...'  I would add the U.S. government which has functioned as the enabler. 

The problem began when  to compete with the Airbus  they decided to 'alter' the existing 737 instead of building a new aircraft from the ground up.  

To expand the context  some of those billions of pubic money could have been invested in a 21st century rail system capable of moving people from city to city.  If you factor in the mess and time it takes to get from airport to city  rail is easily more efficient in many cases.

There is no reason we cannot invest in building our own trains. Instead of telling autoworkers we'll bring back their industry  offer them a job building trains; the skills  the materials  are not so different. 

Yes  I'm dreaming; any move like this would require taxes and investment into a better future.  The interstate hi way system helped the auto and oil industry in major ways over decades.  At taxpayer expense.

If we are done 'investing' in the future then we are done  period.  It's called complacency.  Fatal complacency.
Name: cd

comment: Being a protege of the late Jack Welch should give little confidence that David Calhoun is the right person to assure Boeing the lift it desperately needs.  Consider the non-success stories racked up by other Welch disciples  including Jeff Immelt at GE and James McNerny  who ran Boeing before Dennis Muilenberg  and presumably helped create the culture now urgently in need of repair. Further  Calhoun was on the Boeing board when the actions he decries were being taken.  Trashing his predecessor may be an easy thing to do but it does not absolve Calhoun from his previous oversight.  Besides kicking a person when he is down seems straight from the Trump playbook.
Name: korean

comment:
I am disappointed with how the reporters let Mr. Calhoun  a long time Boeing board member  drop the dirty laundry on the chief. Mullenberg wasn't boss when Boeing culture went untethered. The latter  two bosses ago  was at the scene of that crime; and another one before that.
The string connecting the dots leads not to Chicago or Seattle  but to a conference center called Croton and HQ in Fairfield County. I'd guess  hope  the Boeing board room cleaning is still incomplete.
Name: p

comment: 'moving as quickly as possible to get the grounded 737 Max back in the air.' Herein lies the problem. the 737 Max should be scrapped and replaced by a modern  safe  and comfortable alternative. Until this happens nothing will change...
Name: dersh

comment: More excuses. This guy was not only a director but the Lead Independent Director. His JOB was to supervise the CEO. Does he admit any mistakes  any responsibility? Nope.
Name: not

comment:
Why do we never see a word of discussion about the aircraft itself. The basic issue is simple: is the 737Max airworthy?  Forget about software. Is the design safe? Is cobbling an existing airframe onto new  heavier  more powerful engines safe.
Why all this obfuscation?
Name: reality

comment:
"... Mr. Calhoun stopped short of saying the company has systemic cultural problems."

Then he goes on to say that engineers will be isolated from financial pressures.  If that needs fixing it sounds like a systemic cultural problem to me.  

And nothing about isolating production from financial pressures.  Ya know  the pressures that motivated Boeing to open a plant in a low wage state 3000 miles away from its skilled work force.

I'll believe that any of Calhoun's measures are working when my Boeing friends  who have been complaining about deteriorating quality for years  say that anything has changed.
Name: nan

comment:
Corporate America's concession to ceremonial and mostly ineffective but highly expensive management degrees like MBA  PMP etc are doing a great damage to top leadership decision making in almost every sector. It started aroung 1980s when crony capitalism and corporatization of higher education sector started taking taking deeper roots in US politics and corporate management. Even technical decisions were increasingly been taken by finance and MBA guys. That's when erosion of American society and industrial competitiveness started its steady decline. 

American managers are basically trained to hide problems and glorify themselves for self interest. Corruption  mainly nepotism and sycophancy  started taking its own toll. Boeing's issue is not an isolated one.
Name: bonku

comment:
If Calhoun replaces the management team of cost-cutting MBAs with engineers who care about aerodynamics and safety  Boeing has a chance at saving its reputation.

If not  Boeing is headed for more sloppy engineering  more colossal disasters resulting in thousands of lives lost  brain drain  loss of public trust  and ultimately bankruptcy and dissolution.
Name: cp

comment:
Corporate America's obsession to finance and ceremonial and mostly ineffective but highly expensive management degrees like MBA  PMP etc are doing a great damage to top leadership decision making in almost every sector. Previously only about 10 to 20 percent importance were given to Finance and Management in decent companies. Now it's easily more than 75 percent. Every other employees in the company seem to serve those people.

It started aroung 1980s when crony capitalism and corporatization of higher education sector started taking taking deeper roots in US politics and corporate management. Even technical decisions were increasingly been taken by finance and MBA guys. That's when erosion of American society and industrial competitiveness started its steady decline. American managers are basically trained to hide problems and glorify themselves for self interest. Corruption  mainly nepotism and sycophancy  started taking its own toll. Boeing's issue is not an isolated one.
Name: bonku

comment: “Boards are invested in their C.E.O.s until they’re not." Then why do we need the board for if they are just cheerleading or just for PR. This guy has been endorsing the former CEO until the last minute regardless of the disaster that happened. Why do we believe he can make a difference in his new position?
Name: cliff

comment: Too bad  Times missed an opportunity to dig into the history of Calhoun and his leadership decisions impact on Boeing the past 10 years. As other commentators have noted  Boeing is just another casualty of the Welsh-inspired slash and burn mentality that caused Boeing to make a series of mistakes  starting with their move to Chicago  the 787 and continued decisions based not on building value for stockholders and other stakeholders  but just trying to stick it to organized labor. So 300+ people die and no one is accountable  no introspection on new management's part  no admission that maybe  just maybe  building brand value around community/labor/management partnerships  focusing on quality and safety and valuing the knowledge base that the people in the organization represent as opposed to the widgets they produce  is a better way.
Name: seattle

comment: He states that the prior CEO was basically out of control and the company has systemic problems at all levels. But he  the Chairman of the Board and a long time board member  had no idea about any of it!  Isn’t oversight a key function of a board of directors?  I think the prior CEO isn’t the only one who should have been fired.
Name: tom

comment:
One has to ask whether it is the fault of the outgoing CEO or a system that focuses on short term gains that boost up the CEOs profile to deliver short term gains from long term decisions.

It is not financial returns alone that underpins success  although finance is an essential resource without which businesses cannot succeed. 

In the main what drives businesses is “competitive advantage”.  Competitive advantage must be profitable  sustainable in the face of competition  and appropriable (the profits must be available to the investor and not used entirely to drive the engine).  

Porter  Treacy  Wiersema  Hax all luminaries  on the subject defined Competitive Advantage as being one or more of five ingredients (a) Product Leadership (b) Customer Intimacy
 (C) Operations and supply chain Efficiency (d) System Lock-in or customer Lock-in. Steve Jobs added the last (e) Key Staff Retention. 

Boeing failed on three out of the first four and concentrated on System Lock-in at any cost. The entire business model with Boeing then focused on being profitable and then taking those profits out (i.e appropriable) and not on sustainability. Look carefully at the decision to speed up the 737 Max to compete in a hurry with Airbus as a classic case in point. 

A number of Fortune 500s sit in this camp. It is this mindless ideology around profitability and appropriability without sustainability that needs to change.
Name: roddynz

comment: To paraphrase: "He was making a lot of money for us so didn't look too closely."  Some call it "complacency."  The legal term is "willful blindness."  This is exactly the problem with corporate capitalism and why vigorous government oversight is necessary.
Name: tonyd

comment: Still trying to blame non-American pilots. Such cultural arrogance when it was Boeing’s culture that was at fault... we know they cut corners and that both software  training and then faulty speed recorder were to blame. Meet the new boss... same as the old boss.
Name: jacques

comment: Calhoun should go. He can't be taken seriously.   He had a perch from the board and saw less than nothing.   He was in denial.  If Boeing were just a commercial company its CEO would not be a matter of public interest.  However   it is one of the nation's largest defense contractors.  He must go  now.
Name: james

comment:
Boeing's problems run deeper than this.

The leadership was shifted from airplane engineers to financial wizards. The location was changed away from where they built airplanes  to where they manipulate money. Then they built a new factory in a place they never went  a place with no trained workforce but a lot of cheap labor to hire  and then they failed to spend on training and supervising those new workers.

All of that is not "trusting engineers " even if the new guy had an engineering background himself. It is taking real control away from engineers  which is what we saw  together with its consequences.

American aircraft manufacturing was formed before WW2  from engineers  who worked closely with the military and civilian airline operators. They saw technical opportunities first  and they solved technical wants from their buyers. That is what stopped. 

Instead  they focused on sales  financial terms  and payment schedules. That is why production was pushed  because it met sales schedules and loan terms.

This article skims very lightly over reversing those errors.
Name: mark

comment: A telling sentence in the article: the pressure to raise stock value to ensure that the CEO would get immensely rich.   And the board  did it also get wealthy?
Name: deborah

comment:
In this interview  Calhoun blames Indonesian pilots for lacking the "experience" of American pilots and presumably crashing the Max through their ineptitude. But the leaked internal emails show that Indonesian airlines requested training on the new Max systems and their request was laughed at and denigrated by Boeing employees using crude and offensive language. 

I encourage anyone who believes Calhoun to read his own employees' emails first and see the culture of his company.
Name: avery

comment:
Calhoun is just another Boeing attempt to stem the tide. The tide should not be stemmed but should be out in public view for the world. This company is guilty of letting their internal politics and corporate greed get ahead of public safety. Boeing should fail-they should immediately end the 737-Max to save more face-and passengers. 

Why do airlines need the Max now. They will never need the Max because for the next year or so airlines will be under maximum economic pressure around the world. Corona and the crashes are a double whammy for Boeing. If Boeing has any corporate wisdom left they should end Max and try to reestablish credibility once again.
Name: pushkin

comment: Very traditional tactic for the new guy in charge: blame the problems on the previous guy in charge.  However  Calhoun has been on the board since 2009 and chairman of it to boot.  Was he asleep at the wheel?  Putting him in the CEO position was a decision of the board which he led.  If the board did not address the issues that occurred under Muilenburg  the whole board should have the decency to resign  or better yet  be fired  Calhoun first and foremost .
Name: stefan

comment:
Gee  maybe it wasn't such a good idea to allow the US commercial aerospace industry to consolidate into a single company.

If only there were a whip-smart presidential candidate who had detailed plans for reducing monopolies!
Name: ltj

comment: The arrogance of this man is palpable. He served on the board for 10 years. He was the CEOs boss. Has he reflected on his own culpability and the pressure and the lack of governance/oversight from the board? Doesn't seem like it. He makes no mention of the employees and addressing Boeing's culture that enabled this. He's creating a scapegoat and while there is blame  there is plenty to go around including to the board.
Name: katy

comment: The problems at Boeing began long before the 737-Max fiasco. They had serious production problems with the 787 Dreamliner  for example. I trace the real problem as a culture shift from a wonderful engineering firm to a company focussed only on profit. The clear indicator that Boeing was going down the rabbit hole was moving their management force away from Seattle  where the engineering was  to Chicago  where management did not have to walk the production and research areas to get to their offices. The connection to engineering was severed. The beginning of the end.
Name: peter

comment:
Martin produced a plane that crashed due to similar problems. It was competing with Convair.  These prop planes with engines the same as WWII bombers used were meant to replace the venerable DC3s on relatively short hall domestic flights.  
Martin ended up redesigning entirely the wing for their plane.  By the time all shaked out & the Martin 404 was flying they had lost out to Convair 240 and 340s.  
It appears to me that the Boeing Max has a bad wing badly placed on the fuselage.  Long as the wing is the same and placed on the fuselage on the same place I don't believe it will ever be a good plane. 
If you yourself even look at an assembled MAX 737 from above it doesn't even look well balanced to the eye.  
While the Air Force has flown inherently unstable aircraft that can't fly without computer controlled control surfaces their purposes are not to safely transport passengers for decades  but to bomb people to death.  
Any passenger plane needs an inherent stability  & if it won't fly without a computer fixing what is wrong with it  it is not much of a plane of greatness.
Name: russell

comment: The only way Boeing would regain my trust was if they decided to junk this Frankenstein like aircraft. From now on  when I fly somewhere  I will check the aircraft type and manufacturer before I confirm my reservation. I would rather my life be in the hands of German  French and other European engineers than American bean counters!
Name: viking

comment: Once Boeing became more concerned with financially engineering its stock price  actually engineering went out the window  and planes started crashing.  Corporate stock buy-backs used to be basically illegal in the United States  and Boeing is perfect example of why.
Name: brixton

comment: Boeing has a responsibility to make sure it’s planes are able to be flown by people who pass their training. If you need a lot of experience to be able to fly  then there is something wrong with the plane.
Name: br

comment:
Daviid Calhoun and "candid" cannot be used in the same sentence.

In 2001  Boeing Senior Technical Fellow John Hart-Smith presented a widely-applauded paper warning against precisely the strategies that Harry Stonecipher  Alan Mullaly  Jim McNerney  and Dennis Muilenburg drove.

Mr. Calhoun was a member of the Boeing board while Jim McNerney created the manufacturing  supply chain  and engineering model and culture that ultimately produced the 737 MAX mess. 

The Boeing board would serve the interests of the company  the nation  its employees  and its shareholders by dispatching Calhoun and bringing in a recognized and trusted aerospace executive like Michele Evans  the 
Executive Vice President  Aeronautics of -- dare I say it -- Lockheed Martin.
Name: mack

comment:
New CEO blames past CEO.  Who is surprised?
This is classic PR. Blame the prior administration.  It's exactly what the next CEO will do as well.  None of it addresses how to fix any underlying systemic issues.  It's business as usual.  This guy will be doing exactly what the last CEO did as soon as the press looks the other way.  Profit trumps everything.
Name: steve

comment: It is terrifying to me that Mr. Calhoun is concentrating on rehabilitation of Boeing's stock instead of fixing the problem of their neglect of engineering and quality control.  Shouldn't the quality and the safety of their airplanes be his number one job?
Name: jeff

comment: Software doesn't malfunction.  A sensor that feeds data to software can malfunction  or some other input including humans can malfunction but software does not malfunction.  It doesn't have mood swings.  Software does exactly what it's programmed to do.  It can have a bug  or it can be badly programmed  but those aren't software malfunctions.  Those are human malfunctions  which would have been identified during the normal course of testing and debugging (providing Boeing has a competent software unit manager).  Calhoun seems to be on track to fix his human problem  I think.  But this problem should have been fixed in a couple of weeks.  Something very bad is going on inside the software unit of Boeing.  Fire the manager if you haven't already.
Name: aurora

comment: Based on his record of short term thinking  lack of probing  and poor judgement  is there any substantial evidence that Calhoun is fit to be the CEO of Boeing? Sad to see GE and now Boeing on a global decline.
Name: prad

comment:
Another G.E./Welch trainee well versed in making money for himself ? 

Let's see how he does with a once great company. Right now Boeing only has three things going for it: i) size  giantism covers a lot of mistakes  ii) not much global competition  iii) Trump needs them to succeed. 

Hopefully they still have a core brilliant group of engineers and  highly skilled workers but likely they are not too happy.

Just waiting for all Boeing's ills to be blamed on unions and 'over-regulation'. That may be next in Calhoun's playbook.
Name: bill

comment:
Jack Welch’s sad legacy is that he put shareholders above all else.  Boeing did the same thing and the results are clearly damaging the company’s reputation.  You’re only as good as your employees and Boeing sees their employees as “adding to costs” which is why they moved some production to South Carolina and it’s HQ to Chicago.  

The first job of the new CEO is to restore Boeing to an engineering company.  By doing so they can win back skeptics who are moving to Airbus.  Employee morale is also essential.  It’s a huge task but that’s why the CEO gets the big bucks.
Name: richard

comment:
He's been on the board since 2009.  Why didn't he know how bad it was?

Being a board member is not just an honorific.  It's a job you must take very seriously. (And yes  I know  that boards are typically just rubber stamps  but that's not how they should operate.) 

I think he owes shareholders and the flying public an explanation for why he and his colleagues failed to do that job.
Name: justin

comment: Calhoun's been on the board since 2009 but is just now speaking up?  And blaming the former CEO  who he'd championed for years?  What a farce.  Investors need to clean house at the board.
Name: midleveler

comment: I see a lot of comments about the aerodynamics of the plane (the 737 MAX never being able to fly  it will never be stable  it is "unbalanced"  etc). People need to stop pretending to be aeronautical engineers. It was a software issue  not mechanical.
Name: co

comment: The failure of corporate governance is summed up in this interview. Mr Calhoun was on the Board of Directors that oversaw the 737 Max debacle. To hear him talk  the responsibility lies entirely with his predecessor. What do directors get paid so handsomely ($346 000 annually  according to Fortune Magazine) to do  other than to prevent disasters like this?  And if his predecessor was so bad  why did the Board pay him $60 million severance?
Name: ted

comment: I will continue to prefer airlines that fly Airbuses over Boeing planes. It is going to take a lot to restore my confidence in Boeing airplanes. I suspect that my feelings are shared by a large segment of consumers.
Name: vicky

comment:
How novel for a career MBA to scapegoat an engineer who had recently been handed the yoke of a ship piloted by another career MBA who had (quite literally) built in a runaway stab trim set to crater!  No mention of McNerney in this whole interview and his decision to override his managers who had requested a clean sheet design instead of the MAX?  

I get that Jack Welch proteges have to look out for each other with their questionable legacy  but I don't see how this lack of ownership is any way to endear himself to the engineering staff that he desperately needs to right the ship.
Name: ben

comment:
“Boards are invested in their C.E.O.s until they’re not ”

This suggests that boards (in my opinion) are hesitant to thoroughly question C.E.O.'s and specifically in the case of the 737 we all see the results.

Clearly boards of directors for all companies need to not only be more aggressive in their oversight but also be held accountable when major issues arise just as top line management should be.
Name: paul

comment:
"If it isn't Boeing  I'm not going!" So said the tour guide at the end of the best factory tour of my life.  The Everett tour was milestone in a life spent in fascination of the aerospace industry and a chance to show my super inquisitive 10 year old son what was possible with brains and hard work.  
How very sad it all looks now.
The 737 should have been retired at the 900 series and a proper competitor to the A320 conceived from the ground up.  
Everyone knows this - even Mr Calhoun
Name: david

comment:
The reason Muillenberg walked away from Boeing with a $62 million platinum parachute is that the Boeing board is as guilty as him. They KNEW what was going on with the MAX but decided that profits and stock value are more important than safety and building a quality product. If the board refused to grant the ex-CEO the pay off  the pursuing lawsuit would have exposed how corrupt the leadership of Boeing has become. In other words  $62 million was hush money.

Until the entire board is gone Calhoun has little chance to succeed.
Name: greg

comment:
If I owned any Boeing stock  after reading this article  I'd certainly sell.  Calhoun exhibits a combination of denial and blame shifting.   Rarely ever good leadership traits and absolutely what is not currently needed at Boeing.  The fact that one of his first meetings was with Trump  not employees  customers or on the ground regulators speaks volumes.  So does the fact that he wanted to go off the record about blaming pilots versus Boeing's design and decisions to keep pilots in the dark about the design.

This plane needs to be redesigned from the ground up and so does Boeing's leadership including its current CEO.
Name: honey

comment:
Mr. Calhoun says he is trying to mend relationships with the government  airlines and regulators.  What he leaves out is the rest of us ...the traveling public.  I think he has a huge task convincing us that a member of the Board is not complacent in the wrongs that have occurred and that the company should not have brought in an outsider.

I don't see from his comments that he understands how badly the culture of the company needs to change and revert back to what it used to be.
Name: steve

comment: Calhoun apparently casts some blame on the Indonesian and Ethiopian pilots. I find such a view reprehensible. Why? Boeing is trying to sell MAXs all over the world. They should understand how pilots behave not just in the USA but in every country they sell a plane. Calhoun has to exercise an approach where every worldwide airline has not only a sales contact but also someone technical  probably a former pilot  who will sign off that the pilots of that airline are certified. You can't rely on the FAA to make sure pilots in other countries are equipped to handle emergencies.
Name: john

comment:
Calhoun knows exactly what motivated Muilenberg  namely  a gold-plated compensation package tied to Boeing's stock performance rather than to actually making sure the company produced great products. 

Such compensation gimmicks have propelled stock prices to levels where they no longer reflect the health of underlying businesses and made a generation of senior executives outrageously wealthy. When will we do something to reward corporate chieftains for producing great products  taking good care of employees  minding the impact their business has on the environment and commitment to the communities in which those businesses operate?
Name: ssstrom

comment: Step 1 - abandon the Max and build a new plane  a safe one  from scratch
Name: paul

comment:
Blaming his predecessor?
He was on the board  in the know and went along with everything.
Sounds like a page out the Trump’s playbook.
This is the wrong guy to have in charge.
Name: erik

comment:
This reminds of the old joke: 

Upon being ousted my predecessor gave me two letters with some advice should I ever run into trouble. One in a blue envelope the other in a red one. He said  "Trouble will come. If you can't find a way out of it open the blue one envelope. Save the red one for if it happens a second time". Sure enough trouble came soon after I took charge. I opened the blue envelope. It said  "Blame everything on me." It worked like a charm. About 2 years later I encountered second bind I could seem to find my way out of. I opened the red envelope. It read  "Sit down and write two letters."
Name: still

comment: Calhoun was on the board for the past decade and yet he didn't know what the company culture was?  And he's blaming "the weaknesses of our leadership" -- the same leadership he helped select and stood by through all this turmoil?  At what point do you as a longtime board member have to take responsibility?
Name: steve

comment: So if board included a substantial number of rank and file employees  perhaps some of these issues would have surfaced earlier?
Name: s

comment: I have two thoughts:  (1) Getting the Max in the air pales in importance to getting the public to fly on it.  IMHO the design concept was fatally flawed to begin with.  Taking a 1960's basic design  stretching it  re-engineing it  and expecting software to overcome inherent instability doesn't present like sound engineering judgement.  (2) Mr Calhoun is a protege of Jack Welsh (?)  The man who took on of America's most iconic manufacturing companies and turning it into a financial house?  How is this supposed to instill confidence?
Name: julia

comment: As a Boeing board member since 2009  Calhoun shares in the blame. Perhaps more so than his predecessor. The board of directors is the highest governing authority within a corporation.
Name: karl

comment:
There are a couple of obvious points that Mr Calhoun seems to avoid.

1. the rather obvious fact that the public will just not fly in that plane.  Boeing has already sold almost every 737 MAX it will ever sell.
2. overseas regulators will be far harder to convince of the plane's safety than domestic regulators.  The FAA's initial slow response to the 737 MAX crisis has ruined it's reputation and led to suspicions of regulatory capture.  Foreign regulators no longer accept without question the recommendation of the FAA as they once would have.
Name: melbourne

comment: There’s a basic problem with Calhoun  he was a board member of Boeing for a decade - and Chairman before CEO. He therefore has a responsibility for the same policies he now deplores. Can he be taken seriously? He’s was very much a part of the culture he protests.
Name: mack

comment:
The Max will never fly again. 

Boeing knows when they admit that reality their stock price will plummet by over 50%. They are scared. 

So they continue with the theatrics of getting that plane off the ground while hoping for some undefined miracle. Maybe a government bailout? 

Boeing is in serious trouble.
Name: will

comment: If Calhoun seriously believes that non-American pilots are not up to the job of flying the Max safely  then surely Boeing will no longer be selling the plane overseas?
Name: ali

comment:
Having grown up near the Renton plant and having a lot of neighbors who worked there..

1) start from scratch and build an amazing  stable  future aircraft (hybrid technology) with the incredible team that is there. 
2) STOP trying to undermine the unions who build the planes  utilized their vast experience for the good of the product. 
3) Fire all of the Board  and build an oversight committee that is not so vested in the stock price  but long term success  with the inherent bonuses built into a quality product. Let the team members benefit  not the board and stockholders can take a back seat.
Name: elaine

comment: It would appear that Mr. Calhoun maintains the bigoted attitude that has been apparent from his company throughout the Max issue. As a long time resident of Indonesia I can assure him that Boeing should build its products for all pilots and passengers around the world. If he feels that only American pilots are capable of flying his planes correctly then he should refrain from selling them outside his own borders.
Name: nick

comment: Poor leader spotted. Calhoun was Chairman of the board (one which he has been on since 2009!) and had oversight of the prior CEO and now sitting in the seat he "finally" sees how bad things were. At best Calhoun was incompetent in his prior role or at worst  willfully ignorant. Both of those portend a failed tenure as CEO. Blaming the last guy is always a poor sign.
Name: john

comment:
I’m sorry Mr. Calhoun  but laying the blame at your predecessors feet just isn’t big or clever. Your company has a clearly reported track record of faults allowing pervasive problem of covering up serious design faults  manufacturing deficiencies and sheer ineptitude. 

The traveling public are smarter than you are and we’ll never fly in a 737MAX. Nor will our friends OR family as our lives are worth more than returns for your shareholders. 

The only way you can regain public confidence is to scupper the 737MAX and sack all involved with it from top to bottom.  That would show real leadership and send a message to remaining employees what failure looks like.
Name: steve

comment:
Boeing exemplifies American business.  It's very shoddy.  Almost all  but not all of American corporations are about pleasing shareholders.  

The U.S. government is protecting them.  Trump is trying to protect them.

I recommend not flying at all but riding the train or bus wherever you have to go.  This will maybe force the government to see the stupidity of flying everywhere and maybe lead to us catching up to the rest of the world.
Name: john

comment: When they forced Khruschev out  he sat down and wrote two letters to his successor. He said – ‘When you get yourself into a situation you can’t get out of  open the first letter  and you’ll be safe. When you get yourself into another situation you can’t get out of  open the second letter.’ Well  soon enough  this guy found himself in a tight place  so he opened the first letter. Which said – ‘Blame everything on me.’ So he blames the old man  it worked like a charm. He got himself into a second situation he couldn’t get out of  he opened the second letter. It said – ‘Sit down  and write two letters.'
Name: andy

comment:
This guy is still blaming the victims   the pilots of the two planes which crashed.

Not the way to re-establish trust.
