Humility  not arrogance  please.  esepcially in a CEO who presumes to be a true leader.  Keep in mind that those foul  nasty emails were the tip of the iceberg of Boeing's culture of arrogance.  

Not much has changed.
Name: elise

comment:
The 737-Max crashed two times because intrusive software that no other plane requires malfunctioned. The software is necessary b/c the plane is so badly designed that it's possible that it could stall due to bad weight distribution. 

And the weight distribution is so bad that  if the engines did stall  the plane wouldn't be flyable so couldn't be used as a glider the way that Sully did when he landed a plane in the Hudson. 

That's the plane they're so anxious to get back in the air--to have you buy a ticket on--a badly designed Rube Goldberg machine  that needs patchwork solution after patchwork solution just to be somewhat flyable.
Name: dj

comment:
Yet Calhoun's CEO predecessor left with a $60 million severance package. Tell me the last time you messed up a product at your workplace and left with a $60 million golden parachute.

The 737 is a 1965 design that should have been revised many years ago. We no longer drive 1965 cars  use 1965 appliances or watch 500 pound 1965 tvs. When Boeing decided to add a more efficient engine  they altered the plane's center of gravity and messed with the weight and balance so they tried to bandage the issue with poorly written software. 

We all know how that turned out. 

Then they scrimped by eliminating redundant angle of attack indicators which  on my experimental airplane  costs approx $200.

IMHO  the CEO and board of directors belong in jail for allowing this malfeasance of a design to be foisted on the unknowing public and inadequately trained pilots until 346 people suffered a horrible death. How many other near catastrophes is still not known. 

FAA is equally complicit for allowing Boeing to certify their own planes but that underscores the problems caused by massive deregulation.
Name: pilotbuilder

comment:
There once was a new CEO who was appointed.  When he got to his office he found three envelopes in the desk drawer.  They were marked "Open the first time you run into trouble"  "Open the second time " etc.

He began his new job.

Some time later there was a major problem.  He remembered the envelopes and pulled out the first one.  In it was a piece of paper that said "Blame your predecessor."

Even though he had been on the board for nearly a decade  he went to the media and said “It’s more than I imagined it would be  honestly.  And it speaks to the weaknesses of our leadership.”

Some more time passed.

Later another major problem appeared.  He opened the second envelope.  In it he saw "Blame market conditions."

He went on TV and said "The problems we have experienced have mainly been the result of a complex set of market conditions."

More time went by.

Finally  there was a third crisis that occurred.  The CEO pulled the last envelope out of his desk.  He paused before he slit it open.  Inside he read:  

"Make 3 envelopes."
Name: steve

comment: He doesn't get it. He thinks it is okay for the Boeing software to send the plane into a sudden dive and expect the pilots to react by disabling the system. Boeing replaced one jerk CEO with another jerk CEO.
Name: eric

comment: Any CEO who would take advice from Donald Trump is surely a fool.
Name: dave

comment: So this guy gets a $7 million bag of money if he gets the Max back in the air? What could possibly go wrong?￼
Name: douglas

comment: Fitting that on the day the “Legendary Jack Welch” is buried  Calhoun  one of his protégées is in charge of perhaps Americas most important companies.  He gives an interview to The New York Times and is completely exposed as an empty suit.
Name: jack

comment:
Wow  what a class act! First thing he does is dump on his predecessor. Was this guy a director who didn’t attend board meetings? If he was paying any attention at all  he would have known what was going on and voted to make a leadership change sooner. But now he’s built himself an escape pod and can just keep blaming Mullenburg when he’s unable to turn things around. 
And nobody’s gonna get me to fly on this unsafe plane.
Name: rob

comment: On the board for the last 11 years but its the former CEO’s fault?
Name: fw

comment: The man was a protege Jack Welch  the man who believed a smart businessman could run any business  even one he didn't know anything about. First  blame the previous manager for problems. Second  blame the pilots for crashing the planes that created the crisis. Doesn't sound like a good start for the new CEO. He starts by telling the NYT that production was going too fast but wasn't the problem with the MAX in the design? Wasn't the software badly designed and written? Didn't it violate one of the most common safety measures in the aerospace industry  redundancy?
Name: lester

comment:
Since the 737Max has been grounded  I’ve never felt safer flying. If it ever flies again  our family will have to discern which plane we will be flying on for each trip. And it won’t be the 737Max.
There have been too many problems at Boeing  the poorly conceived Max just one of many massive screwups to ever trust them again.
Fly Airbus.
Name: its

comment:
Mr. Calhoun implied that the pilots from Indonesia and Ethiopia  “where pilots don’t have anywhere near the experience that they have here in the U.S. ” were part of the problem  too.

Asked whether he believed American pilots would have been able to handle a malfunction of the software  Mr. Calhoun asked to speak off the record. The New York Times declined to do so.

“Forget it ” Mr. Calhoun then said. “You can guess the answer.”

My guess is...
Deep down Mr. Calhoun believes only white folks from Dayton Ohio know how to fly airplanes.

I think he exemplifies  and will now propagate  a systemic lack of moral fiber in Boeing’s board.

Out!
Name: george

comment: From the beginning and still  this entire continuing calamity can and ought to be laid at the feet of all the execs AND the board. Those on this board  including Calhoun  are responsible  period. Perhaps all the other members of the board should be questioned as this article questioned Calhoun. Where were each of them when the many strategic blunders cascaded to kill people? No doubt collecting their $ and prestige. We’re so proud.  ￼
Name: jos

comment:
The comments of this individual placing part of the blame for the two accidents squarely on the pilots  and implying that the accidents would not have happened if better trained (American) pilots had been in charge  are appalling on at least two counts. 
First  he ignores the fact that it is the responsibility of the manufacturer to deliver a safe aircraft and to make the operators aware of every detail necessary to ensure a safe operation. It is NOT the responsibility of the pilots to improvise in a life or death situation in order to make up for a defective product  regardless of how well trained they may or may not be. 
Second  it assumes that every single American pilot would have been able to handle the emergency. There is no basis for this statement. There are certainly many excellent pilots in the US  and abroad. There are also mediocre pilots everywhere  which have found their way to the cockpit because of the unsustainable growth of the airline industry.
It is time to put the Max  Mr. Calhoun  and Boeing  out to pasture. Perhaps this will be one of the silver linings of the coronavirus slump.
Name: ajax

comment: So Boeing has a "new set of values...."  Seems to me the managers and pilots who wrote the disturbing emails already possessed a fine set of values.  It's the C-suite who did not and I'm sure their primary value is how fat their salary and benefits are.
Name: diane

comment:
Does anyone out there think the not qualified foreign pilots argument holds water? 
How can you design a plane  say it is safe to fly  not provide a manual for the fatal MCAS system  them blame the PILOTS for  being  inferior and untrained asserting that the US pilots would have...stupid argument driven by  what  risk management?
Name: mort

comment: The former CEO of Boeing is directly responsible for the death of over 300 people  whose punishment was a bonus of over 60 million dollars. How is sich a such an evil and corrupt system allowed to flourish? How many deaths will Boeing need to cause before it is held responsible?
Name: smokey

comment: Another Welch-trained bench warmer checking the stock pice hourly. He had years in a position where *his* job was to see that *his* CEO wasn't doing the sorts of things he noe blames the CEO for doing. That he wouldn't have taken the job without the $7 million tells you about his passion and commitment.
Name: ryan

comment:
As a director  Calhoun 'owns' the Boeing debacle as much as any manager.  The company's board of directors failed to acquit its fiduciary responsibilities  and it is decidedly counter-intuitive to have given the keys to a board member after the belated firing of Muilenberg.

As a company  Boeing has been run into the ground by the McDonnell Douglas crowd.  An organization that historically has depended on savvy engineers and a capable workforce is now being (mis)managed by B-school types who really don't know ground-up design and build processes.

This interview seems to show that the new guy is willing to bad-mouth his own decisions as a trustee--but conveniently diverting attention to a predecessor he backed all the way and helped to keep in power far too long.  I'm not encouraged by the "rebranding " which looks far more cosmetic than substantive.  This is a company whose difficulties still reside in the board room  and Calhoun just came from there.
Name: robert

comment: When asked whether non-American pilots could have handled the failure  the only correct answer - from a leader who actually takes his company’s shortcomings seriously enough to want to fix them - would be “that’s irrelevant; our equipment failed and we are responsible for fixing it.”  Yet instead he follows his predecessor’s example in pure  misplaced arrogance. Let’s not forget: this company’s negligence literally killed people.
Name: eric

comment: Another lord of the universe. What Boeing needs is more humility and less chutzpah.
Name: kelly

comment: He and the rest of the board should be in prison for manslaughter.  Why are corporations considered “people” up until it’s time to take responsibility?
Name: medusa

comment: More poison from the temple of Jack Welch. No empathy for the victims. No empathy for his employees. Just concern for the shareholders.
Name: jeff

comment:
From the article  paraphrasing Mr. Calhoun: "When designing the Max  the company made a “fatal mistake” by assuming pilots would immediately counteract a failure of new software on the plane."

Boeing has learned NOTHING. The design flaw in the MAX has nothing to do with the MCAS software or the lack of redundant sensors. The design flaw was grafting oversize engines onto an existing airframe that was not designed for such engines. As a result  the aircraft cannot be safely flown under manual control. That should disqualify if from certification.

I will NEVER fly on an aircraft whose design is so fundamentally flawed.

If the MAX does get certified  that's only a sign that the FAA is no longer in control.

I will be flying airlines like Delta that don't own the MAX. I wonder why airlines WOULD buy the MAX? It doesn't make sense... unless airline execs are getting a little 'bonus' from Boeing for doing these deals. Why buy aircraft that many people will refuse to set foot in?
Name: shenbowen

comment: As a member of the board  his entire job was to oversee management so that things like this didn't happen. I have zero confidence in his leadership.
Name: sd

comment: I fail to see how appointing a finance guy to lead a company whose problem is that it has drifted away from its engineering roots will fix this problem.
Name: greg

comment: When the employees laid out what needed to be done in gory detail this guy added a day or two ??    Even if he’s being sarcastic that’s just a ridiculous comment.   And if he’s being serious it shows a lack of judgements   Is it too soon (or maybe too late?) to fire him?   Next please    The right answer is we will take as much time is needed to put a safe reliable  airplane into service
Name: chris

comment: Classy! He'll fit right in with one of America's biggest corporate grifters. Note to Calhoun and airlines: NO ONE will want to fly on those planes. EVER.
Name: brooklyn

comment: Calhoun reminds me of Trump.   Blame everybody else- mainly the last guy who had the job and foreigners.   It’s hard to believe what has happened to one of our most storied companies.
Name: scott

comment: I am still outraged that Muilenberg received a golden parachute worth hundreds of millions of dollars while he blithely gambled the lives of thousands of passengers for profit.  He belongs in jail and every cent of that golden parachute should go to the families of passengers who died on those two flights.
Name: syj

comment: Retired 737-800 Captain here... With all things considered  I believe that with the widespread notoriety of the Max  the widespread notoriety of the deception and corner-cutting of management  the numerous lawsuits to be settled for the families  the numerous lawsuits to be settled for their airline customers  etc.  etc.  Boeing will scrub the Max  will pay out to cover its responsibilities  and will start over with a clean sheet of paper  designing a new type aircraft that is not a 737 add-on  but an entirely new type  to be sold to the airlines along with the required training  in order for Boeing to survive.  This will be a textbook case in business schools for decades to come.
Name: john

comment: Boeing was once the pride of American manufacturing and global aerospace. Like so many corporate monoliths  they have lost their way. I often fly multiple times a month for work and pleasure. I will never step foot on a 737 Max. Boeing should cut their losses now and sell every one of these planes for parts. The board of directors should be replaced too  right after they fire David Calhoun.
Name: dabney

comment: The most significant item that I gleaned from this article is that corporate board members are useless.
Name: michele

comment: Perhaps Mr. Calhoun should look back at the changes in culture he supported. As one of the previous Boeing CEO's  Mr Stonecipher  put it in 2004: “When people say I changed the culture of Boeing  that was the intent  so it’s run like a business rather than a great engineering firm.” Fixing the 737 MAX problems will require great engineering and not just business and salesmanship. Stonecipher and Calhoun both come from the GE culture created and made famous by Jack Welch; and GE is another case of a great engineering firm converted into a business that is now floundering.
Name: wvb

comment:
Share holder value is far more valuable then human value.

Wasn’t that Welch’s lesson
Name: rob

comment:
Short version of this whole story; CEO pushes for big money at any cost  Board more than happy to go along because of profit. Lots of dead people and the board gets nervous as profits plunge. Blame guy going out door with big payout.
'Best' part of this is showing how ridiculous the FAA is.
"“Restoring credibility with the F.A.A. was not as hard as people think ” he said..." Of course it was not hard  they are owned by the industry. Many people have to die before the FAA will bother to rouse from their stupor.
Boeing used to be a good company.
Name: vet

comment: Insinuating that the pilots were to blame for these crashes is disgusting. American pilots would have handled it better? Give me a break. What arrogance in the face of an abject failure to meet basic safety standards (by one of most American companies out there  by the way). I would rather see Boeing fail than live in a world where plane crashes can be justified by the fact the pilots were Ethiopian or Indonesian.
Name: robby

comment:
And still the racist lie that American pilots could have somehow dealt with the Max malfunction that resulted in both crashes. 

I flew next generation 737’s - including the Max - for a major US carrier. (I’m now on a different airframe)

I’m not sure I would have been able to recover the jet from the scenario those mishap crews found themselves presented with. The malfunction does not present as a pitch trim runaway. We were not told of MCAS  and even after Boeing admitted to the existence of a secondary flight control system  we were still unaware (As was the FAA) that MCAS would repeatedly fire of 2.5 unites of aircraft nose down trim until humans were unable to physically maintain control of the airplane. 

Shame on Calhoun for not being accountable. He will fail as a leader.
Name: dan

comment: Why aren't the heads of the board of directors on pikes along with the old CEO.  Aren't they supposed to be supervising and monitoring?  In fact the new CEO is from the board and he didn't know so what's the story there... Negligence?  Apart from swanning around at shareholder's expense  what were they doing?
Name: scott

comment: While I wish Mr. Cahoun success in restoring Boeing as a premier engineering firm  it's not encouraging to hear him blame the Indonesian and Ethiopian pilots for not being able to recover from the crisis that bad software threw them into. If he really means to ensure safety  he needs to develop planes that can be flown by pilots without encountering novel surprises like the one that killed 364 people.
Name: michael

comment:
Classic problem.

I experienced it my entire career as a semiconductor engineer and manager. 

The problems are not always at the top. Along the chain there can be engineers and managers who have ego's larger than the Max.

I quit my first engineering job because I was two weeks late. I was the High Reliability Engineer- military/aerospace. The problem was that the prior engineer fudged data. After I uncovered the problem  I was blamed. So I quit. Easy for me to get a better job. After an investigation the manager that degraded me was fired.

Several years later I became a manger at another company  heavily involved in weapon systems for the Gulf war. My earlier experience shaped my work ethic. I never bowed to pressure. I was as efficient as possible  but stubborn about quality.

I think outsourcing  and weird sky-high compensation for CEO's has created a strange ethical landscape. Glad I'm retired.
Name: anyoneoutthere

comment:
I share the shock of many commenters that Calhoun— a long time Boeing BOD member blames his predecessor for the mess Boeing is in today. 

Muilenburg actually inherited the mess that Welch protege McNerney created. Would Calhoun be as equally critical to his ex GE buddy?  

I doubt it but prove me wrong!
Name: tommie

comment:
“Mr. Calhoun said  he is working to mend relationships with angry airlines  win back the confidence of international regulators and appease an anxious President Trump — all while moving as quickly as possible to get the grounded 737 Max back in the air.”

As predicted  Calhoun the hedge fund guy is about making profits and appeasing an anxious (uninformed) president — exactly like his predecessor.  Also like his predecessor he expresses no concern or remorse for the hundreds of human beings killed by an irredeemably-flawed airplane design.

Boeing was once an American icon.  Now it’s just another corporate monster serving shareholders and no one else.  What could go wrong?
Name: fintan

comment: This is a great interview. That is  it is a great interview that ought to be a case study in business school on how not to manage a company. First  there's the problem that the new CEO was on the Board of Boeing for 10 years......apparently he was asleep at the switch  as was the rest of the Board. And apparently they want to perpetuate their slumber parties by electing to CEO one of their fellow slumberers. This is not a good omen for the flying public. Second  his first port of call upon being appointed CEO was to visit with Donald Trump. Oh my God! This is a classic. This alone (forget the 1st problem of incumbency on the Board) tells you this guy is not going to be the solution to Boeing's problems. Trump is lately spending his time trying to suppress corona virus testing so that he can claim its not a problem  rather than empowering those at the CDC (an agency whose budget he cut) to develop comprehensive solutions  such as vaccines  treatments and approaches to intelligently contain the situation.......enough!  Third problem...the CEO is talking about flying the 737 Max again. Give me a break! How stupid does he think the public is?  That plane will never fly again......because passengers won't pay to get on it. It doesn't matter that Boeing didn't bite the bullet early on and discontinue production. They instead kept producing it and renting more space to park these planes  and now they have a huge number of planes parked that they will never be able to sell. Great!
Name: bern

comment: A total phony like almost all millionaire CEO's.  I can only imagine what his severance pay will be.
Name: akamai

comment: I find the resume of the article very misleading. Mr. Calhoun doesn’t really sound candid or honest  especially about the 2 crashes and the question he dodged regarding American pilots. I don’t know how he will  win back the confidence of the airlines with this kind of attitude. He was the part of the board that backed former CEO’s decisions but he doesn’t take any responsibility. Or simply  he was incapable of seeing any of the issues the company had. To me  he doesn’t seem like a good fit to totally turn around the company and sounds more like an interim CEO with a good compensation plan in case it goes well. I can imagine he also negotiated a good exit package in case it goes sour.
Name: aj

comment:
He’s just another guy on another board who’s happy as long as:
-the stock price is up 
-his Director checks keep coming 
-they keep serving those great lunches at the board meetings.

Then  when the bottom falls out  he’s horrified by the ineptitude of the execs he oversaw. All I can see is Captain Renault in Casablanca  who’s “shocked that gambling is going on!” at Rick’s—as he’s handed his fistful of winnings.
Name: dave

comment: Boeing makes billions of dollars in sales with the 737 to low cost airlines around the world  the very airlines they know all too well may need to use more inexperienced pilots than American carriers. Thus  they should design their plane to be operated safely by the least experienced pilots  not the most. Or provide the necessary training and information for all pilots to be skilled enough to handle flight emergencies such as occurred on the 737 Max. It’s disheartening and disingenuous to hear Boeing’s new CEO continue to assign blame to others than Boeing when the realities of pilot training and experience are well known variables in flight safety.
Name: andrew

comment: This all goes back to 1997 when Boeing acquired McDonnell Douglas.  Boeing was engineered based   Douglas was bean-counter based.  Somehow the bean-counters took over the company and instead of ground breaking engineering which Boeing was noted for we got a cut-throat culture  devoted to keeping costs down and favoring upgrading older models at the expense of wholesale innovation.
Name: bofus

comment:
Recently  there was an article in the Seattle Times wondering whether Boeing board of directors could save the company. One of the most disturbing facts disclosed is the fact that NONE of the board is a technician or engineer. Imagine if you owned a company that makes airplanes and none of the top people are engineers. It boggles the mind. (also the board members are paid  on average about $350K per year...).

It's like the leadership in government today. The blind leading the blind  and Americans are fine with this. It seems the only thing important today is coddling the wealthy and the corporations so they are "comfortable" while everyone else is forced to be more productive and justify their existence. 

Are there no true leaders? Is it all only about money?
Name: mrfreeze

comment: He’s obviously failed as a director. Why should anyone think he’d be a good CEO?
Name: sgt

comment:
In my role as a development pilot for an Australian domestic airline in 1980  I worked closely with Boeing engineering personnel in the airline’s specification of the B737-200 Advanced and 3 years later the B737-300 EFIS (Electronic Flight Instruments). 
At that time it was obvious that Boeing was an aircraft engineering company run by engineers  who truly understood their priorities in building safe and efficient aircraft. 
The “rot” set in with the McDonnell Douglas merger and the relocation of the HQ to Chicago. 
Then Boeing became a “finance” company that just happened to be in the aircraft manufacturing business. 
The change of focus to share price as the key performance indicator versus safe and reliable aircraft surely resulted in many corners been cut to reduce production costs  resulting in the MAX debacle. 
I cannot understand how the Boeing safety personnel “signed off” on the MCAS flight control system with a single point of failure  while making the much safer dual system with a comparator warning light a pay for customer option. 
In my opinion  Boeing should return the HQ to Seattle  so that all employees  no matter what their role  are closer to the “coal face” and that they understand Boeing is  first and foremost  an aircraft manufacturing company.
Name: ted

comment: I used to live in Washington and I remember back when Boeing moved its headquarters out of Seattle and changed its emphasis to profits instead of safety. Many of the union members predicted something awful would happen - and they were right!
Name: walter

comment: Go back and read the comments to the recent NYT obituary for Jack Welch. Many  including me  know that Mr. Calhoun a “Jack Welch protégé” and the scores of “Jack Welch disciples” running so many companies and sitting in plumb board seats are actively destroying good companies. Please explain how a previous Boeing board member is going to change the culture? We ALL know the formula: sole focus on institutional investors’ shareholder value which means tomorrow’s stock price and next quarter’s numbers. Will Mr. Calhoun suddenly value the voice of experienced employees and recognize the many stakeholders tied to Boeing’s survival? I doubt it. Image clean up and deep systemic repair of the really messed up culture that led to people dying is going to time  totally different leadership and a different board structure. I fear the damage Milton Friedman and Jack Welch disciples have done to so many companies like Boeing is irreparable.
Name: kw

comment:
"In the meantime  Mr. Calhoun is focused on the basics: producing jets at a pace the factory can handle  instilling discipline up and down the company  and hunting for bad news and acting on it."...Really?

Mr. Calhoun:  how about focusing on the basic idea of making planes that are safe?
Name: chip

comment: Never in this article did the new Boeing chief utter the word “safety.” Isn’t that what customers  passengers  employees and the President want to hear? Isn’t safety the most important word at Boeing right now? The article spoke about stock price  never mentioned safety  and he blamed the pilots for the crashes. There is an arrogance at that company that allowed this to happen and it is still there.
Name: scottc

comment: Calhoun is either lying or he was an incompetent director when he claims not to have known of longstanding and pervasive problems in Boeing's safety processes and culture. Way back in 2015  the FAA was so concerned about a variety of quality shortcomings that Boeing and the FAA signed an unprecedented five-year settlement under which Boeing paid a $12 million penalty  and agreed to make significant changes in its internal safety systems. Are we to believe Calhoun was unaware of that? Clearly as a board member he knew about it  but failed to follow up to see if progress was made...no doubt happy to pocket his stock price increases. Boeing has a long (and continuing to this day  including on the MAX) history of "FOD" (Foreign Object Debris) issues on new planes  so severe that the Air Force suspended deliveries of the tanker. While focus has been on the MCAS system  other problems have been found continually on the MAX during the grounding  raising significant concerns about why an unairworthy plane was put in the air and whether Boeing lied to the FAA. Meanwhile  the USAF tanker is $3B over budget  three years behind schedule  and still has technical challenges. NASA's Starliner development was stopped last year due to problems. Was Calhoun unaware of all of this  too? Did he wear earplugs and a blindfold to board meetings?
Name: in

comment:
A departing CEO gives a new CEO three letters on his first day. "Open these in order each time the company is having a major crisis " he advises the newcomer. 
First crisis  he opens the letter: "Blame the old CEO"
Second crisis  the second letter: "Take the blame yourself"
Third crisis  the letter simply says: "Write three letters"
Name: j_dilbs

comment: Boeing has not yet apologised to the world for blaming the first crash on the pilot.  It has tried to legally silence the speakers of truth.  Boeing business comes above public safety.  Let the public remain aware of Boeing's pro-money pro-Boeing culture.
Name: pk

comment:
Two things.
First  the airlines were told that no training was required for existing 737 pilots. Most of the airlines did not even know that the planes had the MCAS system on board or whether it was enabled. Don't blame the pilots.

Second  I did some consulting work at Boeing over several years and one thing was always clear. It was the engineers and shop floor folks that made gorgeous  reliable airplanes. They regularly challenged management and had quality control responsibility on the shop floor. When jobs started being sent out of Washington to save costs and those experienced folks were gone  so was the culture of excellence. Great result.
Name: pa

comment: What complete garbage. As a board member for over a decade  there are only two possible explanations regarding his involvement in the way the company was run: 1) either he was fully on board with the way Muilenberg was running the company and (in the words of another infamous CEO)  happy to dance as long as the music was playing in pursuit of a high stock price  no doubt because it helped him as well; or 2) utterly ignorant of what was actually going on in the company  in which case he is totally incompetent to take over the company and should be fired - and in fact as a member/ chairman of the board should probably also be liable for failing in his duty of oversight. And now he tries to throw the previous CEO under the bus? Don't get me wrong - I think our corporate culture is completely broken for a multitude of reasons  and Boeing is Exhibit A in this respect  but this total disavowal of any responsibility is breathtaking in its sheer audacity. It takes some chutzpah to think people are going to buy it. Unbelievable!
Name: nyer

comment: The NAB Show in April is another large conference that attracts visitors from overseas  especially Asia where many manufacturers of broadcast and production equipment are headquartered. Last year's attendance was over 90 000 for the 4-day show  plus pre-show conferences. NAB does have a coronavirus update on its home page  and for now  the show is on.
Name: hdtvpete

comment: Paradox. With the exception of Adobe and a few other cancellations  the Vegas Resorts  including off-stirps like The M  as of last night (I am here) are striving. The stocks  like most others  took the fear hit  but the earnings in the future  given the present reality  should not be too negatively effected. Casinos are at this moment crowded. There are lines to get into restaurants and shows. We are as usual  a world onto ourselves  albeit confused why the country appears to panic while the thousands on the Strip seem unafraid. Many are talking about it  they're not oblivious  but the conversations fade into gallows humor.  All still stays in Las Vegas  all but the fear of coronavirus. The City if lit and taking no real hit.
Name: anastasia

comment:
Here’s a clue: for the first time in 15 years  we are NOT planning a Spring/early Summer Vacation to Seattle. We usually go then  and in Early December  for my Birthday.  Each week long trip: flights  Hotel  Food/Drinks in nice Restaurants  admissions fees  and Shopping. Total Cost:  Five to Seven Thousand Dollars  average. It’s been twice that  when we take our Daughter and two Granddaughters.  This is a direct loss of discretionary spending  especially to their local Economy.
   I’m sorry  but I must WAIT and see how bad this will get.  And in the meantime  stock up at Home.  Now  multiply this by Millions.
Name: phyliss

comment:
My wife and I were planning to go to Oregon this summer  now we’re not so sure.  We have a wedding early summer in Canada  once again we’re uncertain about going. I keep reading that my beloved World Series of Poker may be cancelled due to the fact that many participants will be barred entry into the US depending on their port of origin. 
I can say with surety that this contagion has created a world of uncertainty.
Name: bill

comment:
Tourism is an obvious casualty to disease. Las Vegas might as well run up the Yellow Jack. I would strenuously object to any employer who suggested I attend a large conference this year. There might be a vaccine in time for next year's conference. We can reopen the conversation then. For the moment though  forget about it. There's nothing at a trade show that can't wait a year.

I feel the same way about most leisure travel too. Vacation plans are extremely anemic right now. How do you feel about hammocks in the backyard? Pandemic is a great opportunity to finally finish reading Ulysses. We have the Odyssey too in case you're interested. That's about the extent of it. Maybe some mild gardening. I'm sure there's some plant you've neglected for far too long.

Avoid unnecessary travel. I'm sorry. That stinks. I hope you bought travel insurance. Hotels will just have to eat the cost of low occupancy. Grasshopper and the ant. Who was saving during times of plenty? You should maybe spend those dollars lobbying health organizations to get that vaccine out in a hurry. Like 3 months ago.
Name: andy

comment:
No mentioned here was this Major Election year. Hello? Large group rallies  whistle stop tours  huge party convention a few months away featuring delegates from every state by design. 

Not to mention huge long voter lines (thanks red States for closing down a combined 1000's of polling places).

If you're not going to travel for work  go on vacation  attend a Film/Music festival in Austin  take a cruise  go to Vegas  then will you do all of that to attend a rally or party convention and even fear voting at a busy polling place? 

Might want to look into voting absentee now just in case.
Name: brian

comment:
The number of people being "watched" would be useful. And then there are the large number of snow birds returning from Florida  the Carolinas  etc. where outbreaks may exist (no testing so who knows).

We are all going to get this  when  where  and how badly remains the issue as does how being quarantined might impact us.
Name: poslug

comment: Now is the time to brush up on what was successfully implemented during the last massive pandemic  the Spanish Flu. The municipalities that were most successful at containing the disease and those with the lowest infection and death rates were those that got out ahead of the virus by banning large gatherings  closing schools and churches  and encouraging people to stay home. We really need to have our medical historians at the forefront here to help us to understand what the best response is to this type of situation. Let's not be doomed to repeat the past because we have forgotten it.
Name: erin

comment: Without all those planes flying  we'll have lower carbon emissions. I can live with that.
Name: tortuga

comment: And the Fed's rate cut will help this how?
Name: jend

comment: Restricting the coming and going of people to Las Vegas could turn into a real disaster. Who would pay the bill?  As a former resident  I see the place as a desert island  not overly blessed with first rate medical facilities.
Name: eric

comment:
The issue isn't so much trade shows as it is air travel. Airplanes might turn out to be incubators from those passengers that are infected  but don't know it. And then  those visitors depart from McCarren and head to the Las Vegas Convention Center and area hotels. 

Interesting though - The Consumer Electronics Show in January  one of the largest in the world  took place as the coronavirus outbreak was spreading in China  and Chinese companies make up a substantial percentage of exhibitors at the show. Yet  there weren't any reported cases after the show - at least  none that we know of. 

A lot can change in a month. Let's see how things look in Vegas in early April.
Name: hdtvpete

comment: Con-Expo is next week in Las Vegas.  It's the second largest convention behind the consumer electronics show.  It averages almost 125 000 attendees.  I am supposed to have about 50 employees attend next week.  Pretty sure we are going to cancel our attendance.  I know others plan to do the same. Better safe than sorry  have to make the right call for my people!
Name: jamie

comment: Our industry's big event  Natural Products Expo West  was postponed on Monday night  with a start date of today  March 4th.  We are a small food company  and our loss will be about $20 000.  Multiply that by the 3600 exhibitors who were all ready to go  the hotels  restaurants  car rentals  etc. that will not happen  and the business deals that will not be made at the show.  Big problem.
Name: randi

comment: All conferences  sports events and other events should be cancelled  worldwide. At this stage  encouraging people to travel anywhere is criminal stupidity.
Name: a

comment: The virus will level off and decline  then the travel  the trade shows and the conferences will go on.  But what about the cruise lines and their ships?  We've already seen how these boats can function as giant petri dishes with breakouts of other illnesses.  Now  we have the current example  with ships being quarantined  and passengers being exposed to a potentially serious illness just because they took the wrong ship at a bad time.  I'm aware that there are many varieties of cruise ships and cruises  but who would ever want to get on one of those giant cruise ships ever again?
Name: david

comment: Vegas is in trouble.  Business in Macau is down 85% due to the virus.  There is no way the Olympics should be held this year.  Delay it until next year.
Name: bruce

comment: With average attendance of approximately 15 000 the American Educational Research Association is  "examining hourly ongoing developments in the coronavirus spread and appropriate precautions within the United States and worldwide. Consultation has occurred with top city and venue officials in San Francisco and will continue in the immediate days ahead. Please know that the health and well-being of meeting attendees  meeting venue and AERA staffs  city services personnel  and the people of the great city of San Francisco are our first priority as we assess our options and how best to proceed. AERA will continue to update association members and meeting registrants as we assess the situation and learn more in the immediate days ahead. We are also working closely with the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME)  as NCME holds its annual meeting in partnership with AERA’s annual event."
Name: jordan

comment: The president and vice-president should make hotel stays at their rallies across the country to assure people of the safety of travel and overnight stays (if that is what the really believe).
Name: el

comment: This week   the international housewares convention was cancelled in Chicago. This is  annual trade show that brings close to 60 000 visitors to McCormick Place each year who's visitors rent 47 000 hotel rooms.  Obviously the ripple effect of this cancellation will be huge in all areas of Chicago's economy from Hotels to Ubers and restaurants and the Union workers who set up and take down the exhibits.  Other conventions are scheduled later in the month .  What happens if they are cancelled ? MLB's season starts in about a month.  What happens if crowds at Wrigley field that are normally 40 000+   are cut in half or more due to fear of being in crowds ?   This is the type of reduced economic activity everyone is facing.  Then there are the reduced local tax revenues which will hit Illinois and Chicago hard at a time when both governments are deep in debt.
Name: earl

comment:
Walking through the casinos and on the strip  the streets and casinos are packed with tourist.  Without the coronavirus looming  I worried about germs and diseases.  If cases break out in Las Vegas (large foreign populations live here with an international airport)  I suspect the streets will empty out.  

Nevadans are very aware that if the coronavirus is detected  things will change quickly and not for the better.  It's really not if the coronavirus is detected  it's just when.  And I agree with another poster  we have the worst medical care in Las Vegas plus a shortage of qualified doctors.  I don't know how Las Vegas could adequately or safely manage an coronavirus out break.  I doubt we could.
Name: valerie

comment: We were planning a trip to Texas next month  but decided against it due to potential exposure at airports.
Name: vicki

comment:
As insightful New York Times readers have pointed out  we need to dust of the history books and implement limits on travel as they did during the Spanish Flu Epidemic of 1918.

My goodness  that took place during the more decorous era of train travel.   Do many really want the person-to-person exposure to contagion on top of the filthy air and inhumane cramped seating of an airline cabin now?

Services will be affected.   Especially travel.   You have to think that in 2020 our big time professional and college sports will be severely affected.

What are we gonna see at the Final Four?   The pep band playing through surgical masks?   Or as we saw last week in Italian football  teams playing in an empty stadium?

You gotta wonder how many companies in the travel business are highly leveraged and run on credit?   As in 2007  2008  2009 we could see a cascade of bankruptcies.

Oh  I forgot.   That was President Obama's fault.   Well  now the ball is in Trump's court.
Name: wordsworth

comment: Airline change fees should be illegal for public health reasons. Coronavirus aside  how many people travel when they are sick because it would be prohibitively expensive to cancel or reschedule? How much disease is spread over long distances because of this?
Name: av

comment: Jazz Fest in New Orleans. 500 000 attendees last year from all over the world in a racetrack for 8 days. A city that relies on tourism. We better join Pence in prayer as that seems to be what Louisiana has come up with so far. They simply can’t afford to cancel these kind of events. The economy depends on it. Hope I’m wrong.
Name: lori

comment:
People  such as myself  who commuted every day on the IRT/7th Ave. are now leery of crowds? There are crowds in the subways  Grand Central and Penn Station and in every retail store in the City.

What bullet does one dodge by avoiding a crowd at a resort hotel?

Cable news networks drive this panic and the economy suffers because citizens who  as I once did  pack themselves into the Staten Island Ferry  cancel routine conferences and vacations.

We have become such a silly people.
Name: observer

comment: Someone should get a raise for that headline.
Name: elizabeth

comment:
Better article headline  -
"What Happens In Vegas Doesn't Stay In Vegas."
Name: c

comment:
One good virus deserves another...

Viruses and bacterium are tiny  infinitesimal  minuscule life forms. Who said my pal  God  didn't have a sense of humor when he wrote in Matthew 5.5 "Blessed are the meek  for they will inherit the earth." Maybe he was talking about viruses and bacterium  not humble  meek little humans. 

Did you read about the protein molecules found on meteors recently? Like intergalactic spermatozoa  asteroids and meteorites fertilize planets when and if they become fertile. Earth became fertile. 

Now  600 million years later  humanity   like a deadly virus  has quickly spread across its planet killing every life form in its path  for profit. I've seen this happen on hundreds of thousands of planets throughout the universe. 

Few 'planet dominating species' survive. The beast within them  600 million years of genetic competition  compels their pathway through time. 

Typically  they over-populate  destroy their habitat  each other  and disappear forever while their planet slowly starts over. 

Very few planet dominating species find their way into the Universe. Very few of those survive. Time is running out for humanity. I am saddened. I had hoped humanity would find their path to the stars. They have imagined it but fail to honor it. 

Kind Regards and Best Wishes  

The Grand Exalted Ruler of The Universe 
(Also known as: HoodooVoodooBlood)
Name: hoodoovoodooblood

comment: A true "visionary " US commerce secretary Wilbur Ross said the deadly coronavirus outbreak in China could be positive for the American economy.  During a TV interview Mr Ross said: "I think it will help to accelerate the return of jobs to North America".   I wonder if Americans understand just how incompetent each cabinet member of this administration is.
Name: son

comment: I doubt the patrons of Vegas are going to stop going. There are a lot of things you can catch in Vegas  and the corona virus is not even the scariest. Remember  these are people who know the odds are against them yet they keep on gambling. They think they will be the lucky one. Pretty sure they think they won't get the virus even if the odds are not good.
Name: chris

comment: Coronavirus could last for years. If we close schools  movie theaters or Las Vegas  when will they reopen? Thousands of Americans died on 9/11 and for a while Islamaphobia shut down public spaces. Coronavirus has killed fewer than a dozen Americans  but the same panic is setting in.
Name: rick

comment: Trump supporters are avoiding Corona Beer...just in case.
Name: hoodoovoodooblood

comment: "When everything around you is crazy  it is ingenious to stay calm."  Mehmet Murat Ildan
Name: guido

comment: He wants to know what to do with these? I'm sure his local health department or public hospital would be glad to receive a donation of these supplies.
Name: j

comment: I feel like he should have realized this could be a potential outcome of hoarding massive amounts of supplies that rural communities needed.
Name: jeremy

comment: So disappointing to see this side of human nature--and I worry that this is only the tip of the iceberg.
Name: alhmass

comment: i am not quite sure how those two can look themselves in the mirror. i have been trying unsuccessfully to find/buy hand sanitizer for the last days. no words for these kinds of people who want benefit of the misery of others.
Name: jennifer

comment: If we had a competent federal government  such stockpiles would be requisitioned (with a fair price paid to the owner)  and distributed at no cost to institutions and communities in need.
Name: daniel

comment: Donate to healthcare facilities or people who can't afford or really need them.
Name: masalasocial

comment: Price gougers hoarding health care supplies should have their inventory seized by the authorities and redistributed to hospitals  paramedics and police departments for public safety purposes.
Name: rico

comment:
It is inevitable that  in a crisis  there are people who think it's time to profit from the misery of others. These two epitomize that amoral and unethical behavior. What they did deprives those who really need these products from obtaining them. 

It would be helpful if they could donate this hoard (and  yes  it is a hoard) to a local hospital or food bank  where those who are in need can get these things. And then  if I were them  I would pray for forgiveness.
Name: ba

comment: Can't authorities impound the  staff and distribute it  where is desperately needed?eg hospitals  nursing homes first responders etc.As a national emergency has officially been declared  I believe new rules apply.Please correct me if I am wrong.
Name: faliron

comment: If he actually wants to do the right thing  he will put these out on the market at a profit percentage that is normal  and not try to gouge. But of course he appears to have made his entire living by doing nothing but gouging  so I don't think he can own up to that. This is what we get with unregulated capitalism  and it is why we need government to be involved as a counterweight to people like him.
Name: jwinder

comment: Marking up sneakers and toys is one thing. Profiting from a health crisis by price gouging on essential supplies is quite another and unconscionable. I can't even begin to imagine what kind of thought process makes these people think this is okay.
Name: gberger

comment: As he has already profited from what he was able to sell  how about donating some or all of the rest of it to organizations and individuals who could use it in this crisis.   It appears that Mr. Colvin has no concern about what he could do beyond his own self interests.  Understandable that he needs to make a living and provide for his family  but it is sad that he also seems to have no sense of how he could do some good beyond himself.
Name: chris

comment: I have nothing but contempt for this profiteer.  Nevertheless  there is a path to (partial) redemption.  If he's unwilling to donate the items  the least he could do is place the items back online at pre-crisis market prices.
Name: david

comment: No sympathy whatsoever.  Call it what he will -- "public service" my Aunt Fannie --  this is profiteering.  Even with "inefficiencies in the marketplace"  he has taken advantage of us all in difficult times.  He should do a true public service and donate all goods in question.
Name: ann

comment: I am surprised that the tone of this article is so sympathetic to the perpetrator of what really ought to be a crime. This person has certainly and directly caused the transmission of pathogens  potentially including the pandemic coronavirus that triggered his profiteering. His malfeasance has caused direct harm to the wellbeing of others  and the law should treat his behavior as such.
Name: dr

comment:
Just for reference  before the pandemic  a 3M brand N95 mask costs about $2.  Because of my severe allergies to pollens  I usually have a few of these lying around.  

It's disheartening to hear stories of hoarding  but I can understand them.  Buy low  sell high is a religion in America.  When traditional religions disintegrate  other religions move in to take their places:  Greed  hedonism  predatory capitalism  addictions of all kinds  pretensions to godhood (Trump).   

There are far more saintly beings in the world than I  but when a man wearing a "Family Man" t-shirt begins price gouging during a medical pandemic  something has gone deeply wrong with our culture's notion of family values.
Name: kip

comment: Profiting off an emergency is definitely not a public service. As he's clearly already made back his upfront costs  it seems that the moral way to proceed is to donate the remaining products to neighbors and organizations who need them to survive. Keeping them in a storage locker helps no one.
Name: tiffany

comment: Meanwhile those of us on the frontlines are going into work in hospitals without enough hand sanitizer. My inpatient psychiatric unit does not have N95 masks available. He should immediately donate all supplies to his local health department. I’m sure he can figure out how to write off his losses.
Name: c

comment:
I fear we are going to see ever more examples of selfishness and lack of empathy as this goes on.  It’s sad  but seems to a part of human nature.  

His entire stash should be seized by health officials.  Any “takings” claim he raises can crawl through the courts as he challenges it.
Name: drew

comment: This is the much vaunted “law” of supply and demand at work—the greater the need the higher the price. I would hope he’d be ashamed of himself but I doubt he has that capacity.
Name: john

comment: A Gordon Gekko for the 21st century. Spare me the picture of his wife and child  and the violins playing to show that this is the way he provides for his family. The Colvin brothers are taking advantage of a health crisis which can be a life or death matter for many of his fellow human beings. Making a fair profit is one thing  but to price gouge at the expense  not to mention the health  of others is unconscionable.
Name: literary

comment:
Really hoping these two contract the virus themselves. What they are doing is just sick. 

Under emergency measures  government should enact criminal penalties for price gouging. And stores should be required to limit sales of certain items per person.
Name: debra

comment: Where is my world's tiniest violin? If he'd asked himself at the outset  "will my behavior likely hurt other people's wellbeing?"  he would have turned his car around before he embarked on the silk road of pandemic profiteering. Guess he needs (and now will have time) to watch It's A Wonderful Life and realize that it was George Bailey and his endless store of decency and humanity  not Mr. Potter and his stockpile of wealth  who was the richest man in town.
Name: dsl

comment: Toys or boxes of sugar puffs fine  but medical supplies that can save lives shame on those guys!
Name: pamela

comment:
I suspect that Mr. Colvin and his brother is beginning to sorely regret allowing himself to be featured on the front page of the NYT  with his photograph and general location known. 

Also note the predictable ways people will manufacture justifications to soothe their own consciences. 

Upon reflection  I hope he sees that he crossed a line. There is a difference between snapping up vintage Cabbage Patch dolls or fidget spinners for re-sale and basic health and safety supplies.
Name: jim

comment: There are people who leave things better than they found them (relationships  physical objects  the planet  communities  etc.)  and there are people who leave a path of damage behind them. These guys know in their hearts which group they are in.
Name: maria

comment: A public servant indeed  same rationale used by predatory lenders.
Name: jos

comment:
They cleaned out local stores of vital supplies so no one else could buy them and now they can't sell them on the black market?

I'm sorry  but the sympathy meter reading for Mr. Colvin and his price gouging brother is pegging "zero."
Name: pablo

comment: A hospital in Seattle has reported they are down to a 4 day supply of gloves.   These people hoarding badly needed equipment should face a legal reckoning.
Name: linda

comment: I'm not sure that Matt and Noah Colvin can recover any sense of character or self respect after this tragic lapse in moral judgement.  They can donate what they have amassed  but this will follow their lack of care and concern for others for a long  long time.
Name: sue

comment:
Who’s first thought  upon hearing of a possible pandemic  is to attempt to corner the market on possibly life saving products to make a profit? Don’t know what to do with them? Put them on Amazon or wherever for a modest markup and make a modest profit with a 2 item limit. Or sell at cost or donate and save your sorry conscience. Jeez. 

I’m a carpenter and when I went to my supplier to buy a box of dust masks  they were predictably out. I mentioned panic buying and they said it’s not that. They took the hundreds they had  which were sold by box of 20  off the shelf and were giving them individually to regular customers who they knew and who needed them for work. The rest they donated to the local hospital who was running out due to panic buying. I declined mine when offered and decided to take the one I had been using out of the trash and clean it. Those were our reactions to this whole mess.
Name: matthew

comment:
Very disappointing  if not immoral behaviour.  Price-gouging laws by state cover merchants. Do this mean that it won't apply to an individual (not established merchant) selling via Amazon or E-bay?  It should affect  and I hope it does.  

He should give these away to people in need.  Now  that action  not the "substantial profits"  would be a better legacy for his young family.
Name: gary

comment:
Wiping  the shelves  depriving people to purchase and then gouging those same people is really deplorable - I am gob smacked that Mr Colvin doesn’t see nor care how his actions have effected the communities around him.  

Give it all away to public health centers and do it today.
Name: deirdre

comment: This should be criminal.  Hoarding medical supplies during a national emergency is unethical and unconscionable.  The absence of medical supplies from store shelves will inevitably lead to higher transmission and death rates.  There are people who are part of the solution and those who are part of the problem.  Medical supply hoarders are the latter and should be treated as such.
Name: richard

comment: Colvin says he is fixing inefficiencies in the marketplace? There were supplies distributed over a several hundred mile radius in what the market had previously determined was the right concentration and he drove around and bought everything  concentrating all that inventory into a single point. He's CREATING inefficiencies and then insisting on being paid a premium to fix them. How is this guy not like a fire fighter who is also an arsonist?
Name: dcw

comment:
Make no mistake  there are elderly / immunocompromised people who need every last chance they can get against this disease  and the hoarders are taking opportunities for survival away from them.

Every time the vulnerable can’t disinfect  every time they have to out again to another store  and another in search of supplies already bought by the greedy  our parents  grandparents  neighbors  and friends face an increased  and wholly unnecessary risk of death because somebody wanted to make a buck.
Name: bill

comment: I believe there are established laws against war profiteering.  Perhaps we should create similar laws for this situation.
Name: kevin

comment: Pay him a nominal finders fee. Thank him for his efforts. And seize the stuff. Case closed.
Name: calis

comment: I hope he learns greed is harmful. I hope he understands people who are healthcare workers  on the front lines and exposed to this as well as other pathogens found empty shelves because of his greed.
Name: suebsue

comment: Zero sympathy for these people. They can easily donate these  but they don’t. The opposite of good people  I hope they lose their shirts and their savings...
Name: adam

comment:
I wonder if these people have stopped to reflect on the fact that they are hoarding products that may mean the difference between life and death for others.  

I come from business and am a capitalist.  Hoarding things like dolls and designer shoes is one thing...hoarding necessities needed for a pandemic is another.
Name: john

comment: I have no sympathy for this guy at all.    Amazon should take the next step  or our government should take the next step  and make him sell it at the normal price.
Name: physician

comment:
There's a big difference between cashing in on a hot Christmas toy  and profiting from a medical crisis where people's lives are in jeopardy. How could these people seek to profit off these items?  

Putting his family "in a good place financially" at the cost of others' health and peace of mind is the worst form of capitalistic advantage-taking.

Donate the items and take the loss.
Name: lene

comment:
On the one hand  what Mr. Colvin and other like him do is completely reprehensible and I truly hope that he is stuck with his supplies.

On the other hand  McKesson  AmerisourceBergen and Cardinal Health -- three fortune 15 companies -- literally make their money through what is effectively the same practice.  These pharmaceutical wholesale companies buy drugs at price X  and bet that inflation by drug manufacturers will make drugs more expensive over time.  When that happens  instead of making normal small wholesaler margins  they make exponentially more  effectively profiting from gouging by drug manufacturers.  So  we reward these companies for profiting from what effectively is the same practice  which is no less reprehensible.
Name: jb

comment: Do I feel sorry for Matt and his failed profiteering scheme? Not at all. I hope he borrowed money to buy all that stuff he's stuck with. The only problem is  he won't be stuck with it. In the end  he will sell it for a large profile when what should happen is him going to jail for a long time.
Name: mike

comment:
As a physician in Seattle  this is contemptible behavior. Working in the hospital these days feels like preparing for battle. Our resources are low  and we are desperately in need of supplies like N95 masks. They have been stolen from the hospitals and warehouses  and it is hard for us to get more because the supplies simply don’t exist. Our system is being overrun  and it’s only going to get worse.

An N95 is not necessary for the majority of the public while walking down the street or going to the grocery store. It is absolutely essential for the nurses and respiratory therapists who are managing the ventilators of COVID positive patients. We are running out of hand sanitizer and my knuckles are literally bleeding from washing my hands fifty times a day. 

I have no sympathy for these sellers. Making money off a public health crisis and diverting critical resources from where they are truly needed is selfish and dangerous.
Name: cp

comment: Mind boggling. Beyond. And he wants us to feel sorry for him? I do not think so. He and people like him are beyond redemption unless they load everything up  drive to areas where there are outbreaks  and give it all away.
Name: peggy

comment: Capitalism in its essence. This is the problem with championing an economic system that sees the world as objects to be exploited.
Name: tim

comment:
Sounds like the bans are working.  17 000 bottles sounds like a lot.  But if stranding some product is the price we have to pay to stop gouging  it's worth it.   

Let him donate his inventory to the Red Cross and get a tax write off.
Name: nobody

comment: Amazon and Ebay should ban these people. Period. This is wrong on so many levels. There's a difference between trying to make money on the next hot sneaker or toy  and hoarding needed medical supplies and related items that can stop an epidemic and literally save lives. This is just plain evil greed. I hope they get banned and have to actually work for a living -with people they are not related to. Maybe they will grow a conscience and a heart.
Name: pg

comment:
Situations like this bring the best and the worst in people.

Emergency powers should include measures to confiscate such stockpiles and distribute them at retail store prices.

Retailers should introduce limits per person for supply purchases.
Name: zumzar

comment: Hoarding medical supplies to make a profit during a pandemic is unconscionable. There simply is no justification for it.
Name: jessica

comment: I sincerely hope they are prosecuted to the full extent of the law - and in multiple jurisdictions
Name: somethingtosay

comment: His claim that he’s different from “Billy Bob’s gas station doubling the amount he charges for gas during a hurricane” is ridiculous. The “labor” he invested was adds no value to the end product  the only person who gains from that labor is himself. I hope this man and his family do not become sick  but I wonder how they’d feel to be charged 20-50x the price of their medical care  due to the excessive labor required by healthcare workers?
Name: elizabeth

comment: This guy is a monster. If this were beanie babies in the 90s I'd be impressed with him  but we're in a pandemic. He admitted to selling hand sanitizer for 70$ a bottle. That's not selling for a profit  that's price gouging when people's lives are at risk. The doctors fighting for our lives won't have this equipment because he wants to make fast cash. I wonder how he'd feel if his wife was hospitalized for the coronavirus at a hospital that didn't have these supplies.
Name: jane

comment: I'm blown away by the stunning aware lack of self-awareness in the statement  "I’m not looking to be in a situation where I make the front page of the news for being that guy who hoarded 20 000 bottles of sanitizer that I’m selling for 20 times what they cost me."
Name: michael

comment:
"...he said people forget that his price includes his labor  Amazon’s fees and about $10 in shipping."

Guess what?  If you had left the sanitizer on the shelves in the neighborhood stores where you found it  you wouldn't have had to pay any fees and people wouldn't have to pay your predatory prices.  This is greed  pure and simple.
Name: fph

comment: He is the problem. There wouldn’t be much of a shortage if people only bought what they needed.  I am glad Amazon shut down price gouging. He can sell his supplies for a reasonable price. Or take them to the local hospital or homeless shelter.  Do not feel sorry for this guy. It makes me angry.
Name: bonnie

comment: Does he not realize that that $2 bottle of hand sanitizer that he’s now selling for more to account for “labor” would have also cost someone else $2 if he hadn’t cleared out the shelves????? His “labor” means people like me - my town is sold out - can’t buy it. I can’t pay $50 for a bottle online. Such a complete disconnect and utterly selfish behavior. No sympathy for these people at all. The only way they could redeem themselves is to sell at cost or better yet  donate.
Name: n

comment: The most disturbing thing about this?  Matt Colvin thinks it's just fine.  Really?!  Was he influenced by Martin Shkreli who jacked up the price of insulin.  I'm at a loss to understand how during a global pandemic  a time of great need to be a part of a caring community  this greedy  non-thinking "human" plans to make a huge profit off of other people who are trying to protect themselves and others by not spreading Corvid-19.  It's not ok.  Now do something generous and sell them for the regular price  donate them to community centers.  Act like a human being.
Name: marsha

comment: I can only hope that if the brothers Colvin and their families get sick  that their doctors will similarly charge them a lot more so that they too can show what it is to take advantage of the situation.  I wonder if they would feel that was the doctors just trying to make some "crazy money" too.
Name: steve

comment:
there is nothing evil about making a profit and becoming wealthy  but there is a lot of evil about amassing your wealth at the expense of others  the people who help sustain your wealth. you will hurt yourself and others. if not now  then later. it is not sustainable.

in a world where you can be anything  be kind.
Name: dchow

comment: They should donate this stock to nursing homes  shut in seniors and medically compromised individuals. Profiteering in the time of a pandemic is not only morally reprehensible but should be a felony.
Name: sr

comment: This photo will become iconic  as he stands looking perplexed in front of vast quantities of potential life saving products. It's a flaw in our system that allowed him to get here and allowed him to profit in any way from this. His only way out is to sell at cost or give them away to his community. He seems aware that hoarding isn't the answer  too bad that awareness didn't kick in as he was buying out stocks in far greater quantities than he needed to with no regard for the needs of his community. Same could be said about everyone buying multiple mega packs of toilet paper at Costco.
Name: jessie

comment:
One of the sellers didn’t consider he was price gouging because of his efforts to collect and sell the merchandise - this statement makes it seem like he is doing everyone a favor.  Wow! Without people like him hoarding necessary supplies we would all use to protect ourselves  maybe we could actually purchase these items. I think that a solution would be to allow them
to sell the items for what it would cost us at the market. They could also donate the supplies for or authorities could confiscate them.  To be sitting on them and not know what to do? Get them to people who need them!
Name: hannah

comment: Even medical offices can't obtain hand sanitizer for waiting room patients as the medical supply houses are all out of their supply.  What these folks did is morally reprehensible.  People's lives are at stake  and keeping your hands clean is the first line of defense against the coronavirus.  So  they are stockpiling and selling for a huge profit.  I don't know how they live with themselves and sleep at night.
Name: lisa

comment: As a teacher IN Chattanooga  I’m  VERY frustrated to know this was why I couldn’t find hand sanitizer for my students to use prior to the schools closing. Hand sanitizer that I would be paying for my students to use—not to make a profit on. My suggestion—drop off your supply at area schools that will be feeding students during this time off. Give back to your community.
Name: teacher

comment:
Hoarding supplies that are needed to protect our health care providers will lead to exposure and death for some.  In a certain light  this is second-degree murder.  
The state government should immediately requisition these supplies for use where needed.  Reimbursement might be considered  at cost  after the crisis is over.
Name: tom

comment: The owner of my local supermarket - an absolute ZOO for the last 2 days  was telling me a guy purchased $500 worth of canned  tuna.  So he informed him  if your try and return any of these  there will be a 65% RESTOCKING fee.
Name: charles

comment: Please donate these products to nursing homes and homeless shelters. They are the most vulnerable. Profiting from a pandemic is not capitalism. It is selfish.  Do better.
Name: jose

comment: They deserve it for trying to price gouge people and causing other people not to be able to buy hand sanitizer because they went around cleaning out the stores to try to profit from this unfortunate situation. Why should we have any sympathy for them?
Name: eric

comment: Their stocks should be seized without compensation and redistributed to medical facilities and stores (and make sure the latter don’t gouge too).
Name: roger

comment: No he is NOT performing a public service by correcting inefficiencies. He is CREATING inefficiencies because people who could have bought products from their local stores now need to order online and pay hazardous shipping fees plus cuts for him and Amazon.
Name: ann

comment: I'm supposed to feel sorry for these price gougers? They should sell this stuff for what they paid for it  or better yet  donate it to hospitals or nursing homes.
Name: bkb

comment:
I am a physician.  In our private office we see patients with fever and cough daily.  We cannot get the N95 makes that are recommended for us (but NOT for the general public).  We are also running low on regular surgical masks and hand sanitizer.  We are trying to do our job — a particularly vital job at this time — but our inability to get the proper protective gear is putting us  and consequently our patients — at risk.

Mr. Colvin’s selfish actions could truly be killing people.
Name: david

comment: I hope he sold some of his items in FL where the penalty is $1000 per violation with a maximum fine of $25 000 per day.
Name: kelly

comment: A six-figure salary by doing this job? Well  then  he and his family are set for the next few months. May they use all of their supplies in good health. However  my concern is for all of the people living paycheck to paycheck who were just told not to come to work  who have no paid time off  who have no sick time  and who can’t even buy a bottle of hand sanitizer to protect themselves while they work their minimum wage jobs. Enterprising? Perhaps he is by some people’s definition  but he’s just selfish and opportunistic and greedy.
Name: patti

comment: This article was supremely disturbing. I'm particularly upset because i just spoke yesterday with a cousin who is the primary caregiver for my 87 year old uncle. He has pulmonary vulnerabilities so hand sanitizer  wipes and face masks are essential part of his home healthcare. Because of hoarders like those described in the article  she can no longer order in bulk from medical supply companies because she's not a hospital or nursing home. I wish Americans cared more about each other than about making money.
Name: sojtruth

comment: Market inefficiencies? The market works just fine without him meddling in it. Smaller towns and communities  get less frequent shipments of hard goods  where’s larger cities are restocking certain products daily. So cleaning out stock in a small community and selling it online is actually disrupting the supply chain of these smaller communities. The big stores are well aware of what is being bought at every one of their stores in the country. They know where stocks of products need to go  because they run a billion dollar supply chain. They don’t need some profiteer mucking it up. He should get a real job.
Name: jeremy

comment:
Here's a take. 

"Mr. Colvin we don't know what you were thinking(!) but we're the state and we'll buy all your stock at market rate plus $1000. Take it off your hands so you can pull your Chevy back in your garage again. 

We'll distribute all of it to a wide group of people at normal store market rate. 

For agreeing to this arrangement we won't take any legal action against you and we'll chalk it up to a lesson learned. 

Thanks."
Name: paul

comment:
“Current price-gouging laws “are not built for today’s day and age ” Mr. Colvin said. “They’re built for Billy Bob’s gas station doubling the amount he charges for gas during a hurricane.”

Mr. Colvin is 100 times worse than “Billy Bob”.  Billy Bob raised the price for gas he had on hand; Mr. Colvin put forth great effort to deprive a whole community of a needed product so he could profit from the fear and need.  Truly  he should be prosecuted.
Name: cal

comment: Martin Shkreli was convicted for price gouging a life saving drug and was sent away for 7 years. How is this different?
Name: jb

comment: Couldn't have happened to a nicer guy. Love the T shirt and shot of the young family trying to get ahead in these tough times.  Sad that he can't tell the difference between making money off of useless fads and profiteering and extorting money out of other humans in crisis. Hope this is illegal in the states where he did it and that he does time.
Name: sophia

comment: I sure hope the IRS takes a nice  CLOSE look at this guy's tax returns for the last 7 years. The town where he lives should double check that he is paying all the proper BUSINESS Taxes he should be paying and has all the proper Business Licenses he is required to have? Maybe they should also check the local zoning laws to see if he is permitted to run a business out of his home? I wonder if his home insurance company is aware he is using his home for a business and is storing inventory the way he is? Then the local codes enforcement officer should have a look at his property. Is his storage of all these products up to code? Maybe the local fire marshall should stop by his house for an inspection of his business. Is the manner he is storing these products compliant with the local fire codes? Does he have smoke detectors  sprinkler systems  fire extinguishers  etc to deal with a fire? All that cardboard and plastic would be a real nightmare in the event of a fire. So many questions.....
Name: gbof

comment: Nice picture of one of the Colvin brothers with his wife and baby - how about other young parents who need the products he and his brother are hoarding? The rationale for what they're doing is narcissistic and greedy. They should be given the option of either donating their products to hospitals and nursing homes or being prosecuted for their criminal acts during a global pandemic.
Name: greg

comment: Pure and simple greed. A crisis like this can bring out the best in people and the worst in others. I have seen social media posts in my area where people are offering to shop for those who can't and should not go out in public.  And then you have the hoarders and those such as this guy who see a crisis as an opportunity.
Name: kate

comment:
I am a generally a free-market capitalist. But government’s role in a free market is to adjust incentives. Such pernicious exploitation should be punished.  
This amoral man’s stockpile should be confiscated - to help adjust incentives.
Name: adam

comment:
I hope the authorities take all of it off his hands and gives him some time in prison to reflect on what his actions have caused. 

What a perfect example of how greed and selfishness have flourished in this country over the past few decades as wealth and privilege have been accumulated by a few at the expense of everyone else  leading to everyone trying to "get theirs". It may not have a "hashtag" because it predates Twitter and social media  but #Where's Mine? could easily be the meme of the greed movement.
Name: kingfish

comment: An additional problem  they purchased product from remote areas. So  those persons who are less able to travel can not simply walk to their local store. As always  the less fortunate without a car or limited means are the ones doing without. Yes  he should donate today the products that he has and make a difference.
Name: eamon

comment: I was in Walgreen's yesterday. The shelves were bare. I heard one elderly gentleman ask one of the workers if she had hand sanitizer  disinfectant wipes or thermometers. No to all of the above.  Just heart breaking.
Name: chana

comment: I find it dubious that he has an accurate assessment of what towns don’t “need” these supplies.  He is profiteering  and if there are many others like him  he is contributing to the shortage.  The article stated that he didn’t start off hitting rural areas  he swallowed up the local community supply than branched out.  I find it amoral  and it is interesting how he rationalizes it to himself.  A good policy might be for stores to stop allowing these bulk buys from one customer.
Name: patrick

comment: He should donate it all.  It would be a win for the recipients and he could take a tax write-off since he seems so concerned about money.
Name: kathrine

comment: Why won’t he sell his items at a fair price to hospitals  etc. instead of gouging? Would that be a problem? He can at least recoup his output and help others. That seems like a win-win to me.
Name: momo
