There should have been no need to any "agreement" to exist with Google or Amazon (or Spotify  or Pandora  or iTunes) -- both should have worked easily  just as any audio source should have worked easily  the way it did with the early versions of Sonos. Instead  Sonos got bit by their own greed  and now want to triple-dip by suing the companies who helped keep them from disappearing into obscurity.

The world will be a better place when Sonos just disappears. What used to set them apart from everyone else -- easy music listening throughout the home -- is now commonplace. And both Google and Amazon (and Bose  and Samsung  and Apple) are doing it far better than Sonos has done since their first-generation system.
Name: michaelinvegas

comment:
I have Sonos too in my holiday home and can compare with our higher end Naim streamers at home. It is true that Sonos provided a very user friendly product that had little competition 5 years ago  when speakers could easily sync.
No more. They are all good at that now. The higher end product (Naim  Devialet  etc) are so good and elite that they will have a market as long as they maintain quality and excellent audio. The mid range such as Bose and very effective too. Meanwhile I am seriously mad at Sonos for removing the ability to stream directly from my iPhone content (such as podcast). The head of product development should have been fired a long time ago.
Name: r

comment: Yet another reason to avoid gmail. Each day brings several reasons not to trust google or amazon. They skim as much data from emails and transactions as possible  using us as engines for their unprecedented wealth.
Name: de

comment:
The patent system is so broken that a speaker that does like 1 new thing needs 100 different patents. That creates an environment where neither Google nor Sonos have any idea who might prevail in a dispute. Even worse  it makes it nigh impossible for a judge to determine what looks like a just outcome. Google also has 1000s of random patents on nonsense. So Google can bring up that. 

Such a system incentivizes the powerful interests with money to pay lawyers to just ignore the other guys patents while filing many of their own bogus patents. Small players  with no chance of even READING all the patents in a space  are forced to just invent and pray that they aren't squashed by frivolous lawsuits.

The only winners with a patent system this broken are the lawyers.
Name: tyson

comment:
If there is justice  Sonos comes out ahead in this suit.

If there is real justice  these companies start getting hammered by the government for trying to dominate everything in all ways.
Name: walt

comment:
Read a story years ago about a busy florist who relied on FedEx for years  his key business partner. Then FedEx added floral to their raft of 'adjacent' services and marketed to his clients  undercutting his price. There should be a law against this. 

Most countries legal system has a 'loser pays all attorney's fees' provision. We need this also  but the law association lobby won't allow it.
Name: tom

comment: Sonos is coming across as a terrible company lately. Earlier this week I learned they brick perfectly good speakers to prevent them being reused  and now they’re coming out with this patent troll crud instead of making like Google and innovating. These guys should pay some engineers  delay short-term profits  and do the actual work needed for surviving in a market economy.
Name: jon

comment: Gotta give it to Sonos for throwing a Hail Mary pass as their company gets squeezed by larger competitors. The thing is  even if Google did steal their technology  the worst they will face is a few billion dollars in fines  which is a drop in the bucket to them. But I suppose that payout is enough to keep a company that would otherwise fail in business for a few more years.
Name: cp

comment:
I have been a Sonos fan since they first introduced their speaker and technology.
I have a few play-3s  a sonos soundbar and sub.
Someone bought me a Google home speaker and I have never turned it on.
I don't trust it  call me a luddite.
Name: confounded

comment: Google and Amazon are "for profit" companies.  They will undermine  undercut and rip off anyone who stands in their way.  Both companies are monopolies and needs to be broken up.  Europe is working hard taking Google to task  but here in the US  Google owns too  many of our government employees. The first thing we need to do in America is to stop lobbyist from buying our politicians for fortune 500 companies.
Name: valerie

comment:
Like many users here  I have Sonos  I used to love it  but now not so much.

Quality has quickly deteriorated (speakers go on and off during playback)  the company has grown so big now that it's hard to get support. I hate (with all I got) that now they bundle virtual assistants into their products. I will never succumb to listening devices at home. They are getting greedy and now want to make older products obsolete.

When I read this article  I was originally rooting for Sonos. Now that I think of it  if they don't put the consumer back on top of their priorities  bye bye to them.
Name: frank

comment:
Sonos says that it was "naive" to invite Google into its tech house.

I say that it is more than naive to invite any Google or Amazon sound/microphone modules into anyone's house.
Name: tim

comment:
Around the turn of the last century a few mega-companies in oil and railroads misused their dominant market positions and were rewarded with anti-trust actions.

Similarly sharp practices by the tech behemoths in this century will hopefully elicit a similar response in the near future.
Name: peter

comment:
Sounds like Sonos gave away their technology when they “shared it” with Amazon and Google.

Yet when it comes to true sound I’ll take my Denon stereo hard wired with Polk Audio speakers over anything offered by Sonos. My cable box and Blu-Ray player are connected via optical cable and give true theatre sound that can never be achieved via wireless speakers.
Name: rufus

comment: I've been a Sonos customer for many years now  and I've converted lots of friends and family too.  I have to say  I still love all my Sonos equipment - it all still works great  even the really old ones.  I look forward to expanding my system soon - using their outdoor speakers I can colonize the deck with music!  There've been a few hiccups over the years with updates and so on  but never a privacy issue  such as I'd fear with Google and Amazon  and never a serious or unfixable problem with the system itself.  Good on Sonos for fighting back !
Name: bar

comment: The other day I set up two Amazon Echos for my parents. Yikes. What a pain.  I´ll take my Sonos setup any day. I love my Sonos speakers.
Name: debra

comment: Love my Sonos like lots of people here. But because of history of music and audio  I think Apple Inc should buy Sonos  and still let Sonos run as an independent company.
Name: andy

comment:
The courts should force google to ensure that their speakers work without being connected to a google account  and make sure they charge the cost. 

Case in point  I just got delivery of a free google speaker with free shipping because I’m a ‘loyal customer’ of two months for one of their other services. Hard for me to see how they would make money on this except by stealing my data.
Name: gizmos

comment: Sonos is like a Mercedes  BMW. Google Home is like a Hyundai. This is in terms of sound quality. If you want an AM Radio in the shower  go with Amzon or Google. If you want a listening experience  go for Sonos or Bose. End of story  turn out the lights  buh bye.
Name: dirk

comment: So much for don't be evil.
Name: pdxdoug

comment:
Google 15 years ago  "don't be evil."

Google today  "what? Black cloaks are comfortable and slimming  now join us and we shall rule the Galaxy as Emperor and useful-data-point."
Name: anon

comment: Google is evil. And so are the other other over-sized  rolling-in-money  super-powerful organizations. They are not here to serve us. They are here to "serve us" cooked.
Name: mohan

comment: Contrary to the gist of this article  the technology to allow speakers to coordinate wirelessly is trivial in complexity. The caliber of engineers that the tech giants have on staff would allow them to produce similar technology in an afternoon  even allowing for a heavy lunch. What annoys me is that NYT paints this as an unnuanced David and Goliath story. That's an easy story to tell and a catchy one. The reality is that Sonos came up with a facile technology that was doomed to have a short shelf-life once its market value was established. And now that they have demonstrated this market to the big players  their game is up. Playing the intellectual property victim is the only card they have left. So it's not too surprising they are seeing this endgame to its tedious legal conclusion in the hopes of cashing out any remaining value they can from this mickey mouse tech.
Name: campbell

comment: Is anybody surprised? Techies are a pack of thieves. They don't have a profitable idea between them  but they're great at Columbusing existing businesses then gentrifying you out of your neighborhood.
Name: just

comment: Deja vu all over again. Remember when Microsoft was the big bad tech company who wanted to "cut off the oxygen supply" for Netscape? And the old jingle  "DOS isn't done  'til Lotus won't run!" When companies get too big they lose innovation potential. Then they squeeze or assimilate the smaller companies that do have the original ideas. Perhaps we'll come up with a better system  but meanwhile it seems to take the courts to level the playing field. at least for some little while.
Name: patrick

comment: These are the leaders of a major corporation who now claim they were as naive as a toddler? Now  they’re like the frog that was surprised by the scorpion? Please. That’s how capitalism works.
Name: from

comment: Sonos should lean into the "non-smart speakers" - I bought my new Sonos because they finally offered an upgraded mic-free speaker (Sonos One - SL). Believe it or not  there are people out there who do not want Google or Amazon listening in on them!
Name: kc

comment: Please stay afloat  Sonos.  Jawbone's Jambox went by the wayside so I already have one formerly useful speaker that is now useless.  I have 3 Sonos and would happily buy more.  I will absolutely not buy a speaker from Google or Amazon  knowing what we all know about eavesdropping.
Name: it

comment: Because I don’t trust Amazon  Alexa was unplugged.
Name: oh

comment:
So assuming that Google and Amazon hire only the best and the brightest  it appears that their business acumen doesn't go beyond typical street criminal tactics-bully and whip your competition until they submit.  Steal outright and dare them to call the cops.

 Why waste a bunch of money on getting an MBA if this is the result?  This isn't even original  John D. Rockefeller and Standard Oil perfected this in the 1870s.

Interesting in watching "The Irishman"  one conclusion that I drew was that the Mafia obviously had a big hand in trade union pension funds back in the day.  The government went after them and got the criminal element out- now you have Wall St. managing them  the only difference is that what Wall St. does now seems to be legal and the government has no guts to go after them- at least based on what happened in 2008.
Name: hugh

comment: This is a non-story. Sonos suffered from hubris and greed. They tried to take on the giants of the business with mediocre technology in a rapidly changing marketplace. They actually thought they out game Google in audio hardware? Phfff.  And to make matters worse: They took the company public knowing this was their fate. So now they're crying foul  but the true victims are the shareholders for buying the nonsense that management was selling. Noting about Sonos's tech was or is defensible  patents or not. The market shifts fare too fast for a tiny company to ever survive without a small  defensible niche.
Name: observer

comment: 25 years ago  as a Business Analyst  I was instructed to work on several scenarios regarding a business plan:   Don’t infringe  infringe and win  infringe and lose.  In the end  they decided to pass because the competitor  an oil company  had a virtual wall of 90 patents surrounding the technology.  I am sure Tech companies do the same exercise every day.  In my opinion  the only thing that stops infringement is severe penalties - as “white collared management” is deathly afraid of prison.
Name: mark

comment:
I have been using Sonos for 2 years. I love it  and disposed of my CD collection. I can also stream the sound from YouTube videos to it as well. Love watching the NFL recaps that way.

If it’s true  I hope Sonos wins. No different then what the Chinese do.
Name: paul

comment:
Wowzer. This is some news! I work in a store selling Google's smart speakers. The Google Homes are great and work very well. I also have Sonos Beam and the play ones in Google Smart Home. They so sound great. But wouldn't you think that a clever company such as Sonos would have taken out some kind of prenup to say to Google "Look guys we fully respect you but can you sign this piece of paper to say you're not gonna copy our patents". Hmmm...not so smart then. 

I am a real Google fan but Sonos should have tech protected themselves against the mighty Google beforehand. Of course Google will outsell Sonos speakers. Not everyone wants to spend £200 in a smallish speaker when they can get a Google one for far less. I have all Google speakers at home and they work so well. The sound is ok.
Name: julie

comment: Google has gone from Do Not Evil to a state where they absolutely cannot be trusted. I do what I can to avoid them - examples include not using Chrome (I use Firefox) and the fact for my next phone I will pay the Apple tax (higher prices). Oh  by the way  I certainly am NOT an Amazon Prime member and never will be.
Name: murrieta

comment:
This is just stupid.  They are suing Google because Google also makes wireless products for the home?  Sonos hasn't made any real changes in its speakers since 2015 - why are they surprised when others catch up?

Love the comments by others - folks who know NOTHING about any of the companies named.  It seems like socialism is alive and well among the readers of this rag.
Name: california

comment:
I'm shocked  just shocked  to learn that Amazon and Google do evil things to competitors  not to mention users.

We have a Sonos speaker. It is barely able to play music streamed from a blue-tooth attached phone (while the blue-tooth connection stays alive). That's it.

We do not allow "alexa"  "echo" or "siri" or any other such surveillance devices in our home. The Sonos speaker will not do any of the things its packaging promises without such a listening device.

Our home is well-connected with strong and reliable wifi throughout. The Sonos speaker will NOT do what we most wanted -- it will not play music streamed to our audio gear in the living room  so that we can listen other places in our home.

My reaction is "A pox on all their houses". When I pull zipcord and hard-wire extension speakers  they work better than Sonos. They don't fail.

Most importantly  they don't collect and send conversations to anybody.
Name: brooklinetom

comment:
I use Amazon to find and review products. Then  I buy them directly from the product's web sites  not from Amazon. Also  I don't have any Amazon or Google "smart" home invaders.

I do  however  enjoy my Sonos products.
Name: michael

comment:
All the competing services coexist in the Sonos ecosystem. It's an old internet beauty of pluralism where you forge an independent path across multiple services listening for the perfect song or podcast. There are streamjng services if you want but there's old school channel surfing too. There was a pride in discovering a new artist that doesn't exist with algorithmically delivered music -- that wonder of discovery. 

Sonos has at it's core a clear-eyed mission that hasn't strayed; they do one thing right.  They have kept on mission making fantastic smart speakers and supporting their old products. In stark contrast to Google  who has amnesia for last week's service or product. They are high-end speakers that play beautiful sound and work seamlessly and grow across technical generations without interoperability issues. I couldn't be more impressed. If Sonos goes under  despite having a better product  solid IP  and reasonable pricing  some big tech company will cannibalize them and make an inferior product that gets lost in their consuming vision and then later abandoned as a commodity. So you go get them  David! Goliath could be knocked down a peg or two.
Name: chris

comment: I will miss this place and if I can get in today will have trouble deciding what to have.  That said  you did not mention that it is probably the most expensive "coffee shop" in the city.  Perhaps another reason for its demise.
Name: carole

comment: a shame.  I am not a nNew Yorker  but I know and love cities of all sizes and what makes them vibrant and home for so many - not just homogeneous and soulless places.  Local restaurants and diners are (were?) one of those things.  Thank you for this article and best of luck to all who worked at and were not strangers at Burger Heaven.
Name: jim

comment:
Nearly 70 years ago  on my way to summer camp  my mother would have us stop in NYC for three days or so  and we stayed at the New Weston hotel on Madison & 50th. One of the unforgettable pleasures for me was our lunches at Hamburger Heaven  where the burgers were the best  and I discovered Guernsey milk  delicious with its high fat content (but back then no one cared about that).

I will soon be 78  and no one will convince me that I have not lived during the golden age of mankind. Hamburger Heaven was a small part of that  and I am grateful for it.
Name: michael

comment: I don't know about the third-place thing. I'm of that generation you speak of and having a place between home and work/school where I feel just as at home makes a big difference in my quality of life.
Name: jade

comment:
This farewell also mentions gone-but-not-forgotten Prime Burger  my favorite spot of the bunch.  

I am not so sure that I blame the young generation for the grab-and-go mentality.  I do blame technology. The conveniences of being connected online have displaced the joys of a lunch at  these "heavens  whether it's a 20-minute pit stop at the counter  or an hour spent in close conversation in a booth.
Name: nr

comment: Literally brought tears to my eyes.  I don’t live in NYC  but this has been my favorite hamburger restaurant for decades.
Name: jim

comment: You know  we are just entering a different pase that’s all. Welcome to a new scene. Bonding happens at food trucks too  which is ubiquitous of a Manhattan street scene.
Name: orion

comment: Brilliant.  The loss is immeasurable.
Name: lonnie

comment: I don't think I ever ate at this Burger Heaven  but as fellow septuagenarian Michael G. notes below  Hamburger Heaven was a terrific burger joint. Maybe the best of them all. Countless cheeseburgers (and the occasional special burger cooked with burgundy wine!) over many decades.
Name: jerry

comment: I never ate there  but I'll miss it all the same. Places like Burger Heaven help make New York City what it is - or maybe what it once was - and its closing will make it a little poorer. Sad.
Name: richard

comment: Almost worth a plane ride from the southwest to eat one last hamburger— not shared — with fries and slaw  Diet Coke  please  in my one-time neighborhood. I have indelible images of eating here. And a few indelible pounds. Homey  welcoming  delish  we would guiltily agree it’s what we wanted for lunch or dinner. Thanks for the memories.
Name: susan

comment: I loved Bun 'n Burger.  Still miss it.
Name: margie

comment: This  and other similar establishments  are the real New York  to me. I have never forgotten Prime Burger  for example  and while my diet has changed  my memories of NYC include the coffee shops and the lingo. I need a Van-stretch  draw two  and a jack full boat. Give me a tuna salad on whiskey down and make it nice!
Name: joshua

comment: You don't appreciate what you have until it's gone. The young hipsters will regret not having these small pleasure palaces.
Name: msb

comment: Excellent  excellent article.
Name: michael

comment: This is a very well written article.  Zinsser would be proud.
Name: josh

comment: Farewell to their delicious watermelon pickle relish. Oh my. There was a time when it was even bottled and sold at the location across from Saks.
Name: msmadesimpler

comment: This is the kind of place we like to go to. So sorry to hear that it is closing.
Name: dt

comment: For years  my mother worked as an administrative assistant at Esquire magazine whose office was at 488 Madison Avenue  right around the corner from Hamburger Heaven.  What a treat it was to go there with her  with its two levels of booths and tables.  Going to a coffee shop was part of the fun of being in the city after visiting with my mom or shopping at Best and Co. or Bonwit Teller.  Things change--eating at your desk seems to be required if you're not in the upper echelons--but the community of New Yorkers  gathered at Brentano's or Doubleday bookstores or Tower Records or coffee shops seems to have diminished.  It's still a great city  of course  but navigating it is a little easier if you're monied or have a driver.
Name: sna

comment: I have their menu on my office wall.  I took it as a memento from the BH on 53rd between 5th and Lex that closed about a year ago.  The rare bacon cheeseburger with a side of onion rings was to LIVE for.
Name: fred

comment: Reading about the closing of this diner was so sad.  Although I haven't even met them  as I looked at the faces of the BH employees I saw so much love and comfort. It's people like this that make our daily lives so much more than just a grind.  I wish everyone at BH the love and comfort they have shared for so many years.
Name: barb

comment: For all the years I worked on Madison and 53rd  I went to Burger Heaven at least once a week. I always had tomato soup with grilled cheese on whole wheat. Ahhhh!
Name: chris

comment: RIP~ back when midtown wasn´t overrun. "i´ll have the smithfield rare please."
Name: young

comment: Is it really that tastes have changed so much? Shake Shack’s success suggests otherwise! But Shake Shack has a Hospitality Group behind them  not a family.
Name: kitty

comment:
I was not a regular  but I too loved the Burger Heaven across the street from HarperCollins -- or Harper & Row  as it was called when I first worked there in 1981. I was early for my job interview and sat at the counter for a cup of coffee. I still picture myself seated there  25 years old and about to begin a 16-year run in the editorial department of peerless Basic Books. There I would learn to edit and write and love the company of the smart and funny people who chose book publishing as a career in those days.

All lost  along with the scrumptious hamburgers and milkshakes across the street.
Name: linda

comment: I can’t remember the name (and I think it’s because there wasn’t a sign out front) but there was a burger place near the NYU  Graduate School of Business when it was located downtown near the old WTC. It was small; long and narrow and the cook worked the griddle up front. Depending upon your seating  you might walk out smelling like the place. No menu. Just plain burgers  cheeseburgers  fries and coffee. Wall Streeters  students  office workers  et al  would jam that small spot for the best burgers. I do believe that a good burger is a great equalizer.
Name: molly

comment: Our major stop for lunch when we took the bus from Rutherford  NJ to Best & Co.!  Wonderful memories with my mom. I can still picture the gregarious counterman  some 50 plus years later!
Name: pat

comment: A great spot for a simple grilled cheese sandwich. I will miss it.
Name: joan

comment:
When worked on 57th and 5th for ten years starting in the early 1990's   I ate at Burger Heaven all the time. I loved dining by myself  and I often would go a little bit late to miss the lunch rush. I would even go there after work sometimes to catch up with a friend  it was close  quiet and the food was always A+. 
I will be sad to see it go!
Name: jen

comment: I already miss the BH on Madison/40th -- it closed for a different reason  the building (which I don't think they owned) was completely renovating the commercial spaces  and they all shut down.  When I started in this city  back in the mid-80's  I worked at a large law firm in a brand-new office building (520 Madison) next door to the Burger Heaven on 53rd Street.  I worked for a crusty partner whose idea of splurging on the associates was to take them to Burger Heaven.  I felt weird going back there  30 years later.   But it's already closed.  I took visiting family to the BH featured in this story about 10 years ago -- at the time  their youngest would eat mac 'n' cheese and not much else  and BH featured yummy mac 'n' cheese.  I loved getting their tomato soup -- always on the menu -- with a grilled cheese  as someone else here also said.
Name: local

comment: A couple of years ago  a friend and I stopped at the BH on 53rd. One reheated pre-made  frozen veggie burger with the works  fries  and two sodas cost $28. (The sodas were $4 apiece!) Even for midtown that's pricey for not-even-good diner food. I don't think the decrease of the "third place" is the only reason they all closed.
Name: dp

comment: Every year for the past 20 or more years my husband and I have spent a night just before Christmas walking from Rockefeller Center  up 5th  over to Madison at 59th  up Madison to 62nd and ending at Burger Heaven where my husband would order either a hot dog and baked beans or a cheeseburger deluxe and a hot chocolate  the same he has ordered his entire life (he grew up around the corner and I grew up downtown)  and I would splurge on a burger (not deluxe....but I may have eaten a few of his fries when he wasn't looking).  Over the past 10 years  the walk has remained the same  but everything else has changed.  Rock Center is even more of a zoo as Saks added a light show.  Fifth Avenue doesn't have a Bendel's or Takashimaya or Searle or Gant.  There are no windows at Barney's to debate over.  So many storefronts on Madison are empty.  And now even Burger Heaven has gone.  As people who have grown up  met  gotten married and had children in this City  we are desolate at the loss of all that we knew.  Yes  much of what I listed above were commercial entities  but their loss is emblematic of our changing City which is increasingly sterile  homogenous  and very un-local.  Burger Heaven - your burgers will be missed  but your presence will be missed even more.  You were a huge part of our lives.  Thank you.
Name: psa

comment: Like the  tradition of the long lost Sunday family dinner  this closing reflects yet another cultural treasure that fostered communication  communal values with  an opportunity fo the r ties that bind.
Name: vincent

comment: Spent many years in the 80's and 90's at Burger Heaven where I would have breakfast  five days a week  with my friend Bobby. We had initially met at Burger Heaven and became " breakfast buddies'. Bobby ran his own vending machine business and I worked at Hunter College.  We sat in the same seat every day across from another regular  Seymour Durst. The satff were always wonderful but I most remember Addie and her brother from Ethiopia who were the first Coptic Christians either one of us had ever met.  Only in New York.
Name: techfan

comment:
I sometimes went to Burger Heavve when I was living at the Barbizon Hotel for Women back in the mid-1960's.  It was always good

Later  I found the Sunflower Diner near where my daughter lived in the 20's on Third Ave.  I loved that place for breakfast and always went there when I came to NYC.  Alas  now also gone.

It was places like this (and the old Susan Prince restaurant on Lexington in the 60's) that brought a human dimension to NYC.  One "knew" the waitstaff and they knew one and ones likes and dislikes.  It was never impersonal.

No delivery service or food truck will every be able to replace that dimension and NYC is the worse for that.
Name: india

comment:
Teresa's  a Polish-American restaurant on Montague Street loved by so many in Brooklyn Heights  closed a few weeks ago.

Then there was Prexy's  where they offered "the hamburger with a college education."

We continue to lose the beloved stores  restaurants and institutions that made New York so different and so delightful.
Name: andrew

comment: This is so sad. Yet another loss of a small  independently-owned business that makes New York “New York” rather than a homogenized anywhere-U.S.A.  All the best to the family and its staff.
Name: fran

comment: I am a native New Yorker with Flatbush Brooklyn pedigree. Though change may be inevitable  the direction of it at times is disconcerting. As others have commented  we seem to lose a bit of our collective souls when the neighborhood fixtures close for whatever reason. I am old enough to recall the Automats  I miss Dave's on Broadway (Egg creams)  Ebinger's  and others but am happy that Junior's on Flatbush Avenue lives on. C'est la vie.
Name: ortegagon

comment: Burger Heaven defines what made New York City once so great. Independent businesses and their storefronts that served to give each neighborhood its own unique character and its associated vibrant street life. Store owners  their employees and patrons greeting each other by name  interacting as members of a shared community. With chain stores prevalent and delivery services in majority use the richness of neighborhood life that identified New York City is fading away. New York City  the Big Apple that once was. You want to eat an apple now  forget about going out to pick one up from Joe’s corner store. Order it online and get it delivered.
Name: rose

comment: This is the New York that 75-year old me grew up in. Things change; we all know that. But we don't have to like all the changes. That being said  there are the counterbalancing changes for POC  women and LGBTQ folks  for example. Is it a better world? Who knows. It is just a different world. But one now without a good  quick burger and a smile.
Name: insider

comment: The Cyprus family are good people and a wonderful family. I wish them all the best.
Name: cindy

comment:
I remember a NYC when there were no chain stores besides Orange Julius and Subarrow. In the early 70s McDonald’s tried to open a store on Uptown Broadway. The neighborhood went nuts and the were ultimately denied a permit.
Every bodega and deli was different  you took your chances until you found one you preferred.
Now that Times Square is Disneyland north and there’s a CVS on every corner you may as well visit any other city in the US  NY has lost it’s soul.
Name: paulie

comment: Don't fret. These marvelous places will return. The tech and delivery culture will finally burn out and a very real human want for a public place where people feel comfort and the food is safe will reappear. Communal eating places are as old as humanity.
Name: david

comment: I'm not religious  so I mourn the loss of neighbourhood restaurants and cafes more than any other kind of establishment. I fervently hope the trend towards more corporate chains  less idiosyncrasy  less serendipity  is soon reversed. The internet is great  but there is no human warmth in it.
Name: s

comment: I have fond memories of Burger Heaven  but I still miss Hicks. The restaurant on 49th  across from Saks  that Burger Heaven replaced. Mostly for the fresh whipped cream in their ice cream sodas! My favorite part of shopping at Saks  with my mom!
Name: laura

comment:
I so wish I had known about this sooner so I could have had a last goodbye in person. The Burger Heaven on 40th and Madison got me through many a long day and night at my advertising job next door. There was just that "something" to their burgers that has not been replicated in my life since. 

I salute Burger Heaven from New Jersey and I thank them for years of good food and good memories.
Name: paul

comment:
Family and friends  takes about an hour and a half when you add it all up  great quality food  New York.
Those who had great times there must be upset.
We've got fast casual now  right? Just like the rest of America. :)
Name: gerold

comment: Those photographs look like Norman Rockwell paintings! Well done ...
Name: papercut

comment: They had the best hamburgers!
Name: debby

comment: Heartbroken again  NYC! There goes another institution! No wonder left the big Apple a few years ago...
Name: mike

comment: Meanwhile Shake Shack went public and their thick burgers - too mushy for me but apparently delightful to the throngs who were willing to wait on ridiculous  unnecessarily long lines - have become homogenized  thinnish crusts. And it's hard to imagine chilling out and watching the world go by  there. When I get to a new neighborhood I look for a comfortable place to do that  before I look for the supermarket  and I quickly become a regular.
Name: jonathan

comment: The independent neighborhood eatery is slouching towards extinction. What a loss. The cause  of course  is mechanized people  who respond to advertising like zombies and let themselves be drawn to chain restaurants like obedient unthinking cattle.
Name: scrumble

comment: I'll still continue to voluntarily reside in MKE.  Small town and large city all in one.  Pay us a visit and eat at the Wonder Land diner around the corner from my home.
Name: doug

comment: so sad. been eating at Burger Heavens for over 40 years. was at 49th BH last day when it closed. I love the Cyprus family and its the end of NY lunch time dining as we know it. Nicki  where should we have lunch?
Name: alan

comment: So sad to hear that Burger Heaven is closing.  From 1995 to 2010 (when I went vegetarian)  it was a dependable place to get the best turkey burger in town.  When I worked downtown  I would place my order at Lex/62nd  get off the subway at 59th Street  pick it up and then head home.
Name: as

comment: Small shout out to Bryan Derballa for the wonderful photographs that capture the essence of the place as well as the personality of the employees.
Name: josh

comment: This kind of food is terrible for young and old alike. This kind of food breeds obesity and diabetes. Wake up  America; there is no "comfort food" only platefulls of death.
Name: maciver

comment: As I recall  the Burger Heaven on E 53rd had a bowl of fresh parsley on the counter with a sign that read  "You needn't eat your onions sparsely  if you have a sprig of parsley." No one ever taught me that at home!
Name: outsider

comment: This is and the closing of all the Mom and Pop shops is why I will never go back to NYC where I spent the first 38 years of my life. Last time I visited I was shocked by all those franchises and high end places crowding out those shops with personality and warmth.
Name: vail

comment: what will we do without the red relish?!  is there any other NYC coffee shop (and thank you for using the true local vernacular  Mr. Trebay  and not the imposter "d" word!) that has it???
Name: edg

comment:
Yay that Burger Heaven made it this long.   I loved the Chock Full of Nuts heavenly cream cheese/nut/raisin sandwiches.... and the taste of Schrafft's vanilla ice cream-- sans pareil-- anywhere.  The chains do little to compare altho nothing bad about an oreo McFlurry.  I also miss Sedutto's chocolate almond fudge  -- the best lunch in the world.  

Times change … there are places I remember..... in my life...
Name: auntie

comment: I grew up on that block and never went there . It did not have an authentic burger joint feel to it. Much better was Jackson Hole two and a half blocks to the East .
Name: anthony

comment: No way this place was going to survive with a $20 mediocre cheeseburger. Even in Manhattan that price point was just not competitive!
Name: owen

comment:
The unique places of NYC have been disappearing for years. Soon there will be only national chains paying high commercial rents. We frequented the Burger Heaven on 53rd for many years - my wife worked at MoMA  and our dentist is on Mad near 52nd.

Thank God for Eisenberg's and Viand. When those joints close  I'm out of here.
Name: ruben

comment:
“New York can be cold  and a place like this makes you feel like you live in a village ” Kari Lichtenstein  a family lawyer  said last week  as she sat with her mother  Emilie Palef  a Toronto native first drawn here by the quirky stores and homey restaurants.

Hunh? They've gone the way of video porn shops on 42nd St. You want a burger? That'll be $18.95. Ketchup is extra.

Yeah can keep Manhattan.
Name: george

comment:
"Everybody Goes to Burger Heaven"

Nope.  Have not been inside any type of such place in over 30 years.  Just looking at the pictures was almost enough to make me wretch.  What people put inside their bodies amazes me.

You are what you eat.
Name: concernicus

comment: Oh Nancy  I wish we could have one more burger here. I miss you always.
Name: stephen

comment: So sad..  I grew up with Jahn's being our go-to place.  When they closed it was like the end of an era.  Never did get to down the kitchen sink!
Name: yael

comment:
This is really sad.  What is it about food that this generation doesn’t like?

Anyone been to the brand spanking new Hudson Yards recently?  It's the most boring sterile place imaginable.  After spending two hundred dollars on some very disappointing Asian food  there was nothing to do but shop (some more) and  then  slink into a cab for the uptown journey home.

The whole thing felt alien  monied and contrived.  Chanel bags will never replace the heartwarming joy of someone with a smile asking: “Hello  my love  what are you having? The usual?”

RIP to the heart and soul of NYC.  May all those of BH know their future IS in heaven.  It certainly was a great run.
Name: tsv

comment:
A city isn't a city if it isn't in a constant state of flux. Nevertheless...

Schrafft's. Wienerwald. Brentano's. And now BH. Ouch!

The places and faces of my misspent youth are gone  and I feel entitled to enjoy the pangs of nostalgia.
Name: taz

comment:
it's happening everywhere.  The affordable restaurants where the wait staff knows their customers are all going.  

This  weekend the Spitfire Grill  a small restaurant at the Santa Monica Airport  that served the Los Angeles  neighborhood of Mar Vista  for 29 years will closed their doors after selling to an Englishman who is going to redo the restaurant.

The Spitfire has ducted taped booths  and a wait staff that knows your drink order and has it on our table in minutes of our arrival.  When I order my dinner  I am always asked  " your usual?"  That is a Gilder sandwich  no cheese  and the spinach inside the sandwich cooked with a side salad.  

My neighbors and I are already missing it and the wonderful staff!
Name: rb

comment: Burger Heaven got me through a lot of rough nights working late in Midtown throughout my 20s.  I will always remember the warm souls that worked there and that ridiculous cash register they had where the coins spit out and go down a slide.  May it live long in our hearts!
Name: dd

comment: A big reason people these days rely on Seamless/Grub Hub and food trucks/takeout is that companies don't want you leaving the office for an hour to have lunch. I don't know of anyone who goes out for lunch anymore.
Name: annie

comment: I started going to BH  62nd and Lex  when I came to New York after college in 1966.  Saturday morning  first stop Bloomies.  Then lunch at BH.  Plain burger  relish on the side - can’t be beat.  In the years since  it has been my go-to stop on the UES.  I would walk blocks for a seat next to its big windows or  if it was too busy  at the counter.  I hope it isn’t closing because a new generation of owners feel they can do better with something else at this beautiful location.  Sad.
Name: ss

comment:
"... we obtain this small pleasure: being both anonymous and known."

This could not be more perfectly stated; to me this is the very essence of New York's appeal.
Name: l

comment:
"being both anonymous and known".  
Yes  in New York you can be both. You can be alone in a crowd.
Few other cities can say that.
Name: alocksley

comment: For well over a decade  I had a semi-regular Friday lunch date with some of my dearest friends at one of the several Burger Heaven locations in midtown.  Originally  as young tax kids  we spent Fridays at McDonald's  moving to Burger Heaven only after feeling secure enough in our careers to spring for a higher caliber of lunch.  Age and metabolism meant that in recent years  we'd focus more on their soups or salads.  I will miss even the weird  late-stage club incarnation of one of the branches.
Name: taxman

comment: In the mid 1980s  I worked on Fifth Avenue. We ordered from the Burger Heaven on 53rd almost every day. I remember my tuna on wheat dry order fondly.
Name: jcaz

comment:
How sad:  my wife and I always made several visits to the Burger Heaven places anytime we visited NYC.  

It was informal  friendly  clean  calming  often highly caloric  and always delicious.     

I hope the kale eaters are happy foraging in their dark green bowls.
Name: bob

comment: 14th Street Coffee Shop is one of the only places like this still standing  by Stuy Town  let’s hold on to that one as long as we can. The New York I grew up with is sadly almost gone.
Name: greg

comment: I grew up and still live in Los Angeles and there used to be joints like that all over the city and now they are all gone unless it's a chain. Makes me sad.  My favorite coffee shop/restaurant was replaced by a Chipotle.
Name: tracy

comment: On my first day of job hunting in NYC many years ago I wandered into a BH across from Rockefeller Center for a burger and saw Gene Shallat of the TODAY show dining at the counter. My first of many celebrity sightings in the city. I think of it every time I walk down that street...
Name: stephen

comment: I'll miss it! I love eating at a regular diner any day and I'll miss people watching over my burger or grilled cheese  and seeing the grill chef's moves. I'm only 36 so I don't consider myself older than the sweetgreen crew  but maybe my soul is. I must have grown up in a much older New York than I ever realized!
Name: cc

comment: heartbreaking. I never saw HH as another diner - and I love diners! I remember once a few years ago  wandering around  hungry and cold  thinking  'where is the closest diner?' I couldn't find one. Then 'maybe a slice of pizza?' I couldn't find one.
Name: timmrush

comment: I live across from Burger a Heaven on 62 and Lex. I go almost every week  it’s always packed. It’s my “Seinfeld Diner”.  The waitstaff knows everyone and food comes out so quickly and thoroughly  faster than a New York minute. There’s heart and community in that Burger Heaven that Manhattan is losing day after day. I’m thoroughly heartbroken.
Name: sofia

comment: I really don't know what to do with this city anymore.
Name: carrie

comment: The social interaction of going to a diner at which you’re a known person.  The staff knows your usual order  if you come at regular times your fellow diners are familiar with your presence and respond accordingly.  It’s a good harmonious feeling which is getting far too rare today.  I’ll take the ride to a comfortable friendly diner where the world just seems “right.”
Name: michijim

comment: I used to go there back in the 1970's when the price of a hamburger was $1.85.   When Burger Heave recently remodeled  their restaurant on East 49th -- they jacked up their prices so much that their delicious burger just wasn't worth the exorbitant price they were now asking.  And the empty seats proved that others thought so also.  Still I would just like to know how Burger Heaven got their burgers so consistently  nice and juicy.
Name: piggyb

comment: These are some great photos by Bryan D! Especially the first and third. Love the low saturation look to them.
Name: erik

comment: I must weigh in with my favorite Burger Heaven offering  enjoyed many times over the years: chicken salad on rye toast. Superbly fresh all white meat chicken chunks with just enough mayo to hold it together. Sad to see you go  BH!
Name: judy

comment: Shame on the NYT for waiting until Tuesday  Feb 25  to tell those of us scattered around the country that we only have 72 hours to get to NYC for one last visit to the iconic BH. I moved to NYC straight out of college in the mid-70's  a rube in the big city who cried himself to sleep in his first night on the floor of his furniture-less studio. Burger Heaven was my salvation during those first few months. I am tempted to hop on a flight Friday morning to make one last pilgrimage. I will always be grateful and hold a special place in my heart.
Name: simple

comment: Many thanks to Brian Derballa for the superb photographs.
Name: fenhalls

comment:
What is left  what remains of the Manhattan we thought was just another place to live  not the urban refuge for the uber rich and fantasy land for ill informed tourists and wannabes?
Really what remains?
Name: corkpop

comment: What Manhattan needs is a few In-n-Outs and you'll soon forget about Burger Heaven.  A double-double will ease your pain.
Name: richard

comment: Betty at 53rd St used to tell us about Jackie Kennedy.  I went there almost everyday from '88 to 2000.  Coffee and burger deluxe.
Name: gb

comment:
Younger workers don't like to go out of the office to lunch.
They are exploited and simply don't know any better.
Name: lgato

comment: I feel bad for the staff most of all.  They seem like a good bunch.
Name: treetop

comment:
Oh please. Far more cheeseburgers are eaten in Manhattan than Sweet Potato Kelp Bowls  or anything else from Sweetgreen  by an order of magnitude. 
Or are the McDonald's  KFCs  and Taco Bells all shuttering too?
Name: ignatius

comment: It was where my mother ate her last tref (not kosher) hamburger when she was pregnant with me. She thought I should be raised without guilt because my father was an observant Jew. Hah!
Name: ani

comment: Is it gone for sure? Can we set up a GoFundMe?
Name: vanessa

comment: Fond memories of going to Nectar lunch counter  with my parents following a morning at the Met  after driving in from RI. They sure knew how to grill Octopus  so that I a seafood lover actually liked it.
Name: alexia

comment: I went to one when I was visiting New York with my father around 1961. Never forgot it!
Name: charlie

comment: This makes me so sad. I lived in NYC in 1999 and 2000 and recently went back for a visit. I felt that NYC has lost its character. Everything was shiny and new. It made me so sad and nostalgic for those bygone days.
Name: cncrnd

comment: In the 60’s  70’s and 80’s  I frequently ate lunch at Burger Heaven  especially the one on East 53rd Street. Great burgers and a terrific chicken salad.
Name: jack

comment: I grew up in NY in the 60s/70s and always loved the diner scenes.  Put a few coins in the little flip-knob 45 jukebox and happily listen to tunes while wolfing down a burger/BLT with fries.   Fun times.  Just a couple of years ago  we lost a highway  restaurant staple here in Texas that had been in operation for almost 90 years (Franks in Schulenburg  although due to an illness in the family).  It's always sad when something that's been around for so long shutters its doors.  Luckily  a few places from my L.I. past seem to still be going strong:  Massapequa Diner (1950)  Nautilus Diner (1963)  Krisch's Ice Cream Parlor (1955) and All American Burger (1963).  Seeing that those places are still operating makes me very happy.  It's almost like getting to retain a part of one's youth (and at my age  I could use all the retention I can get my hands on).  :-)
Name: independent

comment: Another New York institution bites the dust.
Name: mark

comment: Kudos to Bryan Derballa.  The photos in this article show some real thought - particularly the first one at the table.  I'd buy that.
Name: island

comment: So sad.  Part of the Walmartization of America.
Name: apparatchick

comment: A few years ago I searched the internet to see what happened to a place where  as a young child in the 1960s  I enjoyed hamburgers with my family. I knew the place as “beefburger” and read that the name was changed in the 1970s to “Burger Heaven.”
Name: jeffrey

comment: It would be sad if their burgers were even remotely edible  but they’re not. Survival of the fittest and all that...
Name: anon

comment: When I worked in a midtown advertising agency in the 1990s  I would go to Burger Heaven with friends from my office.  That was our special pleasure  comfort food when the stress of advertising grew too great.  Unfortunately  New York City has been rapidly replacing neighborhood stores and restaurants with big box chains. Manhattan  once unique  differs little from many New Jersey suburbs in terms of shopping.  And that is a shame.
Name: max

comment: I got married in the brownstone next door to Hamburger Heaven  which was owned by the owners of Hamburger Heaven. I planned my wedding menu sitting at one of the tables there. As a child  I took art lessons above Hamburger Heaven  hoping my art would improve and I’d be accepted at High School of Music and Art. I wasn’t. I ate at that restaurant regularly with my Dad who owned Alfred’s Barbershop on East 61st Street and Lexington Avenue. I can still taste the hamburgers.
Name: susan

comment: I pass by from time to time and had been meaning to try them out  so I went yesterday evening just to do it once before they close. The classic burger for $11.00 seemed to be a very good piece of beef but it was very dry with almost no juice. Perhaps the cut was too lean. For an extra $7.00 the french fries were very good  with a nice piece of lettuce and two thin slices of tomato. Two nice-size spears of sour pickle were a definite plus. The lemonade barely tasted of lemon and at $3.00 was not worth it. If  as has been mentioned in the comments  the owners also own the building  then perhaps this is a real estate story and has nothing to do with being unable to stay in business. At $18.00 for what amounts to a burger deluxe  they could probably stay in business if they wanted.
Name: brian

comment: I used to go to the 53rd location for years   now that I don’t eat so much meat   I go for organic or at least responsibly raised   and now the vegetarian burger is my new meat of choice   this location will leave good memories for me.
Name: thewinelistinc

comment: Excellent  evocative writing - well done Mr. Trebay!
Name: dave

comment:
How many New York landmarks have closed in the past year alone?

What will happen to Yossy and the cooks?
Name: hope

comment: My godmother took me to lunch at the Plaza (just like Eloise) for my birthday one year. After we were done she asked how I liked it. I said "It was great  but my dad took me to this place called Burger Heaven...".
Name: anne

comment: I have fond memories of having coffee every morning at the Burger Heaven on East 53rd St. I had just started working at my first job at HarperCollins Publishers across the street. I got to know two young men who were also morning regulars and worked at a diamond cutting shop in the neighborhood. Our waitress was an older woman who we also spent time chatting with. It turned out that as a child growing up in NYC  she had played with the children of the German Expressionist painter  Max Beckmann and had great stories about him. It was such a lovely convergence of people from different walks of life learning about each other and beginning the day with a bit of camaraderie.
Name: nancy

comment:
Just as our bread  mixed and baked  packaged and sold without benefit of accident of human frailty  is uniformly good and uniformly tasteless  so will our speech become one speech.”


― John Steinbeck  Travels with Charley: In Search of America
Name: eric

comment: Soon Manhattan will be a rich-people theme park.
Name: kat

comment: How does the author of this article define “landlord greed”?
Name: mark

comment: It is a wonderful situation when families can meet in pleasant and quiet restaurants. I only feel sorry for the family in the photo and others who eat or  perhaps  have to eat there  hamburgers.
Name: tuvw

comment: According to Cindy Adams  Schrafft's was going to be re-opened by now. But where? What happened? New York without its diners is a truly inhospitable place. Thankfully  new ones open as the old ones close.
Name: plank

comment: I wish I had gone before the closing.  It's always sad to see New York favorites like this go  and I've tried to do my part in keeping places like this alive.  Hopefully new neighborhood spots like this will come along.  As a Chanel-carrying  burger-eating  young Gen X-er  I can't imagine a NYC without these old NYC eateries that are just as much a part of the city's history as the city itself.  I'd take a million of these over the chains any day of the week.
Name: jen

comment:
Their blue-cheese cheeseburgers were unparalleled.   I made reverent pilgrimage to all the Burger Heavens for that meal in particular. 

Also  doesn’t anyone remember their old cow insignia that looked vaguely like a Zulu shield?
Name: david

comment:
Things ain't like they used to be  are they? 
Sign of the Times. Just look around.
Name: timothy

comment: There’s a Hamburger Heaven in Palm Beach  FL that is still going strong and that I used to love for it’s delicious burgers (before I stopped eating meat). I wonder if there’s any connection?
Name: erica

comment: I want my last Burger Heaven Burger! I've eaten at every location and it was always a great staple. My favorite condiment is the red relish. No one else has it. Maybe they'll stay open late tonight on their last day. I really want to go.
Name: belinda

comment:
Ed  Queens Village  NYC

In the middle 70’s I was an employee at Bankers Trust Company located at 280 Park Ave.  just a block and a half from the Burger Heaven on 53rd Street across from Saks Fifth Ave. I started eating breakfast there (many toasted bagels with cream cheese) before I ever had a lunch there. I introduced the restaurant to my kids wherever they visited in me in city. Of course they in-turn did the same with my grandkids.  We have lot’s of memories  not just burgers: grilled chesses  BLT’s  tuna  milk shakes; etc.
Name: ed

comment:
Our hearts are broken!!
Our daughter claimsBH has the best mac & cheese in New York City.  Burger Heaven we will miss you!!
Name: chris

comment: I’m officially in mourning. My most memorable Burger Heaven moment was going there with a friend who happened to be the daughter one of my favorite authors. When we arrived  I was more than a bit awed to find him waiting for us  but there he was: Joseph Heller.
Name: neal

comment:
May the original best burger and onion rings in NYC Rest In Peace. 
Sigh...
Name: andrea

comment: I thought she was true to herself which is enough to make me love this performance. In a world that expects /demands people conform she continues to say here I am this is me and my beliefs. Aside from that I loved the performance she was great.
Name: dkozin

comment: Absolutely an inspiration  but I'd also note that she works hard  and almost full time  at looking this good. That doesn't diminish her in any way  but it should save as a caution against making JLo the poster for what 50 should look like because I have neither the time nor the money to look like that.
Name: laura

comment:
Jennifer is hardworking and tries very hard to please her fans. It's not at all easy way she does. To be a relevant Latina at 50 is an accomplishment! I think her and her dancers have talent and should take it to Broadway. 

However  I don't agree with all the fetishization  sexualization  electronification  and digitalization of music and musical talent. Then should not be conflated with talent and acumen. Gone are the days of Billy Joel  Joni Mitchell  Linda Ronstadt  Arethra Franklin  and musical  soloists and bands who carried their own without all of this hair flipping and torso grinding. 

Our culture has changed radically  and I'm no conservative. It used to be gentler  more tender  more pensive  and more rich . . .
Name: sasha

comment:
I am 69. When I freely tell people my age the first thing they say is “ you don’t look like you are 69.” Then I ask why they say that? That’s how old I am and this is what I look like at this age. So absurd. 
Same with any age !! Of course I doubt anyone likes to hear that they look much older than their actual age but in that case   it is still what you look like at that age. Be as healthy as you are fortunate enough to be  eat right and exercise. Everyday is a good day.
Name: old

comment: What you should be thinking about is the amount of time and money that keeps J-Lo looking as good as she does. The average woman can't afford it. Let's face it. It's her only job!
Name: ryan

comment: Generally speaking (and if you look closely enough)  people look their age. Vanessa Friedman  52  looks  well  50-ish. J Lo  when she's not covered in makeup  looks 50-ish  too. It's a great fallacy (apparently  even of 52-year-olds) that people are suddenly old when they turn 50  and if they continue to behave with youthful vigour at that age we're absolutely stunned  impressed and amazed. Such thinking is the basis of ageism.
Name: relieved

comment: Jennifer Lopez is gorgeous and a great dancer.  That does not make her worthy of an Oscar nomination.  Hustlers is a B movie and her performance is average at best.  She was not snubbed  she just didn't give an Oscar worthy performance.
Name: lisa

comment:
This moment is not a celebration of middle age women  it is just a marketing strategy as younger generations care more about individuality than fashion trends.
The fashion industry is not part of the "age" revolution. It just knows who has more disposable income.
Name: ferdinand

comment: The show was the ultimate in the objectification of women.  You can't applaud the vulgar halftime show and get on the #metoo bandwagon.
Name: carole

comment:
Honestly  I feel sorry for Vanessa Friedman’s having to write about this old chestnut. Cher did it  Madonna did it  someone else will come down the pike doing it again— flaunting their hot bod at such an advanced age! 
The “dress your age” reprimand has been dead for a long time. Why do we keep circling our wagons around this and why aren’t women performers offered more respect for their talent rather than their tight butts?  
It’s just tired!
Name: lola

comment: Really?....funny but I'm impressed with Nancy Pelosi fighting for our democracy; Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar running on a progressive ticket; AOC winning an almost impossible seat in the US House....and all of those migrant mothers running away from violence to protect their kids. J Lo means nothing.
Name: jk

comment:
columnists such as this are the only ones that keep making a big deal about age  please stop the fixation about looks and make up 

 and come on JLo  has workout trainers and nannies to take care  of hers twin kids
Name: jrv

comment:
far from the exception in an “industry famously obsessed by youth ” I think J LO is the perfect symbol of that obsession: she gets attention for magically managing to look a lot younger than women her age.  

it's inspiring that she's successful  but let's be honest: J Lo dancing in a crystal-encrusted bodysuit is just another example of society's ideal  not an inspiration for older women to wear miniskirt
Name: anonymous

comment:
I think Jennifer Lopez is an incredible athlete  singer  and dancer.  Especially at the skill level she performed at during the Super Bowl Half-Time Show.  I have been a fan of hers since I saw her in the movie  "Selena".

My only disappointment is why that production and the costumes worn had to resemble a strip club act.  Borderline obscene is putting it mildly in my book.  

I found many of the movements  especially the pole scene  more embarrassing than entertaining.
Name: marge

comment:
She may be 50 but she would prefer to be younger  judging from what she is up to and how she portray herself.   Let's get over
JLo.  A lot of us have looked great at 50.  Without all the work and hoopla.
Name: krykos

comment:
There are people well into their 60s and 70s who have run marathons  climbed Mount Everest  swam the English Channel  achieved great success at the box office in film and in music  and even became president of the United States. 

God bless them all!
Name: steven

comment: She looked great. Shakira looked great. I looked uncomfortably @ my 10 year old son and wondered if I was a bad mom for letting him stay in the room. He really  really liked it.....
Name: lauren

comment: Two middle aged women acting like they work at a strip club isn't a performance for families with young children. Or families at all.
Name: honora

comment: I don’t remember anyone thinking that it was okay (or not okay) to dress or act like Mick Jagger when the Stones did the halftime show.
Name: john

comment: The hockey game on Sunday afternoon was a lot more interesting and had bodies doing lots of really good unimaginable things.
Name: muddlerminnow

comment: But were her backup dancers also 50ish?
Name: fern

comment: You know  I'm 66 years old  and shaking my head over this column. I dress to please myself  and I don't give a thought to whether it is "age appropriate"  whatever that actually means. I don't need a celebrity to blaze that path for me  thank you very much  and I don't think most women do. We're all doing quite well without personal trainers  fashion designers  nannies  cooks  etc.  etc. Rethink "Dress your age?" That happened a long time ago.
Name: md

comment: She should be applauded.  Our culture needs to understand 50 is the beginning of something new for a lot us.  Not the end by any means
Name: tim

comment: America's obsession with age is unhealthy. The British allow their actresses to age and do not punish them for it-they become "Dames" as in Dame Judi Dench. We need to grow up in the US  in so many ways.
Name: cj

comment: I found the halftime show more entertaining than most  and I am generally a fan of Shakira and J. Lo. But part of the routine was supposed to be about empowering women  I guess  with the Venus symbol (circle with cross below) prominently displayed--this was misplaced and unfortunate. Any message about women's empowerment was lost to the in-you-face flaunting of sexuality by the principals in the show. Women should be empowered by using their sexuality? Wrong message  IMHO.
Name: dee

comment:
Contrast the tone of this article to the one describing the abuses at L Brands. The half-time show said something positive and empowering for women but the Victoria's Secret lingerie show was sexist and demeaning?  Got it  but the outfits sure look very similar.

Kudos to Jennifer Lopez (and her team of stylists  trainers  and perhaps surgeons) for staying fit.  She's certainly a talented woman. But this "performance" is not where women  young or old  should look for inspiration.
Name: det

comment: Why do aging female pop stars keep insisting that they are still sexy  sexy  sexy? Because that culture insists that being sexually desirable to men is the only value women have. If they lose that  they're nothing.
Name: denise

comment:
"an in-your-face demonstration of a woman glorying in her own physicality"

So reassuring to hear. Until now  I had thought strip clubs were merely sleazy pandering. I do hope the Times will now campaign for the re-etablishment of other avenues to such glory  beginning with Back Page and Craig's List's personal ads.
Name: hmi

comment: The bumping and grinding and almost naked costumes were absolutely an embarrassment in this Me Too era.  Why would you want your daughters to watch this?
Name: judith

comment:
I wish them well.

Yet I didn't find it attractive only vulgar  as if my grandma were dancing around in her underwear.
Name: bill

comment: A sleazy show  no matter how you try to couch it  regardless of her age. We have a president who makes me cringe  a Congress that makes me cringe. Can't I at least enjoy the half-time show without a similar gut punch of crassness run amuck.
Name: john

comment:
Yeesh. It’s so important that artists shake their booty in our faces for 15 minutes? God forbid we hear really beautiful music and/or serious dance. I’m glad she looks great  but who cares?
To think that The Rolling Stones once performed here. Oh well. 
No wonder so many are called “ugly Americans”.
Name: ari

comment: Wake me up when companies stop discriminating against 50 year old women.
Name: jen

comment: I found the half time show embarrassing. You want your young daughter or son watching this? Thinking this is how women make their mark in the world? Since when did a strip club become family entertainment?
Name: bob

comment: I don’t think I’m a prude  but I found the whole halftime show pretty tawdry.   I really don’t care if Jennifer Lopez is 30 or 50; she and Shakira reduced women to sex objects  and  considering that Super Bowl audiences have been declining  tools to boost viewership.  There’s nothing new or refreshing about that  it’s just a reprise of the cynical “sex sells.”  No wonder so many people dismiss “me too.”
Name: pkidd

comment:
This all rings so hollow when you consider that JLo has the time  money  and career imperative to spend hours a week at a gym with (I assume) a team of fitness consultants  wear only designer clothes  have professional makeup artists and stylists on call as well as a professional chef  etc etc etc. With all of this  you don't even need a plastic surgeon; but it wouldn't surprise me if she has one of those in her phone book too. 

Yeah  wow  this is what it looks like when extremely rich people embrace their age (?)
Name: qtcatch

comment: You are still visible if you can pole dance is America's Message to Women.
Name: thats

comment: I'm 50  and I'm just as "hot"  if not hotter in every category  than (then?) Jenny from the block.  Her pole dance performance  plus all the grinding and gyrating  was just gross.  Just because you CAN wear that kind of outfit  and dance like that (I can out-dance you  JLo)  doesn't mean you should - at least not in that venue.  My 8 year old daughter was asking me why she kept grabbing her privates.  I told my daughter to pivot  and we walked out of the room.  Leave that behavior for the bedroom  not a family show.
Name: laura

comment: Funny  but how come people are not offended by all the female cheerleaders in the game  (99% white by the way) that are wearing fewer clothes than her? How come they don't criticize their movements  which are quite sexy and overt?  How come they don't say the same about Beyonce? Could it be because she is a Latin woman and that poses a certain kind of threat? Ms Lopez is an Artist with a capital A and her job to be a singer and a dancer  which demands that she be in great physical shape. She is also a mother  actor  composer  writer  and a wildly successful producer. No amount of money can give you the energy to do all that. It takes passion  focus  commitment and the desire to carry a message that is bigger than oneself  which she did last night outstandingly well.
Name: jorge

comment:
Can we get to a point where a female peformer is not required to lead with her body but can instead lead with a talent outside of how she looks? The men on stage at half-time were not expected to perform half-dressed--why were J Lo and Shakira?

After the last few years of brave women speaking out against exploitation of women--including a story in the Times just yesterday about Victoria's Secret-we need to do better. 

J Lo is doing what she knows  but the people that put on that show yesterday just validated every dangerous stereotype that we've been working so hard to overturn.
Name: mags

comment: It was a lewd performance - do you really want kids watching this? Are we without any limits? Please...
Name: sonya

comment: This is what 50 looks when you are a millionaire.
Name: serg

comment: Amazing the younger generation of artists can pull huge crowds and dance w/o gyrating on stage wearing next to nothing. Seriously thought this was lame. Both are super talented and didn’t need to take it there.
Name: t

comment:
A woman "flaunting her age"? We really do need to change the cultural conversation. It's so centered on the socially ingrained male perspective  even a (female) writer in the Times can't see it.

We don't focus our attention on men's looks as they get older or say they're "flaunting their age." 

I'm a 58-year-old entrepreneur with more energy than most 20 year olds I know  male or female. Does that mean I'm flaunting my age or acting in an unusual way for an older woman? Or could it just mean that I'm a human being who's going strong  no matter my age or gender?

This sexist conversation  meanwhile  IS getting old.
Name: mary

comment:
Nobody has mentioned the political statement Ms. Lopez made opening the flag of Puerto Rico while her daughter sang "born in the USA."

There was more to the performance than the physicality.
Name: jasr

comment: Let's move beyond the obvious fact that Jennifer Lopez is attractive and a wonderful performer. What is troubling for me about the performance is the use of a stripper pole. Why is such a well received and athletic dancer and entertainer using this in her repertoire? Glamorizing and normalizing the exotic dancer industry is troubling. Many women (although not all) in this industry are trafficked  prostituted and in general vulnerable. As well we must consider that we are viewing Jennifer Lopez and evaluating her worth and assets  we do so as men and women in the context of our culture. Our society is one where women do not have true economic and educational equity. Women still receive the message in our culture that our primary worth is our sexual appeal. She is of course  beautiful and fit and a great performer  but our fascination and laudatory comments is more about our implicit approval of her fulfilling our society's ultimate role for women: sexually appealing beings.
Name: rb

comment: I am a bit over 50 and I am so glad that my job does not (and has never) involved revealing dress and pole dancing. I liked the performance - always really liked Shakira and the way her music gets a party going. However  I noted and so did the teenagers in the room  male and female  that none of the men wore such revealing outfits and the main male performers got away with baggy pants and shirts. Women  their beauty and their aging are held to very different  rather unachievable standards. And this is the message the young girls in our Superbowl party clearly got...a message that the professional older women and mothers  myself included  tried to counter. I hope it worked.
Name: kostja

comment: Completely disagree with the premise of this article. In reality  her look is actually counterproductive for feminism and makes any woman who doesn’t look that good at 50  suddenly more self-conscious. Her entire life is structured around her vanity. She has unlimited funds and resources to look as good as possible. Sure  she works out a lot I’m sure  but as any movie star who has to buff up for an upcoming role will tell you  if they had to do this alone while working a normal job  they never could. This whole discussion around how amazing she looks is counterproductive.
Name: jh

comment: These women are entertainers.  If you're looking for role models for your kids then you should look in the mirror.  I thought they shook it up and put it out there.  They looked genuinely happy and the dancing was spot on.  Football is about grown men beating each other for money and glory.  Far more offensive.
Name: maryrose

comment: I did not watch the half-time show. I know hardly anything about Jennifer Lopez. But I know one thing for sure: She is a good example of how eating right and exercising can keep you younger looking. Say what you will about her scanty wardrobe or suggestive movements -- she stands as a symbol of hope for the good that can come from eating right and exercising. If all women (and men) had the healthful habits that she has  what a wonderful world this would be!
Name: dan

comment: I just can't fathom why "empowerment" for women always equates to "wear as little as possible and be sexy." The more things change  the more they stay the same....
Name: weary

comment: Progress will finally be made when women do not feel compelled to mention their age and something amazing they are doing. Men have been doing this for centuries. And so have women.
Name: suzanne

comment:
This article is apparently supposed to be a compliment. Guess what  guys? Once many women reach 50  not to mention 45 or 40  they are thrilled-thrilled-thrilled to be considered invisible (except by waitstaff and other service people) and to stop trying to attract men by looking sexy. These outfits and this behavior do not represent some ideal of what "dressing like 50" means to women.  Does the NYT not even comprehend how sexist this attitude is?

Yeccch.
Name: greatermetropolitanarea

comment:
I'm kinda tired of people getting breathlessly excited at how good  extremely wealthy and pampered women can look - at any age  but especially older women.   Melania Trump  anyone?  Isn't she a great "example" of that?
Smoke and mirrors  folks.  Smoke and mirrors.
Name: sunandrain

comment: Gyrating  shaking  pouting  booty-pumping  pole-dancing  hair extension-tossing: it was all quite a vulgar spectacle of misguidedness and rampant pop culture idiocy. Perfect for the Super Bowl strangle hold on American "culture".
Name: kennethwmm

comment: I wanted to watch a game between two excellent teams. I didn't want to watch a vulgar display of nearly naked women  one of whom appeared to be touching herself. And the age is immaterial. Vulgar is vulgar.
Name: abbott

comment:
I find women in their 50s  60s and on up attractive because they look their age.  

As for the content of the performance  fits perfectly with everything going on around us.  Vulgar  shallow  hyper  empty.
Name: eliot

comment:
Sorry  but Taylor  Beyonce  JLo  Miley (and all of the other pantless performers)-- you are not empowered because you are hot and can prove it.  When you have to prove your value by looking or being sexual  when you have to get by on your looks at any level  you are in the same old trap.  Don't kid yourselves.  

And for the record  those super-hyped  over-choreographed performances?  It's not art.  It's commerce.
Name: ps

comment: I am man  and I was embarrassed by the objectification of women that the the half time show represented. So much for feminism.
Name: lens

comment:
"In the meantime  it’s worth pointing out that Ms. Lopez is currently fashion’s favorite celebrity  possessed of not just a Versace contract but two others (Coach and Guess). This is no small thing in an industry famously obsessed by youth."

Yes  it IS a small thing  of very little importance  really.
Name: deb

comment: Since when is "Bump and Grind" artistry? So disappointing! The heights of superficiality...
Name: christine

comment: It was an embarrassment for my daughter to have watched that   (although as a parent I have no one to blame for that but myself). I'm trying to raise her to be of the mindset that she's more than just her body but events like last night certainly don't help matters. The performance did nothing but boil the two singers down to their bodies  and followed up by the barrage of celebrating it because they're 50.
Name: david

comment: What exactly does a 50 year old female look like?  Lopez is a wealthy woman who spends an awful lot of time and money working on her appearance. Are we women supposed to be empowered by this?
Name: michele

comment: Not forgetting she’s very rich  pays for legions of professional support  her living is enmeshed with that physicality  and doesn’t have to endure 5 days a week 50 weeks a year stuck at a desk  computer screen  and putting up with yet more #1 train disruptions.
Name: spnyc

comment: Is anyone really shocked at the way Jennifer Lopez snd Shakira dressed last night?  The actresses attending various awards shows in the past few years have been wearing little and letting a lot of their skin show.  There is very little modesty left and there is no sense of leaving it to the imagination.  Call me old fashioned but I wish we had actresses and performers of years past.  They had style and good taste.  Those days are gone.
Name: kmw

comment: She looks amazing. But anyone who thinks she would look that way without a ton of $ for the work done is naive.
Name: nomad

comment: Way too much focus on the physical body. I'm glad she has hours to pursue physical fitness and can afford a personal chef. For the rest of us  its 40+ hours in the office and then a family to attend. She makes her money by looking good - its certainly not her songs or her voice.
Name: dave

comment: I watched about 25 seconds of this half time show.  Then I remembered I had Joni Mitchell's concert from the Isle of Wight on my dvr. I started watching Joni and my immediate reaction was "Ahhhhh....that's better."
Name: susan

comment: Just in case we needed to be reminded that our still IS a youth-dominated culture  we need to look closely at the gorgeous  gifted and talented J Lo. She indeed is amazing for 50 - but let's remind ourselves that her brand is (even more than her acting and singing prowess) her body. Caring for it and enhancing it through surgery and other processes/procedures so that she looks way younger than her age is a critical part of protecting that brand.  The average 50-year-old woman cannot compete for "the male gaze" with someone who has devoted years of her life to looking as young as humanly possible. So please  no more suggestions that the fashion industry is committing a stunning act by embracing J Lo's continuing beauty by dressing her in figure-revealing ("youthful " I guess) clothing. Their commercial interest in 99.99 percent women over 50 (indeed  over 40 or even over 35) is non-existent.
Name: celia

comment: I get it: Jennifer Lopez is an attractive performer and I can be a fan when I have time  but I missed her halftime show yesterday because I was teaching a bread making class. My work has me lifting 50 pound bags of flour and moving around equipment that is heavy and challenging. I sometimes prep 200 pounds of dough before a class  and for the class I am on my feet all day  at least 10 hours  always moving. I wear a t-shirt  apron  hair pulled back  no makeup. I could not be more proud of my work and the ability to do it  and I think it's the energy I feel about that fact  not how I look  that is the real attraction and power here. I am 65.
Name: sarah

comment: I often wonder what someone like Ella Fitzgerald would have to do to be the a half-time performer at the SB?
Name: bob

comment:
She can show off her body anywhere and it will be all over social media. So what.  I am not interested in watching her run through 20 second segments of her greatest hits  choruses only  while frenetic dancing occurs.
Same for Shakira.
