Put a single entity (a new FEMA Office) in charge of providing supplies for this pandemic.

Following Rep. Slotkin's theme.... Let's take FEMA folks from other FEMA offices  divisions and branches and staff this office now. 

A key first step is finding the right leaders to take on the herculean tasks this new FEMA office would have to solve. Put folks in charge of this office who've managed big  complex projects that involve difficult engineering problems.

Our defense department - our military forces - has systems already in place to manage large supply needs. Find the best leaders who are currently leading our defense logistics and put them in charge of this new FEMA office. That would go a long way towards solving this problem.

During WW2  General Marshall managed this function for our armed forces and really got the job done under herculean effort and under unbelievable stress. Find the General Marshall's of today  put them on this  give them the tools to work  and get out of the way.

This new office must also tighten numbers on critical equipment and protective gear needed to tackle this pandemic. Hospital associations and CDC can help on that. 

Once formed  this new FEMA office can work with American industry to develop separate plans on how industry will manufacture the critical equipment and protective gear that we need.

Get moving Trump. Get moving America.

comment:

This piece states that Trump is "confronting a pandemic". He's not  he's exploiting it. Trump's attacks on women are constant not just because he hates women  but because misogyny is an effective political tool throughout America.

However  lost on Trump is that it is not working here. The excellent leadership of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in fighting the covid-19 pandemic has led to her popularity rising over 20 points to 65%. Trump's vitriol  and Whitmer refusing to even address it  has not hurt her popularity at all.

In contrast  Trump rose a mere 5 points to 48%. It's unprecedentedly bad for a crisis of this magnitude  (George H. W. Bush jumped 35 points at the beginning of the Iraq War)  and poll analyst Harry Enten explained Trump's meager bump came "from non-voters". As FiveThirtyEight shows  Trump's already fallen to 45%.

Trump's not just totally incompetent  he's a true psychopathic narcissist. His signature traits are his absolute affection for himself  his forever trying to pretend he's far more than he is  his always expecting compliments from others  his blaming others for his constant deficiencies and failures  and finally  his total disregard for the welfare and lives of others.

Whitmer is doing everything possible to save American lives. Trump grotesquely brags that if 200 000 Americans die  it's a triumph for him. If a million die  he'll still say he won.

It’s important to note that Democratic officials in New York  including Mayor de Blasio  encouraged New Yorkers to go about their daily lives as they normally would. comment:
Let us not forget the he reserves his greatest obsession for President Obama  Chancellor Merkel and Senator Warren. A successful black predecessor  a successful world leader and a poignant critic whose legacy (consumer protection) he relishes undoing.

As Bob Woodward has pointed out  Trump wants fear to fill the very air. Not to mention fealty and one-way loyalty. It is readily apparent he sees the tools and supplies needed to save American lives as means to obtain these ends. His incessant self-promotion and insecurity take center stage at his daily celebrations of self as the death toll multiplies cruelly. I wonder how many times Governor Cuomo (forced to state he in no political rival) has seethed walking a tightrope because flattery is required toward the personification of dysfunction  incompetence and the bottomless needs of a narcissist. Why are we still surprised he responds like a petulant child  unable to fulfil the requirements of an office that demands the best of an adult?

He has surrounded himself with people who play this game rather than serve as sober counterweights. I believe the cabinet should invoke the 25th amendment. Because we live in a system that will not trigger an election when no confidence is declared  we are stuck with the needs of a child for adoration in the place of mature leadership this crisis so desperately demands.

Biden needs his staff to fact check Trump's nonsense and correct the record so that Americans can hear the truth.  Biden's "missing in action" routine will result in Trump kicking his keister in November (that is  if there's  even an election).

By emphasizing that 2.2 million Americans might die if the gov't. did nothing  he can claim "victory" if only 100 000 perish because of his initial incompetence.  (Remember during the 2016 campaign that Trump told Americans he would be "too busy" to play golf.  For the next 3 years after his election  Trump played at being president on the rare occasions when he wasn't aimlessly riding around in a golf cart.  He was too busy being on the links to forge the links necessary to unite a first rate pandemic response team.)

And now Trump is suddenly magnanimous in giving others in his administration credit for the coronavirus response.  This is sheer brilliance.  If anyone attacks Trump's dereliction of duty  he now accuses the accuser of insulting not him--but everyone else in gov't.  When 100 000 people are about to die  Trump can't ride his cart fast enough away from responsibility.

Democrats beware.  This is not going to end well if things don't change...right now.

comment: Hey don’t forget Fox fires the women first too. Trump is in a Fox anti-women feedback loop/echo chamber.
Name: sw

comment:
The big issue that Trump takes any criticism personally. It makes him lashes out at that person.  He is wired that way  expect it and be amused by it. Time to move on.  
This reaction to questions  enables him to not answer the question and distracts the listener to the issues posed by the question.
Thus Trump becomes the dumbest person in the room.
Name: thomas

comment:
Trump is toxic. 
He must go.
Name: lizinsarasota

userName: Right week to start sniffing glue
comment: Give it a rest; Trump attacks everyone - black  white  Cuban and Asian - man or woman doesn't matter.

comment: Trump's misogyny is -- if this is remotely epidemiological  forgive me -- all over the map.  And it is THE reason he should never have been elected  and THE reason we have to defeat him in November.  Remember the old typing-class prompt:  "Now is the time for all good men..."  Let's retype:  Now is the time for all good human beings in this country to bring this sexist  bigoted  racist  xenophobic  charlatanic tyrant to his knees.
Name: muskrat

comment: Simple.  He hates women.  The nasty comments on the pre-election tape proved it.  He specially  hates intelligent women like Pelosi and Alcindor.  He didn’t get much sophistication from his fancy degrees.  Wharton School  e.g.

comment: Even Nikky Haley has abandoned Trump!
Name: john

comment: You have screamed for more women in positions of power  people in power get attacked more often then others. Where is the problem  are they a special class?
Name: ted

comment: I live in Michigan and voted for Whitmer.  She is doing a great job.  She declared a state of emergancy (allowing expanded executive powers) the first day we had a positive Coronavirus case.  She shut down schools four days later.  Whitmer's approval in the state remains high.  In 2018 female Democrats swept the top offices (Governor  Attorney General and Secretary of State) in Michigan.  Women also flipped two House Congressional seats from red to blue and male to female. My prediction before the pandemic was that Michigan was going to be hard for Trump to win.  I feel that his attacks on Whitmer and Mary Barra of GM just strengthen that position.
Name: bookandcatlover

comment:
“Look at that face! Would anybody vote for that?”   Trump referring on debate stage to Carly Fiorina who at the time was running for President.  

This is what the party of Lincoln has turned into?  The Republican Party needs to be repudiated at the polls.  My grandmother and mother fought hard for women rights and to watch it taken away in 3 years just isn't right.  We not only need to repudiate the Republicans we need to revive and pass the ERA.
Name: hl

comment:
He attacks what he fears.  The more fierce the attack  the greater his fear. He has gotten away with this for years because it has been mistaken for strength  as being powerful--at least by people who do the same thing or wish they could. It can be intimidating  it can be harmful  but it's fake.  He lacks authenticity  which requires a feeling of connection with others. 

So be fearless  be authentic.
Name: kathleen

comment:
I always find myself wondering why we never hear a word about Trump's relationship with his mother  or  actually  anything about his mother at all.

My own grandmother once gave me a piece of advice:  never get involved with a man who had a troubled  relationship with his mother.  I didn't always heed it  but she was right.

Alas  we are all in an insupportable union with this President  and now we are paying for it with our lives.
Name: concerned

comment:
“Every knock from him is a boost for me  quite frankly  so I don’t care what he says ” says Pelosi.  

She seems to be on the same reality show as Trump.   It's about ratings.
Name: ross

comment: Another line of attack against Trump  that he is against women leaders. Trump attacked those women because they deserved it as they said and acted stupid things. Just for example  Pelosi was impeaching the president when the pandemic was spreading in China and she said recently that Trump fiddles  while people die. Can you imagine a more disgusting statement from any leader than this?
Name: alex

comment: Left off the list is Dr. Linda Quick  the American medical epidemiologist embedded in China’s disease control agency  who  according to Reuters  learned her position was being eliminated as of last September. The virus emerged in November.

comment: All of this proves vividly again that Trump is unfit for office.  He is our 'employee' and as they wonderful old saying goes (thanks Harry)...'If you can't stand the heat  get out of the kitchen'.

comment:
I have one question for any woman (or man) that would vote for Trump.

comment: My husband was so offended and angry when he listened to Trump tell Yamiche Alcindor she was nasty. I told him now he knows a little bit about the rage women have felt their whole lives when men tell them to smile more  not to raise their voices and not to stand strong for themselves and others.
Name: sherry

comment: God bless Pelosi. I don't listen to a word he says either.
Name: jo

comment: We women know this guy. I say this guy without a scintilla of respect for him. We have known his type our whole lives and there will never  ever be a change in his attitude towards women. It’s a gut punch that he is the President of the United States.
Name: karin

comment: Yes  often Trump's criticism targets women.  Otherwise  Trump's criticism targets men.
Name: david

comment:
Safe to say that Republican men (and most Republicans are men) have wives  sisters  mothers and daughters.  Can they look at these women they love in the eye and still support Trump?  At heart  he wants a society out of The Handmaid's Tale.  Is that what they want?  

And Republican women  who may like his message on rolling back government regulation or appointing conservative judges.  Do they want their standing in society to be pushed back by 100 years?

He has not hidden who or what he is.  Remember in November.
Name: pat

comment: The defense from the women in Trump’s life cited in this article is that he’s actually equally despicable toward all people.  Well  isn’t that nice.
Name: david

comment:
Let's not forget the footage of Trump pacing behind Hillary Clinton.  There isn't a man alive who doesn't know what message that sends  and I'd venture a guess there isn't a woman alive who has failed to understand the meaning.  It's primal  as is much of what Trump does  and in his case reads as a compulsive  heightened need to dominate.  

Clinton later said she had been creeped out by Trump's pacing. Oh to to have seen her call him out for that  right then and there.
Name: ps

comment: @kevincarey1 Thanks for the article. With less tenure why has the cost of university education gone up so much - less public $ and for-profit influence? Whose getting the money - administration?
Name: bhodi

comment:
Forcing 75% of the courses to be taught by someone with "tenure" won't change much when there are 5-10 times as many PhDs produced as there are jobs in universities. 

As it is  many tenured professors are secretly poor. The universities know that the professor isn't going to get another job with a lifetime contract and so they lowball the salary increases. Tenure is really another way to take advantage of the professoriate. 

Now if Bernie insisted that 80+% of the college employees teach classes  that might be a real change. Anything to get rid of the administrators.
Name: no

comment: CUNY Ph.D in English 2009. I got a lucky break and did admin work for a year. Started working at a U in Canada that had a terrible reputation but good funding. Was made department chair (with admin responsibilities) then given a full-time position. Now the university is growing and my full time pay is near that of my local peers. With admin experience my job is much more secure and the pay is better. I got lucky  yes  but this was what I had to do to survive.
Name: hazlit

comment: Nowhere does this mention the explosion of administrative jobs. While faculty positions remain flat  the ranks of associate  vice  and assistant administrators has mushroomed.
Name: dave

comment: This is not news.  I finished a PhD at Chicago in 1975 with a short-term job then another short-term job that somehow lasted 14 years.  With the final end  there were programs leading into "real world" employment that really worked while I could still do some scholarship on the side  which expanded greatly after "retiring."  A humanities doctorate is a calling  not a guaranteed employment entry  and it has been that way for a very long time.
Name: bruce

comment: Here is what I know about the financial stability of teaching at universities for most people. I was suddenly faced with a divorce in my 50's. I told friends that I planned to take a job teaching high school. Many were shocked and critical : " But you are qualified to teach at the college level and it is higher status. " I said : " And they are mostly hiring adjuncts and there are no health or retirement benefits . They might pay me $8 000 per class to work quite hard and it is absolutely not enough to live on." I could see  on balance  where I was better off. And it is also my observation that for the most part secondary school teachers are more supportive of their colleagues because there is such fierce competition for any tenure track position. It's very sad. I come from a family of academics at such institutions as the University of Michigan  M.I. T.  University of Texas. I am concerned about what this portends for academic freedom and an atmosphere of inquiry in the humanities and sciences.
Name: consuelo

comment:
Maybe the real scandal is that universities are ready  willing  and able to take these students' money to give the PhD while knowing their will be little market for their services.  

Meanwhile  contemporary English Departments seem to have more in common with Mao's Cultural Revolution than learning about literature and writing.
Name: rob

comment: Tuition soars and Universities cut faculty expenses by hiring low paid Adjuncts.  Where does the money go?  That is the real scandal.
Name: bob

comment: Having worked at two colleges in my lifetime  one private and now a public  I can point to an increase in non-teaching professionals that has likely mirrored the decrease in tenured faculty.  Counselors  tutors  disability specialists  accreditation  assessment and diversity administrators  et al.  have taken FTE lines across higher education.  The needs of the recent generations of students outside of the classrooms have to some degree lessened their needs in the classroom.  At the same time expenses have increased to simply keep the doors open for the next generation.  It is not surprising that academia has found one of the few areas where they can control costs.
Name: bill

comment: All phenomena except one have been well described. Could you please add the dizzying increase in administrators as an additional factor that pushed for less permanent faculty lines?
Name: findout

comment: Been there  done that as a graduate and undergraduate adjunct in social work. The most scandalous being the couuple  both tenured  pulling in $100k each who dialed it in  showing up to teach about once or twice a week ostensibly because they were writing a book. I picked up the slack  some weeks even advising students. This I did for five years (12 total) while maintaining a private practice.What killed me and sent me packing was the fact many of the students were the first in their family to go to college  some taking on far too much debt for what they were not getting in return. My old timer father  a Navy man who made sure every one of us got an education saw right through it all  until finally I did too. I miss the students though. Wish it were different on so many levels.
Name: no

comment: Don't become a teacher/professor at a university; they are underpaid laborers.  Aim high: administrator or  if you're really lucky  football coach.  That's where the money goes.
Name: pat

comment:
I am a 34 year veteran of college classrooms - 10 years as an adjunct and 24 as a tenure-track faculty member. Two quick observations based on my experience.

1. The huffing and puffing I hear about wildly liberal professors indoctrinating naive undergraduates is just that - huffing and puffing. Academia can be just as vicious and cruel as life in the private sector (where I spent 11 years). No one should kid themselves - academia is a business similar to other businesses - sharp elbows and all.

2.  Just because someone can continue teaching beyond 70 does not mean they should. I have encountered many faculty members over the years who continued working well past their "sell by" date. I do not intend on being one of them - the eccentric old guy with uncombed hair  a wild beard  ill-fitting clothes standing in front of a class with my fly unzipped because I forgot to check. I always tell my students that should this ever come to pass  they should lead me out to the campus quad and do to me what they do to old horses.
Name: lucien

comment: One point: prestigious universities privilege research over teaching and service.  Isn't that unfortunate for the hundreds of thousands of students signing up for classes hoping they''ll have a good educational experience?  It shows how screwed up academia truly is.
Name: lev

comment:
The current system is basically tenure or adjunct.  A new category would be nice – the multi-year teaching contract. 

Tenure and tenure-track jobs demand research  which creates the publish-or-perish problem.  Young tenure-track profs emphasize publication over teaching.  Most of the publications produced are not only superfluous navel gazing  they are also immature  unreadable sophomoric drivel wrapped up in post-modern gobble-dee-gook.  The act of teaching is where a scholar learns how to test and communicate ideas.  Teaching = bad.

The adjuncts have a different set of problems.  For starters  ObamaCare requires that employers give health benefits to anyone teaching more than approx. 2 classes (based on a difficult-to-translate equation).  As a result  the bastions of liberalism (colleges) won't hire adjuncts to teach more than 2 classes at a time.  So adjuncts must cobble together contracts from multiple employers.  Some colleges still pay as little as $3500 per class.  So if an adjunct teaches 4/4/2 (fall  spring  summer)  that could work out to $35 000 per year before taxes with absolutely no benefits  no travel expenses  no office  sometimes no reliable access to Xerox machines and infrastructure  leading to personal office supply expenses.  Not to mention that a 4/4/2 teaching schedule is outrageously excessive if you try to do a good job.  And  once you are an adjunct you can effectively say goodbye to a tenure track job.  Who can publish while teaching 4/4/2?
Name: rosebud

comment:
If you are paying for your own PhD  you shouldn't be getting a PhD. Graduate programs are cash cows for universities  and higher education is very much a business. Paying for administrative bloat costs a ton of money. 

Most reputable STEM programs offer tuition waivers and stipends for teaching and research  much less so with humanities programs. That should give you a clue to your market value.

Maybe it's time for that "retire at 70" to be put back in place.Professors still interested in teaching can step down to adjunct level to make room for the next generation.
Name: midwest

comment: As an English Ph.D. student in her first year  this conversation is nothing new. Many Ph.D. programs across the country are starting to train Ph.D. students for the non-academic job market. I'm not getting my Ph.D. to make money; I'm doing it because I love the subject  environment  and opportunities I have to interact with bright undergraduate students and fellow grad students.
Name: lauren

comment:
Several commenters have wondered why  given high enrollments and increased tuition revenues  universities found themselves relying on cheap adjunct labor to staff courses.

In the realm of public institutions  the reason is simple: many states are no longer subsidizing education as they have in the past. In the past  80% of the UW system budget was funded by state tax dollars  and the rest was derived by very modest tuition. This is much of the reason why previous generations of students could self-fund their educations with summer work and perhaps a campus job during the academic year.

Now  only 20% of the university budget is supported by the state  forcing extreme competition for increased enrollments and tuition dollars. This competition  in turn  is driving universities to lure students in with increased amenities (cushy housing  scholarships  athletics facilities  extracurriculars  students clubs  etc.)  which further bloat the budgets. 

Did I mention the coming enrollment cliff? Birth rates dipped sharply around 2007  so there will be fewer students in 2025  and hence reduced tuition revenue. It's not a good idea to create new tenure lines now  as most schools will be facing major budget cuts in five years  before the newly hired can secure tenure. 

Guess who probably will get hired in the meantime? More adjuncts.

It's madness  and the lone institution that dares to break the cycle will likely perish.
Name: jd

comment:
Well 
No where in this article is it mentioned that while the number of poorly paid adjuncts has increased and in most campuses the number of tenured faculty have decreased. The number of overpaid administrators has increased exponentially.

Our Department would love to hire more tenure-track faculty. But we are constantly told  by the legion of Admins  paid many multiples that of a new faculty salary  that there is no money.

Yes there are demographic issues  but the rise of Administrative Class and their love of cheap adjuncts is the real problem.
Name: liza

comment: Adjunctification is everywhere in academia -- not just the humanities. In the sciences  for instance  you have people working post-docs (post-PhD temp jobs in labs and/or on research grants) for many years while searching for a permanent job. One of my colleagues was a post-doc for 10 years before finally landing a tenure-track job...and that was only after he had published dozens of articles and secured several million dollars in federal grants.
Name: j

comment: I suspect this writer knows very little about how colleges and universities hire based on the fact that they don't mention lecturers at all. It is very common nowadays for departments to have a limited number of tenured professors and then a whole stable of "lecturers". These aren't adjuncts  but are contracted employees with benefits. They are usually on 1 to 3-year contracts  but are basically considered full-time department members with contract renewals taken as a given. At my old flagship state U  there was 1 tenured prof and 4 lecturers in my department. The lecturers all had their own offices and participated in departmental administration as FT employees. They taught both intro and advanced courses. These types of positions  along with adjuncts  are becoming more and more common. Sometimes they have other titles  like "Assistant Professor of the Practice of [Field]" or "Master Teacher" or something  but they are all basically contracted lecturers.
Name: kas

comment:
Supply and demand -- nothing more than that.

The academic marketplace was awful fifty years ago when I earned my doctorate in history. After a temporary appointment I gave up on Academia and prospered in business. In my sixties I became an adjunct at a state university. But. being an adjunct is not a career -- it is a short-term paycheck  an interesting gig and a chance to work with young people. It is a job that leads nowhere.

Graduate degrees in the Humanities are in vast over-supply and those who enter PhD programs know this. Those who knowingly seek work that is poorly paid  insecure and demeaning will find themselves poorly paid  insecure and demeaned. It is their funeral and they chose it.

On the positive side  adjuncts reduce the cost of education. They are the braceros in the academic vineyard. The rest of society benefits from exploiting their talents -- and why not?

If you feel mistreated as an adjunct then do something else for a living. If you "really love" your subject and only feel at home on a campus then suck it up.

There is no tragedy here -- just an imbalance between supply and demand. It happens frequently in life.
Name: observer

comment: I am an adjunct at a prestigious non-profit college that has been around for over 100 years.  I just taught a class on Saturday. I had 21 students who paid $3100 for my class. Masters level. The school is going to get almost $70 000 in tuition for the class.  I am paid $5000.  No benefits. Not even the ability to take classes for free. I have a doctorate and a decade of experience teaching. My evals are all good. I have a full time job on top of this because there is no way I could live on what I make teaching. Would my students have a better experience with someone full time? Absolutely.  Where does all the money go?  I dont know.
Name: the

comment:
The most general purpose of education is to exercise. sharpen and enlarge the mind.  It produces a mind that is better for all sorts of purposes.  A doctorate in the humanities is a good thing.  But the new doctor doesn't have to get an academic job at a university--there are other interesting things to do.  A job outside academia is not such a terrible thing.

On another subject  the article traces the number of tenured and non-tenured faculty at universities over the years.  It would be nice to see the number of administrators  too.
Name: b

comment: True enough and fair enough  but not a mention of how republican hatred for government and education  and Democrat pusillanimity have contributed to the problem.
Name: michael

comment:
At this point  academe does not deserve the best talent. 

Bad pay  poor working conditions  and no job security for adjuncts has been the norm for decades. It is an exploitative system and you and your life deserve better. 

There is no room for idealism. It will be your downfall. It is a sold bag of goods with no substance. A culture of idealism among young scholars and a culture of dismal neoliberal economics among central administrators (who are often failed academics).  If guided by idealism alone you will overly extend yourself and be assured  the institutions of higher learning will take all that you give.
Name: gr

comment: I'm a tenured professor at the University of Denver. I'm planning on working till I am 70 at least. Defined benefit retirement plans are gone. Volatility in the market place makes retiring on social security and a 401K plan more uncertain. We have an 'average' TIAA/CREF sort of retirement plan that is really inadequate. This article does not cover everything but I have to agree that what is does cover is pretty right on. In our department we hire full time 'Teaching Faculty' that get offices and benefits but lower pay with no shot at tenure. They have minimal research expectations. It is better than adjunct exploitation. I would prefer we all be called assistant associate and full professors on tenure track with differing responsibilities. I like the idea of more full-time on campus colleagues with an office. The culture of universities is changing for the worse. The neo-liberal university is upon us and this is a road to idiocracy: https://www.dailycamera.com/2017/03/04/paul-c-sutton-the-road-to-idiocracy/
Name: paul

comment:
As a long-time  tenured faculty member at a community  I beg my young (and not-so-young) adjunct friends  find another career now. Your chances of getting a full-time position—anywhere—are slim  and the prospects for better treatment (wages  job security  health or retirement benefits) are slim. Higher education is in trouble in a variety of ways  and you'd do well to find another way of supporting yourself for the next 20-40 years. 

And there's the fact that if more of you walk away from this exploitative and immoral employment arrangement  conditions might improve for adjuncts. Not by much  I suspect  but maybe a little.
Name: fred

comment:
Tenured faculty are the least problem here. The most significance rise by far has been in the proliferation of assistant deans  deputy assistant deans  legions of diversity and development coordinators  lawyers  entire departments dedicated to promotion and fundraising  enormous buildings.  Decision making has by and large been transferred from the faculty to the administration. 

Administrators of course love overcapacity.  

Having said this  pursuing a Humanities  ethnic or MFA degrees today is  irresponsible  unless you have a trust fund.
Name: kai

comment: Oh  please  New York Times  this article perpetuates the most facile stereotypes of tenured professors  most of whom themselves struggled through long periods of underpaid post-doc and adjunct positions before being hired on the tenure track. The tenured faculty at the university where I taught were strong advocates for improved adjunct pay and working conditions  and for the hiring of permanent faculty.  This was resisted by administrators (whose salaries were double that of tenured faculty) in the interest of cost-saving. These administrators justify their positions to trustees (who are business people  not academics) by reducing faculty costs.  Unfortunately  when tenured faculty retire  it is not uncommon for administrators to cut that tenure-track line. As society has come to see education not as a way to understand the world more deeply  but in terms of the salary gain that it will produce for graduates  it is not surprising that cost-effectiveness becomes a primary concern in hiring -- the logic of money rules.
Name: paloma

comment:
In the Humanities  politics is central to the work of almost all high-profile scholars  but rarely are those scholars' politics evaluated with regard to their support of adjunct rights.  

If professional organizations refused to hold conferences at colleges that do not provide health benefits or allow unionization of their adjuncts; if tenured professors made an effort to include adjunct scholars in every professional panel and journal publication; and if support of adjunct rights was a litmus test for the real politics of those in the profession  I suspect that momentum for addressing the economic injustices of adjunctification might begin to shift in a more substantial way.

It's not about more tenure-track jobs  it's about supporting the adjuncts who are already the educators keeping higher education humming along.
Name: r

comment:
Dont worry  there will always be associate vice president for ... or senior associate dean of... Each of these positions will come with a generous salary (often 2x that of tenured professors)  spending allowance for "conference travel"  and assistants. 
The blight of administrative bloat continues unabated.
Name: newton

comment:
After 30 years in higher education  I can only say this: 

I am very glad that my son and my daughter chose careers outside of academia. 

They are happier and more settled than I ever was at their age.
Name: rmm

comment: I completed an undergraduate in Classics and begun a graduate program studying Latin and ancient Greek (at an Ivy League college) in 2009.  I had a wise (tenured) professor advise me to drop out  he indicated that there wouldn't be a job for me when I received a PHD.  I went back to school and got a degree in Computer Science - I had a six figure job offer three months before I graduated (in 2013).  As it turned out the learning processes I had accumulated during my study of ancient languages helped me immensely as an engineer.  After seven years of experience I now earn 300k a year.  My dream: to make enough money to support myself and my family  go back and finish my PHD in Classics (my real love)  however  I have no expectation of earning any money in academia...
Name: richard

comment: I helped lead a small movement of 30 or so lecturers in 1981 at the U. of NH. We were all teaching English comp and none of us had medical insurance. Guess what  we won! It can be done but you have to organize and fight. We have regressed to the 1920s in regard to labor organization. Workers of America  it's time to turn up the heat again!
Name: jeff

comment:
The humanities labor market has been in crisis since  at least  1990 -- that's when I was first considering graduate school. At my undergraduate university (top 15  private) beloved and well-published humanities professors were being denied tenure; the sociology dept was being closed; all the funding was flowing to the business and medical schools. It hasn't gotten any better. But this started a long time ago.

The bigger issue is that universities have done a poor job explaining to Americans (Europeans don't have this problem...I'm not sure about elsewhere) how a humanities education has value -- when "value" is only assumed to mean monetary value. As if that could be calculated..... It's shocking how many college students think that majoring in business will better prepare them to work in the corporate world. Please  go learn to think critically about complex things like: works of art  literature  cinema; history  its processes and motivations; anthropology  geology  and how societies and our surroundings became the way they are. This will help prepare you for the corporate world far better than getting a degree in business or economics.

Until the universities do a better job of explaining that  this crisis will continue.
Name: james

comment: I am an adjunct. We have good benefits and fairly ok pay for one reason: we have a union that represents both us and the full time faculty. That is obviously a conflict of interest. However  one of the unanticipated benefits of the Supreme Court’s Janus decision is that if our union doesn’t deliver for us  we can cease paying dues and still work. Once that occurred  the union all of a sudden prioritized our interests instead of the full time faculty  and we received a substantial raise. I would also like to point out that while the overall percentage of university money devoted to teaching has remained flat since the 1970’s  the money spent on administration and administrative salaries has soared. Universities may pose as redoubts of ‘social justice’ - but they are in fact profit maximizing corporations whose gains go to the administrative class. Of course I could get another job if I wanted to- I’m not in the humanities. But I like teaching and I’m doing ok  so I’m not complaining- just explaining the reality.
Name: aaron

comment:
This is how we treat our best and brightest. When I went to college (1978) all of my professors were tenured and conducted research and/or wrote books  articles  etc.  It seem weird that college costs are three or ten times more expensive then when I attended  yet they are saving millions by employing poverty sticking adjunct professors or grad students.

Today  everything is about saving money. IBM  for example  now has half of its workforce in India.
Name: kb

comment:
There ought to be laws against predatory lending and they ought to be applied to higher education. 

How many starry-eyed kids have enrolled in $70 000-a-year programs in film directing or videography -- when the entry level jobs on actual movie sets pay absolutely NOTHING and there might be 1 actual paying job for every 10 graduates.

It's the same story with second-tier law schools who happily enrolled tens of thousands of students at $60 000 a year knowing full well that most of them would never land a job that paid enough to pay back their loans.

And graduate humanities might be the worst of all. Everybody knows it's been a Ponzi scheme for the last 30-40 years. 

My father was an English professor so I certainly respect what English professors do  but it is unconscionable to enroll graduate students for 3 to 5 years of student loans to get training in literary criticism. You're balancing your departmental budget by consigning these poor people to a lifetime of indentured servitude.
Name: tom

comment:
The Upshot calls Senator Sanders' proposal "a highly unusual federal intrusion" on universities that would "probably be attacked by the higher education lobby. "

A federal intrusion?  Most American students are educated in public universities created by the federal government's land grant college legislation.  Most research at universities is funded by the federal government.  Many undergraduates receive a substantial portion of their scholarships through federal sources.

So what "highly unusual intrusion" is The Upshot talking about?

The truth is that American universities would dearly love to have vastly more federal funding  and would benefit tremendously from Sanders' free college tuition.  And let's make clear that most developed countries on the planet offer free  or almost free  tuition to their students.

Nothing radical.  No dangerous "intrusion."  Just what the rest of the world's students enjoy as a right.
Name: sean

comment: I am one of those PhD's left outside the gates. And one of the worst parts of not being able to do what I feel a vocation to do is trying to explain to non-academic friends and family that there really is a crisis going on in the universities. Popular perception is that the kids are still going to college: things must be going ok.
Name: thomas

comment: The academic job market has been rough for decades  especially for humanities. Any intelligent  educated student should be able to do some trivial research to determine whether a PhD is worth the opportunity cost. Hint: it is not. Foreign students use a PhD as a credential to get a job in the US. For Americans it is not worth attending a grad program that is below top 10 in your field. Even then the odds of getting a tenure track position are low. Adjunct teachers always have the option of just getting a job.
Name: lincoln

comment:
This leaves out so much  including the fact that professors who teach in undergraduate institutions (e.g.  liberal arts colleges) have no graduate students and teach all the courses  at all levels  themselves. 

Why don't we retire? One very important reason is that these days humanities professors who retire are NOT being replaced.  It's a gross distortion to paint tenured professors who don't retire as selfish for holding onto jobs instead of letting the younger folks have a chance. All too often  what happens is what happened in my case. I retired at age 64  and the college chose NOT to replace me at all  not with an adjunct  not with anyone. My department went from 3 faculty to 2 faculty  had to cut the courses I had taught entirely  had to restructure (i.e.  weaken) its major  and is now vulnerable to being disbanded entirely for not being "productive" enough. 

Had I known that the administration would treat my department this way  I would never have retired. I would have worked until I died.  I genuinely thought that I was opening up a position for a younger scholar. I genuinely thought I was doing a good thing for my department. And the administrators led me to believe those things  in conversations we had about my retirement. Only two months AFTER I had signed the non-revocable retirement agreement did the administration announce that my position would not be replaced.
Name: meoregon

comment:
There's an essential underlying problem in academia that this article fails to discuss: the declining value in the "real world" of a degree in the humanities  especially an advanced degree - a masters or a Ph.D.

In an era now gone with the wind  a liberal arts education included familiarity with important  and complex  literature.  One had to concentrate and think about what the words on the page meant.

Writing was also taught  and writing referred to more than 140 or 280 character tweets.  Good writing was meant to be insightful  original  and usually grammatically correct.

Unfortunately  today things have changed.  Political correctness and groupthink are not merely acceptable  they are often mandatory.  A single out-of-the-box statement can derail a career  and hours must be spent to ensure that appropriate trigger warnings are provided in coursework.  The popular majors are those that focus on identity politics and victimization.

All this has served to thoroughly devalue a liberal arts degree.  It is this sea change that accounts for much of the decline in the job market for holders of advanced degrees.

To me  and many others  this is all very unfortunate  but it is the new normal.  My best advice: consider a STEM education.
Name: alex

comment: But let's be clear. The job market for humanities PhDs is bleak  but the market for faculty in engineering  science  business and medicine is still strong. It's just supply and demand. There's a good job market for the latter outside of a academia - that's the difference.
Name: grover

comment: Graduates of top doctoral programs have always gone on in the main to teach at much less prestigious institutions  although almost everyone dreams of beating the odds and a very few do.  But in every other regard the situation has gotten steadily worse since the 1970s  except for a handful of well-paid stars.  Part of the problem is that we no longer value truth or the information upon which a civic society is built.  Training people to think matters less and less.  College administrators have tolerated the "critical" approaches of their humanities faculty as long as they have absolutely no impact on the way in which their institutions are actually run.  In many European countries many of the overflow doctorates would get good jobs teaching secondary school as well as working in journalism and many other areas  but these degrees are not valued by American employers  including high schools.
Name: kate

comment:
The one aspect of this debacle that is missing from this otherwise comprehensive and thoughtful reporting: 
Higher education’s turn to consulting firms  which ended up corporatizing the university—and its downstream effects on the problem of academic labor supply/demand.
One highly encouraged practice is to not renew tenure lines in humanities departments when tenured professors retire. 
So many departments are undergoing an organic process of attrition  with the effect of a consequent reduction of tenure opportunities for the glutted market over time.
Name: lauren

comment: The solution is simple. Universities must limit the number of graduate students they recruit  based on their recent history of placements--and they must provide this information to their prospective graduate students. While graduate departments are busily providing alternative career training--which should be a red flag to their students and should be questioned since these faculty do not know anything much about alt/ac careers--what departments should be doing is either closing down their grad programs or reducing grad student admission to the average number of grad students per class who land tenure-track jobs. When demand for PhDs goes up  so too will the inducements.
Name: valerie

comment: I am an adjunct  and I want to thank you for bringing this issue to light. Politicians talk much about teacher salaries  but almost never mention this nightmare scenario. I agree with many of the comments below. It's not the fault of the tenured professors  but rather the administrators who get paid double and create these Draconian conditions. Ph.D's who hold adjunct positions cannot afford even the cheapest of apartments and often have to live with others. You are told that you have to publish more and more in order to get non-existent jobs to pay off your looming student loans. I myself am in this position as are many of my friends and colleagues. The stress level is so high that some have suffered physical and mental breakdowns  and without health insurance most are unable to see doctors. Is this the cost of a liberal education in America? Our universities are literally devouring their most gifted offspring. The callousness and greed is really difficult to imagine and it has to stop.
Name: brian

comment: As a Baby Boomer attorney who majored in humanities as an undergraduate  I offer the following advice to new college students.  Major in a field that has decent employment prospects and then learn on your own what gives you passion.  I never studied Russian literature  but over the last 40 years I have self-educated myself in this field and think I have knowledge comparable to a Master graduate.
Name: james

comment: What Bernie Sanders and the left ignore is that we have a student debt crisis because the universities can charge whatever they want and get paid by students who just borrow more.  The schools (and their faculty and administrators) have a huge financial interest and its reflected in tuition rates that have skyrocketed versus inflation. It's almost criminal that the universities encourage students  especially those in the humanities  to borrow with abandon and essentially leave school with few prospects and the equivalent of a mortgage hanging over their heads.
Name: paul

comment:
When I went to grad school for my PhD  I never imagined that it would be nearly impossible to obtain a professorship  and that I would be left to swing in the wind for nearly a decade before my colleagues decided if I was worthy of receiving tenure.  It was a hard lesson and one I pass on to my children now.

Do not go to graduate school unless it is a calling to you and you can't imagine doing anything else.  If it is not a calling  get a degree in an area with excellent job prospects and a good salary.  School is a financial decision that will have repercussions for the rest of your life.  


Same for choosing a grad school.  Make sure there are spots for you and you have a source of income that is sufficient to support you during your graduate career.  I had to choose a far less than satisfactory major professor because only they had grant money and were willing to accept me as a student in their lab.  

Always remember the financial and quality of life decisions when you considered both undergraduate and grad school.
Name: desire

comment:
As someone who has been a professor for 30 years (in a tenured position and as an adjunct)  I'd like to add another perspective:

Get rid of the tenure system. It's the nexus of the problems in the profession.

Tenure forces colleges to retain faculty who:
- might not be particularly good teachers.
- might be burned out  coasting to retirement  or feel protected enough to no longer care about their job.
- might specialize in an area/skill that is no longer relevant to a field; or saddle a dept with someone whose skills no longer match a curriculum that has changed.

Apportioning tenured lines between departments makes departments and colleges unable to reapportion their resources to match changing needs.

On the other side: The tenure system makes finding a job in academia an all-or-nothing gambit. In most fields  you have only one or two shots at getting a tenured job: 1) within a few years of completing your degree; or 2) only if you attain high stature in your field. If you're an adjunct  no one will consider you after a few years: "They must be no good  or else they'd have a tenured job by now." If you look for a new job after 5-6 years in a job: "They're probably not getting tenure at their current job; damaged goods."  After tenure: "Why are they leaving a tenured position? They must have done something bad."

Replace tenure with renewable 2-5-year contracts. This would undo the jam and increase flexibility within the whole system  for both colleges and job-seekers.
Name: paula

comment: Sounds like a bunch of aging boomer Professors had no problem sweet talking young kids into expensive post graduate degrees only to then take advantage of the poor kids in adjunct positions. And of course  the required retirement age for those boomer professors was wiped away so they could continue to feed at the trough well past 70 years of age. But let’s continue to blame lack of government support for universities because god knows that in the hallowed halls of higher education  education means success  and those in positions of power are all about sharing that success.
Name: john

comment:
I went to a state university in the late 1970s when professors were expected to teach in addition to doing research.  I had some really good professors who could teach and seemed to enjoy working with students. However  there were some who could barely hide the disdain they felt for the little teaching that they had to do.  

Maybe the professorial staff needs to be split in half  with one half dedicated to teaching and the other half being dedicated to research and chasing grant money.  Everyone would be tenured.  

Finally  not a funny story.  Here in Connecticut a some ancient professor in the medical school who was being paid well north of $300K per year just disappeared for several months.  No one realized he was gone until someone noticed the power point presentation he was responsible for had not been turned in.  His only job was putting together this presentation. It turns out his wife had murdered him and put his body in the basement.

Maybe the return of mandatory retirement is warranted unless you are still publishing or teaching a full load of classes.
Name: connecticut

comment:
Yeah we should be totally talking about this as it relates to every other structure that increasingly embraced a neoliberal model of corporate efficiency. Schools are not business  but are run like them (in this way  not so dissimilar to the post office--public institutions  private profit accruing expectations). 

I'm an adjunct with over ten years in the field. Can we talk about how swollen the mid-level management ranks are in higher ed?
Name: jason

comment:
One important thing that I think these articles usually miss (because there seems to be one much like this one every few months): the risky ratio of candidates to positions in university humanities teaching is probably best comparable to that found in the arts. Nobody complains that there are too many students studying in music conservatories  even when only the tiniest fraction of those students are lucky and talented enough to earn a good living from the craft they have learned. Same for art school graduates. If a person wants to pursue a passion like this  be it intellectual or artistic  more power to them. But the odds of success (if that's measured in a job at the end) are obviously slimmer than slim from the start. I think we should let people study what they want  with eyes open and all risks assumed. 

The one point I agree strongly with is that the ratio of full to part time faculty is a mess and needs to be fixed  for the reasons explained in this article and others.
Name: agusti

comment: I know of several PhD holders who have left the country and taken jobs overseas  where credentials are still valued.  I don't know if what I've seen is a trend  but the people who left  many of them very talented  did not see any opportunities in the United States.
Name: jack

comment:
It has been this way for 50 years.  It's not much better even in the sciences  where there are some  but not many  jobs outside academia.

Wake up!  Don't go to graduate school (except  maybe  in some engineering fields).

The universities  and  in the sciences  the federal funding agencies  lie about the job prospects.  They want cheap labor.  They are not looking out for you---you are to be used  and then discarded as unemployable trash.
Name: jonathan

comment:
Why do young people still pursue a PhD???
We have known and been told for greater than 15 years that the PhD degree—particularly in the humanities—is a dead end.

Stop already.  Don’t protest  drop out of your graduate program and learn a skill to make a living like everyone else.  In other words  get a job.
Name: jag

comment: This article fails to mention another important factor  at least in large public universities--and that is the destructive role of administrators who are passing by--almost all of whom move some where else in a span of 3-5 years. Almost every dean and provost at major public universities is looking to build his/her resume as they are looking towards a potential audition for a higher job somewhere else  by creating centers  creating new positions  creating new bureaucratic rules  most of them quite counter-productive. There is little resistance to this trend since a typical university president tries to get along with his/her deans and provosts  and university professors at large universities are too busy with their own work to be bothered about how their university is being run. As a result of this long term trend  the budget available to departments has remained flat even in good times  and the departments have managed with larger fraction of adjuncts.
Name: stanveer

comment: I fell in love with teaching when I shifted from a career in architecture to teaching art and design as an adjunct professor. After five years of contractually limited student contact hours (to avoid having to pay me as a full-time employee) I realized that the system was a racket. I am now a public school teacher where I enjoy health benefits  a retirement plan  and a living wage. Teaching college-aged students was one of the most enjoyable jobs I ever worked  but I couldn't afford to keep doing it.
Name: rogan

comment:
This is just one small example of what is happening to almost every part of the American economy:  less stable jobs  fewer benefits  lower wages  no retirement.

Yet  candidates for president who propose to address structural social ills are denounced as radical and unelectable (in this very newspaper  for example).
Name: ds

comment: My experience (lecturer for 17 years at state colleges)  was that higher education institutions have an inordinate number of ‘administrative’ positions (chairs  associate chairs  deans  coordinators  etc.) drawing outrageously bloated salaries  who rarely  if ever sat foot in a classroom or interacted with students. This causes university budgets to be top-heavy  and tuition to increase to support this travesty. Meanwhile  adjuncts and part-timers do a greater percentage of the work with students. One of the reasons why I oppose current free college tuition proposals is that they would only support this corrupt system.
Name: matt

comment:
Here's some more insight into academia from a former law school professor that may or may not make you cringe:

1.  Most tenured professors have never had a "real" job that requires them to do actual work in their field  and/or have any relevant real-world job experience whatsoever.

2.  Most tenured professors have unjustifiably inflated egos  and visions of their self-worth.  This is an extremely significant contributor to the high cost of tuition and abuse of grad students and adjuncts.

3.  If most tenured professors were to expectedly lose their teaching job  they would never be able to function like the rest of us in the real job world - i.e.  show up every day  produce something that matters and/or could be measured  be held accountable  etc. etc.
Name: frommc

comment: is no one going to mention the precipitous decline in state funding for public universities?
Name: swampprof

comment: The other key part lies in the fact that  while it's admitted that universities could have increased the ranks of tenured faculty and chose not to  they instead vastly increased the ranks of administrators.
Name: jem

comment: The ignorance on display in many of these comments (e.g. 'no one cares about the past' [forget any consideration of the legacy of slavery on today's politics]  AI  [such as employed to monitor and police consumer-citizens] has done away with the need for the humanities  etc.  illustrates the consequences of the turn to training in 'practical subjects ' at the expense the kind of actual education universities can provide. No wonder an amoral game-show host can be elected president: the natural outcome for a society that doesn't value its educators.
Name: dada

comment:
The elimination of the law requiring professors to retire at 70 was a huge mistake.

This is just one more iteration of the Boomer generation hoarding resources in old age rather than gracefully stepping aside and empowering younger people for the betterment of society. The "me first" generation strikes again.
Name: kyle

comment:
"Yet at no point did universities seem to consider slowing the flow of students into the Ph.D. pipeline. The opposite happened. In 1988  the number of doctorates in the humanities conferred was estimated to be 3 570  and it increased to 5 145 in 2018.

Tenured professors like having graduate students around. They teach the boring undergraduate sections for little or no pay and provide inexpensive research assistance."

There's the rub. Grad students are money makers. Meanwhile  the administrative layer on college campuses grows  with a lot of  in my opinion  overpaid administrators.
Name: anne

comment:
Some people are trying to make this about the humanities. It isn't: My brother-in-law is a physicist who tried to make it in academia  spending years working for peanuts first as a postdoc and then as an adjunct  and found that it just wasn't possible. And he's not the only family I have that has been involved in the "ed biz".

If you pay attention  you'll find out this didn't just happen. It was very deliberate  and was specifically the result of conservative groups angry about egghead professors supporting liberal causes without being professionally ruined for it. Through a combination of big donations and state-level politics  they've gained control of many institutions of higher education with the specific goal of eliminating tenured faculty so that professors who fail to toe ideological lines can be summarily fired for it.

Nothing good has ever come from an environment supposedly dedicated to learning where political orthodoxy matters more than the truth. But that's exactly what many people in control of our universities today want.
Name: dave

comment: As a previous adjunct and PhD in history now working outside of academia  I just want to affirm that this article is spot on. Excellent journalism
Name: dave

comment:
I have a PhD in a biology-related field. When i was in grad school in the 90's  we were all concerned about how much harder it was getting to obtain NIH funding for research. We weren't told how hard it would be just to get a job! 
This article really rang true to me. I have colleagues in their 70's who are tenured and have no plans to retire. Meanwhile  the university has tons of adjunct faculty teaching positions available  but precious few tenure track positions.
When your child applies to college  make sure to look carefully at who will be teaching them. Will it be adjunct faculty  who survive on one-year contracts and may not be an expert in what they are teaching? Or grad students? Pick a college based on the quality of their teaching  not their reputation for research!
Name: dee

comment: There is another factor at work that should be considered. More power over search and hiring decisions is concentrate at the top  in the hands of the Provost or even the President. When a tenured faculty member leaves their position through retirement  the faculty line commonly is NOT in the control of the department or college where that faculty member had an appointment. The department essentially loses that position unless it can makes a very strong case for a replacement. This does not incentivize an older faculty member to retire  even if that would make the most sense. The solution is to allow faculty members to take back a stronger role in governance at their institution  but guess who does not want to see that happen? The state bodies governing their flagship universities.
Name: carbn

comment: As a joke  I calculated my university's student-to-vice president ratio and compared it to other liberal arts colleges in our immediate region.  We "won" handily.  Only a question of time before we appoint a Vice President for Undergraduate Laundry Affairs - who will of course need Associate Vice Presidents for Off Campus Undergraduate Laundry Affairs and Graduate Student Laundry Affairs.  Each with an office and support staff  of course.
Name: kim

comment: A very dear friend returned to school to complete her PhD studies which she interrupted to marry and raise her children. At the completion of her studies  she was unable to obtain a full time tenure track position. She spent her entire career as an adjunct professor commuting between two Boston area colleges. She received no benefits or retirement.As she approached retirement age  a much younger department chairman refused to give her classes and her career was over.No explanation and no thanks.
Name: maya

comment: Where’s the analysis of the extraordinary rise in administrative costs  relative to every other cost  in higher ed over the last 30 years and how that affects professor pay? That mirrors admin costs in healthcare?
Name: dave

comment: I wish that the line about how UCSC grad students teach “as part of their training” would stop. This line comes from the university administration; it does not accurately reflect what grad students do. For instance  the fact that UCSC students teach undergrad courses and are responsible for their grades is what they do. They have the same classroom responsibilities as adjuncts and full-time professors. It’s hard to say that they’re being trained when they’re actually teaching standalone courses.
Name: george

comment: There is a desperate need for qualified high school teachers but everyone (including these recent PhD's) stigmatizes K-12 and community college education as a "not optional" career. This is institutionalized hypocrisy. Public school teachers are the foundation of our society and far more valuable than biomedical researchers in shaping our future. Why not fill that demand with these qualified individuals?
Name: ryan

comment: This article gives me hope that at least some people at the Times are doing real analysis of the state of the country and economy and see that Sander’s platform is the only one that truly addresses the depth of the problem. As a long-time adjunct in the humanities  teaching ethics and humanism  I can’t afford health insurance and have no job security. Treating teachers worse than janitors is part of why this country doesn’t believe in science and thinks money is the measure of virtue. It’s grotesque.
Name: jeremy

comment:
People have pointed out the glaring omission in this article: administrators. There are exponentially more of them. They all have a staff. The pay scale is orders of magnitude higher than the pay scale for full-time faculty. They don't teach or have any special expertise. They make paperwork.

You know where else we see this? Medicine. Yes  doctors are paid loads better than adjuncts - but they are absurdly overworked with no time to spend per patient. Nurses are overworked at least as badly and underpaid to boot. Where does the money go? Again  a massive explosion in high-paid middlemen and administrators  backed up by massive  massive cubicle farms full of clerical workers underneath them. All producing what? Paperwork. 

Getting a PhD is really hard work. Becoming a doctor or a nurse is insanely hard work. Why do this  when you can pick up an MBA in two years  sit in a glass-walled office all day  and make double or triple the money? No stacks of grading or trying to teach Chaucer to a kid whose HS education left them semi-literate. No telling anyone they are Stage 4. No cleaning up a desperately ill patient or helping someone sick and in pain.

Student loan debt and health insurance costs are the two things strangling the middle class to death. Because the tiny class of people who do the real work are each carrying fifty useless middlemen on their broken backs.
Name: glen

comment: As a tenure-track professor in the humanities let me assure you: I don't want universities to hire more adjuncts  thereby gifting me more time to do research. I want more tenure-track jobs for young scholars and less exploitation of vulnerable workers. If that means I teach more composition classes  that's just great.
Name: prof

comment:
I was an adjunct for a dozen years.  My salary was pretty good  much better than adjunct pay at nearby schools.  One idle afternoon  calculator in hand  I figured out I was teaching close to 2/3rds of the overall enrollment in my department.   
Several keystrokes later  I learned I was getting paid about $30 per student per instructional hour (no benefits) while tenured faculty earned  on average  $120 . . . a sum shaped by their benefit package and the lower enrollments in their upper division courses.
Name: richard

comment:
This article focuses on the humanities  and for good reason. The situation is dire. But I would add that the same thing is also happening in STEM fields. Maybe not to the same degree  but it's still a gigantic problem  and it's getting even worse. The data shown in the table indicates that the number of Ph.D. recipients in STEM fields overall has more than doubled between 1988-2008 (compared to "only" a 40-45% increase for humanties and arts).

It's true that STEM Ph.D.s have more alternative career options than humanities Ph.Ds outside of joining the academy. But the situation for STEM Ph.D.s is still getting worse and fast  just perhaps not as much as in the humanities.

The myth that an advanced STEM degree will automatically lead to good job prospects is pervasive... and especially among humanities Ph.D. holders who think the grass must be greener on the STEM side. Nope  the grass is also brown. Maybe just a slightly lighter shade of brown...
Name: canadian

comment: I wish that this essay did more to emphasize the difference between getting a PhD in the humanities and getting a PhD in STEM  given that the title of "The Bleak Job Landscape of Adjunctopia for Ph.D.s" seems to cover both. Specifically  STEM PhDs are in high-demand in well-paying industry jobs. I'm a PhD student in a statistics department at a public school (Florida State) with a respectable statistics department. Most of our PhD graduates in Stats or Biostats get jobs immediately after graduation; working as data scientists  statisticians  biostatisticians  bioinformaticians etc. at technology companies (Google  Microsoft)  pharmaceutical companies (Merck  Eli Lilly)  or insurance companies (Liberty Mutual  Travellers)  with starting salaries around or above 100k. So yeah  if you're going to get a PhD  best to do it in a STEM field  and it will be well worth it.
Name: dy

comment:
4th year PhD here: All this sounds familiar. My advisor pushes me to hurry up and finish my dissertation  but I wonder -- for what? What jobs are waiting for me out there? 

At least as a student I get $20k/year conducting research and teaching for the university. I mean  I had to teach in another city last semester and the university didn't provide any gas reimbursement for the 100+ mile round trip. And we don't get family health insurance  so I have to take my daughter to the local clinic. And the university housing we live in increases the rent 3% annually  but the same university keeps our wages flat. And I have to go to the local food bank to feed my family. And my hair is falling out from stress. And we don't get dental coverage  so we now get our teeth pulled when we can't afford the procedure. And my husband is losing weight from food insecurity. 

But all this STILL seems better than the bleak prospects waiting for me after I finish!
Name: tired

comment: All true - but assumes that the only use for a PhD is teaching in a college or university. Finely developed skills in research  analysis and communication are valuable in any field.
Name: b

comment:
To say that higher education is a complete mess is an understatement.  Colleges have continued to raise tuition to the point where many talented and motivated students can no longer afford to go to college.  College presidents know that it is easier to get rich donors to donate to new buildings than to donate to defray the cost of faculty salaries and undergraduate programs.  College presidents also know they are in an arms race with other schools to see which school can have the fanciest student centers  athletic facilities  football stadiums  etc.  And so the "edifice complex" continues apace  at the expense of students' wallets  tenure tracks and faculty salaries.

It has always been a puzzle to me that someone or some group doesn't create a small college designed simply to teach  i.e.  a college with no facilities other than classrooms  a small facility for the college's few administrators and faculty offices  and a library.  The college would offer tuition that would look more like the 1970s  offer a tenure track to almost all faculty  and good faculty salaries.   

One key component would be admission based only on a single admissions test (similar to the test to get into Oxford or Cambridge).  This method  plus the low tuition  would attract very academically-talented students -- and would attract talented PhDs wanting to teach them. 

Yes  yes  I can already hear the naysayers' complaints.  But it seems to me this no-frills model should be given a chance.
Name: alb

comment: I was an adjunct because there were no full-time professorships to be found. I taught a 3/3 load while full-time professors taught a 3/4 load. (Number of courses each semester.) The full-time professors were paid $70 000 plus health insurance. I was paid $12 000 plus nothing.  All of my students said I was an excellent teacher  in some cases that I changed their lives. I had to quit academia so I could eat.
Name: giulia

comment:
The curse on the US universities is the insane amount of funding that goes to football stadia  coach salaries  etc. 

To all the jobless PhDs  consider what many highly qualified immigrants do coming to the US  get faculty positions abroad in countries where funding is available. China for example. Emigrate until conditions improve.
Name: linus

comment:
I'm put off by some of the comments in this thread. I don't want to live in a society that denigrates other people for pursuing higher education  regardless if it is in a STEM or humanities field. That goes to the very bedrock of whether our nation values education and speaks to the insidious nature of anti-intellectualism.

I see way too many people who scoff at someone pursuing a humanities or arts degree because of the perception that those folks will never be able to support themselves. I see that view as incredibly narrow-minded. As someone with a very job-specific degree  I still can see the value in a humanities degree. It speaks to versatility and being well-rounded. As a military member  I know our community highly prizes the idea of warrior-philosopher and that is backed up by the high numbers of officers up and down the chain of command with humanities degrees.
Name: cory

comment: Although the data are difficult to ascertain (some adjuncts have full time jobs elsewhere and simply want to teach only a course or two on the side)  AAUP data indicates the shift from tenure/tenure-track began in the 1980s  especially in Rust-Belt states like Michigan and in California where tuition to U. of California and the Cal State systems were kept artificially low by hiring adjuncts. Baby boomer Ph.D.s were also flooding the markets. State funding began to shift away when Medicaid expenses began to soar  also in this period. As I recall  only about 30% of faculty position were full time by 1990s  according to AAUP data. Frankly  university grad departments did a lot of lying for decades. Today  they are more candid with grad students about grim prospects. (I discourage the undergrads I teach from going to grad school in arts and sciences.)
Name: frederickrlynch

comment: I did not consider my employment prospects when I started my Ph.D. program 35 years ago. I was one of the lucky ones  demand for my field turned out to be strong. I would urge anybody who is considering a Ph.D. today to consider not only their interest in the field but also their employment prospects. This is not only a problem for humanities  it affects some science fields too.
Name: joel

comment: Meanwhile  the College Presidents  Deans and Department Heads have decided they all deserve CEO type salaries. I am wondering what will happen to all these adjuncts when the student loan bubble bursts. There are people who are near retirement and have still not paid off their student loans. Even Bernie Sanders  if elected President  has no magic wand to make $ 2 Trillion in Debt go away.
Name: rahul

comment: I would like to share my experiences and reflections on a failed academic career (but a moderately successful scholarly one)  but I’m pretty sure it would do no one (especially me) any good.  When I dropped out of law school in the mid-80s  I did do some research on the future of academia.  The coming population bubble and retirement of an aging professorship convinced me of the viability of a career in the humanities as a college professor.   What our author fails to mention is the shift in so many state legislatures to a fiscal conservatism that strangled higher ed budgets and demanded the short term solution of adjunct teaching.  And the consequences of this short-term thinking  along with public demands for “accountability” and the growing sense that higher ed is a service industry  are run-away grade inflation  coupled with a dumbing down of the curriculum  to the point where college grads now write in emojis.  In short  it’s is not just that there are a lot of hard luck PhD’s on food stamps; it is that  as a democracy  we have stopped demanding the critical apparatuses that would ensure our success.  I need only point out the current political climate to underscore this last point.
Name: daniel

comment:
I have not looked at the demographics for faculty in STEM  so I have to limit my comments to my own experiences.  Years ago I understood that I had some kind of unwritten obligation to "move on" at 65 or thereabouts.  I was probably 40s when I developed that notion.

I'm now 66 and still going at it as a long tenured full prof in a life sciences department.  However  I intend to finish up existing grant and student obligations over the next year or two  and to step down.  It's time for "new blood " but given the nature of university budgets there is no assurance that I will actually be replaced as a slot opens up.

Unfortunately  I see too many of my colleagues who are doing too little yet still hanging on well past 65  well past 70 even.  This isn't healthy.  Though there might be no legal obligation to retire  we would do well to follow Europe and Japan and provide exceptions for employment after 67-68 to only those of the very highest caliber.

Those of us who have been fortunate enough to enjoy a productive life in academe ought to recognize a moral obligation to pass it on rather than to hang on.
Name: gdawg

comment:
This article might lead one to believe that a PhD is only for a career in academia.  This is hardly the case.  Both industry and government need--and hire--people with well-honed analytical skills  and the deep research of PhD-level training is especially good for this.

The fact is that most universities do a very poor job of connecting their newly-minted PhDs to anything but an academic track.  Of course  this has never made sense--one single tenured professor might supervise many dozens of graduate students over their academic lifetime.  It's impossible for them all to go into academia.  Universities owe it to all their PhD students that they are shown a wide choice of career options  not just the tiny market of academia.
Name: stubborn

comment:
Just want you all to know   it's not all peaches and cream in the STEM fields either.   If you were an unfortunate grad (I was   Winter 2007)  during the economic downturn  there were no post-docs.  As a STEM PhD  you have a small window of 5 years to post-doc and then move to academia or private industry. Neither were hiring..... and now we are considered obsolete  toiling away in non-field industry jobs for 1/3 of what we thought we were worth  while watching the new grads snap up lucrative post-docs that we are still very qualified and desperate to do.  I would give almost everything to conduct research in my field again....I am not too OLD!!!

-Frustrated and heartbroken GenX Phd Chemical Physics
Name: khataan

comment: This is an interesting article.  My PhD. brother  31 years at his very well known land grant university  retired about 4 years ago.  The 10 years prior pay raises had been meager or non existent.  His lab didn't even have running hot water anymore.  The focus from administrators was how much grant money he brought in so they could scarf off 25% for "administrative" costs.  My brother loved teaching - little credit was given for that.  When he retired they filled his position with a Master's level contract person and paid them less than half what he was earning.  My brother and I were discussing this situation interestingly just yesterday.  He is aware of PhDs have turned down positions because the contract requires them to bring in 5 times their salary in grant money - which has been drastically reduced in recent years.  Meanwhile  what this article fails to address is the top heavy administrative staffing and costs at many universities.  It also fails to address the higher and higher fees being charged and the longer time it takes to get a degree.
