I find it distressing the ways in which young women are routinely targeted and blamed for this behavior  as if they aren't teenagers simply imitating their idols and being targeted by the manufacturers of these clothes. I don't mean to dismiss their behavior  but the tone of this article smacks of the holier-than-thou attitude that is anything but constructive in these situations. 
This article does not shed light on the shopping patterns of Gen Z  but instead accuses them of narcissism and consumerism as a part of that tired narrative first targeted at Millennials. Hardly an original take  or a fair portrayal  for that matter.
Name: m

comment:
Empty pursuits in search of "likes " taxing the environment with disposable clothing that ends up in landfills or getting burned. Most fast fashion is made from petroleum. Massive amounts of water used to produce junk. 80 pounds of clothing waste per year per American.
 

There's no "sustainable" brand. It's all marketing hype for shallow minds.
Name: c

comment: I've got three work shirts. They're T-shirts with a company logo given to me when I was hired. I also own two button-up casual nice long-sleeve shirts that I wear on days I'm not working. One is a burgundy-brown plaid shirt. The other is all-white. Two shirts. I've been alternating between these two shirts for I don't know how long now. A few years.
Name: chris

comment:
“I wouldn’t really want someone seeing me in a dress more than once.” 

That sort of thinking is why Instagram and social media is anti-recycling. 

Stop using so much stuff! The planet is dying. No time for your wasteful narcissism.
Name: rax

comment: First thing I thought of was these Gals are missing concept of Quality over Quantity in their fashion picks. I get it. It's really fun to shop and gather... but there are some downsides and not to be a Debbie Downer on Fashion Fun but a lot of the merchandise is cheap plastic short-lasting (only lasting a few wears) and long-rotting environmentally. Might want to think about that Gals. https://www.forbes.com/sites/natalieparletta/2019/11/30/from-recycled-plastic-to-3d-printing-more-creative-solutions-for-sustainable-fashion/#1fa6e7291fc4 https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2019/jul/16/the-big-fashion-fight-can-we-remove-all-the-toxic-invisible-plastic-from-our-clothes
Name: former

comment: Ugh  what an infuriating set of interviews. "fast fashion" = garbage clothes  made of plastic. Disposable garments manufactured by people working in terrible conditions for low wages in polluting factories  and headed to a landfill after a brief interlude on the back of a fool who talks about wearing a dress only once as if it were some kind of virtue. Meanwhile  the planet burns. Thank god my own teenage daughter has no interest in this idiocy. I hope these young women wake up and make better choices some day.
Name: andrea

comment: More cheap junk = more environmental Destruction and predatory economic trade relations. But I guess that pales in comparison to a dope Instagram feed  amirite?
Name: aj

comment: Gen Z shoppers have also shown some remarkable concern for the charitable image of the brands they wear. While there's a long way to go  seeing brands such as Bombas socks attract young buyers by giving away a pair for every pair they sell says as much about their consumers as the company.
Name: seth

comment: Well  about to hit 50 and if I didn't know I was old before now I know! I am happy to wear something I love over and over again  old friends I pull out every year and if I'm lucky  still fit. Made of natural fabrics  wool  linen  silk they surely last  if taken care of. When they are done  I re-purpose them into buttons  pillows  purses and sell them. Recoup a little cash  engage my brain and hands  keep them out of the landfill.  Ahhh  to be young again. NOT.
Name: embellishedlife

comment: What an utterly depressing article. One would hope the world has more Greta Thunbergs than these girls. They are facing existential threats  and they don't even know it.
Name: susie

comment:
I learned the hard way both the value of having one well made thing instead of 10 and that expensive is not always well-made from high quality materials.  I have nice things to dress well  easily  with my style  and with minimum distraction.    

But what saddens me most when I look back is the sum total of money (the value of a new car?  more?)  and the time I spent on the 'learning' of a simple thing:   Others do not notice or remember what we wear.  Even in our gorgeous airy downtown law office full of stylish young people.  

Do you notice what others wear?  Do you remember?   I bet you don't.    All we remember is that someone looks classy all the time.    I let my grey turtleneck reign (under a camel blazer  black slacks  and a neck bauble).  Ah  others do love the few baubles i got - so there's that. 

I think the gals here will grow out of this when real life kicks in.  In their own time.
Name: officekat

comment:
I learned the hard way both the value of having one good thing instead of 10 and that expensive is not always well-made from high quality materials.  I have nice things to dress well  easily  with my style  and with minimum distraction.    

But what saddens me most when I look back is the sum total of money (the value of a new car?  more?)  and the time I spent on the 'learning' of a simple thing:   Others do not notice or remember what we wear.  Even in our gorgeous airy downtown law office full of stylish young people.  

Do you notice what others wear?  Do you remember?   I bet you don't.    All we remember is that someone looks classy all the time.    I let my grey turtleneck reign (under a camel blazer  black slacks  and a neck bauble).  Ah  others do love the few baubles i got - so there's that. 

I think the gals here will grow out of this when real life kicks in.  In their own time.
Name: officekat

comment: This makes me want to scream.Buy quality  well-made garments and fewer of them that will last for years! These girls have no idea. We’re doomed.
Name: scs

comment: I would like to think that  as was the case back in my day  interesting and conscientious dressers are still shopping at thrift stores  where they can assemble inventive outfits (and lifestyles) while doing less harm to the planet.
Name: day

comment: Just another trend. This too  will come to pass.
Name: scott

comment: In a few years people will look back on this type of "lifestyle" as one of the examples of how civilization took a very wrong turn. Of course there are many people who are conscious about their consumer habits. Economists talk about peak oil  but I have a feeling there is going to be a turning point in the quantity of purchases of consumer products. Peak consumerism  if you will. Personally I only buy things meant to last and that'll age well and I buy vintage/used clothing. I also buy clothing made with natural materials as much as possible.
Name: aspen

comment:
How many people here are purchasing on Amazon? 
Cheaply-produced objects that are packaged in way too much plastic  oversize boxes  that will inundate our landfills?
Name: left

comment: How about stop pushing consumers to purchase more. It is not sustainable and many Americans are already in debt.
Name: awl

comment:
Youth is a time to be self-absorbed.  I can remember being obsessed with clothes and cute outfits and spent real time on my hair and grooming.  Still I would like to tell these lovely young people that an imagination to create new outfits from items already owned (and more carefully selected) and the confidence to rewear items is more stylish.  Be gutsy and rewear your things. See what happens. Most will not notice and you will not lose friends or admirers  unless they are the shallowest of sorts. 

Clothing quality has been on a downward slope for decades  however social media has contributed to the problem.  New styles and trends made of polyester and acrylic arrive at a rapid pace to satisfy the demands for something new.  I long for garments that aren't so flimsy and will last for more than one season.  Even the young who partake in fast fashion will find that they have a closet-full of clothes and nothing to wear.

It is very difficult to find natural fibers and classic shapes  even in department stores and retailers that were previously known for quality.  It's a sad state of affairs contributed by globalization and a demand (an expectation) for dirt-cheap prices.  We all need to stop buying fast fashion and so many clothes in general.  True fashionistas understand that they're shooting themselves in the foot when they do so.
Name: lori

comment: what's strange to me is that there is no desire to be creative... i e have 10-20 pieces of clothing but wear in different and unique ways? that makes you unique. you are just buying what someone else created (or ripped off etc) i doubt her fans who are simultaneously following tons of other people would even notice. To me it is sad and as an environmentalist i am freaking out.
Name: barbara

comment: So sad they they don't really care about anything other than "likes" without understanding the implications. https://fashionunited.uk/news/fashion/h-m-accused-of-burning-12-tonnes-of-new-unsold-clothing-per-year/2017101726341
Name: steve

comment: Looks like reckless  environmentally unsound consumer behavior to me  and The Times seems to be celebrating it.
Name: unreceivedogma

comment: Here it goes the anti-consumerism of past generations. Perhaps global warming is a divine punishment  after all. We have become parasites with Instagram dementia.
Name: sg

comment: This is pathetic. I wish all of these women could watch Hasan Minaj's recent episode of Patriot Act about the unsustainable nature of the fast fashion industry. The good news is that  these women aside  there does seem to be a backlash brewing  and throw away clothes will be deemed unhip and irresponsible.
Name: eric

comment: "Cheap" is all you need to know. Millenials  GenZ  GenX  STOP buying cheap junk clothes made by children in slums around the world. Pay more to get responsibly made clothing. Your unlimited access to information is fully offset by your lack of wisdom.
Name: mrdeepstate

comment: This is the Kardashianization of our society.  It not only effects millennials  I see it in gen X as well.
Name: cari

comment: Like makeup  this is all to impress other women. The guys couldn't care less.
Name: don

comment: Two words...thrift store!!!
Name: michael

comment: "what I wore to the Listen Out festival yesterday  I ordered on Tuesday morning  it came on Wednesday morning: literally in 24 hours. That means so much to me."  Ordering clothes online for delivery means so much to her...that was so depressing to read. Certainly there are more important things?
Name: nope

comment: Time to take away their phones! If you can't leave your house without agonising over how you look on Instagram then you have an addiction problem  possibly narcissism. They are working to buy clothes to wear going to restaurants to create a curated life for strangers on the internet.
Name: gf

comment: What is the endgame?  What are the countless social media posts leading to?  If you can quit what you're doing and there are no consequences  then what you were doing is of no value.  In 2019  I expect more from young women  including my own daughters  than looking "cute" and groveling for likes on social media.
Name: bcm

comment: Seems like there’s are market somewhere for rental clothes...wear once and return. Then check out a new one.
Name: david

comment: The "Take whatever you want  but eat whatever you take" mindset needs to applied to fashion.  I'm curious about what their parents think of this rampant consumption and vanity. Do the parents share this mindset?
Name: josh

comment:
I gotta' say  I must be the only millennial that does not have an Instagram  or Insta as the kids refer to it these days  I believe. I just don't take a lot of pictures.

It's sad to see these young women think about fashion the way they do. Fast fashion is destroying the world and if I had any daughters or even sons  I would tell them the truth about fast fashion if they were ever looking to purchase any of it. 

As for myself  I do repeat outfits and do not mind one bit. However  I do love thrifting for new clothing and take care of the clothes I have by always babying them so they last longer or even forever. My closet is only so big though that I do not have as much clothing as the young women in this article have though. But if the clothing I currently own is to stay in my closet  it has to currently fit my body 24/7 or it's going into my donation bin for someone else to wear hopefully.
Name: m

comment: Depressing to think that so many young people around the world are little more than mindless consumers. They've been sold a message--and they've believed it  that their primary identity is not someone who loves  or helps  or serves  or is part of something bigger than themselves.  No  their primary identity is someone who consumes (clothes  social media  technology).
Name: jeff

comment: Sustainability at this rate is a pipe dream. Humanity only becomes more engrossed in selfishness  and this article really personifies that. At least for the most part they aren't addicted to spending incredible sums of money for individual items.
Name: k

comment: There was a time in my life when I was obsessed with designer fashion - nothing less than a Hugo Boss shirt topped with an Armani tie would do. And this was way before the days of instagram and social media; in fact  the internet was an infant. Thank God I am so over that now - but  darn it all  how I wish now that I had been a bit wiser with my money . . .
Name: ps

comment: Happy (so happy) to be 45.
Name: jen

comment: Fast fashion is wasteful  opposes our climate imperatives  and utilizes oppressed labor.  This is something young people need to learn.  It's all part of a sustainable lifesyle.
Name: shillingfarmer

comment: And this is the generation that is supposed to be most concerned with climate change.
Name: a

comment: I thought the younger generation was supposed to be less wasteful?! Who only wears a dress once or twice before chucking it? The girl who said that actually has zero style and imagination since she can't seem to come up with creative ways to style a dress differently each time she wears it. This is really sad and gross.
Name: atb

comment:
As if we need more trash to fill the ever expanding landfills!

This sad story is one more reason why government supervision is necessary to hold business interests accountable for the environmental mess they leave behind as they pursue their blind profit goals.
Name: daniel

comment: How sad that they and most youth have such a thin  weak sense of self and thus have bought into an awful retrograde definition of both feminine and masculine as simply consumerism.
Name: maggie

comment: I blame their parents.  It's the job of the parent to educate and instill values in their children.  Children and adolescents are shortsighted and have poor decision-making skills.  The parents need to intervene.
Name: ald

comment: It's really sad that we live in a world that is so self-centered  shallow and petty. This is what reality TV has gotten us--people that aren't wealthy worrying about being seen in clothing more than once. Reality check girls: no one cares.
Name: morgan

comment: I don't think there is anything wrong with wearing a dress twice...or 50 times. How exhausting to have to shop all the time
Name: casablanca

comment: Add to this an article I read the other day about plastic surgeons seeing a demand for “Instagram face” and you will realize that Instagram is just as pernicious as Facebook  only in a different arena.
Name: a

comment: Before we blame these kids  let's look at our three-car garages   in Mcmansions with 5 bedrooms  all groaning with stuff. They are only perpetuating what they see.
Name: g

comment: The world needs more Greta Thunbergs and less people like this.
Name: dottie

comment: Victory of capitalism.  Why bother to think when you can shop>  Why report on the homeless in Chiacgo  NYC  small town America  when you can write about three girls and how they shop.. BTW IMO this is soooooo yesterday.  And I wish Amal Clooney would refuse to pose for Vogue.  And isn't it great that Kim K is studying law!!
Name: auntie

comment: I read things like this and I’m like  “Yeeeeeah...maybe the world burning down completely wouldn’t be so bad.” Time to just start over  clearly.
Name: olivia

comment: The decline of civilization seems to be right on schedule.
Name: socrates

comment: A moment on Instagram  a lifetime in a landfill.
Name: mf

comment: These young people get a temporary pass (because they’re young)  but the kind of mindless rampant materialism they characterize is a metaphor for why our planet is dying so fast. No wisdom  only self-absorption. How about a few nice non-sweatshop made pieces instead.
Name: jeff

comment: Next time these shoppers are browsing fast fashion perhaps they'll think about the people featured in this article and think twice before buying: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/16/business/fashion-nova-underpaid-workers.html#commentsContainer&permid=104164810:104167888 And why is it that me a 58 year old who doesn't have children cares more about sustainability and the climate crisis than some gen Z do? It's your funeral kids.
Name: nom

comment:
The subjects of this article all say they buy clothing to wear only once or a very limited number of times before disposing of it.

A current WSJ article features dumpster divers listing and selling their findings on Amazon.

This defines today’s capitalism: trash begets trash begets trash  ad infinitum.

How could anyone wonder that the climate change we have begotten is going to destroy us?
Name: unpresidented

comment:
Enjoy rampant and unrestricted consumption while it lasts.

Wearing a dress once?   Being concerned with how you look on social media?  A need for immediate satisfaction?  So much wrong here.......

I wonder how this generation of narcissists will cope with a Soylent Green future when their primary focus will be on where their next meal is coming from.  

Wait... pardon me ..... they'll be fine.  As I recall  young women came with the high end residences where the retired Soylent Executive lived.

I really want to believe that humanity can be saved - and deserves saving - but I find it harder and harder to retain any hope.   If these people are our future  please end things now while our species still has some dignity left.

I note that 'Interviews have been edited for style and clarity'.   I wonder how these young women actually sounded...
Name: cynicalskeptic

comment: I mean  it's three kids. It paints a really small picture. And I just want to say that there are just as many gen-Z teenagers who  yes  care just as much about social media  yet subscribe to a more simplified outfitting style  prizing second-hand  comfortable looks over junky glam. And  get this: they're all out there buying up our old JNCO jeans from the early 90's! and it's COOL to them! Who woulda thought...
Name: n

comment:
It doesn't "sound" shallow  it is.  If it even rises to that level.  "Down to earth and relatable"?  To whom?

No-one needs that many clothes  it's disgusting.  And just because it's young women doing it doesn't make it right or excusable.  This is something to aspire to?

Social media promotes this type of phony  self-absorbed  narcissistic behavior  makes millions and avoids all of the consequences.  If only the rest of us could.
Name: lou

comment: we are a society in decline. social media is just speeding things up.
Name: tim

comment:
Where is the affordable  (not dirt cheap)  sustainable clothing which is designed to last more than five washings?

Once you produce that list we can cull through it looking for something not made in a hellish sweatshop.

Then we can look into the footprint of shipping the zippers half way around the world and the cloth from where it's made to where it's dyed  on and on.  

Next comes the plastic wrap  the shipping by sea and trucking by land and finally to the consumer who *demands* that every item they buy arrive by special messenger "Overnight" from UPS or Prime or the hundreds of private delivery "disruptors" I see clogging the streets with their own cars dropping off a shirt that UPS paid them a dollar to deliver.

Thanks Steve Jobs.
Name: ck

comment: I'm not stylish and never have been  so all this is a mystery to me  but these comments -- let's be fair. "Nice" clothes made of silk and natural fabric cost much  much more and they are not appropriate for the lives these young women are living -- they don't seem to work in lawyer land.  Secondly  I didn't hear any of the women talking about throwing away their clothes. They donate them or sell them and they are part of a clothes recycling and resale community that their social media presence enables. And finally -- yes  the fact that people are paid $2 a day to make horrible cheap clothes is awful.  It is clearly not the fault of GenZ that this is the world we live in.
Name: jennifer

comment:
I've travelled a lot in a life that's now stretching toward the end. Forty years ago  in India  walking with a pack in remote areas  I often encountered interesting fellow travelers  from many countries.
No longer. Now  the young people from Europe or Australia or  rarely  the States  cluster at the coastal resorts. They no longer speak; no longer wish to meet strangers. They sit  looking at their phone.
Name: john

comment:
“ Interviews have been edited for style and clarity.”
Noted.

Seriously  though  I’m so happy I grew up before documenting one’s daily life was the norm.  It sounds exhausting.
Name: karen

comment: One of them says: "Style is about changing for whatever the situation you are in and for different events." No  she is wrong. Style is about having a personal stamp  a signature look  a presentation and way of being. Think about Audrey Hepburn. That scoop neck little black dress. She didn't need a thousand pieces of garbage. Real style does not depend on that.
Name: eva

comment:
Teenage girls being themselves. Issue is not excess clothes which have been the marker of cool forever but excess photos. If you're being constantly scrutinized on social media how can you wear the same outfit twice?

Turn. It. Off.
Name: ag

comment:
Hello what’s wrong with wearing an outfit twice? It takes creativity to recycle the outfit  plus it will save you money and it’s also good for the environment.

Another idea is to get subscription boxes - although that idea made me cringe. I am glad I dress for myself and my comfort and not for others to praise.
Name: tsl

comment: This is what drives our consumption based society.  The more consumption the faster our economy grows.   We all had unique priorities when we were young   this generations are different and driven by other forces.  At 16 I had to have a car  go out to the mall and spend my money on my personal priorities.  Now it is working hard  paying for college and saving for retirement.   Things change   but the desire and freedom these girls have to do what they find important is inspiring.  They to will change and look back as their priorities become different.  This generation of Gen Zrs are changing society.  I am biased because I have 2.  Glad to see them wanting to live life on their terms and leverage the social media tools we gave them in their own pursuit of happiness.  Makes you wonder if Instagram survives once this generation moves on.
Name: timothy

comment: Used to be that the style books recommended one or two good pieces a year  that you could accessorize and combine for a lot of different looks and wear for years. Advice was to use good shoulder shaped hangers  mend seams  sew on buttons  polished shoes. It was simpler  and took a lot less time  and once you found your style  you could always look good. I enjoy wearing favorite things over and over and thinking about the nice times I had wearing them over the years  and the compliments I have gotten.
Name: rural

comment: My mother sent my sisters and me to sewing classes at the local Singer store. We ended up with the ability to make the most unique cutting edge fashions by adapting patterns and sourcing interesting fabric. Not fast fashion but no one had the same outfit.
Name: sm

comment: Very thankful those web-stores exists  I don't know how could I do if my daughters were to shop at net-a-porter  mytheresa  ... they occasionally come with full basket of clothes ranging from $2 to $10 they found at SHEIN  and I am happy to pay for it. Balenciaga is overrated  Gucci looks so old  Lagerfeld is dead  Bernard Arnauld so rich.
Name: gazmend

comment:
Sad that this is the generation that thinks "OK  Boomer" is a clever retort to anything that they don't like about the baby boomer generation.

I'm a late boomer and proud of it -- and all that we've accomplished! Are we perfect? No. But a lot of good has been done. 

And where would Gen Z be without snapchat  Instagram  online shopping and all the technology that drives their world? Technology driven and built on the foundation envisioned by us Boomers!

Now go shop and fill those landfills!
Name: linda

comment: How I wish they would read Sasaki’s book “Goodby  Things” and decide to follow his suggestion of simplifying life by wearing a uniform of one’s choice - maybe  in this case  a pair of quality black jeans  black turtleneck  black boots (maybe two of the former  for laundry purposes!). Maybe  and this is a big maybe - they’d be amazed at how freeing this is - on so many levels: environmental  mental  consumer/economic  psychological  not to mention - chic! Go figure.
Name: ninamargo

comment: American teenagers live very artificial lives with all their makeup  hair styling tools  spanx... things I was introduced to when I came to the USA from India at age 30.
Name: rajani

comment: They are destroying the planet over nothing. Fast fashion is an environmental disaster.
Name: amn

comment:
The narcissism displayed by these young women is  is depressing.  It's one thing to care about how you look.  It's quite another to be obsessed with it all day every day  posting photographs of yourself and breathlessly waiting for positive comments.  

Maybe we haven't come such a long way  after all.
Name: lauraf

comment: O.K. they are teenagers  so hopefully they will learn fairly soon that they don't have to worry about being objectified as women since they are doing it themselves!
Name: rebecca

comment: Clothes are fun but to make them the center of your on line- off line life is dramatic. Who cares really ?
Name: jo

comment: The first girl from the UK is the spitting image of my teenaged daughter...I swear she wore the identical outfit this past weekend!  I thought she was the only one immersed in throwaway fashion.  I came of financial age during the celebrity designer era of the 90s and would eat rice and beans for months to save for a status handbag.  I have shoes that are older than my daughter and have lovingly preserved every starved for Chanel jacket for her.  But nope  she doesn't want any of it!  GenZ...go figger!
Name: annaliviaplurabelle

comment: Obviously  only "woke" when it allows them to criticize other people's lives. This throwaway "fashion" is very bad for the planet and the carbon footprint. What hypocrisy.
Name: lona

comment:
Come on guys! These are very young women having a good time.  Criticisms of the younger generation as heedless and wasteful are as old as the human race.

My hope is that in ten years  these young women will be thinking less about their faces and bodies and more about the world around them. I hope that we  the people who designed our earth-consuming global capitalism  have left them a world in which to mature.
Name: jo

comment: And the impact on the world’s climate continues on as these vapid women strive to look good for an instant on instagram with clothes they will wear once or twice then discard. Please don’t tell me how millennials  Gen X’ers  Z’ers or any other alphabet self-absorbed group cares about the environment.
Name: steve

comment: These children have bought into the mindless  wasteful consumption patterns that the corporations want from consumers.  Tragic and depressing portraits of unaware kids who have no idea how they have allowed themselves to be cogs in the wheel of capitalist destruction of the environment.
Name: le

comment:
Wait  miniature backs are no longer in? Are they out? I just got some for people for Xmas.

But seriously as someone who has developed a destructive habit of buying things online (an environmentalist and self-described minimalist theoretically!)  I can say that shopping habit is like smoking cigarettes. When you’re a smoker  you’re constantly planning when you’ll have another throughout the day  anxiously biding the time you’re not smoking. When you quit  you don’t even notice all those increments of time that used to semi-consume you. 

Man  if I could get myself down (and I do donate to a battered women’s shelter as much as I can—sadly there are always people really in need quite nearby—to seven outfits total or less I’d feel so much better  FREER. But at least stopping buying stuff...

As for the selfies thing—it’s a really depressing phenomenon but I guess younger generations (I’m 37) can’t see the “big picture” right now. I’m glad I’m no then because I am not photogenic. The whole thing seems basically fine-ish for photographically attractive people  but doesn’t it kind of make many other people feel bad about themselves unless they have the (right-minded) strength to “buy out”?
Name: juliet

comment:
Is no one talking to these young women and men about the people making the cheap clothes? The conditions the workers endure? This isn't really style...it's homogeneity in appearance and addiction to new stuff. And like other addictions  a great harm is done to the source of the "drug."
Posted by P. Thayer's spouse.
Name: p

comment: This is such an utterly depressing article. Someone needs to educate these teens on how their clothes are made and what happens to them afterwards. These kind of kids make me fear for our future. But hopefully they will learn and get better.
Name: bnygal

comment: As a millennial  I’ve pinned my hopes for climate change awareness  environmental advocacy and desire for sustainability on my generation and those below me  but Greta generation this is not. What a waste.
Name: heather

comment:
What they should be doing is buying and reading books.

Das Kapital  for starters.
Name: raven

comment: If we make college education "free" for these folks  they'd have more money for clothes and accessories. /sarc
Name: h

comment: Gen Z wants a livable planet. Cmon.
Name: l

comment:
The #metoo movement has been very effective in stamping out unacceptable behavior by powerful men in high profile positions. A similar movement could work in stamping out unacceptable behavior by companies like Fashion Nova  which should not be allowed to turn a blind eye to suffering  exploitation  and abuse of a work force that is predominantly women.

Cardi B could be a powerful voice by demanding that all of the workers making clothing for Fashion Nova are paid and treated in accordance with law  not just her clothing line.
Name: david

comment: The whole fast fashion industry is immoral on many levels. It creates an obscene amount of waste and promotes incredibly unsustainable buying habits that result in tons  yes tons  of clothing going into landfills. And don’t believe the greenwashing that some of these companies are trying to do when they say they will take the clothes back. For a really good take on this  watch Hasan Minaj’s episode of Patriot Act on the subject.
Name: eric

comment:
We continue to read  in this publication among others  that the US job market is strong. Yet many US workers are relegated to working for a pittance and in squalor  with the threat hanging over their heads that their employers can get the job done for less overseas. While workers in the developing world have every right to better their lives  what we’ve actually done in fostering this race to the bottom is to exploit all workers.

More conservative economists state that in a “perfect” market  there should be no need for a minimum wage. But there’s no such thing. There is no invisible hand  just unscrupulous actors looking to put their thumb on the scale.
Name: sean

comment:
“We assume the workers are getting paid minimum wage.”

They all know better: they just don’t care.
Name: ert

comment: This isn’t something that hasn’t been going on for ages.  Kathee Lee  Nike  et al.  Fashion made with the blood sweat and tears of people being paid little to nothing.
Name: really

comment:
As long as these "influencers" get their clicks  right?
Sad.
Name: dc

comment: It has always bothered me when people are vehemently anti-fur but many think nothing of wearing sweatshop clothing either from this country or from around the globe. Or they never question where and how the electronics they value so much are manufactured or where the key elements for the same are mined and under what conditions as they post.
Name: marielle

comment:
“They need to buy a lot of different styles and probably only wear them a couple times so their Instagram feeds can stay fresh ”

The moral bankruptcy of this sentence is staggering.  How wasteful and polluting consumer culture can permeate even the most politically liberal parts of our country shows how little we understand the global environmental emergency we face- or refuse to face  at our own peril.  

An international conference attempting to create a treaty that would address the main part of this unfolding disaster has disbanded with very little media scrutiny  although its importance to our species eclipses coverage of the Trump impeachment circus (with the clowns primarily supplied by the GOP). 

Meanwhile  it is still culturally acceptable to purchase clothing worn twice and then disposed of with no personal responsibility required on the impact of such behavior on our environment.  

I'm feeling like a stranger in a strange land as I read about the accelerating die-off of species  an increasing human population that  adds almost 200 thousand people to feed  clothe and shelter every day  oceans choking for oxygen and studies that tell of a climate warming much faster than was previously predicted.  Meanwhile the world as a whole continues do display no sense of urgency.  

Yes  we need to protect the wages of workers in this country and abroad  but if we allow ourselves to be distracted from our main challenge  almost everything else just won't matter.
Name: alan

comment: If these so called influencers have this much power maybe one day they can  push for buying local  promoting real  honest retailers  that source their goods  instead of really cheap  throwaway clothes.   ha ha. I'm dreaming.
Name: linnea

comment:
We need our courts to fast track some of these cases of unscrupulous employers exploiting workers (undocumented or not) with sweatshop conditions and illegal wages and and throw THEM in jail for once  rather than their “slave laborers.” 

Companies like Nova turn a blind eye to the human misery
“sewn” into their clothes  as long as the price is right.
Name: susan

comment:
Made in America.

What's not to like?
Name: michael

comment:
I'm astounded that there's still ANY garment industry left in the US.   I'm NOT surprised that wages are so low.   

Piecework is pretty much guaranteed to leave workers underpaid.   The fastest workers are used to set rates.  Most will never come close to the speed needed to make a decent wage.
Name: cynicalskeptic

comment: Tell Greta!
Name: lon

comment:
People in our country illegally should not even be working.

This is an affront to every immigrant who comes legally and every citizen trying to get a job.
Name: randy

comment: I'm glad NYT is shining a light on this issue. It's not a big surprise though. My mother worked in a garment factory for most of my childhood. She would sometimes bring us to work because there was no way she could afford a babysitter. The conditions were terrible. What a privilege it must be for anyone is who "shocked" by all this.
Name: mark

comment:
If you buy clothes that are so cheap you know people are not getting paid

Clothes are made by humans. They are not stamped
Name: mary

comment: Am always amazed when an article like this garners so few comments.Most folks dont CARE!!
Name: jai

comment:
I don't know who is worse off  these very low income people or lower middle class wage owners who are being hit from every side number one being lack of affordable health insurance.

Let the rich guy make as much as he wants as long as the above two groups have a quality  affordable living. 

Right now it is not happening.
Name: paul

comment:
Employers should not be allowed to employ ANYONE (US citizen  legally or illegally in the US) below minimum wage  and the law should be enforced.
That would eliminate resentment towards illegal immigrants driving down wages  and eliminate the perverse incentive for employers to hire illegal immigrants for sweat-shops wages.
Name: atutu

comment:
This has been going on in Los Angeles for years  think American Apparel. There is no magic in making inexpensive clothing  cheap labor is the key.
Amazon was discovered making garments in Bangladesh the were not approved by an industry watchdog group.
Why  cheap labor.
Name: hps

comment: It's naive to imagine that "cheap" anything has zero repercussions. What we think  say and do  matters; not only to people in our immediate neighborhood; it can affect both neighborhoods down the block and a "world" away. We are all in this together.
Name: gail

comment: The system is intentionally set up this way: the article says the retailers aren’t being fined  so where is the disincentive to continue? Viva capitalism  US-style. Oh sorry  I thought it was all about sustainability now  good governance  mindfulness about social issues? What does Cardi B think about this?
Name: winteca

comment:
The garment industry has always been  source of entry level jobs for new immigrants  and unfortunately they have always been exploited.  This helped lead to the rise of the garment unions in NYC early in the twentieth century.  These workers would benefit from union organizers engaging with them.  
What they could use  even more  are protective tariffs  not just against Chinese imports but from all countries.  If this means consumers pay 10 or 15 percent more for their clothes  so be it.  People deserve a living wage for their hard work.
Name: scott

comment:
Anyone who has ever had anything to do with the San Gabriel Valley can tell you this sort of thing has been going on for longer than I have been alive  and is absolutely rampant  and is by no means restricted to the fashion industry.

It is exploitation of the worst kind and it exists because it pays.  Wage theft is by far the leading theft loss mechanism in the United States today  and this is so because nobody cares.   People are too busy making money off it.

There are ways to isolate the beneficial owners of such a sweatshop from the sweatshop itself.  Thus  if the shop gets shut down it does not impact the owners  who look at the risk of shut down and/or loss of equipment and stock simply as the cost of doing business.  Until this changes such practices will continue.

And they won't change.  Such change would take teeth in the wage laws  and real enforcement  and that just ain't gonna happen.  The people practicing wage theft know precisely what they are doing and it is cheaper to buy a politician or two to prevent enforcement than to obey the law.

Welcome to America.  Now get back to work.
Name: alternate

comment: This situation  is the result of the half-century push for "free trade" and open borders.  Originally  American citizens were put into direct competition with semi-slave labor abroad; there was no way for US based production to compete. So the production has been pushed abroad to slaves  or kept here by not meeting US production laws and employing illegal immigrants under the table.
Name: si

comment: Over one hundred years ago Italian and Jewish immigrant women made lots of our clothing; they were poorly paid  put in dangerous locations  and suffered greatly.  In time their families rose into the middle classes and did well  becoming the strength of America.  The same is happening now with other groups of immigrants and poor people.  Instead of weeping over them  give them a chance to work and to succeed.  It take time and effort. Stop the sentimentality.
Name: n

comment: What’s the translation of ‘clothing shame’ into Swedish?
Name: winteca

comment: Not only trashing workers  but trashing the planet.  Wearing something just one or two times??
Name: karenanne

comment: It may be time to bring back the Union Label on clothes that was popular during much of the days of ILGWU power.
Name: mg

comment:
This  and people who do not care about others' lives  is the problem: "Under federal law  brands cannot be penalized for wage theft in factories if they can credibly claim that they did not know their clothes were made by workers paid illegally low wages."

The fact that our Legislature drafted this 'catch me if you can' miserable excuse for labor law clearly demonstrates that it's time to throw the bums out of Congress.  We need term limits in Congress  and fast.
Name: j

comment: And yet another reason to avoid social media. Every tried to speak with a live human versus interacting with (mostly) fake digital wrapper?
Name: shantanu

comment:
Ms. Kitroeff 

You have totally missed the meat of this story. Where are the interviews of state and federal legislators who are responsible for supporting the laws which insulate retail from the workers? You write as if this sorry state is a fait accompli.
Name: rh

comment: I expected cheap labor to be a major factor in affordable clothing. But reading such an in depth article was quite eye opening. I never knew how bad the working conditions were. Great journalism!
Name: m

comment:
We listen to the politicians cry and complain about the conditions the employees of companies that make products off-shore for our market.
We are appalled about the working conditions  say  Bangladesh  in which that country has had a few tragedies concerning their sweatshops.
Bring the work here Trump brays.  He brags about those jobs HE created.  He bleats  along with McConnell  Graham and many other monied people  that regulations are killing our job market making it hard for employers to create jobs.

Well  oh capitalists  free market scions  Trump supporters.
Here are the jobs you hoped for.  Sweatshops  piece part pay.  Working conditions in factories that up until days of Trump may have been shuttered until compliance with those terrible and pesky rules that were created to protect the worker from abusive employers.

Yesiree.  We want that product at the lowest price  always  yet turn a blind eye to those who make the product-the vulnerable and easily exploited-who basically become indentured servants.

Yes  I can hear the screeching concerning those employees who are here illegally-send them back  this is what they deserve for being illegal.  But  I suppose rules are only for pure Americans.
Name: dan

comment: when workers cannot afford to live  the right wing becomes resurgent. it's only a matter of time. there will be fewer and fewer middle class people  more and more poor people  and a thin slice of super wealthy people in gated and armed redoubts.
Name: no

comment:
"her pay varied depending on how quickly her fingers could move. Ms. Cortes was paid for each piece of a shirt she sewed together" 

That's standard garment manufacturing industry practice  and it has been since the beginning. No factory owner is going to pay a slow worker for piece-work the same as he or she pays a much faster worker. The way it works out is that the factories end up staffed only with fast workers.
Name: bayarea

comment: This report underscores the crucial role that celebrity plays in sustaining a very inequitable economic system.
Name: jim

comment:
Much of this us tied to some people’s disgusting need to consume cheap clothing like a throw away. 

But a lot is tied to our laws that let companies subcontract work out and then claim ignorance of the actual conditions. 


Clearly a big lift with a Republican senate and a MAGA president  but the Dems in the house should at least start the process.
Name: midwest

comment: There is a flip side to this story.  No work at all.  As these sweatshop stories have proliferated over the last two decades  honest manufacturers - who are trying to keep jobs in the US - find it nearly impossible to make things affordably and legally in Los Angeles. The result is to send everything out of state or overseas. This downtown garment industry is a shadow of its former self. And it has lost the highly skilled workers who used to make long-lasting  fine garments.  Those days are long gone. All that is left is the bottom of the barrel fast fashion -- and not much of that either.
Name: the

comment: Shame  too  on the complicit so-called "influencers".
Name: heidi

comment:
Business "leaders" like Fashion Nova's GC  Erica Meierhans  should be ashamed of themselves.  However  what should we expect when generations of students are raised in academic environments where economic results are promoted as the ultimate measuring stick of success and human value?

Yes  there is a direct connection between academic  university culture and corporate exploitation.  Law schools  for example  is no longer have academic environments fostering the principles of justice  but  rather  servce as a mechanism to understand and use the legal system to make mo' money  mo' money.
Name: alexandre

comment:
I just read another article on NYT about the decade tech lost its way.

I have news for everyone: the main goal of technology in business is to replace human workers.

Automated systems are cheaper n the long run because management can downsize their HR department due to the decrease in employees.  The workers in this article are no different.  They are not considered human employees by management  but a cost to be minimized in the production of goods.

Management wants to minimize the amount they pay workers  which then forces them to shop at discount outlets that - ahem - sell at a lower price because the goods are made by minimizing the cost of human labor.

Either that or shop online and buy from Amazon  who minimizes the human cost through automated distribution centers. How long before your pizza order is delivered by a robot or flying drone?  That will happen when management deems the technology cheaper than paying people.

So what happens to all those people that no longer earn wages?
Name: chris

comment: The number of ills that have created this situation is pretty staggering.  Social media  and the desire of scads of people to be famous on some level - rejecting the mundanity of an off-camera life in exchange for likes and follows.  The ubiquity of "fast fashion" - which seems to depend entirely upon exploitation of workers.  The economic stagnation that means that people can only afford  and have gotten accustomed to  cheap clothes - mostly from countries that also exploit their labor forces.  The egregious weakening of our labor unions.  The obliviousness of most of us to the true human cost of fast and cheap fashion (I am complicit too - every time I buy a piece of clothing at "40% off" the list price that no retailer ever actually sells at).  The law should be changed to take away the false screen between the brand and the manufacturer  (i.e. the "subcontractor").   And we would all benefit from understanding the cradle to grave cost of all our garments.
Name: eloisebig

comment: So what are we to assume about the workers in Vietnam  Maylasia and other countries who toil putting together clothes for Ralph Lauren ?
Name: john

comment: It's not difficult to find out if you are doing business with a sweatshop. Before establishing a business relationship with a supplier  the companies selling this clothing should hire a private investigation company to do a background check on the company making the clothes they sell to find out how much they are paying their employees to produce the clothing. To incentivize these background checks  there should also be significant monetary penalties for companies that sell clothing manufactured by sweatshops.
Name: william

comment: Wouldn’t it be nice to see an “influencer” make a point of wearing the same outfit multiple times (God  forbid!) and choosing clothing that is ethically sourced!
Name: andrea

comment: Grifter capitalism at its' best. The sweatshop was the first GIG economy.
Name: donald

comment:
Shame on Cardi B. 

Shame on Fashion Nova. 

Shame on any Instagram poster.

Shame on us all for buying or accepting or ignoring any product made by people forced to accept FAR LESS than minimum wage. 

American Consumers must stand up for workers and demand fair wages for anything they wear  eat  sit on  etc. We must demand fair wages for all - and be willing to understand and pay the value of a product produced by fair wages.

Nothing cool about looking the other way  pretending not to know. Nothing cool about wearing clothing produced by slave-wage labor. 

Thanks NYT for letting us know  again...and again...and again.
Name: suzanne

comment: So it turns out that fast fashion isn't just bad for the planet  it's bad for people as well.
Name: fenella

comment: Secret?? What secret?? It's only a secret to those who have absolutely no knowledge of how the world works. This has been going on for centuries!! How did cool trendies and fashionistas THINK clothes were made??
Name: stevevelo

comment: About three years ago  the Los Angles Times did an investigative report on this very topic. Wages at about $4 or less per hour. However  the stores involved were discount stores found in malls.
Name: kb

comment: So..... The Dems are moving too far to the left???? Excuse me? It’s nothing but right wing policies that allow greed and slavery like this to exist along with a healthy dose of corporate scumbaggery. The shamelessness of our society is simply staggering. This is what comes of destroying worker’s unions. We’re living in a 21st century gilded age of robber barons.
Name: tim

comment:
"Under federal law  brands cannot be penalized for wage theft in factories if they can credibly claim that they did not know their clothes were made by workers paid illegally low wages."

So under federal law  slavery is legal.
Name: george

comment: Instagram notwithstanding  not very much has changed in clothing factories in the last 100 years. Shades of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory and Norma Rae!
Name: laurence

comment: Anyone who is buying and wearing these brands needs to think where and how are these made. Those who are profiting from the labor need to be punished not by going to jail but instead being made to work for the wages they pay for a number of years. Until they walk in the shoes of those they abuse nothing will change.
Name: john

comment:
I’ve seen the workers picking strawberries in the fields of California. It’s a job I would never want. Strawberries are fairly cheap  especially in season  likely due to underpaid  possibly illegal  labor. Am I willing to pay more?

While I may drive past factories where people are sewing my clothes together  I don’t see them. Still  I’m pretty sure it’s also not a job I would want. And it’s likely a job held by an underpaid and possibly illegal laborer. Am I willing to pay more for my clothes?

Here’s what hurts to admit: even if I pay more  clearly it won’t assure the worker is paid fairly. 

Our economy is broken when it sits upon the need for us to spend more and more and more and when it sits upon the backs of those who are deemed disposable and dispensable. 

Sadly  too many think all is well in our economy if all is well for them.
Name: as

comment: This is not only about the way the workers are being treated  but additionally about the waste that is being generated by fast fashon which is designed to be worn once or twice and discarded.
Name: charmaine

comment: If we had a real labor department that was truly set up to protect workers rather than the corporations  companies like Fashion Nova and all their shadow companies would be shutdown rather they are allowed to operate with slaps on their wrists while still abusing workers freely.
Name: mahew

comment: Here are some clothing manufacturers who advertise their fair wages and ethical materials sourcing practices:  Blue Canoe  Toad & Co.  Indigenous.  There are many  many more like these.  If the customer looks around online  h/she will find no shortage of opportunities to buy and wear clothing which has none of the stigmas discussed in this article.
Name: pella

comment: Consume consume consume: the underlying ethos of our economic system  which never fails in its exclusion of the environment as a consideration; nor  of course  of justice to its economically most fragile. Only eco-economics can put us on the path of preserving the natural world and ourselves.  But we're apparently too impressed by the endorsements of celebrities to see through the implications of our unyielding consumption.
Name: vincenzo

comment:
Nothing new here.
It would be easier for the National Rifle Association (NRA) to accept federal regulation than the Republicans in Congress to legislate a minimum wage increase. They continue winning an election because there is a real divide in America between the poor and capitalism. Nobody is speaking for the poor except Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders. In November 2020  we can give them a mandate. Vote in November 2020.
Name: afrikanneer

comment: This article makes me physically ill. Our values are so out of wack. Where do we start the cleanup? Hold the brands accountable  NOW.
Name: joe

comment:
Sweat shops are Trump’s life blood.
Disparaged  out of sight laborers.
Just take a look at the tags on MAGA caps or Ivanka goods.
Name: db

comment: don't like it dont buy it. simple as that.
Name: justin

comment: Human vanity and selfishness is boundless.
Name: rick

comment: Clothes that look expensive?  You have got to be kidding!
Name: lawyermom

comment:
Fast fashion is bad for everyone. If these clothes cost so little  obviously they are poorly made and by slave labor. Shop second hand: it’s better for everyone. 

I must say I’m glad that I am at an age where I no longer care about being “in style.”

comment:
“They need to buy a lot of different styles and probably only wear them a couple times so their Instagram feeds can stay fresh ” Richard Saghian  Fashion Nova’s founder  said in an interview last year.

And I'm sure these same people constantly pat themselves on the back as they demand no straws in their drinks.
Name: beyond

comment: How can we stop in an effective way the insanity and cruelty of fast fashion? So destructive for the planet and the people working in it!
Name: ana

comment: and that means most of the clothing  worn once or twice by an "influencer"  ends up in a landfill. I wish those influencers would use their powers for good

comment: In what way do Fashion Nova’s clothes “ look expensive” ? Expensive to me would mean well-made. The patterns in the waist band and the base of those plaid pants do not even line up.   To me they look as if they were made by people who are paid by piece work ( and exploited). Maybe we need to get away from fast fashion and go back to having fewer  well-made clothes that last.
Name: maggie

comment: And where are the criminal charges against the owners of these plants  both for underpayment of wages and for hiring illegal aliens?
Name: jim

comment:
Federal law. If they can ‘credibly claim’ they didn’t know of illegally low wages  undocumented workers. Weasel words. Designed to avoid liability. 

And what has this president  this administration  this Senate  done in the past 3  years for it’s base- American workers wanting a fair  living wage? How is E-Verify coming along (with it’s own weasel wording)? Has it proposed new legislation  tightening up laws that allow these practices? 

Any new legislative ....incentives ...to states that tighten up their incorporation laws on name changes  responsibility?

No. But build that Wall. Sooner or later  that...base...is going to realize they’ve been scammed. 

As for the so-called celebrities wearing these sweatshop garments. Maybe they should try and find the factories  do a televised tour. Take a break from their well-paid careers. 

Do not wonder why progressives  wanting major changes  are causing jitters in the corporate world.
Name: jo

comment:
"The working relationship would continue  unless workers file another complaint against the same factory or another one that the contractor hired during those six months. At that point  the brand will suspend the contractor until it passes a third-party audit."


This is supposed to address the problem?  Seriously?  If the contractor wasn't paying its employees in the past  it won't in future  either  because the fines imposed by the government in the unlikely event they get caught are much smaller than what they'd owe if they paid what the law requires.

I would argue the government - be it federal  state  or local - needs to do more  to ensure that it's more costly *not* to obey the law than it is to obey it.  Until then  consumers should  at an absolute minimum  treat Fashion Nova to the same 6-month probationary period.  Every time one of their suppliers doesn't comply with the law  consumers stop buying their brand  with the probations running consecutively every time they're busted.  At 50 investigations finding Fashion Nova brands made by underpaid workers  I guess we'll see you in 2044  Fashion Nova.

Of course  I'd never even heard of "fast fashion" before  much less bought anything from that industry  so it's not like they're actually going to lose my business when they never had it.  Guess we'll see how socially responsible the "Instagram elite" and their followers may be...
Name: joe

comment:
We can wring our hands and reach for our fainting couches all we want.  But until we either start making all our own clothes or refuse to buy inexpensive clothing -- whether made in the US or abroad -- this problem will continue.

The simplest thing is probably to buy fewer  more expensive and better made items.  Stop trying to follow instant fashion.  Learn to craft your own clothing (whether that be sewing  knitting  crocheting).  If you really want to take it to an extreme  learn to weave and make your own fabric -- it's less difficult than you might think.

Of course  none of that helps the people who are so desperate for money that they work at these sweatshops  whether they be in the US or in other countries.  I'm not sure what the answer to that is
Name: jm

comment:
Nobody should be surprised when reading stories such as these. The media has reported human abuse in this and many other industries worldwide for decades  yet we still buy and wear our "designer" outfits without regard to the indignities piled on those whose hands make them.

I am the grandson of two immigrants who spent their entire lives here in the USA weaving fabrics for what would become Brooks Brothers clothing. When she retired after 40+ years that often included 12-hours-plus days at her plant  my grandmother was making what was then just above the minimum wage. She lived in a "company town" where all prices were controlled by a single individual and she came from England at a time when our minimum wage was not to be complained. 

But she  like the workers here and at other "fancy" apparel factories around the world  was abused by her rich overlords.
Name: michiganmichael

comment: Why do you suppose UNIONS were created in the first place? It is " Man's inhumanity to man" that will never go away. This country is floundering   and the only way we can stop being abused by those employers who have no ethics is to have a collective voice and effective laws to enforce them.  Bring back UNIONS and the rule of law!
Name: pam

comment:
In California a clothing manufacturer is required to have a 
Garment License issued by the California Labor Standards
Enforcement Department. The initial application requires a test
at a department office and there is an annual renewal fee based
on revenue - $750.00 on up. My small company had annual 
inspections  time cards and invoices examined and employees
interviewed in private. Small  disputable violations were always
found  with fines in the $200.00 to $300.00 amount for each.
We did not appeal  however some companies did  and these
appeals required significant time and resources from the department and their legal staff. The result was that the companies that always appealed were not issued violations unless
 it was flagrant. Being in business since the late 1970's ( I'm
retired) I did not encounter abusive sweat shops in any of the many companies I did business with in the SF Bay Area.
The Labor Standards Department has an "Enforcement" policy
rather than a supportive and educational one  often resulting
in companies leaving California - loss of jobs - and smaller
"Good" companies giving up.
Name: ta

comment:
Why do we have laws when the only punishment for ignoring them is having to pay back what you stole from your employees?  If you did it on the street you'd end up in court and/or jail.

Also  we're talking about the federal laws here.  Doesn't/shouldn't California have its own minimum wage  given its high cost of living and enforce it properly?
Name: pj

comment:
Fine them into oblivion. 

How many labor law violations is a company allowed to accrue?
Name: kusala

comment: 20 years ago I worked as an auditor for several clothing name brands. I conducted surprise payroll and health and safety audits of garment factories  in Mexico  Central America  and Southeast Asia. Of all locations worldwide  downtown Los Angeles consistently displayed the MOST egregious violations. The practice of factory owners changing business entity names  etc. was (and is) all too common. Until the factory owners themselves are held personally responsible (civil liabilities / assets seized)  nothing will change. Perhaps the creation of a fund (where all garment employers would be required to pay into - similar to Workman's Comp) would hold owners financially responsible.
Name: carlos

comment:
It's not an entirely fair comparison to write  "Amante paid Karis $2.20 to sew each garment. Fashion Nova sold the top for $17.99" implying a profit of $15.79

There's the cost of materials  freight  shipping to the customer (usps/fedex/usps)  warehouse labor  consumer discounts  overhead  advertising spend  customer returns  etc.

All of this taken together means probably $2-3 profit per item. While this doesn't necessarily justify Karis' labor wage  there are LOTS of middlemen who get paid out of the difference between the consumer price and the cost of one aspect of labor.
Name: gw

comment: Unfortunately  these practices are absolutely the norm worldwide and there is little to no oversight overseas. Fashion companies all make the claim they subcontracted out and pretend there’s nothing they can do. Certain sustainable brands include their garment workers and factories on their websites. The clothes are more expensive but reflective of the actual cost of the garment: as in someone somewhere is paying for that “steal”. If it’s not you  the customer  it’s probably the garment worker. Secondhand is also a good way to go until some oversight has been established in these factories. (Another one just burned down in india. The staircases were locked up and I believe about 40 mostly young men just died.) Meanwhile  so many clothes are being produced  companies can’t even sell them all and end up burning a lot of them. Or  if sold  they don’t even get worn at all and end up in the secondhand market here or overseas  glutting the clothing markets in Africa. Here only about 30% of your donations even end up being sold. It’s a mess.
Name: izzy

comment: I'm not surprised  downtown LA has always had sweatshops.   It's just like the "Italian" clothes made by Chinese workers in Prato  called made in Italy .  Really  it is Instagram which is driving this little sector.

comment:
I’d wager that many of the workers who are clearly being exploited are not here legally  which is one reason they don’t personally make claims through the Worker’s Compensation system or private attorneys who specialize in bringing unfair labor practice claims to court.   

This is yet another example of the demand side of illegal immigration.   If we had a robust identification system under which only legal entrants with work permits or visas  or citizens  could be hired and paid  illegal immigration would not be nearly the problem it has been and remains  and we sure would not need a crazy  giant wall.

comment:
Every Night & every Morn 
Some to Misery are Born 
Every Morn and every Night 
Some are Born to sweet delight 
Some are Born to sweet delight 
Some are Born to Endless Night 

From: Auguries of Innocence  William Blake

I think about these lines every time I read a piece like this. The world is  as ever  so deeply unequal. And for what? A cheaply-made Cardi B-endorsed throwaway item of clothing. 

Human systems of governance have found no good answer to this inequality. The system we have now (which is the only paradigm globally today) is failing miserably in this regard. 

Can we escape a slide into total decadence  total abuse  followed by either fascism or revolution (or both)?

comment: Conditions haven't changed much since the days of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in 1911 (146 dead). We had the Tazreen Fashions factory fire in Bangladesh in 2012 (112 dead) and then the collapse of the Rana Plaza building that killed 1 134 garment workers. A 2016 fire at a garment factory in India killed 13. Just this month 43 workers were killed in another factory fire in India.

comment: There is no bottom to the level of quality Americans will accept for cheaper prices. Most Americans cannot afford pieces that last 10 years  or the upkeep to maintain them. Do the math. comment: Many commenters here are calling on the Times to do a piece on companies whose affordable clothing is produced ethically  with fair and transparent labor practices. Others are listing such companies in this section  but in the interest of really spreading the word and reaching a wider audience  I think the Times should profile them and make it front-page news. There are many out there who might not do the research on their own  but would gladly make a point of spending their money if the facts are right in front of their faces. We can sit here all day cursing and lamenting the bad. I would like to publicize  patronize and support those who are good.
Name: barton

comment:
In a fully free market  a buyer need have no concern about how the product is produced. The buyer need only pay the lowest bidder.

To avoid exploitation in free markets  we regulate markets and their participants. 

We can require buyers to certify that labor conditions are safe  paid not less than $15/hour (regardless of country of origin)  and just. 

Even the retail end customer could be required  on pain of fine  to buy from firms that display on the purchasing document or clothing tag that their suppliers are certified to have adhered to fair labor conditions.

We can end the claims of "I'm not responsible" for the hunger and despair of the people who expend their lives making our clothes.
Name: daniel

comment: The wages paid to these workers are criminal. I started sewing my own clothing and thrifting the rest about a year ago. It takes me hours to make a single garment. It’s time to stop supporting the fast fashion industry. In addition to exploiting workers  it is a major cause of pollution (through toxic dyes and textile waste).

comment: What an apt metaphor for the New Gilded Age  in which it’s not just the rich  but the narcissistic wanna-bes that take part in the exploitation.

comment:

We already know that factories overseas are filthy places.  It’s a fools game to think that factories being forced to have proper fire exits - as in workers are not kept as prisoners until orders are done - care one bit about roaches and rodents.

NAFTA and open trade ruined forever American apparel manufacturing.  There is simply no way to make apparel at correct prices.

comment: These days  I sew my own clothes. I try to buy fabric that's produced responsibly  but it's extremely difficult. But at least  I know the clothes aren't made in a sweat shop--here or abroad.

comment: Companies always pretend they did not know about the problems in their supply chain. comment: I avoid fast fashion like the plague.  I'd rather spend $7.99 at Goodwill on used brand name clothing because 1) they will last longer than any fast fashion items; and 2) it's recycling!  I've found denim that was originally more than $200 for less than $20.
Name: deborah

comment:
When my family immigrated here from Hong Kong 50 years ago  both my parents worked in the rag trade in LA's Chinatown. My mother bought a machine to do piecework at home. I helped her out in small ways at home  and then I eventually would go to the "factory" (that's what my brother and I called it) to do some work bagging clothes  putting on hang tags or whatnot. I may have been 8 yrs old or something like that. I didn't consider it slave labor because I didn't know better  and all I knew was that I was helping my mom. The owners of the factory as far as I knew were not exploiting my mom even though I knew she was paid by the piece. That was the way things were; there probably wasn't any other way seamstresses were getting paid then. The working conditions weren't great but I don't recall seeing roaches or rats.
Both my parents worked very hard (my dad eventually cooking in restaurants)  scraped together enough money to by a house  and saw my brother and I graduate college. My mom's hard work should have earned her a restful retirement  but unfortunately  she was killed crossing the street 3 years ago by a distracted delivery driver. If there's justice in this world  I'm still waiting to see it. There will always be people working hard at the bottom propping up the people at the top  who keep turning a blind eye to the inequities they perpetuate.
Name: whatsitallabout

comment: This points to a trend I've been noticing in the fashion industry...anyone else notice that newer clothes last less time and hold up far worse than before? It's crazy how we're being pushed into systems that are more wasteful and just reinforce an increasingly materialistic culture
Name: sapa

comment: What I find most (sadly) comical about this is that many of these celebrity "influencers" can be found beating the social justice drum. Yep  right until it comes between them and their money.
Name: richard

comment:
I wish I could say that I'm shocked. My reaction is instead and so what else is new? This is the "new" economy. The "disrupters" are today's Robber Barons -- from Uber to Amazon to Fashion Nova to whomever -- that got and get rich by exploiting workers and massively underpaying them.

This is an important story and only reinforces the need to stop rampant exploitation by supporting a new "New Deal".
Name: blairga

comment:
I wish the Times attempted to get “Cardi B” and other big names to answer publicly for the pay and working conditions of their clothing lines. Even a “did not respond to a request for comment” printed here and bounced around Twitter for a day can sometimes be enough to not only raise awareness of the public but also shame a “star” into at least attempting to make a change. 

Going down to the “garment district” on the eastern side of downtown LA was an adventure during my youth that many Angelenos undertook not only for “good deals” but also the dynamic multicultural energy of the scene. There were many more cultures than Hispanics in the trade those days including Asians  Middle Easterners  and even a few New York or Chicago Jews whom I distinctly remember hearing talking loudly in the backs of stores saying things like  “what can I say? I’m in the schmatte business.” It was a very different feel than that of late ‘70s/early ‘80s malls and a lot more fun. 

So much of that has changed with offshoring of American manufacturing but businesses like American Apparel seemed to be reversing the tide until its owner was revealed to be yet another toxic white male who couldn’t keep his zipper zipped. I haven’t shopped down there in years as I’m all about thrifting and old school  quality these days. Thanks to the NYTimes for keeping an eye on my town.
Name: left

comment: The "fashion" and "beauty" industries are in fact hideous and reactionary predators. comment:
if anyone has ever asked themselves why so many prominent Democrats in California want open borders and unregulated migration from Central America  now you know why. And Republican Leadership wants the same thing. For most of the same business interests.

And the middle class is okay with that. It means they don't have to pay the Filipinos who watch their children  the Hondurans who scrub their toilets  or the Mexicans who mow their lawns a living wage.

comment: I was driving behind a truck in Europe that had a bumper sticker: "If you want me off the road  stop buying stuff!"

comment:
This is why no one  beyond pieces purchased at a thrift or secondhand store  should be paying such low prices for clothing. Beyond the environmental impact (and the insane amounts of waste these types of clothing make when you only wear them a handful of time)  the social impacts are egregious. These people are being exploited right in our own backyard - and we've known for a long time that the fast fashion (and really any fashion company who is producing goods outside of a seasonal cycle) industry has been exploiting people in southeast Asia and southern Asia for many years. 

It's time for customers and these "influencers" to get smart about what the true cost of that clothing is - is something for free or sold at a low price worth the exploitation of another human being or our planet? Perhaps you should wear your clothes a few more times and think about the impact you're having before you try to influence another person to behave so irresponsibly. Let's buy high quality staples that we can wear for many years and end the cycle of rampant consumerism.
Name: amanda

comment: I was disappointed that this article did not focus more on the influencers that are touting this merchandise. comment:
Clothing used to be expensive - even for ordinary workers.   You'd be lucky to have a set of work clothes and 'good' clothes for church.

Think of what it took to make clothes before industrialization:

Hand spin thread - a job for old women or children
Weave cloth - a man or woman's job
Cut cloth and sew clothes (by hand) 

Everything in the process took time and effort.  Quilts were a way to use the scraps of cloth left over.   The scraps were worth too much to waste.

Even when industrialization automated thread and cloth production  the cutting of clothes and sewing them took time.  
Sewing machines were the first 'appliances' bought by most households.  First pedal driven and then electric  they greatly sped the process of making clothes.

Even when clothes became 'factory made' they were meant to last because they were NOT cheap.  Shirts had replaceable collars and cuffs - the parts that showed wear first.   

Even in my youth - the 1950's and 60's children were lucky to get two new sets of clothes a year.  And if you had an older sibling those could be hand-me-downs.  Outgrown clothes would be traded among extended families until they fell apart.  Mothers still mended clothes and often made their own.   That mindset supported a robust domestic garment industry.

The key is because they are paid by piece. Whether a worker spends 10 min to do a task or 10 hour  they are paid the same. If someone that's high skilled  don't take long break  don't spend long time on the phone  she/he can make a lot of money. All garment factories around the world do the same. 

When inspector reviews their wages  he/she simply calculate wages divided hours worked. If a worker is not very skilled  take many breaks  on phone a lot  not whole a lot of money can be earned.

Yes there are lousy employers out there  but there are also workers  paid by hour that spend a lot of time on cooler talk or on long breaks. It is not fair for employer that pays at least $100 per day per employee (CA minimum wage is $12 and NY is $15) and finds little progress is made everyday. 

Please keep both sides in mind.

This article misses the bigger picture: there is almost no option BUT fast fashion for millions of Americans who don’t want to look like they shop at Walmart. I get it.
