comment:
Please stop the misinformation!  

"Case rates" is a totally meaningless statistic because it assumes similar testing capabilities and processes.  No one knows how many people have this disease in the community  because no nation has tested every citizen.  They only test those with symptoms  and asymptomatic coronavirus carriers are anywhere from 50-90% of cases.  So saying that New York City has a 40% daily increase in cases may simply mean that NYC is now testing 40% more people each day.

Even more  comparing this to Wuhan is foolish.  It is an apples to oranges comparison.  The Chinese had no real testing process there for most of the outbreak.  They recorded deaths and others with symptoms.  The US now has tested 600 000 people.  You cannot compare the two.

Please stop scaring people.
Name: chuck

comment:
One important aspect of the data that doesn’t seem to be discussed here is that the initial peaks showing cases doubling can’t realistically represent what is happening in the community. It is very unlikely that cases would double every day because the virus has about a 5 day infection-transmission rate  so requires 5 days to double. Hence a 20% daily increase indicates an R (transmission rate) of 2. A 100% rate (which is a doubling) would be a ghastly R=5; even 50% (R=2.5) is terrifyingly high. These numbers all assume we are testing well- clearly not the case. 

My point is that early on what is being measured is our lack of testing capacity. When those curves level out or straighten  perhaps we get a real idea of reality. Sadly  our testing issue hamstring good interpretation of the data.

Brian F
Fred Hutch Cancer Center  Seattle
Name: brian

comment:
All the work is great. Keep it up. But there should be more caveats stated as we are trying to get to grips with understanding what is going on and where we are. And missing is the most important statistic.

Others have commented on China. For the US  the death count is too much to much of a lagging indicator to be helpful now. Some states (MA and RI at least) are reporting the test rate as well as the confirmed infection rate. The surprising thing to me is that the confirmed rate is around 10% of the tested rate. Given the difficulty to get tested this seems surprisingly low. Louisiana's rate is 13% New Jersey's rate is 50%  California is 3% and New York's is not shown on their website. 

If testing is too limited (New Jersey?) to make confirmed cases a good metric  and deaths are too lagging  what about hospitalizations? That's one of the key numbers that would identify indicates whether a community can cope with the outbreak (which is what flattening the curve is about) or has exceeded this and needs federal help. Louisiana shows hospitalizations (and ventilator use) on its COVID-19 data page. Would that all states did this and we could see the trend there. Then maybe the need for ventilators and hospital beds would be front and center of the debate and in black and white.
Name: peterr

comment:
A statistician here. At this point no matter what comparisons we make  they should be viewed as anecdotal. I believe we have become more aware of the importance of social distancing  or at least become more careful because the reality is closer to us  so hopefully it can change the course  at least a little. 

Here are a few random components that make the comparison and prediction near impossible. (1) Time-to-symptom: it's hard to know when a patient got infected. This makes it hard to know the impact of the measures (like school closure). (2) Time-to-death: Time to the fatality also varies a lot for each patient (because everyone is different and the condition when admitted varies). This makes it difficult to use death toll as a measure of progress of epidemic. (3) As we all know  lack of testing. (1) and (2) are not something we can control  but we did really bad for (3).

Wuhan's data is probably not to be used as reference point. In particular when they celebrated 0-new patients a few days ago. Statistically speaking  it's simply not true. 

Currently the only one reliable measure is the fatality rate from South Korea. The fatality for different age group from there is fairly reliable  although their number is based on much better managed health care system without overburden. So we will see much worse fatality rate (# death/# admitted).

At this point it's just too early to predict much. Anybody says something confidently about the future of the epidemic  they're lying.

comment: These graphs are not suited to displaying the data for NY. We had a surge in testing and detection of cases last week. These plots make the trendlines difficult to assess. It is much easier to see the trend using semi-log plot of cases or cases per million such as found on graph 19 here: http://nrg.cs.ucl.ac.uk/mjh/covid19/ The early NY trend of +35% increase per day with a surge for testing is clearly shown. Fortunately the increases for the last two days have been following a +22% per day trendline. Hopefully the 'flattening of the curve' will continue and the doubling time is truly lengthening to every 3.5 days. The numbers from the past two days suggests that the effects of last week's partial lockdown are being seen. The full lockdown should have a very strong effect on reducing transmission although it won't be seen until the end of next week.
Name: lne

comment: Herein lies the fallacy of easing the restrictions prematurely. In much of the country  Missouri for instance  things are only now just beginning. It may be well more than a month from now before the wave crests. Things look normal  as I understand they do before a tsunami.
Name: scott

comment:
In the United States  we need to be aware the political shell game that Trump and the GOP are trying to play with the "we will reopen in two weeks" mantra. This is clearly something they know people will not follow but that they can later say would have "saved the economy if we only listened to Trump." Its a cheap attempt to pull yet another con. 

Oddly  Putin  another pathological lair has the antidote to this. From here on  we can use the 'data' from Russian to demonstrate the difference from a quick response and the path Trump chose.
Name: aluetian

comment:
These statistical analyses can lead to the false impression that we can somehow analytic our way out of this crisis. The reality of the matter is that the ONLY way we can stem the number of infections and therefore the number of COVID-19 cases  hospitalizations  ICU admits  and death is to stop the insanity of returning people who are COVID-19 positive back to their homes and communities. Instead  we must ISOLATE COVID-19 positive individuals in supervised quarantine. This is the only way to drive down the all-important R0 (R-Naught) value of the virus that stands between 2 to 3 and bring it to below 1 when the curve will finally bend. 

Make no mistake about it: the real battle against COVID-19 is happening on the ground. The only way to win the battle is to identify people who catch COVID-19 early and professionally isolate them before they infect one other person. Otherwise  we are simply managing a revolving door to a catastrophe.
Name: uc

comment: Harder to calculate  but still important - how many cases and deaths due to inadequate medical supplies? If the growth rates depicted continue to outstrip the growth rate of medical supplies  we are in for a very hard time.
Name: humanist

comment: I think the growth rate is key.  The media loves to publish numbers of total cases but you can't figure out the growth rate (is it exponential?) unless you keep track.  There should be more emphasis on charts showing how the growth rate has increased or decreased over time.
Name: gone

comment:
We're being asked to "shelter in place" to avoid "overwhelming the medical system". But nobody is giving us statistics about the medical system:

How many hospital beds are available vs used?
How many ventilators are available vs. used?
How long are people staying in beds  on ventilators?

These stats  day by day  would show undeniable facts rather than almost meaningless test results.
Name: shawn

comment: As a physician in Pittsfield  I have been sounding the alarm bell for weeks! We had community transmission in the first week fo March. Unfortunately Gov Baker and the state were so slow to start. Testing has been taking between 2-7 days to get back. Really disappointing response considering Massachusetts is usually ahead in healthcare.
Name: emmie

comment:
In the absence of significant population testing  given what we know about the R(0) and virus shedding prior to becoming symptomatic  as well as the reality that around 80% of people with coronavirus are asymptomatic  we can only look at the curves of new and total cases.  A logarithmic plot easily gives the doubling time  which for the US is around 3 days.  It takes time for social isolation effects to be seen  probably at least 3 doubling times  but maybe more.  This is because the US is heterogeneous in terms of local virus spread.  We have leader community and follower communities.  To determine the benefit of social distancing  one needs to plot the accession curves for new cases by smaller region  but this information has been hard to find.  The Johns Hopkins site does not drill down in such a manner.   Also  for this purpose  death rates are not a good metric  because they lag even further behind the overall incidence data.

Bottom line:  Trump is wrong.  For the safest approach  continue social distancing as advocated by the CDC and many medical organizations.  This is going to be a prolonged bumpy ride.
Name: jeff

comment: I have been doing modelling based primarily on  mortalities since the backlog of testing (now apparently in the order of 7 days)  means that number of confirmed cases needs to be carefully interpreted.  Instead  I have been using the daily number of deaths as reported on Worldometers as a basis of analysis.  According to a couple of recent research papers  for people who die of the virus  the average time between infection and death is about 14 days.  This is due to the larger proportion of elderly and those with underlying conditions who die.  I then considered the most likely mortality rate.  Although a wide range has been reported  the higher rates are associated with situations where the health system was being overwhelmed and testing was only done on the more severe cases.  Imperial College propose a mortality rate of about 0.75% and Dr Fanuci  (ex-director of the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases) has suggested a MR value of 1%.  Plugging those to values (1% MR) into the basic model suggests that the spread of infection in the US was about 800K on Mar 19th and now stands around 3 million.  If you correct for the 7 day backlog of test results  this implies that about 12% of the infection was detected on the 19th.  Another recent research paper suggested that about 86% of new infections during the outbreak in China were from undetected carriers. This would suggest that a similar situation exists here.
Name: tj

comment:
Theoretically  the ratio of deaths to acute cases will reach a tipping point if/when the acute care hospital space passes the point of overload.

The “beautiful timeline” will be a fatal timeline  particularly for older people with underlying health concerns  who will also be on the wrong side of triage protocols.

It would seem the “cure is worse than the disease” argument is better for individuals immune from resource shortages.
Name: ian

comment: Since testing has been astonishingly unavailable virtually anywhere in the U.S.  I don't understand why these articles don't focus on metrics that are not radically affected by availability of testing and differential testing of different demographic cohorts.  For example  wouldn't the number of deaths in a given month this year versus last year give us some sense of the real scope of this human health crisis?  What if the death rate of young people or people afflicted with various diseases has increased exponentially this year versus historical averages?
Name: doug

comment: Our governor Inslee (Washington) did a fairly good job of locking down activity early (still a  month later than it could have been  with hindsight). The "Snake" (Trump's insult) has been a good manager of the crises out here. The rest of the US  has to accept staying home  it is all that will end it.
Name: roger

comment: China has been lying through its teeth regarding the numbers  on top of their admitted practices of not counting the dead whose test results were not produced before death occurred and not counting cases that were turned away by hospitals.
Name: s

comment:
I am sorry to read that you situation is as bad as it is here in The Netherlands.

Please try to be nice to each other.
Name: wouter

comment: Since this is statistical  let's start by realizing that the data from China are lies. Perhaps 10x as many people have died in Wuhan alone  to say nothing of the actual numbers of people infected in China. Putting a question mark on data from any dictatorship should be standard practice.
Name: dan

comment:
Very useful analysis  but it makes one thing clear:
NYC metropolitan area needs to be placed under quarantine. China very successfully stemmed the epidemic in the country by placing Wuhan under quarantine.
We need to do the same if we don't want the rest of the country to follow the NYC trajectory.
Name: bill

comment:
The total number of cases is not useful. It is hugely limited by the rules and availability surrounding tests. Further these tests have huge false positive and false negative rates.

In Bergamo  400 people died this past week but only about 100 in the same week a year ago. Of the 400  only 91 tested Covid19+. NYT should just track the number dead - in aggregate and per day. The number of cases may be off by 50-99% depending on the place.
Name: bharat

comment:
The multiple graphs provide a good cross referencing for  the issues of measuring an outbreak such as this.

There are limits to the picture these graphs can paint. 

Two elements not captured are a) those who have the virus and have not been tested;(Tests are in short supply so residents are discouraged from getting tested)  b) the spike in numbers can to some degree (unknown and not measurable) be attributed to the beginning of testing. I.e.  the numbers go up simply by finding out how many there are.

In Seattle (King Co) we appear to be flattening  but to what extent is that due to the spike as testing commenced? 

Also  percentages can be misleading.  March 2 we went from 6 cases to 10. 4 new cases is interpreted as 40% hike. March 26 we had 218 new cases  but only an 11% increase. So  by percentages we are doing better  but the number of cases has more than doubled in the past 7 days.

All this aside  I am grateful to our Governor  County Exec and Mayor who have set the standard for a proper response.
Name: seaattle

comment: If you do more tests  as in NYC  you find more cases. The authors seem aware of this but didn't properly control for it. Their conclusions are questionable at best.
Name: andy

comment: I would be very skeptical of the reported case numbers from Wuhan. China has distorted and/or suppressed data about much less important things. Rather than accuracy  their primary considerations are international prestige  economic recovery and social control.
Name: rick

comment: Glad to see that we have had some early success flattening the curve here in Seattle.  Most people I know have been diligent in practicing social distancing  working from home  etc.  but then again  we are a progressive/educated city that took the advice of experts seriously instead of minimizing the threat and relying on magical thinking like Trump supporters.
Name: js

comment: Watch European figures ... all countries have messed up a bit; all countries could have done better; some have more hospital beds / ventilators and some do testing earlier and in greater numbers ... but the only thing that really seems to impact infection growth is social distancing  aggressive containment measures (something that democracies are bad at) and massive  testing of all including asymptomatic spreaders ...
Name: bright

comment:
Charts based on non-random test results (i.e. things like 'confirmed cases') are basically worthless.  You need random population sampling (testing) to actually get decent statistics.

Charts based on mortality are marginally more useful  because most of the deaths caused by COVID-19 in the U.S. will be properly counted as being caused by COVID-19.

In particular  a death represents someone who was infected roughly 30 days prior (+/- 10 days  for a rough mean).  You can use this back-date and compare against the date that the state/county/city implemented strong measures  along with the exponential rate of increase calculated from prior deaths  to calculate how many people will die up to 30 days in the future.

When something changes  such as policy  it gets a bit more murky because you won't have any good data on the effects the policy change has on the infection rate for at least 30 days after the policy change is made.

So  I'm afraid  most of these graphs are just not all that useful.  The error bars have got to be massive  there aren't enough data points  and there is no random population testing to drive the sorts of comparisons you are trying to make.  Its better not to publish them at all  frankly.

-Matt
Name: mattzn

comment: If there were 1000 random tests given in NYC at least it could be determined how many asymptomatic people there are  how many people have had and recovered from the illness and how many are actively sick.
Name: bob

comment: The "San Francisco" area as you define it includes too many outlying suburban and rural areas. If you look at San Francisco County only (whcih has the same borders as the city of San Francisco)  it looks more like New York. Would love to see this modeled.
Name: juliet

comment: I have a problem with the data on the affected people. The number of affected people depends on how many tests you run. If you test aggressively  you have many affected people (even asymptomatic). If you do few tests  you have few positive cases. The reality is that until we decide to test everyone we will never be able to understand the extent of the problem and whether herd immunity has been achieved.
Name: alfredo

comment: My city's government is far from perfect  but I appreciate that they took strong measures quite early. They probably saved a lot of lives.
Name: steve

comment:
Hopefully someone (s) can comment on this. Nowhere can I find it addressed in any of the  the data that are posted on positive test results. Here is the point. We see the numbers of "new" cases precisely reported. But I feel that using that alone mistates  an important measurement. 

We know that the  majority of Covid cases..some 80% I think do not require hospitalization and can be treated at home with OTC meds. In fact  some test results are in asymptomatic  people...who present risk because they can pass the virus on  but no burden on the medical treatmemt front.

That said  is not the number of Covid cases requiring hospitalization more important to the measurement of the spread and the impact on health systems than the total cases? If in my area we test 100 people and have 100 positives  but none requiring hospitalization  that is vastly different on many front than 100 tests with 40% requiring hospitalization.

Also  now that testing is ramping up e need a data point that adjusts for more tests rather than a spreading infection. Again  if 100 test yesterday revealed 40 positives and today we tested 200 and had 60 positives the infection rate has actually gone down.

In fact  having a growing number positives compared to hospitalizations is  good if there is immunity since those people are out of the danger zone and can work.

I do not think these are trivial mathematical questions but go to the heart of the issue on wether or not we are going control or losing it.
Name: alex

comment: Here is something puzzling that was not addressed in this article and barely touched upon elsewhere. Since so few people have been tested or have active symptoms  the rule of thumb that experts have said is that there are 10x the number of infected people than what the official numbers show. So NYC really has ~448 000 cases  not the 48 000 shown in the official numbers. If you have 10x the number of cases  then the death rate is actually 1/10 of what is currently shown. A bad virus  but not as deadly as the stats show.
Name: mike

comment:
People not realize some of the very extreme measures that were taken in Wuhan. Not only was all travel prohibited  but within apartments families had to wear masks and plastic bags on their feet and change them every few hours. They were told not to drink water because urinating would require a change of of the PPE they were wearing.

This went on for over 2 months.
Name: david

comment: In Ohio we have a 'stay at home order' and all non-essential businesses are closed.  We have a thirty year old Deaf-Blind daughter with an auto-immune disease.  She lives in her own apartment with the aid of staff who come in daily.  Since she can't stay at home by herself we have brought her to stay with us. Her twenty year old brother works in an 'essential' factory.  To protect his sister  he moved in with his girlfriend's family.  Her parents  all five of their kids  and my son have had all the symptoms of COVID-19  but since everyone recovered  no one (but my son) ever left the house or required medical care  they will never appear in anyone's count.  I'm sure this is not an isolated case.  Be like the second little piggy - stay home!
Name: ann

comment: Here in Michigan  you can only get tested if you have extreme shortness of breath.  If you have a cough  fever and sore throat  you are sent home without a test.  So the fact that Detroit is skyrocketing is because so many infected are in very bad shape.  They won't test you if you are not.  The Detroit metro area numbers are only the people that have to be hospitalized.
Name: anndotcom

comment: I understand that in Wuhan extreme measures were taken  still I do not believe for a second that they were limited to some 80 000 cases.  I'm a scientist.  Given how fast and extensively it spread in other crowded places  and given how crowded Chinese cities are and that they at first denied the outbreak  there is simply no way that there are only 80 000 cases in Wuhan  nor is it likely that it didn't spread vigorously in other densely populated Chinese cities.   In short  I'm not buying it.  The numbers for China are grossly under reported in my opinion.  They have a communist government  where information is tightly controlled and they often make up numbers to please the Party and stay in power.   I think we should take the China data for what it is  don't rely on it too much.
Name: brian

comment:
I am sure this has been said  but why are they bothering to do case counts when we are barely testing? 

In NYC medical workers are told to test only people so sick they need medical intervention.   People very sick at home are not tested  people mildly sick are not tested  asymptomatic people (30% in S Korea I think) are not tested.  

Thus  the number of "confirmed cases" is not meaningful. Until we have surveillance testing  speculation about anything other than the death rate seems pointless.
Name: mm

comment:
Divide the number of confirmed positive cases by the number of tests. Then multiply the ratio by 100 to express the ratio as a percentage. Washington State calls this the “Positivity Rate.” It is the percentage of positive tests. 

This simple arithmetic operation adjusts for the ever-varying number of tests. I am using the Positivity Rate to track progress in Washington State where the number of tests if different each day. The WA rate is currently steady at roughly 7 to 8 percent. 

The same rate can be applied to other states for comparison purposes. New York City has an alarmingly high positive rate: around 50%. This is consistent with Dr. Birx observation that the NYC attack rate is 5 times higher than Washington.

BTW  I have running figures on my blog. Search on “COVID-19 Numeracy.”
Name: pjd

comment:
This is the best article on the corona data that I have seen.  Using basic epidemiologic methods like rates rather than just numbers is important to understanding the epidemic and being able to compare different groups or locations.  The CDC  NIH  and WHO all need to take lessons from you all.  Their web sites don't have this basic info  at least I can't find it if they do.

We need rates of testing and rates for positivity by location and by age and sex  not to mention cases  hospitalizations  and deaths per thousand people in the population at the county level.

Thank you very much for starting to tell us this basic information.
Name: cab

comment: Although Wuhan City had a severe outbreak  of Covid-19 and though they unfortunately covered it up for way too long  they did get a handle on this immediately.   Tragically trump down played the urgency and being the stable genius  he said he is  declared a miracle would occur and it will be gone.   Now  thanks to him  it's out of control.   Guess the churches won't be full at Easter or even Christmas for that matter.  By his lackadaisical attitude  and the hit and miss testing  that's not being done  the intelligent thing to do  for everyone's safety is to stay at home.  It's a minor inconvenience when you think of the alternative.
Name: sari

comment: The % growth curve is misleading. Since the denominator is increasing with time it looks like NY  Detroit  Miami are getting things under control. The slopes here would decrease over time even if the number of new cases per day was the same. It looks like San Francisco has "flattened the curve" but this is not the curve you want to flatten (which is the cumulative incidence curve). In fact a constant %growth rate of this type is the definition of exponential growth. The East Bay Times  today  reports a record new number of cases in San Francisco for each of the last 3 days.
Name: wjf

comment:
Experience in Italy  Spain and now in my location the UK is that there's a very long lag between the imposition of any "social distancing" measures or "lockdown" and a reduction in the tragic daily body count.
In Italy and Spain there's still no reduction despite the imposition of very stringent measures.
From what I've seen on TV of NY this isn't "lockdown"  there are far too many people gathering in groups and milling around for it to be an effective measure. Quite shocking to see as you still don't seem to "get it". You need to take a much closer look at the measures taken across Europe and note that even these  have STILL not yet had a noticeable effect. You are in for a truly agonising 4 weeks as you watch that body count double every 3 days whilst being powerless to stop it.
Name: mark

comment: The data is basically meaningless and telling a false tale based on tragically incomplete data.  The true extent is really unknowable until we have accurate numbers.  In downstate Illinois we already have hospitals being pushed to the limit and running low on PPE. But  the tests have been nearly unattainable.
Name: sam

comment:
It's the height of irresponsible journalism to make any comparison to Wuhan and/or China.

Excuse me for saying the obvious  but Chinese officials aren't exactly the paragons of honesty and transparency as far as the spread of COVID-19 is concerned. Does anyone truly believe that a nation of over 1 billion people has had barely any new infections over several weeks running now? The same goes for Russia which saw an unusual surge in pneumonia cases in Moscow but hasn't been forthcoming with its official number of cases.

On top of some governments being cagey with the fact  we have to contend with different standards of reporting even among the more "honest" nations.

Germany's low mortality rate is misleading. For example  it doesn't attribute deaths to COVID-19 unless the patient had a confirmed infection prior to death; Germany will not perform an autopsy to determine whether COVID-19 was a factor after the fact.

These and other discrepancies make for apples-to-oranges comparisons which don't help the national conversation one bit.
Name: jason

comment: I don't know what to say. We politely ask all our residents to stay home and avoid social contact. People flagrantly ignore these pleas. Then we look at the countries who have this seemingly under control-- Singapore  for example-- and see that they have implemented measures such as checking in on people via video conference 3x daily and spot checking. If people are non-compliant they can be detained and forcibly quarantined to avoid putting others at risk. We don't want to do that. Why do we expect a better result than what we have? It's insane.
Name: matt

comment: The city of Seattle has been solidly deserted  save for the seemingly homeless  for two weeks now.  Seattle  and its surrounding areas  recognized the implications of covid-19 early.  Amazon  google  Facebook  Apple  Starbucks  prestigious and not-as prestigious law firms  etc.--they sent employees to work from home right from the start.  This city is of one mind  and I don't think you can say that about a lot of places in the U.S.
Name: diane

comment: In New York the number of tests has increased rapidly  thus so would the percent increase of confirmed cases.  That is ignored by the comparison chart.
Name: l

comment:
The graph of growth rates shown on the front page of the NYT is very misleading. The humps are almost entirely driven by the amount of testing  which varies dramatically among states and at various points in time. For a casual reader  it looks as though the growth rate is going down recently  when this change is known to be driven by the continued failure of testing to keep up with the exponential growth in infections. Social distancing will help  but not enough time has passed to measure its effect in most places. 

Why publish a graph based on numbers that reflect testing practices more than actual infection rates (as vaguely acknowledged in the article)?
Name: scienceeval

comment: Lombardy and Italian health care is really good  probably one of the best in the world and is collapsing due the virus. Italy now has very strict quarantine rules  we applied immediately restrictions and population is following the rules widely. And even  we have a very high number of deaths  expecially in Bergamo area. I recommend you to take the problem very seriously. I think that US president underestimated the problem  and this will costs many lives. Be prepared: the worst has to come. A huge hug from Italy.
Name: marco

comment:
I just really think that confirmed cases is a useless measure. I live in Brooklyn. I know at least a dozen people well who've had the hallmark symptoms  particularly shortness of breath which doesn't seem like your basic flu. None of us have been tested (I'm one of the people). We can't get tested! Only the sickest of the sick are tested  and apparently the rich. I know only one person who has been tested  and she's a nurse. (She has it.)

This analysis nods to the inconsistencies in who is tested and includes one chart based on death rate instead  but I don't think it comes anywhere near to acknowledging and dealing with how totally our botched testing situation means that all the data we have is close to useless.
Name: bcbc

comment:
Trusting statistics from China is foolish.  They have shown that they are trying to avoid responsibility for their early refusal to recognize the seriousness of the outbreak in Wuhan.  All very understandable. 

I am surprised that the extremely literate editors and readership of the Times have not recognized that the behavior of the authorities in Wuhan has been previously represented by Ibsen's "Enemy of the People"  that the pressures brought upon the doctors in Wuhan reflect the conflicts in Ibsen's play  and the resolution of the story was foreshadowed by Ibsen  with the difference being that Dr. Li Weinliang gave way to the authorities whereas Dr  Stockman tried to fight.  Dr. Li probably felt he couldn't  and he needed to get back to helping the ill  eventually at the cost of his own life.

Last  the silly argument over the terminology as to what this thing should be called.  I vote for Wuhan.  That is where it first presented itself.  But it is also a way of recognizing that the failure of the authorities in Wuhan  and to a lesser extent China as a whole  allowed this disease to break-out.  As Ibsen points out  this is a lesson in morality for authorities.
Name: asr

comment: "Let them eat cake!" That is the message from the" haves" to the "have nots" in this national and global crisis. Those with resources feel they are entitled to be first in line. A sentiment of selfishness and greed of course. However as history and our own consciousness knows  "it's better to give then receive." This concept is part of all religions and successful cultures. But it's not intuitive for most folks and is why we need leaders who talk the talk and walk the walk. We don't have that leader now and history has shown ignoring this basic tenet of human life results in chaos.
Name: dr

comment:
Governor Cuomo finally shut down "non-essential" construction on luxury condominiums and hotels in NYC thankfully after workers started getting sick. It's only till April 21st though. That isn't long enough for a shutdown  it should be till June at the very least. 
   It's also not fair that low paid workers who work as cashiers in supermarkets are classified as "essential" workers. The stores have done next to nothing to protect their employees who have direct contact with the public and are told not to wear masks or nitrile gloves to handle germ ridden cash. I have a family member who worked for a major supermarket chain and I told him not to return to the store  the extra $2 they are paying him on top of his $11 an hour pay isn't worth it. These low paid grocery workers have no choice but to continue to go to work because they are classified essential while the owners of these large stores shelter at home in their million dollar mansions. Many of their workers are classified as "part time" and have no health benefits. Their lives are at risk working in these stores with irate customers complaining about shortages of cleaning products and paper products. They also complain about only being allowed to purchase one or two of an item. The supermarket workers should be allowed to quit their jobs if they want to due to the very hazardous nature of the job and qualify for unemployment benefits immediately. They are being forced to work in a very dangerous environment with no PPE.
Name: sam

comment: Socialized medicine  where a patient is tracked with a single system probably yields better data from testing to death.
Name: ronrich

comment: Let's say China did  somehow  knew within days that a totally unknown viral zoonosis was spreading from an epicentre into the Chinese population. Even if they immediately told the world that a  as yet  unknown but apparently high mortality viral infection was spreading in one city in China does anyone really  really believe that other countries in the world would begin quarantine procedures. Even if they shouted to the world immediately few if any countries would have done anything. After several weeks when China did warn the world what could be coming few did anything. Even when spreading through the world the USA did nothing. Do not try to suggest that if China only informed the world earlier that we wouldn't be in exactly the same place now.
Name: mick

comment: I thought this same thing visiting a supermarket in Ramona  California.  The numbers of confirmed cases in the immediate area is low but testing has been low too  so you really have no clue who might have it.  You need to assume that over a full shift a cashier will serve customers who have the virus.  That is essentially face to face  three feet apart  handling money and groceries that have been handled by the customer  with no protective barriers of any kind.  That’s a high risk job right now.  Supermarkets need to make changes so their employees are not in such risky situations.
Name: mikemc

comment:
Confirmed cases per 1000 people?  This is very often largely a function of how many people have been tested  and far from indicative of how many have been infected.  

You would be better off comparing the numbers of confirmed cases to the numbers of deaths  since this would at least give you an indication of how representative the 'confirmed cases' figure is.   If you get above around 2% deaths from that calculation  you have not tested a remotely representative sample of that population  given that the lethality of the coronavirus is thought to be around 1%.  Caveat... if hospital care capacities are exceeded  let's hope they are not  then the lethality rate is going to climb steeply above 1%.
Name: malcolm

comment:
It is worth reading the piece  "The Coronavirus Isn’t Just A Blue State Problem. Detected cases are higher in blue states  but growing faster in red states " at FiveThirtyEight.

It emphasizes that "blue states are hardly alone in what is becoming a nationwide epidemic. Jefferson Parish  Louisiana — which went for Trump by 15 percentage points in 2016 — has a death rate about equal to that of Manhattan."

As the article correctly states: "Although the number of detected cases is higher in blue states  the number is increasing at a more rapid rate in red states"

Most importantly  from the standpoint of the analysis offered here  is the obvious problem with testing  as "blue states have conducted more tests per capita than red states". It means "that the large majority of coronavirus cases remain undetected"  and that "the lower rate of cases in red states" is "an artifact of less testing" in those states.

Therefore  almost all available data from red states is from full-blown infections  in which case testing is only done After a patient is already admitted to a hospital and is often in the ICU. The test merely confirms what’s already known; that the patient has been infected for weeks and in now in critical condition. 

Finally  as "9 of the 10 states that have seen the most rapid increase in coronavirus from Monday to Thursday are states that voted for Trump in 2016”  one must question what can be learned about the progression of the virus based on the data now available.
Name: robert

comment: China has 1.386 billion people  USA has 327 million people. How is it possible that USA has more confirmed cases than China?
Name: save

comment: You should include the results related to Seoul to have a sense of proportion and some respect for what the Koreans have achieved in such a big and congested city as Seoul.
Name: ahmet

comment: How soon do we refer to the administration’s response to the pandemic as a scandal?
Name: peter

comment:
What's really happening  it seems to me  a self-selected group shows up at the hospital ER with COVID-19 symptoms  are given the test and some of them test positive. They become the "new" cases against a baseline of other self-selected known cases from the previous day. Then we see a "surge" statistic like "30% more cases today!" Please correct me if I'm wrong  but -- Is this statistic basically worthless except for news headlines? It gives us no idea of the growth rate (incidence rate) in the total population  only the number of self-selected known cases from one day to the next. Adequate testing  which hasn't happened and may never happen  would give us reliable growth rates. I'm not holding my breath.
Rather than the number of known cases  I'd rather look at the number of hospitalizations. A real person is there and must be showing serious symptoms to be hospitalized. I also watch for the number of deaths.
I want to know how severe the symptoms are in the known cases. It's my understanding that the majority of infected people experience moderate and survivable symptoms. Is anybody keeping track? I meet ordinary healthy people who believe that if they catch the virus they will become very ill or die. Unwarranted fear  if that is what it is  doesn't help them or us in this difficult time.
Name: djy

comment:
This from a treatise on the Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1793 in Philadelphia:

"THE want of a lazaretto [hospital for quarantine]  whither persons labouring under contagious disorders might be sent  and of a proper law on the subject  empowering the civil authority to interpose with the necessary energy  at the first inroad of such a dreadful destroyer  has been the cause of our late sufferings; for  humanly speaking  had decisive measures been adopted any time before the first of September  while the disorder existed only in one street  and in a few houses in that street  there can be little doubt  that it might have been very soon extinguished. But the former sufferings of this place in 1762  were soon forgotten— and no steps taken to provide for the removal of such an evil in future  after it should invade the city. It is to be hoped our legislature  as well as that of every state in the union  will see the propriety of giving this important subject the consideration it so amply deserves  and of making provision against like calamities in future."

. . .  plus c'est la même chose.
Name: george

comment: How can you use any stats from American cities?  They don't test!  Here  they only test if you are admitted to the hospital!!  That is not ALL cases--it's merely that portion of cases so serious they had to be hospitalized because they could die otherwise.  If the stats are correct  that's just a bit over 1%  correct?  It's insane.  Elsewhere  they test if the person does not have the flu.  Wuhan tested entire families who were locked in their homes  not hospitalized unless it was necessary.
Name: cyninoregon

comment: I live in Staten Island. According to a text yesterday from a nurse at my local hospital  80% of all cases there are now Covid patients. In the past few days I have seen and heard more ambulances than I ever did in the prior two years. I don’t know what to say  because it’s going to become a disaster of PTSD proportions.
Name: temp

comment:
You really need alot of high quality randomized testing.  

If we had perfect testing - everyone is tested instantly for $0.01 or less (perhaps with an app)  we could end the epidemic in 3 weeks.  The known cases are quarantined. 

What happens when testing is less than perfect?  Or in the US  very limited? 

Its an information problem.  Lack of information "spreads" the disease.
Name: h

comment:
A lot of good comments recognizing that testing is still not happening at a higher rate. The CDC dropped the ball early on. It refused to accept the WHO test guidelines used by other countries. Instead  it moved forward with developing its own test. The CDC tried to develop a test that also screened for SARS and MERS. That test turned out to be faulty when it was sent to some state labs in early February.

There were only 15 confirmed cases in the US through February 28  and 12 of those were connected to travel. There were 45 other cases consisting of people who returned to the US after becoming sick outside of the country. And it’s not surprising the count was so low. The CDC’s criteria for testing was initially limited to persons who had close contact with someone confirmed to have COVID-19 or to anyone who had traveled from China and then developed both respiratory symptoms and a fever. The CDC expanded its criteria on February 27  to include people who traveled to Italy  Iran  Japan or South Korea.

The CDC was responsible for delays in testing and it’s testing  criteria was too narrow. Once private labs began testing there had already been so much delay that it’s not surprising to see how quickly the number of confirmed cases grew.
Name: pw

comment:
Testing for the active virus is flawed  no test is 100% accurate  and testing negative only means you are vulnerable. Several of the first test kits were flawed. We likely miss most of the milder cases who still can spread the virus. But models like these are very helpful to dispatch available resources.

Test for antibodies will be available soon  they are much cheaper  faster and more reliable than the RT-PCR test for the active virus and can thus allow for true mass testing.

The Chinese might have been late  but when they acted they went all in. Sealing the entire Hubei province and quarantining the population  restricted travel in all of China  dispatched thousands of doctors  nurses and tons of equipment  to Hubei and built many makeshift hospitals. Intense testing for active virus and other diagnostics too. In our western nations we only reluctantly employ such draconian and very expensive measures.

For now China seems to have some control over the pandemic at home and can once again export protective gear and even send doctors to assist other nations. 

In Denmark ( 5.8 million ) we are entering our third week of controlled lockdown. We do not know how many are infected  recovered and immunized. But we know we have 430 severe cases hospitalized and of them 119 are in intensive care with 89 on ventilator life support. We have by now recorded 52 deaths. We have broken the exponential curve of severe cases and experience a linear growth our hospitals can handle.
Name: old

comment: There are lessons to be learned from this pandemic.  The first is the importance of public health medicine and the need of governments to fund it.  It is that branch of medicine which emphasizes the importance of exploring every human contact which a patient with coronavirus has had  not only to detect the source but to prevent the spread among those contacts with the virus.  This is costly and time consuming work and depends on adequately funded public health departments. It was this approach as well as the lockdown which caused the success of the government in Wuhan  and probably Singapore  perhaps South Korea.  Number two  it is important for governments to have a plan to institute when there is evidence of a pandemic  and to pay attention and implement it when there is the need.  That was more or less done in Italy  but from what I read in the papers  the plan in the USA was not instituted as it had been stricken from the National Security Council when the Trump administration came in.
Name: harold

comment:
Neither the charts nor the graphs show the story being told--That places in the US could have outbreaks worse than Wuhan.

The graphs show rates and rate changes that are mostly declining  contradicting the message  and the charts show much lower rates  such as death rates  than in Wuhan or Northern Italy. 

Comparing what's been going on in US locales the past week to what's been going on in Wuhan and the Lombardy region the past 7 days don't tell the right story either. Of course things look better in Wuhan now. What needs to be compared are the rates  and changes in rates  recently in NYC  etc. to rates in Wuhan 5-6 weeks ago.

The problem isn't that the message is wrong--things are getting worse in NYC and the US  but this presentation of data doesn't depict that. We know  as others here have pointed out here  that testing rates have a huge influence on what is bring reported  along with the myriad other data issues.

I can imagine these graphs and charts (like the low death rate in NYC compared to Wuhan  etc.) being used by deniers to argue against the true general narrative that things in the US are getting worse than in Northern Italy and Wuhan. 

When presenting data in graphic form in the mainstream media  you need to keep in mind that most of the audience is unsophisticated and will only grasp what looks obvious to them at first glance. And that’s a group of rate lines pointing downward and a far lower death rate in the US than in Lombardy and Wuhan.
Name: anothercitizen

comment:
The article says it's focusing on cities but then talks about Lombardy which is a large region with many small villages  rural areas.
It seems to omit main point: Testing rates. That is the thing that is going to make the main difference in the number of cases.
In Germany there are 53000 cases and 400 deaths  in France there are 33000 cases and 2000 deaths  in South Korea 9500 cases and 150 deaths. Doest that mean that the mortality rate in Germany is 0 75% and 6% in France and about 1.5% in S. Korea?
Surely not. One could possibly take the Korean mortality rate (testing is widespread and the virus has been there for a while) and deduct the number of actual cases in a place with rather good and not over-saturated health care. That would give about 135 000 cases in France. I read an official estimate about 2 million cases in France at present which doesn't seem unlikely. Here many people I know have had mild to moderate cases.
Name: french

comment:
Has anyone anywhere explained why Covid is spreading everywhere EXCEPT China? Other than Hubei only ONE Chinese province has had more than 8 deaths  and that one only had 22.

Meanwhile the deaths/healed ratio in China is about 1:19 while in Italy it's almost 1:1.

Italy and the US began locking down about as quickly as China did in Wuhan. Other Chinese provinces don't seem to have completely locked down at all. And SURELY there was more traffic between Wuhan and Beijing  Shanghai  and Guandong than there was between Wuhan and Milan or New York.

Why are we not hearing even any theories accounting for all that?
Name: green

comment: I keep thinking of the Icelandic data.  One half of the positives have no symptoms.  I think this will be very hard to get rid of.  Every time we think we're through  and let our guard down  it will recur.  Is this not the case?
Name: williamigriffith

comment: I'm neither an MD nor a statistician but if we used part of our limited testing capacity to test a random sample of the public rather than only symptomatic people could we not obtain a statistically significant estimate of the prevalence of CV-19 in the population?  And if we repeated the testing  an estimate of the first and second derivatives?  It seems to me that if we used a test that measured CV-19 antigens we would also have an estimate of how many have had the disease and already recovered.
Name: kenc

comment:
As a former college mathematics professor  I think the sheer variety of tables and charts DO NOT clarify much for the average intelligent reader. For example  some of these charts should display data points rather than connected segments. Others mislead by distracting from the rates of change (slopes)of infection in some of the graphs and contrasting those rates on graphs where the slopes of segments have little or no meaning.  One might easily think NY is "flattening the curve" -especially if one looks at the wrong curve. Also there is generally too much data on most of the curves- they are way too busy.
Suggestion: Use the language for nuance and lighten up on the perhaps confusing diagrams. Too many "dots" may eventually become a blurry page.
Name: j

comment: These data are totally confounded with the rate of testing   The bump then decline of cases in New York reflects the rate of testing as much as the number of new cases.  The comparisons between would only be meaningful if the testing rate were factored in.  It has not  as best I could tell from the article.
Name: meadowviewite

comment:
Dear Authors    As a data scientist  I am confused about your data presentation and how the data was analyzed.  As an example  while NJ has the 2nd highest cases numbers in the US  there is no mention of NJ.  In fact  your graphics combine NYC with NJ.  It is so important that the NJ numbers are reported as NJ  your current methods skew the data and don't provide the information your NJ readers need to understand the impact to NJ.

NJ is also seeing several hot spots  one which correlates with an area in the state that are not complying with the shelter-in-place order.  A quick search of the NYT and local papers document these noncompliances.  Separating NJ data from NYC will flag this as well and hopefully result in the publics compliance.

Lastly  your graphics give the false impression that the cases in the cities presented have peaked  better to 'keep it simple' so the nonscientific read can easily visualize and see  we have a way to go.
Name: redbank

comment: Unfortunately the horse is out of the barn in the New York area. Residents some of whom were infected have freely driven to the second homes along the Connecticut coast  Berkshire County Massachusetts and other areas. This has spread the epidemic quickly to new areas. Worse  the 14 day shelter in place policy for New Yorkers was late in being announced and widely ignored if the supermarket lots are any indication. Whether we like it or not we are going to have to prohibit travel from areas with large outbreaks and make it stick. We simply will not get on top of this epidemic without temporary aggressive travel restrictions.
Name: jrs

comment:
Had this been a problem on a test  the correct answer would be: Insufficient information due to insufficient testing data. 

Essentially the data does exhibit a curve; however  because that data is wholly inaccurate  the curve is similarly inaccurate.

The solution of any problem is only as accurate as its data--remember the Butterfly effect? Hyperbole? Sure  but this is prose not math and science  which require accurate data.
Name: james

comment: Efforts to prevent a disease are usually proven to be effective  when the number of new cases per population goes down. The numbers in this article reflect the continuing development of testing capacity and offer no understanding of our costly control measures. At this point it is better to highlight: 1) Are we testing all the critical people? 2) Do we have quick testing to inform the clinical care of individuals  protection of staff  and protection of uninfected persons in general? 3) Can we test reliably enough to create safe workplaces  schools  and other institutions needed for societal needs?  Until then  these case reports are highly speculative and overlook the more important message about the need for better testing.
Name: bob

comment:
This might be a good time to remind people of the "rule of 72": divide 72 by the increase rate in percent to get the doubling time.

Thus  if the increase rate is 30%  the number is doubling every 2.4 days.  At 20%  doubling occurs in 3.6 days.  A successful campaign to reduce the increase rate to 10% results in doubling every week.

And now that the number of infections has been allowed to get large  a doubling is far more significant than it was when there were just a few cases.

The late  great Al Bartlett said (to anyone who would listen)  "The greatest shortcoming of the human race is our inability to understand the exponential function."
Name: brian

comment:
Data on rates of admission to ICUs as % of new cases  and also on length of time on ventilator  would be helpful.  The BBC is beginning to show the rates of admission in the UK.  Plot these data against number of ICU beds and ventilators and the result will give what you might call the Overwhelm Factor: the number and rate of effectively untreatable patients.
Here in Ireland (small  socially cohesive) there is great cooperation about social distancing and  I believe some of it comes from a realization that the health infrastructure will collapse quickly without slowing the spread of the virus.
Name: malcolm

comment: These numbers are about as reliable as pre-election polls. They provide Zoom chatter fodder for MPH wonks but nothing more. Until testing is ubiquitous  the only useful metric is the number of patients requiring hospitalization. At present  the essential danger of this disease is to the health system's ability to manage the most severe cases.
Name: celso

comment: Is it possible the covid virus was here in the US at the first of the year? I ask because right after New Years day  I got the cough  the fever  sudden chills  had to lay in bed for three days and spent the next three weeks coughing up whatever was left. I assumed it was the regular flu that just held on for awhile longer than it should. Now I wonder if I had the covid and didn't know it. It could be a lot of us have already had it.  We need to find out when it actually got here.
Name: missy

comment:
Pretty misleading analysis.  It is highly probable that people will glance quickly at the graphs and mistakenly believe that the incidence of the virus is peaking.  Nothing of the kind  of course  just the growth rate of the growth rate is slowing down (the second derivative).  We're far from the peak  the only thing you can say is that it will take a longer period of days for the number of cases to double.  In NY city's case  say from 2 1/2 days to 4 1/2 days.

I think the data should have been presented in a more straightforward fashion to better convey the sense of urgency.
Name: kidcanuck

comment:
Most of the numbers we see are basically wrong  because we don't have real data. 
I have three friends here in NYC that have all the symptoms and haven't been able to get tested. Like them there have to be thousands. And thousands more without symptoms yet...

Death numbers might be more reliable here  but I wouldn't trust numbers given by other countries like Iran or even China (or by Trump  like the big crowds for the inauguration...)

New cases in hospitals? What about people without insurance that don't want to go to a hospital? Or people that don't take it seriously and think it's probably just the flu. I fear many will seek help when it's too late  and we're not there yet. One of my friends I mention above was sent back home  without being tested.

Numbers matter  but it's difficult to get the right numbers.
Name: roni

comment: A big difference between Wuhan and New York City is that the Chinese government got behind the quarantine and treatment efforts  whereas NYC has till now has had just state and local efforts  with the Federal government holding back.
Name: paul

comment:
Albany Ga is a relatively small  sleepy city. Why is it doing so poorly. NY is due to density and federal failure to jump to preventative measures early on  Louisiana is due to Mardi Gras celebrations. But what happened in Albany to allow the coronavirus to penetrate it's community so deeply so quickly.

An answer could be key in preventing the same happening in other places.

My initial guess is church. They all went to church when they had the information to not to attend large group events.

Could it finally be that religion is deadly if not tempered with information and critical thinking skills evangelicals believe they are too privileged to have to heed?
Name: no

comment:
I fear that people with lower literacy skills ( like the President  for example)  will look at those graphs and say  "Hey  look! The numbers are going down! All is well! Time to go back to church and open the malls!"

Meanwhile  Oregon is an epicenter of ignorance  sandwiched in the I-5 corridor between SF and Seattle. There are a lot of foolish people who seem to think that because our "numbers" are low we are not in danger. But the reality is that it's nearly impossible to get tested here.
Name: alison

comment:
Without testing we:
-  Don't know who is sick  spreading infections without symptoms so we have to quarantine everyone
-  Don't know who had a mild case  recovered  is immune and can safely work outside quarantine
-  Lack accurate statistics on new  existing  recovered and deaths
-  Don't know when it will be safe to see our grandchildren
Name: alden

comment:
What makes the statistics listed here difficult to credit is that as just reported by WashPo fact checkers coronavirus death figures are massively understated.

"The daily tracking number for covid-19 is substantially below the real figure of deaths that can be attributed to the coronavirus. It represents only the bare minimum — confirmed deaths reported by hospitals  medical providers and state health authorities as caused by covid-19. The actual number is substantially higher."

There is already "evidence that many deaths that stem from covid-19 are not being recorded as such. Doctors and nurses have told BuzzFeed News that deaths in the United States are not being correctly reported". Doctors are seeing thousands die from covid-19  yet a lack of test kits mean they aren't tested and another cause of death must be listed  such as pneumonia or heart failure. 

The fiction exists because the Trump administration wants the number of recorded covid-19 deaths kept artificially low. As covid-19 causes those infected to die of pneumonia or heart failure  without a positive test  doctors cannot list the actual cause of death: covid-19.  

The conclusion is chilling: "The numbers so far for covid-19 are only laboratory-confirmed deaths." Studies already "indicate that the official lab counts may be missing as many as 9 in 10 deaths." 

It means that as of now 1 700 Americans are recorded as having died from coronavirus  but in reality over 15 000 have likely died from the disease.
Name: robert

comment:
Without serological testing across large sections of our population we are really flying blind on calculating rates of infection  hospitalization and death.

For example  I do not think it is unreasonable that perhaps over one million Wuhan-ians out of 11 million now carry the Covid-19 antibodies  and almost none of them know that they do.

Yes  China did institute the most draconian actions to contain the virus  but that was only after eight or more weeks where the virus wasn't even recognized and had already rifled through the population.  Does anyone really believe that less than 100 000 out of 1.4 billion Chinese got the virus instead of millions?  We need to see the serological data.
Name: sparkythewonderpup

comment: Hi  lombard (and italian) data have been criticized by experts here in Italy. They say these data are simply not reliable due to a large underestimating  mainly because (so far) only people with serious symptoms were tested. Most scientists in Italy say the real number of cases in Lombardy can be 5-10 times larger. Same thing for the number of victims  at least in most affected areas (province of Bergamo  for example).
Name: gpda

comment: I fear that those who do not carefully read the text of your article or consider the continuing widespread lack of availability of testing may only look at decreasing line graphs for "Average daily change in total cases" and have the impression that the situation is rapidly improving.
Name: molly

comment: Why is this even a headline? OF COURSE cases will be worse than Wuhan - social distancing measures were more extreme there. Also  until there is sufficient testing capacity and encouragement for testing  the numbers aren’t accurate.
Name: kerry

comment: It’s striking to me that cities that appear to be successfully “flattening the curve”  like Seattle and San Francisco  are among our wealthiest communities.  Cities that are among our poorest  like Detroit and New Orleans  are seeing rapid increases in infection rates.  The New York area is so large  it would be useful to look at infection rates there in relation to neighborhood income.  Could it be that self quarantine is a luxury that only the wealthy can afford?  For our low income and very poor citizens  life goes on much as before  with crowded living conditions  public transportation  and low income jobs that cannot be done remotely.  Covid 19  like so many diseases  might turn out to be spread by poverty.
Name: lucy

comment:
"If the rate of growth in coronavirus cases in the New York metro area continues  it will suffer a more severe outbreak than those experienced in Wuhan  China  or the Lombardy region of Italy. "

That is the opening sentence for the article.

However it is difficult to find such a bleak assessment in any of the charts  which all show numbers going down.

It takes an expert to visualize declining rates into upward curves.  I gave up.

Poor presentation of information  in my opinion.  Unless I totally missed the point.
Name: charles

comment: The charts in these graphs are totally confusing and I am a scientist. Why not show daily rate of increase instead of % change since as the number grows bigger the % change goes down even though the number of new cases daily is increasing. To someone who doesn't understand the difference it would give the impression thing aren't as bad as you are trying to convey.
Name: drtmunich

comment:
Best to consider this article as examples of how growth rates might look. Not nearly enough data are currently available to make these a representation of reality.  I took it that way and found it useful anyway.

We are now in what military strategists call "the fog of war"  where decisions must be made based on incomplete  inaccurate and often conflicting information.

We've been conditioned in the era of big data to think that everything is measured and exactly correct. I've noticed that mariners have lost their innate sense of where they are without a device constantly telling them. Dead reckoning is indeed dead.
Name: charles

comment:
There is beginning to be a very reasonable doubt that the US is being supplied with as many tests as possible. It appears the tests are being limited on purpose.

We know there is a very large group out there that would test positive  and  warrant admission into either a hospital or quarantine. In China they built hospitals  or conscripted beds for quarantine to handle the numbers.

Here we just limit the tests and send you home to infect others as you will. This prevents us from overwhelming the hospitals and making a lot of people look really bad.

But  more importantly  it keeps the panic level low  and thats whats most worrisome to some if not most of our decision makers.
Name: mark

comment:
You should put Madrid  Spain in that graph  situation is pretty bad over here.

 I said it before somewhere else and I will say it again  few tests taken mean few positives  and only those who died having been tested make it to the official death numbers.

 People dying home or in nursing homes do not make it to the covid19 death list  some (maybe most)of those deaths are just considered to be pneumonia deaths or other from causes like heart stroke and such. 

Check the ICU occupancy rate  that will give you a more accurate view of what you are facing right now.

Take care  keep safe  and question those official numbers;  you have the right to do so.
Name: javier

comment:
This is a very informative summary of the available information. The New York Times has the expertise to make this available to the public. We should all be grateful for the institution.

I am a physician and a mathematician. Most of the folks who have opined about these statistics are correct. We can all make our assumptions and then use mathematics to draw conclusions.

As a physician and scientist  I admonish you to not jump to conclusions. We won’t know what the truth is until we get the data. We won’t get the data until we have near-universal testing. It will take a minimum of a month and perhaps as long as three months to have that data. Until we have it  we are in the Middle Ages. We can only use social distancing. While we are there in our studies distancing ourselves from our neighbors we can engage in intellectual pursuits and define scenarios. But we won’t know what’s really happening on the ground until we get the testing.

So  let’s not get ahead of ourselves. Don’t jump to conclusions. Stay away from people. Do what you can to improve the conditions for the people who have lost their jobs and wait for the data. It’s the most difficult thing in the world to do. It’s the only thing that you can do that will help.
Name: stuart

comment: Since graphs are visual devices  a log graph might be better.   A constant growth rate would appear as a straight line but an increase or decrease would show as a bend in the line.
Name: fourteen

comment:
Where are the statistics about people who have tested positive  for the virus and then recovered?  I see stats like that when I read some non-US news sources.

Also  I'm also waiting for stats about antibody testing.  The UK has ordered a million antibody test kits and will use them as soon as they are deemed reliable.

I live in an area which has (had) constant  heavy travel to and from China for years.  

I find it hard to believe that this virus hasn't been circulating in the San Francisco Bay area since at least mid December.  When I got a respiratory infection (with lots of coughing) in early January it lasted longer than usual. I thought it was just an cold or a cold that had become bronchitis.  But was it?  I didn't seek any medical treatment.

I look forward to widespread antibody testing in this country and the accompanying published statistics.

comment: Funny how people are accusing China for inaccurate number while the US is severely under testing (positive rate in NY is 30%  which means a lot of people get undetected and are probably still going to parks  grocery stores  etc.)  and China  at it’s peak  tested 1.6 million people in a single week. comment: I have many friends in the Wuhan area of China and according to them  the number of deaths is hundreds of thousands  not the small number reported by the government. The state is reporting that things are getting back to normal yet according to the people living there it is devastation.
Name: joe

comment:
It should also be noted that not only are the total number of coronavirus cases in the United States vastly underestimated due to lack of testing--so are the total number of deaths from it. As frightening as the reported number of American deaths from COVID-19 already appears  the actual number is likely to be many multiples of the reported figure due to inadequate testing. My cousin works in a medical examiner's office and  like his colleagues across the US  has been seeing a horrifying surge of "unexplained pneumonia" deaths in the country since at least early February if not late January. However  with testing still so inadequately low in America  these pneumonia deaths were never actually tested for COVID-19 even though the patients showed all the hallmark symptoms and had no other causative agent.

As a result  the American death rate for COVID-19 is grossly underreported  and the only way to see this is to count up the otherwise mysterious skyrocketing of deaths from "pneumonia of unknown cause". In fact one of the reasons why Italy and Spain seem to have a higher COVID-19 death rate than the US on the surface is that  contrary to the USA  both Italy and Spain do extensive postmortem COVID-19 testing especially for pneumonia patients to get an actual cause of death. The US does not and is woefully deficient in both postmortem COVID-19 testing and in hospitals. So the US death rate appears artificially low  conveying a dangerous false sense of security on COVID-19.
Name: radek

comment:
My simple analysis is this: 8 days ago there were 10 000 positive cases in the US. Today we passed 100 000. 

An exponential increase of 10 X in 8 days. 

I don't know how many tests there are in the US. Are there over 1 million tests available  which is the direction we might head 8 days from now? 

If not  then the cases could actually be higher than they are now (very probable)  and are actually going to be higher than 1 million in 8 days  but we won't know that. 

There are stories of people being tested after they die and they are testing positive. Or  they are tested and die before the positive test results become known. 

trump's announcement of ending this by Easter is as unrealistic as his announcement that "everyone can get tested". It's going to be a very long  damaging recession and health crisis. 

And it is squarely on his "I take no responsibility at all".
Name: motownmom

comment:
Trump's cynical calculus will cost lives.   But not the lives of the wealthy and connected.  They can afford to shelter in place indefinately to wait out the crisis or until a vaccine proves effective. If the wealthy  become ill  they will have access to testing and  the best medical care. 
  The people at risk are the ones who have to work. They risk exposure when they go out.  They won't be able to get tested even if symptamatic.  Then they will face an overburdened medical system.
Name: william

comment:
At a time when Dr. Fauci is the target of right wing fringe hate  and Dr. Birx's attempts to soothe middle America with Thursday's emphasis on urban hotspots (dangerously close to an implicit dogwhistle  intended or not) and with talk of assessing "low risk" counties where life can supposedly return to normal: 

Could someone who has both access to accurate nationwide data  and the requisite statistical competence  and unbiased integrity to speak truthfully  tell us the real public health capacity of small towns and rural areas to deal with the inevitable spread of the pandemic? 

Whether due to Mardi Gras tourists or Florida spring-breakers  it's a matter of time before community transmission arrives. (Note that Bergamo  Italy got hit so badly after 1/3 of a local town went to Milan to attend a major soccer match.) To the extent that these areas are also under-resourced and the population is older and with comorbidities  the rate of hospitalization and death may be severe. 

Someone needs to be honest with these people now. It won't just be about NYC and and NOLA and Detroit and Chicago and Philly.
Name: lowell

comment:
To all who are criticizing the graphs and interpretations in this article and elsewhere in the Times:

At this point  the efforts to present meaningful data are somewhat akin to a tap-dancing elephant.

The elephant may not be very good - - but you really have to appreciate the effort!!

We are in a situation which is evolving more rapidly than ANYONE can keep up with. Just obtaining “data” is difficult. Turning it into “information” is even more difficult. But the NYT is making a gargantuan effort to do so and we must all not let “perfect” get in the way of “pretty good”.

Without these efforts  all we will have is hand-waving and the vomitus being spewed by Fox News  Rush Limbaugh  etc.
Name: peterw

comment:
Crematoriums in Wuhan are releasing cremated remains. Lines outside of them are extremely long. Reporters from Taiwan were able to make contact and 1 of the 8 crematoriums in Wuhan is reporting 6500 cremated remains they are releasing.

6500 x 8 = 52 000.

Chinese official data is 2500 deaths within Wuhan.

Do not trust Chinese numbers  please!

comment:
I live in the very rural south between Pensacola on the east and  New Orleans on the west.
To use a Civil War metaphor I feel like someone whose home is the path of General Sherman's March to the Sea.  
I can see what it is doing in New Orleans  and then Biloxi/Gulfport  then Mobile  then across the bay to Loxley...
I know it is coming and there's nothing I can do to stop it.
I am not saying I have it better or worse than anyone else  I thought perhaps a different kind of experience might be interesting.
Be safe.
Name: mark

comment:
Please note that what you are calling "Miami" in the article is actually the tri-county area of Miami-Dade  Broward & Palm Beach Counties - the actual City of Miami has 463 000 people (about 17% of the county's total) and now where near the population of New York City.  

The population of Miami-Dade is 2.7 million  Broward is 1.9 million and Palm Beach is 1.4 million (2017 numbers).  There are currently 869 cases in Miami-Dade  631 in Broward.  Both Miami-Dade & Broward County are under shelter in place orders  with many cities within those counties issuing "safer at home" orders.  

The counties / cities are taking the lead because the governor won't do it (DeSantis is a mini-Trump)  so the cities and counties are trying to protect people.  Have no idea what that idiot was thinking when he left the beaches open for spring break and then allowed thousands of New Yorkers to fly into Ft. Lauderdale & Miami airports  but we're all going to suffer for it.  We can dump Trump in November  but we have to wait 4 more years to get rid of DeSantis (and he's apparently decided exposing his voter base of elderly Republicans to this virus is a good way to win an election?) 

My whole family is made up of first responders and RNs.  The president has failed to help the country.  The governor has failed to help Floridians.  Anything they've done this week is too little  too late.
Name: karen

comment:
Ground truth prevails in every arguements.

We laughed at Wuhan's total "lockdown" as inhuman  undemocratic  and no freedom. The pain lasted 55 days  and now people in Wuhan can move freely and appreciate life more.

Houston mayor cancelled the annual rodeo show in March  and New Orleans mayor continued the Mardi Gras parade.  The difference in numbers of infected patients between the two cities is astounding and shocking.  I would praise the intelligence of Houston Mayor Turner to make the tough call.

With NYC in such a deep virus trouble  president Trump even considered a "lockdown" in there.  This is unthinkable just two months ago.  

Maybe we should now open our mind more and think a bit about long term benefits rather than the short term glory and pleasure.
Name: usok

comment:
How deadly is Covid-19?

According to the CDCs  the 2009 Swine Flu Pandemic (it originated in California!) infected  on average  61 million Americans. 12 469 people died  on average. (CDCs report ranges of numbers.)

Thus the mortality rate from the swine flu was only 0.02%

As of now  we have 120 204 confirmed Covid-19 positives and total deaths of 1997.

Thus the mortality rate from Covid-19 is about 1.7%. 

This looks rather small  doesn't it? (Yes  only if you watch fox "news.")

Compared to the swine flu  Covid-19 is 83 times more deadly!

Put it differently: Over 1 000 000 Americans would have died had the swine flu been as deadly as Covid-19 today. (Only 12 469 did. A tragedy still.)

Dr. Fauci tried to make this very important distinction in one of his press briefings  but alas it was bigly lost in the trump noise chamber.
Name: jay

comment: We have absolutely no idea how bad the epidemic is in Wuhan.  Accepting China's statistics at face value is at best ignorant and at worst willful misinformation.  It's getting bad in the United States.  We don't know the true scope of how bad it was (or still is) in China.
