comment: If you want clear data on what is going on NYT check out your subsidiary the Boston Globe they can teach you how to report and analyse the numbers: https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/03/10/nation/latest-coronavirus-numbers-massachusetts/ Click on the link folks some surprises await you re the data in the state of Massachusetts as of yesterday (updated daily at 4:00 pm): - cases by county by clicking on a map - near vertical curve in case growth day by day chart - total number of persons tested positive vs. total number of persons tested - case breakdown by gender (50 - 50) - case breakdown by age (under 19 few; 20-29 about = 30-39 about = 40-49 about = 50 - 59 all around 500; 60 - 69 and 70+ less than the 20-29 30-39 40-49 50-59 age groups) If the Boston Globe can deliver this caliber of truly useful and easily readable information to the people of Massachusetts why can't the New York Times do the same for the people of New York?

comment:
"Dr. Fan  as both surgeon and patient  had a message for a nation debating how to fight the pandemic. It was short enough to whisper between coughing fits: Just stay home."

Harrowing situation--"his only risk factor was his profession."  Such brave  dedicated souls working their tails off to treat the sick  and the frightened.  

That Dr. de Souza had to get new test kits from outside authorities that  added days to the results because of bureaucratic red tape (new testing criteria  new lab) was mind-boggling.

It's a tale of two cities--Washington DC seemingly divorced from reality  and NYC at the front lines of pandemic.

A beautiful and terrifying account of heroes  right here in the middle of Brooklyn.  I'm amazed and humbled by all the people who are working in hospitals who are returning to this virus everyday  walking towards danger as the rest of us protect ourselves.

comment: Inside of hospitals  orders are written and notes are written using computer keyboards which physicians and nurses all share with one another.  In years past  before we were all mandated (yes  mandated) to use electronic health records rather than paper charts  doctors and nurses would each carry their own pen  which was never shared with anyone  and could be easily disinfected.  It is likely that we are going to find evidence of COVID19 contamination on all shared surfaces in hospitals  including ones that never should have been there in the first place.
Name: middleman

comment:
These professionals deserve far better than what the current system and current leadership has provided.   After numerous dangerous viral episodes in our history  these conditions are simply inexcusable.  
These nurses and doctors and their support teams deserve all we can give them  in whatever form that takes.
When we come out of this  we need to take a close look at who  and what  we prioritize.  And make definitive changes.
Godspeed to them all.
Name: thomas

comment:
Why aren't hospitals getting the results of the tests?

And why is testing still so limited?

I understand that the answers to these questions may require  some speculation... 

But I can't help but wonder....

Is it possible that a president who "likes" certain kinds of (inaccurate) numbers and doesn't like other (far more accurate) numbers is trying-- for personal/political reasons-- to limit the collection of accurate data? 

 The same question should be asked of Trump's refusal to use his war-time powers to make the federal government responsible for providing doctors with the protective and life-supporting equipment they need to do their jobs.  WHY ISN'T THIS HAPPENING?

The doctors and nurses and hospital staff have enough to do. Enough to worry about.  What can we all do to help these people?  
I'm thinking asking WHY --- and also reckoning with/pursuing questions a leader who doesn't like bad news or responsibility-- is a starting point.

comment:

Trump constantly reminds us that he donates his paycheck each quarter.  Perhaps he doesn't need the money because he has already received billions from Putin. comment: Nine days after my daughter got off a cruise ship she developed 102f fever. Her clinic told to stay home and that she could not be tested. Based on an analysis of Chinese patients  the number of people shedding virus is probably 10 times greater than is reported by the state.

comment: I presume that all of the proponents of just "going back to work" now and treating it as a flu  are prepared to volunteer at their local hospitals ?

comment: Thank you for all the hard work the ones in the front line are doing. All over the country and world. Amazing angels.
Name: ads

comment:
God bless these doctors and health care workers. What bravery and courage! What did Hemingway call it  "grace under pressure."

When this all becomes a bad old memory  I hope countries will build memorials and monuments to these folks. China  Italy  Spain  the U.S.  others.

Nobody deserves it more!

Thank you Dr. de Souza.
Name: history

comment: My spouse (not clinical staff) works there. They are in desperate need of PPE - masks  gowns  gloves  etc. They also desperately need more ventilators.
Name: a

comment: Excellent article and one all the naysayers and “I can do what I want” people should read.  This isn’t just about illness.  It’s about our capacity to help those who need medical attention - any kind of medical attention.  What about this don’t people understand?
Name: tammy

comment:
Hospital medical clerks  cleaners  supply room staff  nurse's aides  maintenance workers  dietary staff: your work is invaluable  too. 

Thank you.
Name: cary

comment: This is across the street from our apartment. Everyday we watch the people line up. We know people are dying in there. We know there are courageous people who are putting their lives on the line every day to help those that are sick. It is heartbreaking to watch  and even more painful to be so powerless. We don't know know how to help. Instead we watch and pray. Mentally preparing ourselves for the amount of illness  pain  and death just across the street is something we never thought we was only for war torn nations  not here. Not in Brooklyn. Thank you for this article - but most importantly - thank you to all of our medical workers who put their lives on the line every day to help someone else in need.
Name: claire

comment: thank you for writing about our heros. My mom works at Coney Island hospital and the camaraderie and heroism are the same. We failed our heros  our doctors and nurses.
Name: elina

comment: Dear Doctors  Nurses and other Health Care Workers  I am in awe of your courage  compassion and professionalism.  Thank you for all you are doing.
Name: malcolm

comment:
When this health apocalypse has ended  there will be too many American heroes to count:
* Heath-care workers
* Service-industry workers (grocers  pharmacists  couriers  etc.)
* Government workers (from Postal workers to USDA scientists)
* And so many others I could list here...

All brave people who have risked their lives to care for and serve those infected  or possibly infected  with the coronavirus.
Name: ken

comment:
Praise to the heroic doctors  nurses and other healthcare and support staff. 

Our city and country owe them more than we can repay.
Name: neil

comment: There is just one word to describe the federal government’s response to this pandemic: DISGRACEFUL. For the medical professionals to have to risk their lives because of a PPE shortage and for patients to have inadequate access to testing and ventilators is the result of incompetence and indifference on the part of President Trump and his team.
Name: bezerkly

comment:
"Patients with the coronavirus who develop pneumonia can often require two to three weeks on a ventilator. “The intensity level is higher ” Dr. Gasperino said. “It’s harder to oxygenate than your typical flu patient who’s sick.” He added  “The staff is anxious.” So far none of the coronavirus patients requiring ventilators have recovered enough not to need one  although several younger patients were rapidly improving  he said."

I would like to know what the damage to the lungs from the virus is going to be for the people who have to be on ventilators.  Fibrosis is scarring and doesn't resolve.  Will these people have lifelong breathing difficulties and have to live on oxygen?  Surely enough people in China have recovered to give the experts a feel for what can be expected.  Please   NY Times  research this and let us know so we can make informed decisions regarding our care should we become infected.
Name: expatmx

comment: The dedication  selflessness and courage that these people in the front lines are showing is what makes America amazing. My deepest respect and thanks to all of them.
Name: jeanee

comment: What is obvious and clear  is that the US is completely unprepared in the case of conflict involving atomic  biologic or chemical weapons. It would not even take war  maybe not even a single gun  to have a system collapse.
Name: peter

comment:
I was baffled as many were and still are as to why the President would not use the Defense Protection Act to repurpose factories to make more respirators and PPE. However  a light went on in my head  when recently the President mentioned something about not wanting the US "to become Venezuela." as being why he didn't want to require factories to make respirators and PPE. He would prefer to get companies to volunteer to help using the threat of using National Defense Act as 'leverage'.  I think he is seeing what would be just the temporary repurposing of factories as representing the nationalization of factories or 
'creeping' Socialism. This is the very ideology he planned to run against in the coming election. He wants to appear to stand for free enterprise and against "big government"  even in these perilous times  when an organized national effort to fight the virus is urgently needed  hence comes the frequent rhetoric about how governors have to handle much on their own.  There was a Federal response to 9/11 and a Federal response to WWII. For some reason the President seems to want a fragmented response in this war.

 I wish Congress would take more of a leadership position not just by funding  but also in the rapid procurement of needed equipment for the coming storm.  Could they not ask FEMA and the Armed Forces to use their departments which specialize in  logistics and deployment? Congress is a co-equal branch.  Could they not pass veto-proof legislation on this?
Name: a

comment: Thank you to all of the medical professionals and hospital staff for their courage and compassion!
Name: jen

comment: These are heroes children should learn about-everyday people who when the going gets tough  they don't whine and fall apart. They get going. I am grateful beyond measure for them.
Name: urbanwarrior

comment:
I realize that the comment I am about to make may be wishful thinking but I am going to make it anyway.  

During WW2 we had men as young as 14 joining the army to fight.  While I don't advocate inducting children into the military I believe it illustrates a point.  We don't utilize the capitol of youngness.

The enemy is not always some other country or terrorist.  This little virus enemy is every bit as dangerous to our national safety.  We need to create at least an arm of the military that is ready to step up to such medical crisis.  They should be a fast mobilization force that can set up field hospitals  morgues  testing facilities and have surpluses of needed equipment.  

I also believe it is time for national service at age 18.  Two years -then go on with one's life.  The benefits of this are huge to both the inductees and the country.
Name: stan

comment:
It's given some mention in the article  but it should be emphasized at every opportunity. There are praiseworthy people at every level of a modern hospital. Like people often take their health for granted until there's a crisis or their personal health fails  it's perhaps too easy to take for granted  for example: cleaning staff  whether their responsibiliy is in the ED or in the ICU where/when they have to turn over the rooms  from one patient to a new patient. Or a unit clerk that's good at their job  calm  especially under high or 
exceptionally high pressure conditions. I bet that ICU nurses and experienced ICU docs would tell you that a good unit clerk is "priceless".
Name: dennis

comment:
If we had more test kits we would then know who is infected and where we would absolutly need the scarce protective equipment.  The issue at it’s core is we don’t know  even now  who is infected. 

Now  everyone has to have protective equipment  everyone is assumed to be infected. Everyone should be tested every week  the infected isolated  and within a month  by shear math  the outbreak would be controlled. 

Health workers would then be the only ones needing masks gowns and gloves.  It’s exasperting to me  certinly not an epidemiologist  that this is not seen as the path to control. We need tens of millions of test kits  now. And  that is where the emphasis should be.
Name: prant

comment:
It’s time to start talking about a national holiday honoring medical professionals and other first responders who put their lives on the line at times like this. Many of us have family and friends who chose to pursue such careers. Others only encounter them during a crisis. But we all admire and respect their courage and dedication in situations that we desperately want to avoid. 

To those who choose this path.....I SALUTE YOU.
Name: richard

comment: I was treated in this ER two weeks ago for a severe allergic reaction  and I can't stop thinking about the folks who treated me that morning. In the "fast track" area  I made some grim jokes about the coming pandemic with the attending physician and I regret this more and more... I want to say this: To the triage nurse who forgot to remove the blood pressure band from my arm  to the med students for didn't put the port in my arm correctly  to the nurse who didn't explain I was getting injected with epinephrine but then comforted me out of a panic attack  and to the doctor who forgot to take my port out - I get it. Your minds were all elsewhere. I understand the stress and the anxiety even then  and I can't possibly imagine the situation you're in now. I have nothing but gratitude for you. Thank you  thank you  thank you.
Name: emily

comment: So  the hospital says they had the first case 3 weeks ago  so 3/5. The schools were open until 3/13. The hospital is practically across the street from the largest high school in the US with 6000 students  one of them being my son. No one in our family has symptoms yet. But we are very worried. It is easy to see things in hindsight. And in hindsight  the US should have begun shutting down flights and aggressively testing and isolating cases back at the beginning of February.
Name: ivo

comment: Is anyone aware that the Donald and his administration have been quietly  for a long time  dismantling our infrastructure of rapid response to possible crisis? We cannot build it up in a day or two. Even a few weeks ago Trump announced that the COVID 19 was just a hoax  and even yesterday he announced that on Easter the churches should be "full"  disregarding the facts that it may result in thousands of new cases. Why he  his family and Congress republicans give an example and go en mass to the nearest church.
Name: stefan

comment: One acquaintance of mine bought up several cases of masks. He is terrified of germs  yet this is no excuse for this hoarding. I am headed off to work at a hospital job as a 'traveller'  and he has offered one box for my protection. I plan to turn these masks over to the hospital at which I will be working.  Anything less is unacceptable.  We must all pull together and stop thinking 'me me me'.
Name: tentoes

comment:
Congratulations  trumpies. Reports of America's hospitals now sound like war-torn Syria. 

And it's so unnecessary! I think trump is delaying implementation of the war powers act because lobbyists convinced him to allow manufacturers to sell PPEs  masks  etc for the highest profit first. It's exactly what he'd do  the simpleton.
Name: deb

comment: this may sound crude but America needs to see photos and footage of what is happening in Brooklyn. People do not believe. As the saying goes a picture is worth a thousand words. It worked in Viet Nam it can work again. Gods speed Brooklyn.
Name: j

comment: The persons for the year for 2020 should be all medical workers as a collective.
Name: paul

comment:
All health care people have the personal right to just stay home...instead of being at the center of this world’s war. You are the world’s health and survival warriors. We thank you for your service.

My daughter  too  is on the front lines  a doctor in a large hospital’s emergency room.. I pray for you all.
Name: neil

comment:
This unfolding pandemic is teaching us all many serious lessons  some good  many quite horrific. Pay attention since our world is changing before our eyes.
For the positive; the selfless call to duty in the face of great personal harm shows us what’s best about the human race. 
Everything else I’m seeing is shocking in the extreme.
The country held up the be the strongest  richest  “best on earth” is a hollow sham. American capitalism  with its 1% and everybody else ( 30% with 0 or _ wealth)  its feeble production chains enriching a China instead of American factories booming and leaving us with critical shortages when supplies are most needed. Healthcare denied to millions  too expensive for families  and at the mercy of for-profit Wall St. This while we watch it collapse under the onslaught of Coronavirus. McConnell and the GOP fighting to keep laid off American workers from receiving their due unemployment insurance because “ it will make them lazy”. The whole political structure  from an unstable president to an out of touch millionaire class quaking in the face of this real threat. It seems nothing works. It is all broken. No one is in charge or coming to the rescue.
I just hope when this  pandemic blows over we can start to look with clear eyes at these failings and begin to rebuild with all America  and the world  in mind.
Name: mltrueblood

comment: The most powerful nation in the world and what do we have to show for it.........late start from our federal government in addressing COVID-19; lack of desperately needed supplies for hospitals; and waiting a week for test results of COVID-19 test. The President continues to talk about the economy more than about saving lives while downplaying COVID-19. Trump needs to realize that there will be no economy without the people.
Name: aaf

comment:
Bless them all!

We have a choice how are tax dollars are spent. We make that choice every November at election time. But we back it up if when we write our representatives and demand that they prioritize something good instead of something bad. Only apathy and sloth can hold us back — fight those deadly sins in your own mind — speak up to all who'll listen and try to be patient when they disagree. People are convinced by reason coupled with compassion mnot simply the fact that you're right. Go forth and persuade!

Imagine the trillion dollars plus spent invading Iraq for the oil companies (yes  that's all it ever was  and our betrayal of the Kurds proved that) having been invested in Hospitals and medical infrastructure.

Imagine the trillion dollars plus spent occupying Afghanistan having been used to create a national health care system  subsidizing young doctors and nurses education. 

Imagine the trillion dollars plus spent arresting young teenage boys for marijuana and other misdemeanors and incarcerating them in a for profit prison system (owned by politicians relatives) thus turning them into real criminals being spent on scientific research and education for that msame lost generation.

Well defeat this pandemic with hard work and compassion. But we can only save ourselves from the next one by changing our political priorities. Participate in your republic  vote in the primaries  vote in the general election  pressure your politicians. And bless you for it.
Name: arthur

comment:
As a retired physician  I salute Dr. deSouza and her incredibly brave staff trying to make do with so little.  A few thoughts:

“It’s harder to oxygenate than your typical flu patient who’s sick.” 
That needs to be shown to every person who says "this is just the flu."  Thank you  Dr. de Souza  for pointing that out. Maybe it will make AM talk radio.  

A week to get results of a coronavirus test at this time--in America. This is disgusting and shameful.  I hope Pence sees that his 4 million kits promised 2 weeks ago  another "PP" (Pence Promise). 

Administrators need to be figuring out what to do with the other patients when the hospital becomes full out Covid  because every patient who is admitted there either has known Covid or will have it.  Like it or not  every hospital is now a Covid hospital. 

Thank you  Dr. Fink  for this article. I wish I had a decent fraction of both your medical and writing skills.
Name: mike

comment:
The Public is so busy thanking healthcare providers for their sacrifice they fail to realize that if that talented ER doc  Cardiologist  ICU doc dies next month due to lack of PPE who will take care of them when they get COVID19 in the summer? Who will be left to take care of their CAD  COPD  Brain tumor  appendicitis  high risk pregnancy  traumatic injury... why isn’t anyone holding Trump’s feet to the fire to enact the DPA to force private companies to manufacture PPE now? It takes 15 years to train the next great MD and just the regular MDs.  And don’t forget the 5 -7 years to train a good RN.  Healthcare Providers are not so easily replaced like an N95 should be. 

We unblinkingly let young folks die in war because we have a large supply of new 19 year olds... Americans are in for an awful surprise when they let a few generations of Healthcare Providers die for lack of an N95 and a plastic visor.
Name: sasha

comment: From today's Guardian: Spain "has only a third of the hospital beds per capita that are provided by Austria or Germany. Yet that is still more than the UK  New Zealand or the US."
Name: francis

comment:
Courage is great. But heads should roll at the CDC for bungling the test and not adopting something (gasp! made overseas!) that worked months ago when it could have made a difference.

And maybe we can reassess the corporatists' insistence that global interdependence is best; it's quite clear that when supply lines become weak and disruptions happen in other countries (like making rubber gloves in Malaysia)  we get screwed. We need to maintain a certain capacity to make a range of goods here. For real national security.
Name: ag

comment: It's not just testing that's critical.  A fast turnaround of those tests is equally critical.  The longer someone is under investigation  the more PPE's are used.  In CA  it's taking 7-10 days.  Consider all those valuable PPE's (masks  gowns  shields  booties  bonnets) that are used by multiple people to take care of that patient.  In addition that patient has to be in isolation  using up valuable bed space.  Basically  US just watched China go through hell and foolishly thought it would not suffer the same disease.  We did not learn anything from SARS  MERS  and Ebola.  Will we learn from COVID?
Name: sadie

comment: I think this article warrants a Pulitzer prize. Every one in government should read it. Stop fake worries about socialism and ACT.
Name: kathie

comment:
Thank you to all of these heroes on the front lines. 

And a big no thank you to all those posting about how difficult it is to quarantine all the while seeking attention through social media. This is your big life obstacle? Eating  scrolling your feeds  and sitting in the comfort of your home? Maybe articles like this one will wake people up but I doubt it.
Name: yep

comment: Two Detroit city police have died. Neither older from what I’ve heard. One sickened and died very quickly. Here in West Michigan (Holland) we are faring better but it has started. Fortunately our governor put us on restrictions early and lockdown came Monday. Only essential services and activities allowed. We have enough parks and open space for people to get outside. We can only go to the doctor via telemedicine and have to get prior clearance to go to an ER. In our town of Zeeland and the entire rural communities  we can only get tested for the virus if we are sick enough to be admitted to the hospital. So there are I’m sure a growing number f infected people who are undiagnosed. Grand valley state university science departments just donated 90000 gloves to Spectrum Health  our main health provider for our side of the state. The governor has asked for anyone to donate masks. Even the scarcely populated Upper Peninsula has the virus with more counties every day having infected people. Still we are not as bad off as other places. I plan to garden this year in containers. It will be a necessity. This is not going to be over by Easter. That is ludicrous. At least the Pope tells the truth!
Name: kristi

comment:
An outstanding article  but these conditions are nothing new in our healthcare system. As an RN for over 30 years in Manhattan and nearby suburban areas  this lack of supplies and staff is inherent.  Signing out your set of PPE.. reminds me of when latex gloves were in short supply and locked up during the AIDS epidemic.  Homemade PPE? This is a disgrace.  How about Congress sitting in the bleachers with yellow pads and pencils  or the Wall St.traders camped out on the cobblestones around the bull?  
Wake up America..this is your life..I'm a nurse because I love what I do but I can't save your life with thoughts and prayers...send drugs and money!!!
Name: annie

comment:
Today  we will pass Italy and China in the number of cases to become world leader in Corona cases. 

The speed of our ascent and the fact that the number of dead exceeds those who have recovered from the disease point to the worst days and weeks ahead of us. 

Iran has been able to turn the tide more effectively than us.  In fact  most of the developing world is doing better than us. 

This is due to the complete and utter failure of leadership. Early on  when rather than cancelling non-stop flights from China (as if viruses only like traveling non-stop)  we should have been coordinating worldwide response  producing test kits and sourcing ventilators and vaccines. 

History will judge as harshly. We elected the man completely incapable of dealing with the crisis and we allowed him to stage kabuki theater and spread propaganda of "perfect" response while we literally did worse than Iran.
Name: yuri

comment: Now  now  what's more important? Using billions of dollars to fund our military might protecting the back door of a sliver of a country on the shores of the eastern Mediterranean  or using that money to properly fund staffing and supplies at Brooklyn Hospital? Well  sorry about that Brooklyn  but your tax dollars have to go to something more important that deadly threats to your health. Wouldn't it be nice  as The Beach Boys sang  if we made sure to take care of the survival of our own population first  and then looked out for that other country that completely drives our foreign and military policies? Yeah  sure would be nice  at least for the residents around and patients and staff within Brooklyn Hospital.
Name: cm

comment:
In Wuhan  healthcare workers and military checking on people in their homes wore hazmat suits.  I'm a retired RN and have taken care of HIV and H1N1 patients when the illnesses were first discovered.

Healthcare workers require hazmat suits to work in these current conditions.  The US healthcare system is a greedy business model and now the ugliness of that is on full display.
Name: barb

comment:
We've been robbed of the right to a well-run country. 
We've been robbed of affordable healthcare. 
We've been robbed of living wages. 

And all of that predates this. 

Now we're being robbed of a timely  effective response. 
We're being robbed of a cohesive response (insane that we're doing patchwork shut downs; that simply ensures that the outbreak will last ten times longer).
We're being robbed of accurate information. 

And our medical professionals are being robbed of safe working conditions and PPE. These latter two alone will cost untold lives. 

It's long past time to become righteously furious. I mean well and truly enraged and to demand that all of these be fixed. We've been supine zombies for far too long. We now must do life-saving triage  so ensuring supplies and safeguarding the medical field are key  but nothing will come right if we don't forge a new society from the ashes of this debacle. 

The president and the GOP bear direct responsibility for their shameful handling of every facet of this. Let it not be forgotten that when Americans were at their most desperate  this GOP turned its eyes to Wall Street and literally went on record as wanting to pay the poorest Americans less. 

Deplorable was always an aspirational state for too many of those on that side of the aisle and this pandemic has been their proving ground. Vote them out and hold those who retain power accountable. 

Returning to business as usual shouldn't be an option. It was a deadly limbo.
Name: ahbrightwings

comment: In story after story  profile after profile  two things stand out to me: the unwavering dedication of those in the medical field and the absolutely dysfunctional approach to testing for COVID-19 in US.
Name: calimama

comment: My utmost heartfelt gratitude to health workers on the front line. They are true heroes.
Name: annie

comment:
First off  excellent article. 

Secondly  if ever anything showed how much the US has not had its priorities straight for the last couple decades - how much corporate interests in this country have skewed policy making and screwed us - here it is. To think we have a millions upon millions of dollars available to buy patriot - and cruise missiles  hellfire rockets etc (the first couple at a price tag of ~$1.5 million a piece  the latter ~$120 000 a piece) and burn through $50 million in an afternoon of maneuvering in the South China sea.....   abandoning all other priorities..... it is criminal at best and a testament that DC needs cleaning up.

We are posturing and waving our stick in front of a country that we are told is our enemy yet we allow pharmaceutical companies to off-shore our complete drug supply to..... essentially placing our country's survival entirely into their hands. What lawmaker or head of executive branch would do that unless government were not entirely beholden to shareholder interests rather than the welfare and future of this country.

The COVID test pictured in this article was made in Italy. I'm glad that Italy  in the midst or this crisis  was still able to provide tests to the US.
Name: mn

comment: The idiot president has the power to get manufacturers to start building ventilators. It happened during WW2. We were building over 50 aircraft per hour during the height of of the war. Unfortunately  there is no leadership or national will.
Name: sparky

comment: Where is our PRESIDENT!!! Why can't we mass produce at least masks (like in wartime. This is a WAR!) Give us armor. Protect us so we can fight the fight and take care of the people. Health professionals could decide to bail on patients and demand protective gear before coming into the battlefield (hospital). Because we are taking the risks  our lives. But (abandoning people) that's not in most healthcare workers belief system. However  we should not be taken advantage of  killed off. If we die  you die!! Give us support  get protective gear -- mass produce the masks. Who cares how many beds you have or hospitals  if you don't have anyone to work in them. This the age of Amazon  get anything in 2 days or less. Consumerism at its height. Find a way  Trump  do your job for the PEOPLE!!!
Name: meghan

comment: Dr. De Souza -  That is what  real leadership looks like.
Name: nothing

comment: If Hillary Clinton were president  there would be face masks  maybe even for the entire US population.  Competency matters.
Name: lauren

comment:
Respirator allocation will be in a large part based on electoral votes that will be delivered. 

Blue states will be short changed. 

Is there a calculus to kill off older blue state voters who vote in higher numbers as a method flipping states?

Who needs dystopian fiction when you can read today's news.
Name: lawrence

comment: As a former ED physician at this hospital  I am scared for my former colleagues but more proud than ever. The doctors and nurses at The Brooklyn Hospital Center have been on "the front line' long before COVID-19 hit. Without the cash that the behemoth health systems in Manhattan have and with the square footage suited more for a rural hospital  the staff here has been doing their best as a safety net in an unequal health care system for decades. COVID is exposing the neglect that inner-city hospitals have experienced for a long time. I have always felt that the ED is the great equalizer  rich or poor  if you have a life threatening emergency you may be separated by a curtain from the homeless man you pass on the street. Your heart attack does not take priority over their stroke  regardless of your river-view loft apartment or wall street corner office. Now we are here. The true social experiment revealing long-standing inequities. A viral pandemic over-crowding an ED in a highly gentrifying area of NYC as unfortunate as it is  is exposing an underlying bitter truth. The doctors and nurses  I have no doubt will continue on with courage  hope  and a vision to keep the sickest out of danger despite the underlying challenges. I am so proud of these folks. Good luck and keep going strong ... my NYS medical license has since expired (I work in Mass now) but call me tomorrow and Ill be in my scrubs on the doorstep of the ED to lend a helping hand.
Name: jord

comment: The armed forces have stockpiles of medical supplies. If there are no plans for military adventures on the table  those supplies should be released.
Name: pelasgus

comment: Thank all the doctors  nurses  respiratory therapists  EMT's and other health care workers today and every day going into the future since all of them are heroes who put their own lives at risk to save ours.
Name: jacquie

comment:
America's health care providers will never  ever forget the way they were pushed into battle without adequate PPE. 

They will never forget how their corporate executives and work-from-home managers pushed them to continue non-critical services in the midst of the pandemic  to bolster the bottom line.

They will never forget the bumbling Trump administration response that prioritized a stock market sugar high over their safety and their families' safety.
Name: pablue

comment:
I’ve been an Emergency Physician since 2004- it’s..
It’s hard to say this. But for many of us- MANY- this is the first time we have ever felt appreciated  understood  or even thanked.
It’s as if people have finally begun to see what we do.

Thank you for all of the support. Please stay home unless you can’t  wash your hands  and be safe.
Name: samuel

comment: I shouldn't have to spell it out  but I will: The tax cuts Republicans are so fond of de-fund our government's ability protect us.  Good public education is imperative for a well-functioning society. A strong public health system must have the funding needed to prepare for unusual situations such as this  rather than scrimping by just to provide the basics in ordinary times.  Out transportation infrastructure  water and air quality  human services are necessities.  Under-funding  these things is a betrayal of the citizenry.  With the growing wealth disparity in this country has come dramatic burden shifting.  Every tax break for the rich is subsidized by the rest of us  resulting in a more fragmented society.  We are reaping what the GOP has sown.
Name: arnp

comment: I hate being a voice in the wilderness.....but my alrm bells are going off over Italy's message to US: "treat at home  hospitals are spreading the virus."

comment:

comment:
The corporate bailouts in the Senate bill provide enough money to send $9 500 to every adult in America with $500 billion left over for public health funding.

comment:
I have nothing but admiration for our doctors  nurses and other medical professionals.  They're on the front line in treating this deadly virus.

comment:
It is clear  and we are thankful  that we have true HEROES  in the form of doctors  nurses and other medical support staff  working in the hospitals across the country and world.

It saddens and angers me that the support and supplies the heroes need to be even more successful  is inadequate. I  personally  blame this on the monster living in the White House.

comment:
Real American Heroes.

Every day  again and again.

To underfund them is treason against the United States.

Are you listening  you greedy super-rich?
Name: william

comment: Could NYTimes please tell us how to help these frontline medical workers?
Name: citizen

comment:
I just watched a video of nurses in China putting on layers and layers of protective gear before going in. Comparing that with the photos in this article  it worries me that medical staff in NY and other states don’t have enough PPE to protect themselves. 

At the early stage of the outbreak in China  over 1000 doctors and nurses contracted the virus  mostly due to not enough awareness in non-infectious disease departments and lack of PPE. After that enough PPE kicked in and medical staff were much safer to save lives. 

As someone who lives in the US for years and been following global coronavirus news closely  I’m only saying this on my behalf: it pains me to see doctors and nurses literally risking their lives to save people and it shouldn’t be like this.
Name: anna

comment:
"But the staff keeps showing up." 

I think it's clear to anyone paying attention that we're on the thin edge/tippy ledge of complete panic and social collapse. Thus far  we are  thankfully  on firm ground but only because heroes like this keep showing up and doing so knowing that the complete lack of or badly compromised quality of PPE threatens their own lives. 

What happens when some choose safeguarding their own lives and families? And who can blame them  especially those with young children depending on them  if they do? What happens when the sick arrive and there is no bed  no ventilator  no nurse or doctor? What happens when the first responders stop responding? That's precisely what happened in many (not all) places in 1918.

The only firewalls we have right now are our medical profession and those who keep showing up to stock food shelves. Let's work overtime to support them in every way we can and keep doing the little we've been asked to do in social distancing. 

If these brave people can come face to face with the critically ill  the very least we can do is retreat six feet.
Name: ahbrightwings

comment:
The very next piece of legislation congress should take up is student loan repayment for the heroic professionals who incurred substantial debt in training that now allows them to serve on the frontlines of this pandemic. Call it the GI Bill 2.0.

Many of these doctors  nurses  and technicians have burdensome loans from their many years of training — training that has now become crucial for our national efforts in suppressing the virus  and saving lives.  Just as loan forgiveness programs now exist for health care professionals who elect to provide care in medically underserved areas  congress should immediately get to work on legislation that will pay down loans for those who have stepped up  and will step up to serve their country now.
Name: mary

comment:
I worked in the "dirty team" of my hospital during the SARS epidemic in Hong Kong.  There are some points that must be considered.  We did not know what we were dealing with and many mistakes were made.  My cousin's cardiology division in another teaching hospital was decimated when almost every cardiologist fell ill.  My cousin was gravely sick  but some of his colleagues continued to work in wheelchairs and hooked up to high flow oxygen  because there was nobody else who could do some emergency procedures.  It turned out that a design flaw in the ventilation system of the ward distributed the virus  which was aerosolised during medical procedures  to everyone.   
 That happened before they had a test for the disease  but tests are also in short supply during this epidemic.  Do NOT use nebulizers and spirometers on ANYONE  and take great care during intubations.  Examine the ventilation systems.  You are unlikely to have enough negative pressure rooms.  The virus can be transmitted by stool and vomitus.  This is a very common mode of transmission of SARS in hospitals  and faulty drainage systems is a big risk.  Make sure the toilet seat is covered before flushing  since virus is aerosolised and can stay alive suspended for a considerable time.
It is most risky when caregivers take off their PPEs.  You might be tired after a long shift  and relieved that it is over.  Do not let your guard down.
Name: erica

comment: The greatest city in the world within the greatest country in the world should show how American propaganda machine made us susceptible to all of this. We made a Great War machine and now have no basic essentials for our hospitals. Americans should be mad. Americans should be embarrassed. Americans should demand basic fundamentals be made here.  This article makes me cringe at the thought of what we as a society are lacking in the total healthcare package. Right here in our greatest city in the world. It’s a disgrace.
Name: unbelievable

comment:
Doctors  nurses  admitting staff  all with their game faces on  doing their jobs expertly and efficiently  in these most stressful of times.

Thank you all.

Now our president looks at the pandemic and sees transactions that can be carried out  money that can be made  political friendships that can be cemented  palms that can be crossed with silver. comment:
As a retired nurse  I simply can't believe what my fellow professionals at the hospitals are having to endure.  

Wearing protective equipment  masks  gowns and gloves  etc is drilled into you.  It is written in stone.  You MUST wear.  In normal times  you would be disciplined for NOT complying  as a risk to yourself and others.  The fact that our government and our systems are allowing people to work in these conditions is actually criminal!  

Every politician and bean counter at hospitals needs to wake up and take action on this.  Every citizen with any connection must help if they can.  Any business that can do something to help must stop whatever widget they are working on and get on this effort.  And anyone who knows of hoarding of gear in the public  warehouses and garages full of stuff needs to alert authorities.   

We are lucky that these hospital workers have not simply walked off the job.  I think they are within their rights to do so  as their lives are being put in harms way.  This is not what people signed up for.  We assume our employers can and will protect us.
Name: celeste

comment: My father  Robert Markowitz  was the director of The Brooklyn Hospital in the mid 60's- early 70's   He is no longer with us  but I know that he would be so proud of the hospital's staff  under extraordinary circumstances.   Thanks to the homegrown heroes who are trying to save lives.
Name: randi

comment:
Hi Sheri 

Thanks for the coverage. My sister works as a Nurse in the Long Island Community Hospital and they have been dealing with Covid patients without adequate protective gear. Since they don't have adequate supply  they are reusing the masks and gloves which is a big health hazard. She is absolutely terrified especially after a young colleague of hers was put on ventilators after being infected with the virus. Is there anything we can do to get support to her hospital or to staff like her?

comment:
I was removed from the floor this week and told to take off my mask and report immediately to the office.  Apparently wearing a mask  asking how we can train for this and asking what the chain of command is grounds for discipline.  But it's not called discipline early on.  I was told that I needed to take some time off because my anxiety was affecting the unit.  
There is a widespread PPE shaming going on  where the people in the hospital who should be protecting us are instead actively creating a culture that shames us for wearing a mask or to mention that we may have run out of something.
Name: nurse

comment:
"A few weeks ago  the hospital was able to send test swabs to the city's public health laboratory  which returned results in a day.
Now  swabs are picked up by courier and sent to a Quest lab in California. At first the results took 2 days  then 4  and now it was a week."

This confirms my belief that the vaunted "public/private" partnership was a money grab.
Name: peg

comment:
When this is all over  I hope congress isn't to chicken to investigate the public/private partnerships and the money trail. States competing against one another in a time like this for private sector PPE is true insanity.  Every unfilled federal position over the last 3 years should be evaluated and people made to explain their justification for not even interviewing for those jobs. 

We arguably have the best logistics team in the world: the US Military. How in the most unprecedented crisis in the last 100 years can we not have central organization?

This crisis here exemplifies the point of an operational Federal Government. Maybe these boneheads who think some loyalty to small government and 'constitutionalism' will be finally voted out.  The past is dead -- I can literally call the furthest place away from me on earth and instantly talk to someone.
Name: jon

Michael Bloomberg holds a press conference.  Seated at his left and right are hospital CEOs  ER docs and nurses.

comment: God bless these hospital workers. Individually  they're all heroes. But our healthcare system as a whole was caught shamefully flat-footed in preparation for this event despite all the money we throw at it.
Name: ja

comment:
It's an inspiring story. And yet it illustrates in so many ways the failure of the American health care system. 

We have a disorganized  completely uncoordinated network of hospitals  doctors  manufacturers and drug companies. There are good hospitals that care  and doctors who care  but overall the the mission of the American medical care system is to make money -- to generate bills and collect them. The mission is not so much to help sick people.

We double  sometimes TRIPLE what other modern countries pay for health care  and our response to COVID-19 is far  far less effective than Germany  France  South Korea  Singapore  Taiwan to name a few.
  
If there's any silver lining in this  maybe it will be that America finally wakes up and realizes it needs a different kind of health care system.

comment: This story breaks my heart.  The courage of the Nurses  Doctors and entire staff is absolutely profound.  History is full of moments like these where people risk and sometimes lose their lives to help others.   It’s inspirational.  But it’s also sickening.  It’s sickening because the entire situation could have been avoided  but for the greed of the ruling class.  Republicans cutting what they call “waste ” like Pandemic response teams  like massive organizations that work full time year round to prevent the situation we are currently in.  For-profit private insurance companies cutting costs at every corner  leading to shortages of basic equipment like masks and gloves.  Every system needs slack to account for surges  but slack reduces profit  so here we are.  It’s time to end this corrupt and amoral health care system and adopt a publicly run system like the police department  the fire department  public education  roads and infrastructure  and unemployment.  It’s time to vote the greedy  stingy  ignorant  small-minded  selfish and utterly hypocritical republicans from office and reduce their threat to public health.

comment: As a medical student I completed several of my rotations at the Brooklyn Hospital  including emergency medicine. The residents and attendings were some of the best teachers I ever had. On a normal day  all of the doctors and nurses were swamped and overworked—now  I cannot imagine what they’re dealing with. The workload of a typical medical professional is something that most Americans are unaware of. With no real end in sight  this situation is quickly deteriorating. Our healthcare system is broken and one day when this is all over we must collectively take a hard look at the factors that contributed to this cataclysmic explosion of sick people. We must hold our elected officials accountable. The virus didn’t break our health care system; it simply exposed weaknesses and exacerbated a system that was already at its breaking point.

comment: So thankful and humbled by the tireless work of all New York City's medical care professionals.
